Title: In re Paul C. Larsen, P.A.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Fort Myers Division.
Headnote: Bankruptcy Court's finding, that trustee of closely-held corporate debtor's Chapter 7 estate failed to show that individual who was debtor's president, shareholder, and director used debtor fraudulently or for an improper purpose, and so did not satisfy second element to pierce corporate veil under Florida law, was supported by individual's testimony that debtor was his "business identity," that, although he used funds from debtor's accounts to pay for such things as his personal health insurance, rent and renter's insurance for his personal residence, and remodeling of his home office, those expenses were related to his various business dealings, and that individual considered "dividends" from debtor to be his salary, as well as by lack of evidence that investors in other entities controlled by individual were "defrauded" by his use of investor funds to make loans to debtor.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Trustee did not establish that closely-held corporate debtor was used fraudulently or for improper purpose, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Belliveau v. Barco, Incorporated
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Because direct evidence of actual fraud is scarce, courts may deduce fraudulent intent from all of the facts and circumstances in considering whether piercing the corporate veil is warranted under Texas law. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Licensor was not entitled to pierce the corporate veil to hold shareholder liable for corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Moss v. Associated Underwriters, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: A plaintiff seeking to impose liability for a corporate debt on a shareholder has the burden to show by a preponderance of the evidence that the corporate identity must be disregarded to prevent fraud or injustice to the plaintiff.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence warranted piercing corporate veil of insurance corporation to hold corporation's sole shareholder liable for unpaid judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: AvenueOne Properties, Inc. v. KP5 Limited Partnership
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Amarillo.
Headnote: Evidence was legally insufficient to support finding that commercial tenant's president caused tenant, a corporation, to be used for purpose of perpetrating and did perpetrate actual fraud on landlord primarily for president's direct personal benefit, as was statutorily required to pierce corporate veil and hold president jointly and severally liable for breach of lease; only evidence of representation made by president outside terms of lease itself was statement in letter from landlord to president giving notice of default and listing unpaid amount "based on your personal representations[,]" and such statement was not evidence of actual fraud perpetrated primarily for president's direct personal benefit. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Landlord and Tenant. Evidence was insufficient to find that tenant's president perpetrated actual fraud for direct personal benefit, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: QVC, Inc. v. OurHouseWorks, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, although buyer of household cleaning kits could not simultaneously pursue contract-related damages from corporate parent of dissolved seller, pursuant to both veil-piercing and unjust enrichment theories, failure of buyer's stand-alone unjust enrichment claim against parent was not by itself fatal to buyer's equitable request to pierce corporate veil, requiring buyer to demonstrate that failure to pierce corporate veil would sanction fraud or promote injustice, which could be satisfied by proof of unjust enrichment, since piercing corporate veil on unjust enrichment theory only required buyer to establish that parent was unjustly enriched, but did not require buyer to satisfy additional prerequisites for stand-alone unjust enrichment claim.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Failure of buyer's stand-alone unjust enrichment claim against parent corporation of dissolved seller was not fatal to buyer's veil-piercing request.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Ramlall v. MobilePro Corp.
Court: Court of Special Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: When asking a court to pierce the corporate veil, the burden of proof is on the one charging fraud to establish by clear, specific acts, facts that in law constitute fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Mergers and Acquisition. Successor corporation was liable for debts of nonsurviving corporation following merger.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Ruffin v. New Destination, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, a party seeking to disregard the corporate entity and hold shareholders personally liable for corporation's obligations must prove by affirmative evidence that there is unity of ownership and interest and use of the corporate form to perpetuate fraud or wrong.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Contracts. Under District of Columbia law, company that provided counseling services breached its contracts with social worker and counselor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Superior Transcribing Service, LLC v. Paul
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: There was no evidence that owner of corporation used domination of corporation to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff, as required to pierce corporate veil and impose personal liability on sole shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Imposition of personal liability on corporation's sole shareholder was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Ireland v. Dodson
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, substantive fraud claims were subject to higher standard of proof than alter ego claims, and thus jury's rejection of buyers' claim that seller corporation had engaged in fraud was not inconsistent with its decision to pierce corporate veil to hold seller's principal's father personally liable for breach of contract to sell aircraft and radio equipment.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Brokerage agreement between aircraft sales corporation and its principal's father did not justify piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re The Heritage Organization, L.L.C.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: In determining whether there is sufficient evidence of fraud or unfairness, of kind required under Delaware law in order to pierce corporate veil, court may consider relevant evidence that is also pertinent to question of whether the two entities in question functioned as one.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. LLC's membership distributions were actually fraudulent to creditors under Texas law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Dick's Last Resort of West End, Inc. v. Market/Ross, Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Evidence was legally and factually sufficient to support jury's findings of alter ego, sham to perpetrate a fraud, and evasion of existing legal obligation in landlord's suit against former tenant, where former tenant and its affiliated corporations planned to use the corporations to ensure the landlord could not recover any assets in the event former tenant decided to vacate before the end of the lease term, concealed the plan from landlord while committing to a ten-year lease term, and evaded the contractual obligations to pay rent for the full term of the lease and to make payment under the guaranty. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Contractual disclaimer of extracontractual representations did not preclude landlord's proof of actual fraud for purposes of piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: N.L.R.B. v. Bolivar-Tees, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Determination of National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) that controlling shareholder fraudulently removed assets of corporation that had committed unfair labor practices, such that adherence to corporate fiction would sanction fraud or lead to evasion of legal obligation, in ordering corporate veil pierced to allow enforcement of backpay order against controlling shareholder, was supported by substantial evidence, including controlling shareholder's disposal of offending corporation's assets for less than fair market value or at least without formal assessment of their value, failure of offending corporation to receive approximately 45% of this lesser value, and shareholder's preventing corporation from becoming profitable, by charging sister corporation less than corporation's operating expenses for its services. National Labor Relations Act, § 1 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 151 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Unfair Labor Practices. Corporate veil could be pierced to enforce back pay order against controlling shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Schuster v. Seipel
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil to hold members of corporation's board of directors individually liable to attorney for fees he claimed he was owed in breach of contract action attorney filed against corporation and members was not justified, as there was insufficient evidence that members were the alter egos, instrumentalities, or agents of corporation, or that the corporate entity was used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience, justify a wrong, or perpetuate a fraud.
Document Preview: Background: Attorney filed breach of contract action against corporation that assisted people with their property tax issues before Department of Revenue and Tax Appeal Board, and two members of corporation's board of directors, alleging that defendants owed him approximately $41,000 for legal services he provided to corporation pursuant to two contracts. Members of board of directors filed motion for partial summary judgment. The District Court, Cascade County, Kenneth R. Neill, J., granted motion and dismissed members from suit. Attorney appealed. Holding: The Supreme Court, John Warner, J., held that piercing of corporate veil to hold members of corporation's board of directors individually liable was not justified. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Rosson v. McFarland
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: Homeowner failed to demonstrate that development corporation's president committed fraud or misfeasance by using corporation as a shell corporation to shield herself from personal liability, as required to pierce the corporate veil, in his breach of contract action against corporation, builder and president, arising out of contract to build home, although the house did not comply with standard building code and president was not a licensed homebuilder; evidence did not show that president used homeowner's money for her own personal benefit, and president's application to magazine that recommended her was factually correct.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Homeowner could not pierce corporate veil because he failed to demonstrate frustration of contractual expectations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Country Village Homes, Inc. v. Patterson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to establish that common owner caused builder to be used to perpetuate actual fraud, for purposes of the Alter Ego theory to pierce the corporate veil, in home purchasers' breach of contract and fraud action against builder, developer, related businesses and common owner; there was evidence that common owner, when he told purchasers that they would owe no more than an additional $15,000 for extras when he induced them to issue a check, was already in possession of invoices builder later used to claim that more than an additional $15,000 was owed for extras, that common owner was attempting to collect unsupported charges when purchasers were subsequently billed over $100,000 for extras, that common owner had a pattern of seeking payment for extras far above what could be justified, and that common owner engaged in various manipulations of the corporate assets of his enterprises. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Error in failing to instruct actual fraud was an element of Single Business Enterprise theory was not preserved for appeal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Country Village Homes, Inc. v. Patterson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to establish that builder was used to perpetrate an actual fraud for the personal benefit of common owner, for purposes of the Alter Ego theory to pierce the corporate veil, in home purchasers' breach of contract and fraud action against builder, developer, related businesses and common owner; common owner, employee of common owner's corporations, and purchasers' expert testified that common owner paid for personal items such as utility bills and car payments out of his companies' accounts, and there was evidence that common owner was using builder's corporate assets as his own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Error in failing to instruct actual fraud was an element of Single Business Enterprise theory was not preserved for appeal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Wechsler v. Macke Intern. Trade, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: Absent evidence that competitor's corporate officer actually took affirmative steps to reconfigure competitor, a mere allusion to "reconfiguring" competitor made in the course settlement negotiations failed to indicate an intent to defraud creditors, as was required to hold officer liable, under California law, as competitor's alter ego for infringement of patent for portable device for feeding animals.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Damages. Award of lost profit damages to patent owner was not supported by substantial evidence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Boyo v. Boyo
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to establish that husband used Delaware corporation to commit a fraud against the community and that such corporation served as husband's alter ego, in divorce action commenced by wife; Delaware corporation was formed after husband and wife were married, foreign limited liability company in which husband was the majority shareholder was the majority shareholder of Delaware corporation, there was evidence that husband commingled community estate funds with Delaware corporation funds, wife testified that husband, Delaware and foreign corporation were one and the same, wife testified that husband retained control of both corporations despite his claim that he lost control of foreign corporation before the divorce, and wife testified that husband through Delaware corporation made several questionable transfers to his friends, relatives and business associates.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Community Property. Default judgment against foreign corporation alleged to have conspired with husband to hide community assets set aside.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: City of Toledo v. Allen
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Lucas County.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to "pierce the corporate veil" and find incorporator of automotive corporation liable for nuisance on property allegedly owned by corporation; there was no evidence as to who owned shares in corporation, and there was no evidence that incorporator used corporation to perpetrate a fraud or illegality.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Nuisance. Evidence was insufficient to support finding that corporation was an owner" of property under city nuisance statute."

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Rimade Ltd. v. Hubbard Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Finding that corporate shareholder had not used corporation to commit fraud for his personal benefit, based on his subsequent resale, on credit, of merchandise that he received from suppliers to company that was owned by his son and that ultimately went out of business, was not clearly erroneous, given that shareholder had no personal interest in his son's company, and that son's company had paid more than $500,000 for this merchandise before ceasing to operate; thus, shareholder was not liable, on veil-piercing theory based on these transfers, for corporation's debt for merchandise that suppliers thereafter provided and for which they did not receive payment. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21, subd. A(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Veil could not be pierced based on shareholder's alleged fraud.

Title: Flynn v. Ohio Bldg. Restoration, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Corporation could be found to be employer's alter ego notwithstanding lack of proof that corporation was created to evade employer's obligations for contributions to multiemployer pension fund pursuant to ERISA and collective bargaining agreement (CBA). Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 515, as amended, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1145.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. ERISA alter ego test for corporation requires consideration of similarities with employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Medscan Diagnostics & Imaging, Inc. v. Diversified Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh District, Lake County.
Headnote: Evidence, including numerous confirmations and correspondence between buyer of medical equipment, seller, and its corporate officers, and testimony from seller's president, buyer's representative, and equipment manufacturer's representative, was sufficient to support finding that seller's officers engaged in fraud in connection with sale, such that the corporate veil should be pierced and officers held personally liable to buyer, even though officers were acting in their official capacities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate officers were personally liable for fraud in connection with sale of equipment.

Title: Patrick V. Koepke Const., Inc. v. Paletta
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Two.
Headnote: President of debtor corporation did not commit fraudulent transfer justifying piercing corporate veil, although creditor alleged that debtor paid himself a salary out of proceeds of sale of property, rather than satisfying mechanics' lien; evidence of salary and distributions, without proof of effect on corporate assets, was insufficient to prove that debtor used control to strip corporate assets to avoid creditors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Debtor did not commit fraudulent transfer warranting piercing corporate veil.

Title: Sellers v. Home Americair of California
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Deposition testimony of two shareholders of prospective corporate franchisees of oxygen equipment business, admitting that they had contributed $1.2 million to one corporation, was insufficient basis for imposing alter ego liability; formal infusion of new capital to corporation belied any inference that corporation was formed to defraud creditors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Franchises. Franchisor could not establish any grounds for alter ego liability.

Title: Atlantic Veneer Corp. v. Robbins
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Fourth District, Pike County.
Headnote: Evidence that debtors were sole shareholders, directors and officers of closely held corporation, that corporation participated in fraudulent transfers, that creditor had been unable to collect judgment from debtors due in part to their transfer of assets to corporation, constituted some competent, credible evidence supporting decision to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Some competent, credible evidence supported decision to pierce corporate veil.

Title: Government of Aruba v. Sanchez
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida, Miami Division.
Headnote: Aruban government failed to demonstrate that motorsports promoter organized or utilized promotion company, established in connection with development of new racing facility in Aruba, as mere device or sham to work fraud on creditors, as required to pierce corporate veil of company under Florida law; although promoter allegedly dominated and controlled company, allegations regarding its lack of corporate formalities and inadequate capitalization did not suffice to establish requisite intent to defraud.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Government of Aruba was liable for expenses and lost profits to motorsports promoter.

Title: WorldCom, Inc. v. Arya Intern. Communications Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Jury's decision to pierce corporate veil and hold shareholder responsible for damages resulting from communications corporation's breach of settlement agreement with telecommunications services provider was against the weight of the evidence; while shareholder admittedly dominated corporation, there was no evidence of fraud or that corporation had been used as his alter ego, as required to disregard corporate entity, in that, shareholder did not use any personal promises or funds to induce provider to continue services.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Telecommunications. Communications corporation's shareholder was not personally liable for damages owed to provider.

Title: Folger v. Cottle
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Fact that shareholder had made numerous loans to corporation engaged in the business of manufacturing parachute containers was insufficient to support alter ego liability on strict liability claim brought by wife of professional skydiver who was killed when his parachute malfunctioned, absent evidence that shareholder was motivated by an intent to defraud when he made those loans.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Undercapitalization of corporation was insufficient, by itself, to invoke alter ego liability.

Title: Real Estate Investors Four, Inc. v. American Design Group Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Five.
Headnote: Actual occupant of leased premises was alter ego of corporate lessee, and thus liable to lessor for nonpayment of rent and damage to premises, where occupant created and controlled lessee, occupant used its control to commit fraud, lessee was inadequately capitalized, and these acts proximately caused financial injury to lessor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Actual occupant of premises leased to corporation was liable to lessor under alter-ego theory.

Title: Aetna Elec. Distributing Co. v. Homestead Elec., Ltd.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil would not be pierced since plaintiff failed to produce any evidence showing that sole shareholder used his alleged domination of corporation to commit a fraud or wrong against it.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would not be pierced.

Title: LFC Marketing Group, Inc. v. Loomis
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Evidence that judgment creditors had been unable to satisfy judgment against individual debtor for three years, despite debtor's being dominant force behind Nevada corporation, and that debtor's brother, as corporation's sole shareholder, would not be harmed if debt was collected from corporate assets, supported finding that refusing to allow reverse piercing would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter ego doctrine permitted reaching corporate assets to satisfy judgment against controlling individual.

Title: In re Marriage of Morris
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Wife was not entitled to $5,000 from husband as reimbursement for medical expenses that were owed to her by corporation solely owned by husband, absent any evidence to show that corporation was husband's alter ego or that husband's actions as sole owner were made to perpetrate a fraud or other injustice on wife.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Spousal Debts. Wife was not entitled to $5,000 from husband for expenses owed by corporation solely owned by husband.

Title: Residential Warranty Corp. v. Bancroft Homes Greenspring Valley, Inc.
Court: Court of Special Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: Mere speculation on part of issuer of home warranties for defects in construction, that distributions from real estate development corporation to its shareholders were either fraudulent or left the corporation grossly undercapitalized, without factual evidence to link the distributions to the fraudulent actions, did not establish fraud, so as to allow court to pierce the corporate veil and hold shareholders liable for corporation's obligations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Mere speculation regarding fraud was insufficient to pierce corporate veil.

Title: In re Maxx Race Cards, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. North Carolina, Charlotte Division.
Headnote: Mere fact that corporate creditors may have been better off if related corporate entities had not continued to maintain debtor at time when it was "balance sheet" insolvent, during which time debtor's trade debt increased from $688,000 to roughly $2.5 million, was insufficient to show any fraud or wrongdoing by these related entities, of kind required for trustee to pierce corporate veil when debtor eventually failed and filed for bankruptcy relief.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Officers and directors did not owe fiduciary duty to corporate creditors.

Title: Huard v. Shreveport Pirates, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: There was insufficient evidence of fraud by owner of football to support piercing of corporate veil to impose liability on owner for salary owed vice president and head coach who had been discharged; owner did not intend to defraud plaintiffs when they were hired, owner had continued to place his own money at risk by making large weekly deposits into corporation's accounts, and funds received by team both from owner and city were used exclusively to pay other creditors.
Document Preview: Former vice president and head coach for football team brought suits against team and its sole owner arising out of their termination.  Actions were consolidated.  The United States District Court for the Western District of Louisiana, Donald E. Walter, J., refused to impose personal liability on owner, and plaintiffs appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Dennis, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) there was insufficient evidence of fraud to pierce corporate veil on that basis, and (2) there was insufficient evidence of disregard of corporate formalities to support piercing of corporate veil on that basis. Affirmed.

Title: White v. Midwest Office Technology, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Former employee's evidence was insufficient to raise a serious question about the separate corporate identity of her employer, or to establish that the employer's owner or general manager used the employer's corporate status to perpetrate fraud, evade existing obligations, or circumvent the law, and thus, the corporate veil would not be pierced on an alter ego theory; evidence revealed a properly capitalized, substantial business enterprise with operations in several metropolitan areas.
Document Preview: Employee brought action against her employer, its owner, and its general manager, asserting claims of sexual harassment and retaliation in violation of the Kansas Act Against Discrimination (KAAD) and Title VII, and state common-law claims for tort of outrage, tort of retaliation for filing a workers' compensation claim and breach of implied employment contract. On defendants' motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Saffels, J., held that: (1) employee made sufficient showing of continuing course of conduct to avoid summary judgment as to incidents that allegedly occurred prior to Title VII's 300day limitations period; (2) manager's alleged conduct was not sufficiently severe or pervasive to objectively alter terms, conditions or privilege of employee's employment; (3) employee failed to establish a claim of constructive discharge; (4) employee failed to establish a claim of retaliatory discharge; (5) employee failed to establish that she was subjected to disparate...

Title: Menetti v. Chavers
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: Evidence was legally insufficient to prove actual fraud as required to pierce corporate veil and hold shareholders personally liable for corporation's faulty construction of addition to home, absent showing that any of relevant representations were material or knowingly or recklessly false when made or that shareholder personally benefited from any misrepresentations; evidence showed only that shareholders were careless bookkeepers, that perhaps they enjoyed tax advantages of living off their corporate funds with little effort to preserve corporate fiction, and that they provided shoddy workmanship. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21, subd. A(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was insufficient to prove actual fraud as required to pierce corporate veil and hold shareholders personally liable for corporation's faulty construction of addition to home.

Title: Koch v. Lind
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: Driver hired by delivery service, which was operated as corporation by its owner, failed to show that corporation was established for illegal or fraudulent purposes or was sham corporation, as would allow driver to disregard corporate form and recover individually against owner in action to recover for injuries sustained when he was shot while making delivery.
Document Preview: TRANSPORTATION - Motor Vehicles. Delivery company did not have superior knowledge to that of driver hired as independent contractor regarding risk of being shot.

Title: Garcia v. Coffman
Court: Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Headnote: Evidence satisfied requirement, for piercing of corporate veil, that dominated corporation be used for improper purpose; there was evidence corporation was used as part of scheme to provide unnecessary medical services to chiropractic patients.
Document Preview: Patient sued chiropractor and his corporation, alleging scheme to provide excessive services and charge excessive fees.  The District Court, Bernalillo County, Susan M. Conway, D.J., awarded nominal damages and punitive damages for fraudulent misrepresentation and breach of fiduciary duty, and awarded attorney fees.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Flores, J., held that: (1) patient could pierce corporate veil and recover directly from chiropractor; (2) patient could not recover for both breach of fiduciary duty and fraudulent misrepresentation; (3) punitive damages were recoverable; and (4) attorney fees were recoverable. Affirmed in part; reversed ion part. Hartz, C.J., concurred specially and filed opinion.

Title: Northern Tankers (Cyprus) Ltd. v. Backstrom
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Plaintiff seeking to collect arbitration award against shipping company from individual principals who controlled such company failed to prove fraudulent nondisclosure claim, which claim was based on intentional withholding of critical discovery documents during early stages of litigation; principals delegated their duty to comply in good faith with document requests to others, and plaintiff failed to prove that documents were withheld in furtherance of company's business, as would support liability under agency or alter ego theory.
Document Preview: Company brought action against individual principals of large group of shipping companies, and against shipping and real estate entities created by such principals, seeking to collect arbitration award for breach of sub-charter agreement.  The District Court, Goettel, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to conclude that principals dominated their companies and disregarded their corporate forms, as required to pierce corporate veil; (2) bad faith breach of contract claim was barred by res judicata; (3) plaintiff could not prevail on fraudulent nondisclosure claim; (4) plaintiff was entitled to recover on claim alleging conspiracy to fraudulently transfer mortgage; but (5) plaintiff could not establish claims for conspiracy to defraud against individuals and partnerships who were alter egos of other alleged participants in conspiracy. Ordered accordingly.

Title: Zimmerman v. Eagle Mtge. Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Second District, Montgomery County.
Headnote: For purposes of piercing the corporate veil, sufficient evidence existed to find that transfer of corporation's assets by its sole stockholder and director constituted an intentional act to defraud former employees who brought suit against corporation by depleting value of company to such a degree that any judgment awarded to former employees could not be satisfied.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. Burden of proof rests on employer to show that deductions from employee's paycheck for expenses are valid and proper.

Title: Hilton Oil Transport v. Oil Transport Co., S.A.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: In maritime action, trial court erred in piercing the corporate veil to impose personal liability on primary owner of corporate charterer, absent evidence that corporation was organized or utilized for fraudulent or illegal purposes, despite lack of corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, overlapping owners, officers and directors of entities owned or controlled by individual, use of same corporate office, informal loan transactions, fact that corporation was in effect financed by individual, corporation had only two other employees, and directors appeared not to have acted independently in best interests of company but in favor of owner when they authorized confession of judgment in his favor in foreclosure action against the corporation.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Charters. Detention of vessel not commercial frustration of charter party.

Title: Seymore v. Lake Tahoe Cruises, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil to impose liability for breach of implied contract and breach of implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing on sole shareholder and director of cruise company was not warranted, where there was no evidence of any bad faith, undercapitalization, misrepresentation or fraud that would warrant imposing alter ego liability.
Document Preview: Former cruise ship captain sued cruise company and its sole shareholder under whistleblower statute which protects seamen who report statutory or regulatory violations to Coast Guard, federal maritime law and state law.  On defendants' motion for partial summary judgment, the District Court, Levi, J., held that: (1) genuine issue of material fact regarding reason for captain's termination precluded summary judgment on whistleblower claim; (2) genuine issue of material fact regarding reason for captain's termination precluded summary judgment on his wrongful termination claim based on federal maritime law; but (3) no basis was shown for piercing corporate veil. Motion denied in part and granted in part.

Title: Wolf v. Walt
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Complainant seeking to impose liability for corporate debt on shareholder has burden to show by preponderance of evidence that corporate identity must be disregarded to prevent fraud or injustice to complainant.
Document Preview: Lessor of cattle brought suit against sole shareholder of lessee, seeking recovery under theories of conversion, constructive fraud, breach of contract and bailment.  Claims were either dismissed by trial court or found against lessor by jury, and the District Court, Cuming County, Robert B. Ensz, J., entered judgment for lessee.  Appeal was taken.  The Supreme Court, Lanphier, J., held that: (1) corporate veil would not be pierced; (2) shareholder had not converted cattle; and (3) shareholder had not committed constructive fraud. Affirmed.

Title: Thrift v. Estate of Hubbard
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, failure of lender to prove that corporate borrower's owners had committed fraud in loan transaction precluded lender's recovery of debt from owners on alter ego theory, even though owners had committed fraud in another transaction with lender; for alter ego theory to apply, statute required showing of actual fraud with regard to transaction, and fact that borrower's owners committed fraud in another transaction could not support finding of fraud for transaction at issue. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21, subd. A.
Document Preview: Lender and software company brought action against borrower, which was also software company, and borrower's owners, to recover money allegedly due and owing and for declaration of rights in certain software.  Borrower and its owners counterclaimed, alleging that lender misappropriated software, interference with contractual relations, defamation, and intentional infliction of emotional distress, and seeking injunction regarding lender's use of software.  The United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, John W. Primomo, United States Magistrate Judge, awarded varying damages to all parties, all of whom appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Emilio M. Garza, Circuit Judge, held, in accordance with Texas law, that: (1) failure of lender to prove that borrower's owners had committed fraud in loan transaction precluded lender's recovery of debt from borrower's owners on alter ego theory; (2) borrower's owners were personally liable for...

Title: Ackerman & Co. v. Lostocco
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: There was no evidence of fraud or abuse of corporate form which would authorize piercing corporate veil to hold president of partner in parking lot partnership liable to leasing agent for breach of agreement even though the party seeking to pierce the veil alleged that president of partner had issued a "cash call" to other partners to pay outstanding bills, where president was not listed as general partner. O.C.G.A. § 14-8-1 et seq.
Document Preview: Business Entities. Summary judgment and fee award was properly granted to individual, sued as partner together with partnership, where individual was in fact president of partner.

Title: In re Sheridan
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, limited partners in limited partnerships for which other limited partnerships controlled by Chapter 11 debtor acted as general partners failed to show that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice, and, thus, veil of limited liability would not be pierced to hold debtor liable on alter ego theory for attorney fees and costs incurred by limited partners in connection with defense of lawsuit brought by entities controlled by debtor, management fees paid to entities controlled by debtor, and damages for waste and mismanagement allegedly committed by entities controlled by debtor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS. veil of limited liability would not be pierced to allow limited partners to proceed against Chapter 11 debtor or his estate to recover attorney fees and costs in defense of lawsuit brought by entities controlled by debtor.

Title: In re Hillsborough Holdings Corp.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division..
Headnote: Fact that claimant has proven intentional misconduct necessary to establish fraudulent conveyance under state law does not necessarily indicate that claimant has established wrongful conduct necessary to pierce corporate veil; however, fact that entity has undertaken one or more fraudulent conveyances may serve as evidence that entity has engaged in deliberate misconduct necessary to support piercing claim.
Document Preview: VEIL PIERCING. veil piecing was not warranted absent showing that corporate parent committed misconduct with regard to subsidiary's creditors.

Title: Bass v. Happy Rest, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: Former employee failed to establish any fraud sufficient to justify piercing corporate veil to hold shareholder and officer of employer personally liable for alleged wrongful termination of employee; employee was paid amount promised and did not rely on any other promise from employer.
Document Preview: Former employee filed action against employer, employer's parent company, and president of both companies, asserting various claims arising from discharge. The Circuit Court, Second Judicial District, Minnehaha County, Richard D. Hurd, J., entered judgment in favor of employee on breach of contract claim and dismissed other claims.  Appeal was taken.  The Supreme Court, Gors, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) employee failed to establish fraud to justify piercing corporate veil to hold president of employer personally liable for alleged wrongful termination; (2) employee could be discharged at-will despite agreement for share of profits; (3) genuine issues of material fact existed, precluding summary judgment, on whether conduct of president of employer rose to level of intentional infliction of emotional distress; and (4) evidence did not support finding that employer's income records were incorrect and, thus, did not support estimated...

Title: Belvedere Condominium Unit Owners' Assn. v. R.E. Roark Cos., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Ohio.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to pierce corporate veil of condominium developer and holder developers' majority shareholder individually liable in action brought by unit owners' association; association did not introduce any evidence that shareholder used his control over corporation in such manner as to defraud association.
Document Preview: Condominium. Condominium developer does not owe fiduciary duty to owners' association.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Sea-Land Services, Inc. v. Pepper Source
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence adequately established that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence for five related business entities would sanction fraud or promote injustice, as required to pierce corporate veil under Illinois law; creditor of corporation adequately showed that owner of business entities and his corporations were unjustly enriched, as owner had obtained benefits at expense of creditors and Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and had used corporate funds to pay his personal expenses, creditor established that owner used his corporate entities as "playthings" to avoid his responsibilities to creditors, and owner's fraudulent conduct was "blatant."
Document Preview: On appeal from a judgment entered after a bench trial in the Northern District of Illinois, James F. Holderman, Jr., District Judge, piercing the corporate veil and awarding appellee $118,132.61 in damages, the Court of Appeals, Timbers, Senior Circuit Judge, sitting by designation, held: (1) that evidence adequately established that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence for five related business entities would sanction fraud or promote injustice, as required to pierce corporate veil, and (2) that evidence adequately established that there was a nexus between injuries of creditor and fraud or injustice committed by owner and owner's corporations so as to allow for piercing corporate veil. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Sea-Land Services, Inc. v. Pepper Source
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence adequately established that nexus existed between injuries of creditor and fraud or injustice committed by owner of five related business entities and owner's corporations so as to allow for piercing corporate veil under Illinois law; owner assured creditor that creditor would receive payment from owner's business entity for shipments performed for entity by creditor as long as there were sufficient funds, owner knew at that time that he would manipulate funds of entity so as to insure that creditor would not be paid, owner eventually manipulated those funds, and owner's intentional and improper financial maneuvering caused creditor's inability to collect on its subsequent default judgment against entity.
Document Preview: On appeal from a judgment entered after a bench trial in the Northern District of Illinois, James F. Holderman, Jr., District Judge, piercing the corporate veil and awarding appellee $118,132.61 in damages, the Court of Appeals, Timbers, Senior Circuit Judge, sitting by designation, held: (1) that evidence adequately established that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence for five related business entities would sanction fraud or promote injustice, as required to pierce corporate veil, and (2) that evidence adequately established that there was a nexus between injuries of creditor and fraud or injustice committed by owner and owner's corporations so as to allow for piercing corporate veil. Affirmed.

Title: In re Shailam
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Trustee failed to establish that debtor's transfer of funds to his professional corporation's defined benefit pension plan was with intent to perpetrate fraud upon creditors, and thus failed to satisfy requirements for piercing corporate veil under New York law in order to avoid transfers to plan as fraudulent; there was no evidence that professional corporation's separate identity was disregarded, and at time debtor decided to continue plan, debtor had incurred large debt to various brokerage houses and was under federal mandate to restore funding to plan. N.Y.McKinney's Debtor and Creditor Law §§ 273, 273-a, 275, 276; Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 206(d)(1), as amended, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1056(d)(1).
Document Preview: Trustee objected to debtors' schedules claiming as exempt the debtors' interest in pension and Keogh plans valued at $421,000.  The Bankruptcy Court, Justin J. Mahoney, Chief Judge, held that: (1) ERISA does not preempt trustee in bankruptcy from raising argument that funds deposited into qualified ERISA plan are avoidable as fraudulent conveyances under New York law; (2) trustee failed to establish that debtor's transfer of large amount of funds to his professional corporation's defined benefit pension plan was with intent to perpetrate fraud upon creditors, and thus failed to satisfy requirements for piercing corporate veil under New York law; and (3) permitting trustee to avoid as fraudulent conveyances under New York law transfers by one debtor into defined benefit plan would violate antialienation provision of ERISA. Objections overruled.

Title: Lawton v. Temple-Warren Ford, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: There was no evidence that officers and sole shareholders of truck dealership were hiding behind dealership's corporate entity in order to insulate themselves from fraud they themselves were perpetrating on buyer or from fraud they knew or encouraged others to perpetrate on him, and therefore buyer could not pierce corporate veil on basis of fraud.
Document Preview: Truck buyer brought suit alleging fraud against dealership and its officers and sole stockholders.  The Chatham Superior Court, Head, J., entered partial summary judgment on issue of liability against dealership, but granted stockholders' motion for summary judgment, and buyer appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Sognier, C.J., held that buyer was not entitled to pierce corporate veil on basis of either undercapitalization or fraud. Affirmed.

Title: LeRoux's Billyle Supper Club v. Ma
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Lucas County.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to sustain trial court's decision to pierce corporate veil and hold sole shareholder liable for corporate debt; there was no proof that corporation was used as "cloak for fraud or illegality," that corporation engaged in fraudulent or illegal conduct in entering into repair contract, that personal and corporate funds were commingled, that corporate formalities were not followed, or that corporate records were not kept.
Document Preview: After sole shareholder and his corporation intervened as defendants in foreclosure action, another defendant in action, plumbing company, filed cross-claim against them for breach of contract.  Corporation had failed and plumbing company sought to collect on contract for work performed for corporation.  The Court of Common Pleas, Lucas County, entered judgment in favor of plumbing company, and sole shareholder appealed.  The Court of Appeals held that evidence did not support piercing corporate veil so as to make sole shareholder liable for corporate debt. Reversed and remanded.

Title: Matter of Estate of Rahill
Court: Court of Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 3.
Headnote: Evidence did not support finding that brothers had entered into business as joint ventures and did not support piercing of corporate veil in order to allow one brother's heirs to inherit a portion of corporate assets; there was no evidence that the other brother or their sister defrauded decedent concerning the existence or purpose of the corporation and he held no ownership interest in the corporation.
Document Preview: Sole shareholder appealed from order of the District Court, Oklahoma County, Carolyn R. Ricks, J., which held that decedent's estate was entitled to one half of corporate assets.  The Court of Appeals, Hunter, C.J., held that evidence did not support piercing of corporate veil. Reversed and remanded.

Title: U.S. v. Nagelberg
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, evidence was sufficient to justify piercing corporate veil to hold corporate officials individually liable for unjust enrichment of corporations into whose accounts credit union funds were deposited; corporations were inadequately capitalized, in light of their involuntary bankruptcies, there was great overlap of personnel, corporate funds were intermingled with those of officials, and there was evidence of fraud.
Document Preview: Government brought unjust enrichment action against principals of corporations into whose accounts credit union funds were deposited. Government moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Glasser, J., held that: (1) evidence showed that corporations were unjustly enriched, and (2) corporate veil would be pierced to hold principals individually liable. Motion granted.

Title: American Trade Partners, L.P. v. A-1 Intern. Importing Enterprises, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Evidence established that corporation's managing shareholder, who knew of debt to creditor and used corporation's money during debt's pendency to pay shareholders' personal expenses and who continued to use corporation to pay his own personal expenses during the time that debt was due, defrauded creditor of corporation.
Document Preview: Creditor of corporation brought suit against corporation, its four shareholders, and a new corporation formed by two of the shareholders. Title: Farr v. Sun World Sav. Ass'n
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: Evidence supported conclusion that shareholder had used corporation to perpetrate actual fraud and to obtain direct personal benefit for himself, so as to be individually liable on corporate note; shareholder caused corporation, which was engaged in mortgage lending, to take on new business even though it was "out of trust" with other customers, to continue to service Fannie Mae transactions although not having required net worth, and to cancel restrictive endorsement on third-party note which it had pledged as security for obligations with a bank in order to make unfettered use of proceeds from Fannie Mae transactions.
Document Preview: The 65th District Court, El Paso County, Edward Marquez, J., entered judgment in favor of obligee under a corporation's note, against principal shareholder in his individual capacity.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Koehler, J., held that principal shareholder had used corporation to commit actual fraud upon obligee, so as to justify individual liability. Affirmed.

Title: Torco Oil Co. v. Innovative Thermal Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, evidence justified piercing corporate veil of corporation that breached contract to sell natural gas to reach assets of other corporations controlled by one of its principals; in addition to corporation's undercapitalization and failure to comply with corporate formalities, there was evidence of intent to defraud.
Document Preview: Following jury verdict for buyer in suit for breach of contract to sell natural gas, seller and two other corporations controlled by one of seller's principals moved for judgment notwithstanding verdict or new trial. The District Court, Posner, Circuit Judge, sitting by designation, held that: (1) jury could find that seller breached contract, based on testimony of buyer's representative that seller's agent had no complaint about standby feature in letter of credit tendered to him, and (2) under Illinois law, evidence of intent to defraud justified piercing of seller's corporate veil to reach assets of other corporations. Motions denied; final judgment for plaintiff.
