Title: Ohio Bur. of Workers' Comp. v. Widenmeyer Elec. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Medina County.
Headnote: It was error to pierce corporate veil to hold employees and officers of corporation personally liable for workers' compensation lien; although evidence established that officer and employee exerted excessive domination and control over corporation, their dominance was not used to commit a fraud or wrong upon the Bureau of Workers' Compensation; record did not indicate that failure of corporation to pay workers' compensation premiums resulted from failure to observe corporate formalities, or that inability to collect earlier judgment from corporation resulted from ignoring corporate form.
Document Preview: After Bureau of Workers' Compensation obtained a judgment against corporation for unpaid workers' compensation premiums and penalties, it filed complaint alleging that second corporation was successor to first corporation, and that employee and officer were alter egos of first corporation, rendering them liable for judgment.  The Court of Common Pleas, Medina County, found defendants liable on earlier judgment, and they appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Baird, J., held that: (1) trial court did not err in finding that second corporation was merely a continuation of first corporation, and in imposing successor liability upon second corporation, and (2) it was error to pierce corporate veil to hold officer and employee of first corporation personally liable for workers' compensation lien. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Mancorp, Inc. v. Culpepper
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Trial court's judgment non obstante veredicto (judgment n.o.v.) for individual who was sole shareholder and president of corporation on alter ego theory could not be upheld; testimony indicated that throughout dealings with construction contractor, president led contractor to believe it was dealing with him as an individual, and evidence regarding financing of building construction and interaction of president, contractor, and lender permitted inference that injustice would result if president were not held personally liable to contractor, as contractor had relied on president's misleading representations to effect that he was backing construction project, and lender had foreclosed on project, so that it might be inferred contractor might go unpaid by corporation.
Document Preview: Building contractor brought action against corporate owner and its sole shareholder and president for breach of contract.  Defendants counterclaimed for breach of contract, breach of warranty, and deceptive trade practices. The 272nd District Court, Brazos County, John Delaney, J., entered judgment against owner and judgment non obstante veredicto (judgment n.o.v.) for owner's president.  Contractor and owner appealed.  The Court of Appeals, 781 S.W.2d 618, affirmed as reformed.  The Supreme Court, Spears, J., held that: (1) judgment n.o.v. for president on alter ego theory could not be sustained; (2) any error in admitting testimony of expert witness not timely designated in answers to interrogatories and witness was harmless, where testimony of the expert was entirely cumulative; and (3) jury finding regarding costs of remedying defects in building construction project went to measure of contractor's damages for breach of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Cotazino v. Basil Development Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate vendor's vice-president and one-third shareholder could not be held personally liable to purchasers for corporation's breach of contract and/or warranty and negligence, where evidence did not establish that vice-president used corporation to transact his personal business or that there was sufficient fraud, illegality or wrongdoing to warrant disregard of corporate entity; evidence only showed that corporation never held meetings, operated from vice-president's home, shared legal fees with vice-president, failed to be identified on some contract documents, was managed exclusively by vice-president, and was used by vice-president to avoid personal liability, and that amount directly paid for purchase of land from corporation was deposited in joint bank account of vice-president and his wife.
Document Preview: Purchasers brought action against vendor contractor and its vice-president, seeking damages for breach of contract and/or warranty and negligence.  The Supreme Court, Albany County, Prior, J., entered judgment for purchasers pursuant to jury verdict, and defendants appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Yesawich, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support jury's $20,000 verdict for breach of contract and/or warranty; (2) evidence did not support jury's $17,000 negligence verdict; (3) personal liability should not have been imposed upon vice-president for corporate vendor's acts; and (4) interest would be computed on warranty and contract awards from date of closing, and on negligence award from date that suit was presumably commenced. Affirmed as modified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Rothermel v. Ermiger
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: One of two shareholders was improperly held liable for corporate debt absent evidence of shareholder's control over corporation or that any fraud or misrepresentation was perpetrated; there was no evidence in record to support trial court's purely conclusory remark that shareholder and corporation were alter egos.
Document Preview: Creditors of corporation brought action against shareholder. The County Court, Warren County, Moynihan, J., affirmed town court judgment in favor of creditors, and shareholder appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Kane, J., held that shareholder was improperly held liable for corporate debt absent evidence of shareholder's control over corporation or that any fraud or misrepresentation was perpetrated. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: LaPorte, Sehrt, Romig & Hand, CPA's v. Gulf Island Operations, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Individual who was officer of corporate partner and officer of corporate partnership affiliates was not solidarily liable for balance due to accounting firm for accounting services rendered in partnership liquidation pursuant to court order, where there were no allegations and no evidence of any fraud on part of the individual as officer of corporations that would make him personally liable for partnership debt and there was no evidence that would support piercing corporate veil to hold individual personally liable for partnership debts of corporate partner. LSA-R.S. 12:93, subd. B, 12:95.
Document Preview: Accounting firm brought action on open account for balance due for accounting services rendered during partnership liquidation proceedings against partnership, corporate partners, related corporations, court-appointed liquidators for partnership, and individual who was corporate officer of one partner and affiliate entities.  The Civil District Court, Parish of Orleans, Division I, Bernette J. Johnson, J., rendered judgment against corporate partner, two corporate affiliates, corporate officer, and liquidator, and they appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Ciaccio, J., held that: (1) corporate partner was solidarily liable for partnership debt for accounting services pursuant to partnership agreement article; (2) affiliates of corporate partner which had no interest in outcome of partnership liquidation proceedings other than that of any other debtor or creditor could not be held liable for debt for accounting services; and (3) individual...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Major League Baseball Promotion Corp. v. Colour-Tex, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Copyright and trademark owner failed to show that sublicensees used retailer to perpetrate fraud or injustice or established retailer for illegitimate purpose and, thus, there was no basis for piercing corporate veil under New Jersey law to hold sublicensee liable for retailer's alleged trademark and copyright infringement. Lanham Trade-Mark Act, § 32(1), as amended, 15 U.S.C.A. § 1114(1).
Document Preview: Copyright and trademark owner filed infringement action against sublicensees. Sublicensees counterclaimed for wrongful seizure under the trademark laws and brought various claims under New Jersey law.  On cross motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Gerry, Chief Judge, held that: (1) a sublicense agreement entered into by the owner's licensee without the owner's prior written consent was invalid and, thus, the sublicensee was liable for copyright and trademark infringement; (2) the issue of damages was premature; (3) goods that were surrendered voluntarily to the owner's agents were not wrongfully seized and could not support an action for wrongful seizure pursuant to the trademark laws; and (4) the owner's obtaining and executing an ex parte order was not malicious interference with process, intentional infliction of emotional distress or negligent infliction of emotional distress. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Board of Trustees of Mill Cabinet Pension Trust Fund for Northern California v. Valley Cabinet & Mfg. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Finding that sole shareholder of corporation did not have fraudulent intent when he transferred $200,000 from its account to his personal account, so that corporate veil would not be pierced to allow pension fund to recover from the sole shareholder's estate for unpaid contributions, was supported by evidence that the corporation did not believe that it owed money to the fund.
Document Preview: Pension fund brought action against estate of sole shareholder of employer to recover amounts owed to the fund.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of California, Charles A. Legge, J., denied relief, and fund appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Boochever, Circuit Judge, held that evidence sustained trial court's refusal to pierce corporate veil. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Union Camp Corp. v. MW Equipment Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Buyer failed to establish fraud or injustice, undercapitalization of seller, or incorporation of seller to insulate another corporation and, therefore, was not entitled to pierce seller's corporate veil under Wisconsin law, even if seller possibly could not satisfy judgment, may have had no assets, and could have been near bankruptcy.
Document Preview: Buyer of automated packaging system brought action against seller and another corporation to recover for unjust enrichment and to pierce seller's corporate veil.  The District Court, Myron L. Gordon, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) seller was unjustly enriched when it removed system and retained partial payment and buyer's bag stabilizer; (2) buyer was not entitled to prejudgment interest; and (3) buyer was not entitled to pierce seller's corporate veil. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Seaside Industries, Inc. v. Cooper
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Evidence established that judgment debtor's president engaged in sham to perpetrate constructive fraud and that corporation fiction could be disregarded to hold president personally liable; less than two weeks after judgment, holding company was incorporated to own judgment debtor's parent corporation and newly created corporation; newly created corporation then did business at judgment debtor's location and used its personnel, leasehold, telephone number, trade name, and advertising; parent corporation paid dividend in amount of parent corporation's debt to judgment debtor; and president admitted forming new corporations to avoid paying the judgment.
Document Preview: Judgment creditors brought action against judgment debtor's president, debtor's parent corporation, holding company of newly formed corporation and parent corporation, and newly formed corporation itself to recover for sham to perpetrate constructive fraud.  The 44th District Court, Dallas County, Candace Tyson, J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of creditors. Defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Thomas, J., held that: (1) evidence established that president engaged in sham to perpetrate constructive fraud upon creditors and to prevent collection of judgment; (2) evidence established that debtor could have paid judgment but for president's actions to prevent payment; and (3) evidence supported award of exemplary damages. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Gibraltar Sav. v. LDBrinkman Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, corporation's creditor was not entitled to pierce corporate veil, though evidence may have supported its "sham to perpetrate fraud" theory asserted on appeal, where sole ground addressed by parties below was "alter ego," which was distinct theory, and evidence did not support such theory; though there was some laxity of corporate minutes and documentation, and holding company officers provided certain services for subsidiary debtor, entities had separate directors and kept separate books, and made effort to observe corporate distinctions.
Document Preview: Creditor brought action against corporate debtor's holding company and its owner following default on promissory note.  The United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, Lucius Desha Bunton, III, Chief Judge, entered judgment for creditor, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Jerry E. Smith, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) creditor had standing to bring suit, though debtor was in bankruptcy; (2) holding company and its principal shareholder were not alter egos of subsidiaries who obtained loans, and thus were not contractually liable to lender, absent evidence of lack of separateness; and (3) evidence was sufficient to support finding that holding company tortiously interfered with debtor's contractual relations. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Egudin v. Carriage Court Condominium, Dehrvill Group, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to establish that acts of shareholder of corporation handling condominium project were fraudulent with respect to sale of condominium unit so as to warrant piercing corporate veil and holding shareholder personally liable for losses incurred by prospective purchaser; closing could not take place because unit was subject to prior mortgage, even though purchaser had paid full purchase price, and shareholder failed to immediately notify him of nature of problems, merely asking for extensions. LSA-C.C. art. 1953.
Document Preview: Prospective purchaser of condominium unit brought action against real estate agent and shareholder of corporation handling condominium project, seeking specific performance and damages arising out of failure to deliver title.  The Twenty-Fourth Judicial District Court, Parish of Jefferson, G. Thomas Porteous, J., entered judgment in favor of purchaser for damages and attorney fees, and agent and shareholder appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Dufresne, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to establish that shareholder's acts were fraudulent so as to warrant piercing corporate veil; (2) evidence was sufficient to establish that shareholder engaged in unfair trade practices; and (3) evidence was sufficient to establish that agent breached her fiduciary duty to purchaser by failing to escrow sale price deposit. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Amason v. Whitehead
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to warrant piercing contractor's corporate veil to hold sole or principal shareholder liable to subcontractor for masonry cleaning services requested by contractor; there was no evidence of fraud, no abuse of corporate form, no commingling of assets and not even a showing of corporate insolvency at time of transaction, but only that at time of trial corporation had no assets.
Document Preview: Subcontractor brought action against corporate contractor and sole or principal shareholder to recover sums allegedly due for performing various masonry cleaning services.  The sole or principal shareholder and corporate contractor filed counterclaim for subcontractor's alleged failure to perform services in workmanlike manner.  The Gwinnett Superior Court, Henderson, J., entered verdict against sole or principal shareholder and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Beasley, J., held that evidence was insufficient to warrant piercing the corporate veil to hold sole or principal shareholder liable. Reversed with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Speed v. Eluma Intern., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Finding of constructive fraud warranting piercing of corporate veil was sufficiently supported by evidence that, after creditors had obtained temporary restraining order preventing bulk transfer of debtor corporation's assets, corporation's sole shareholder foreclosed claimed landlord's lien and transferred assets anyway; jury could have concluded that foreclosure sale purchaser was merely continuation of corporation, with sale being used to avoid creditors.
Document Preview: Corporate creditors brought action against corporate principals to recover for constructive fraud.  The 14th District Court, Dallas County, John McClellan Marshall, J., entered judgment on jury verdict for creditors, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Thomas, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support finding of constructive fraud, and (2) awards of actual and exemplary damages were supported by evidence. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Drilcon, Inc. v. Roil Energy Corp., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: Evidence of either actual fraud or constructive fraud may be sufficient to pierce corporate veil in a given case.
Document Preview: Drilling company brought action against corporation which hired it and corporation's president alleging breach of contract, negligence, and constructive fraud.  The District Court, Flathead County, Leif Erickson, J., entered judgment in favor of drilling company.  Corporation and president appealed.  The Supreme Court, Gulbrandson, J., held that: (1) special circumstances existed which supported jury finding of constructive fraud on part of defendant corporation and its president; (2) there was sufficient evidence to support theories to pierce corporate veil; and (3) substantial evidence supported finding that corporation breached drilling contract. Affirmed. Sheehy, J., filed a dissenting opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Hamrick v. First Nat. Bank of Stevenson
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: There was sufficient evidence of sole shareholder's abuse of corporate form to sustain trial court's holding shareholder liable on note executed by shareholder on behalf of corporation, in light of misstatements in financial statement provided to holder of note and transactions between corporation and shareholder.
Document Preview: Holder of note brought action against sole shareholder, who executed note on behalf of corporation, claiming that corporation was alter ego of shareholder.  The Circuit Court, Jackson County, W. Loy Campbell, J., rendered judgment against shareholder, and shareholder appealed.  The Supreme Court, Steagall, J., held that there was sufficient evidence that shareholder abused corporate form to sustain ruling holding shareholder liable. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Landbank Equity Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division. .
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that particular corporation was instrumentality of corporate debtor used by family related to debtor for fraudulent purposes, and thus supported piercing of that corporation's veil in bankruptcy trustee's action; testimonyrevealed that properties developed by corporation were financed by loans from corporate debtor placed in names of corporate debtor's employees, that corporation was known by several different names, that family used corporation to collect all rent f or rental property in everyone's name, including rent on properties held by other corporations, and that family relatives were beneficiaries of gratuitous transfers from corporation in form of real estate and cash bonuses.
Document Preview: Trustee brought action seeking to recover from relatives and entities related to debtor funds trustee believed went to them illegally.  The Bankruptcy Court, 66 B.R. 949, Hal J. Bonney, Jr., J., awarded trustee monetary damages against various defendants, and defendants appealed.  The District Court, Clarke, J., held that: (1) evidence supported piercing of veils of various corporations; (2) loans made to officers or employees of corporate debtor and its affiliates with no payment or nominal payment of points violated debtor's policy and deprived debtor and its creditors of assets that would have been available if loans been made to public, and accordingly, points not paid were allowable item of damages; (3) loans received from debtor by individuals who were officers and employees of debtor and its affiliates were recoverable on grounds they were fraudulently obtained; and (4) threefold damages were properly awarded against various...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Reverse Vending Associates v. Tomra Systems US, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Statement by general partner of Pennsylvania business, that executive of Norwegian manufacturer and its United States subsidiary told partner that subsidiary had no power to make any decision not approved and ratified by manufacturer, unsupported by any independent evidence that manufacturer controlled activities of subsidiary and had usurped subsidiary's corporate identity, was insufficient to sustain partner's burden of proving that separate corporate form of either manufacturer or subsidiary was used by manufacturer as means to perpetrate fraud or promote injustice akin to fraud so as to mandate piercing the corporate veil and conferring upon Pennsylvania court personal jurisdiction over Norwegian manufacturer under Pennsylvania's long-arm statute. 42 Pa.C.S.A. §§ 5301, 5301 et seq., 5322, 5322(b); U.S.C.A. Const.Amends. 5, 14.
Document Preview: Pennsylvania business brought action against Norwegian manufacturer's wholly-owned United States subsidiary and Norwegian manufacturer of reverse vending machines.  Norwegian manufacturer moved to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction.  The District Court, Raymond J. Broderick, J., held that: (1) Pennsylvania business' solicitation of customers in Pennsylvania was unilateral activity insufficient to establish manufacturer's minimum contacts with state for purposes of Pennsylvania's long-arm statute, and (2) Pennsylvania business failed to sustain burden of proving subsidiary was merely alter ego of manufacturer. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Estudios, Proyectos e Inversiones de Centro America, S.A. (EPICA) v. Swiss Bank Corp. (Overseas) S.A.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Substantial evidence supported decision to pierce corporate veil and grant writ of attachment securing assets of horse-breeding farm owned by corporation so as to provide available funds to satisfy possible judgment against corporation's controlling shareholder; controlling shareholder created corporation and transferred ownership of his horse-breeding farm to secrete his personal assets and thereby defraud his creditors.
Document Preview: After debtor defaulted on notes, creditor's assignee brought action against various guarantors and simultaneously filed emergency motion for writ of attachment.  Writ was granted and sheriff seized personal property and business records from horse-breeding farm owned by corporation of which one guarantor was controlling shareholder.  The Circuit Court for Dade County, John A. Tanksley, J., denied corporation's motion for dissolution of writ, and corporation appealed.  The District Court of Appeal held that: (1) evidence supported decision to pierce corporate veil and grant writ of attachment securing corporation's property so as to provide funds to satisfy possible judgment against guarantor, but (2) trial court erred in authorizing attachment of corporation's financial and property records in issuing writ. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Ellis v. Edwards
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: In action by creditor against individuals to recover debt owed by corporation, creditor has failed to show evidence of abuse of corporate form for purpose of promoting fraud or injustice or evasion of tort or contractual responsibility by defendants; therefore, defendants are not responsible for corporate debt.
Document Preview: Creditor sued individual defendants to recover debt owed by corporation.  The Superior Court, Pike County, Miller, J., entered summary judgment against creditor and creditor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Birdsong, P.J., held that: (1) individuals were not liable for corporate debt where statement that individuals were lawful owners and sellers of businesses owned by corporation did not pierce corporate veil nor did statement of individual that he was good for money, and (2) no evidence of abuse of corporate form for purpose of promoting fraud or injustice or evasion of tort or contractual responsibility was demonstrated. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Castleberry v. Branscum
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Disregarding corporate fiction on ground of sham to perpetrate a fraud was supported by some evidence, indicating that remaining officers and stockholders of closely held corporation manipulated the corporation and formed competing businesses to insure that stockholder who had been bought out did not get paid on his corporate note.
Document Preview: Action was brought against corporation and its shareholders to collect promissory note executed by the corporation.  The 193rd District Court, Dallas County, John Whittington, J., entered judgment holding shareholders individually liable, and they appealed.  The Dallas Court of Appeals, Fifth Supreme Judicial District, Ted M. Akin, J., 695 S.W.2d 643, reversed and rendered, and plaintiff brought error.  The Supreme Court, Spears, J., held that: (1) in order to disregard corporate fiction on the basis of sham to perpetrate fraud, showing of constructive fraud is sufficient; (2) disregard of corporate fiction on the basis of sham to perpetrate fraud was supported by some evidence that defendant officers and shareholders manipulated closely held corporation and formed competing businesses to insure that plaintiff did not get paid on corporate note; (3) error in instruction was waived by not properly objecting; and (4) the basis for...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: S.I. Property Owners' Ass'n, Inc. v. Pabst Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Individual liability could not be imposed on corporate shareholders under alter-ego doctrine for corporation's alleged misuse of funds where there was no evidence to show that corporate separateness had ceased or that shareholders had used corporation to perpetrate fraud or otherwise justify wrong.
Document Preview: Corporation composed of property owners brought suit against corporate developer and its shareholders for misapplication and improper use of maintenance funds.  The 23rd District Court, Matagorda County, Allen P. Stilley, J., entered a take-nothing judgment, and property owners' corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Dorsey, J., held that: (1) no express warranty pertaining to the maintenance funds was created, and (2) developer's corporate veil would not be pierced to impose individual liability on its stockholders. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: In re Nash
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Bankruptcy court's finding that there was no fraud between corporate debtor which issued note underlying lien against single family residence and individual debtor, corporate debtor's principal, who owned single family residence, and thus, that identity of individual and corporate debtor did not so merge prior to transaction as to render note invalid was supported by evidence that vendor, who subordinated her trust deed to corporate debtor's trust deed, agreed to subordinate her position knowing that prior lien would imperil her security upon default and that vendor did receive valid lien which attached to at least some equity in home.
Document Preview: Junior creditor challenged request by senior lien claimant to foreclose its security.  The United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of Arizona, 49 B.R. 254, George B. Nielsen, Jr., J., determined that senior lien claimant was entitled to relief from automatic stay to foreclose its lien, and junior creditor appealed.  The Bankruptcy Appellate Panel, Meyers, J., held that: (1) finding that there was no fraud between corporate debtor which issued note underlying lien against single family residence and individual debtor, corporate debtor's principal, who owned single family residence, and thus identity of individual and corporate debtor did not so merge prior to transaction as to render note invalid was supported by evidence, and (2) where junior creditor agreed that note would have priority over her purchase money deed of trust in single family residence, note could not be voided under Arizona law, absent fraud or duress. Affirmed. Sidney C. Volinn, J.,...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Dow Chemical Pacific Ltd. v. Rascator Maritime S.A.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: District court's decision to pierce corporate veil to hold shareholder personally liable for carrier's unauthorized deviation of cargo was supported by evidence that shareholder both treated corporation as his alter ego and used it for fraudulent purposes.
Document Preview: Shippers brought action against carrier subtime charterer and its agents to recover damages for impermissible deviation of the vessel for purpose of asserting a lien on the cargo.  Following entry of judgment by the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, 594 F.Supp. 1490, vessel owner, carrier, and carrier's agent moved for reargument, amendment, or vacator, and the District Court, Kevin Thomas Duffy, J., affirmed in part and vacated in part, 609 F.Supp. 451.  Carrier and agents appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Kearse, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) vessel and carrier were liable to plaintiffs for impermissible deviation of the vessel; (2) agents were liable to plaintiffs for damages and to vessel owner and time charter for indemnification; and (3) defendants were not liable for attorney fees. Affirmed in part and vacated and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Dorton v. Dorton
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Finding that president of corporation fraudulently caused corporation to issue note and deed of trust to president's mother was not supported by evidence, where there was no showing that notes and deeds of trust defrauded corporation or minority shareholder, and minority shareholder had not presented any evidence that loan proceeds were diverted for improper purposes, that corporate assets were encumbered without good reason, or that notes and deeds of trust in any way harmed corporation.
Document Preview: Equitable distribution order was entered by District Court, Durham County, David Q. LaBarre, C.J., after earlier actions concerning custody, alimony, and child support, and divorce were consolidated by stipulation of husband and wife.  Wife appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Webb, J., held: (1) husband's dental license was separate property and must be considered as one of factors affecting equitable distribution; (2) husband who knew of existence of family corporation and shared in duty to observe corporate formalities would not be allowed to disregard corporate entity on basis of noncompliance with formalities; (3) trial court erred in terminating writ of possession regarding marital home contained in earlier child support order; and (4) trial court did not improperly consider marital fault as factor in distributing marital property. Judgment vacated and remanded.

Title: Brand Structures, Inc. v. Madison Computer Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Even though president and sole stockholder of corporate lessee was president and 75% stockholder of lessee's guarantor, lessor of computer failed to make out cause of action for piercing corporate veil with respect to guarantor, where misrepresentation, materiality, scienter, reliance, and damage were not alleged and lessor failed to show that president had misled it with respect to creditworthiness of guarantor.
Document Preview: Lessor of computer brought actions against corporate lessee on debt due under lease, corporate guarantor on guaranty, and third cause to pierce veil between lessee and guarantor.  Lessor subsequently moved to amend its complaint to add individual, who was president and sole stockholder of lessee and president and 75% stockholder of guarantor, as party defendant and to allege, in separate causes of action, that he was alter ego of each corporation.  The Supreme Court, New York County, David Saxe, J., entered partial summary judgment against lessee and granted motion to add individual as party defendant, and appeal was taken.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) lessor was not defrauded or misled by lessee's inability to pay, and (2) lessor failed to make out cause of actions for piercing corporate veil with respect to guarantor. Reversed; motion denied.

Title: Eig v. Insurance Co. of North America
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: There was no basis for piercing corporate veil and holding president of corporation personally liable for loss suffered by insurer which had to pay on a surety bond issued in name of corporation, where there was no proof that corporate form was a mere device or sham to accomplish some ulterior purpose, that corporation was organized or used to mislead creditors or to perpetuate a fraud upon them or to evade existing personal liability, or that nature of relationship between president of corporation was so completely personalized that proof of actual fraud was unnecessary in order to hold him personally liable for indemnification of insurer.
Document Preview: Insurance company which had to pay on a surety bond issued in name of corporation when corporation defaulted on payments for airline tickets brought suit against president of corporation seeking to hold him personally liable. The Circuit Court, Dade County, Moie J.L. Tendrich, J., entered judgment in favor of insurance company, and president appealed.  The District Court of Appeal, Hendry, J., held that: (1) evidence was insufficient to support finding that president signed a personal indemnity agreement, and (2) there was no legal basis for piercing the corporate veil to hold president personally liable. Reversed.

Title: Harlow v. Fibron Corp.

Title: Harlow v. Fibron Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Headnote: In action brought by judgment creditor to pierce corporate veil, evidence was sufficient to support finding that sale of corporation's assets, which was without notice to judgment creditor and was in violation of New Mexico's bulk sales provisions, was nevertheless not the equivalent of commercial fraud.

Title: K Mart Corp. v. Knitjoy Mfg., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Where there was no evidence that individual defendants had abused corporation's corporate form in any way for personal gain, and plaintiff corporation did not show that it or anyone else was defrauded or misled by fact that defendant corporation operated as corporation with individuals as its principals, plaintiff corporation failed to make factual exposition sufficient to justify piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: Plaintiff corporation brought action against manufacturers and officers of manufacturer seeking damages for breach of express and implied warranty and fraudulent misrepresentation in sale of goods. On defendants' motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction, the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan, Cohn, J., 534 F.Supp. 153, denied motion. In supplemental opinion, the District Court, Cohn, J., held that individual defendants, residents of the Philippines, were subject to personal jurisdiction in Michigan under the Michigan long-arm statute because of plaintiffs' allegations that individual defendants were parties to fraud which caused consequences giving rise to action for tort to occur in Michigan. Order entered.

Title: City of Austin v. Schonfeld
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: City's claim that individual plaintiffs changed names only to avoid or evade payment of their utility bills was without support in record, there being no evidence to show that plaintiffs and a corporation were alter egos or that corporation was plaintiffs' partner or any evidence showing any basis for holding plaintiff individuals vicariously liable for debts incurred by corporation.
Document Preview: The 126th Judicial District Court, Travis County, Pete Lowry, J., granted temporary injunctive relief to plaintiffs, prohibiting city from terminating electric and water service. The city appealed. The Court of Appeals, Phillips, C. J., held that: (1) when customer of public utility presents good-faith claim, based upon reasonable grounds, that he does not owe amount claimed by public utility, then utility may not terminate service prior to judicial determination of correctness of its decision, and temporary injunction may properly be issued to prevent termination of service, and (2) paying third party's debt in order to prevent termination of electrical service, where termination is against defendant city's regulations, and then suing to recover that amount is not adequate remedy at law precluding temporary injunctive relief. Affirmed.

Title: In re Palmer Trading, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Absent showing that fraud or wrong was committed by affiliated commodity trading brokerage through bankrupt brokerage, and absent showing of connection between alleged corporate manipulation and harm bankrupt brokerage's creditors suffered, doctrine of piercing corporate veil could not be applied to disregard separate entities of the two brokerage corporations so as to entitle bankruptcy trustee to affiliated corporation's income tax refund.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from order entered by the Bankruptcy Court allowing trustee of bankrupt commodity brokerage to retain federal income tax refund of affiliated corporation. The District Court, Flaum, J., held that: (1) absent showing that fraud or wrong was committed by affiliated commodity trading brokerage through bankrupt brokerage, and absent showing of connection between alleged corporate manipulation and harm bankrupt brokerage's creditors suffered, doctrine of piercing corporate veil could not be applied to disregard separate entities of the two brokerage corporations so as to entitle bankruptcy trustee to affiliated corporation's income tax refund, and (2) absent showing that reliance by creditors of bankrupt commodity brokerage caused them to detrimentally change their position because of manifestations that affiliated brokerage and the bankrupt brokerage were same operation, the bankrupt brokerage was not estopped from denying that tax refund was transferred to...

Title: Vallone v. Vallone
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Although many acts by owner of incorporated restaurant deviated from ideal management practices, there was no showing or indication that the acts were committed for purpose of perpetrating a fraud on his former wife or others or that in fact a fraud resulted from the acts, and thus, in divorce action, trial court's finding that the corporation was not alter ego of the owner was not against great weight and preponderance of the evidence.
Document Preview: Former wife appealed from that portion of divorce judgment rendered by the District Court, Harris County, Sam S. Emison, Jr., J., which divided the marital estate. The Court of Civil Appeals, Warren, J., held that: (1) former wife's acceptance of at least some of the benefits of the divorce judgment did not estop her from pursuing the appeal; (2) trial court's finding that transfer of restaurant assets to former husband from his father was a gift was not against great weight and preponderance of the evidence; (3) finding that 47% of stock of the incorporated restaurant was separate property of former husband was not against great weight and preponderance of the evidence; (4) trial court's awarding of virtually all of the parties' income-producing property to former husband and in giving former wife a money judgment was not unfair; (5) trial court did not take into consideration large increment to former husband's separate property by reason of community labor and as a result...

Title: Crawford-Strauss Properties, Inc. v. Sagebrush Sales Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: In action brought by seller against corporate buyer, its alleged principal, and other businesses alleged to have been controlled by him to recover payment for lumber purchased from seller, evidence was factually insufficient to justify jury in reaching conclusion that principal intended that one business rely upon his financial statement in extending credit to another business.
Document Preview: Seller brought suit against corporate buyer, its alleged principal, and other businesses alleged to have been controlled by him to recover payment for lumber purchased from seller. The 68th Judicial District Court, Dallas County, Owen Giles, J., entered judgment for plaintiff, and defendants appealed. Title: Crawford-Strauss Properties, Inc. v. Sagebrush Sales Co.

Title: Murphy v. Walters
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: In action seeking to hold officer of corporation liable for alleged fraudulent representations in contract of employment, evidence that failure of corporation to pay advertising manager in full one month's salary, due to shortage of funds, while at same time, corporate officer openly acknowledged shortage and promised to make it good in next paycheck was not such evidence of fraud or fraudulent intent as to fasten personal liability on corporate officer as officer and director of corporation for damages calculated on five-year employment contract.
Document Preview: Advertising manager sued corporation and two officers in three counts alleging fraudulent representations by officers, the same by the corporation and against all three based on securities law. The Circuit Court, Lake County, Robert K. McQueen, J., entered judgment for defendants. Advertising manager filed motion for rehearing, and the trial court entered judgment in favor of advertising manager on the first and third counts. One of the officers appealed. The Appellate Court, Unverzagt, J., held that: (1) advertising manager had failed to establish that the corporation, through its officer, had perpetrated a fraud upon him by knowingly making false statements to him, and therefore, personal liability of officer was improper; (2) there was no basis for finding violations of sections of securities law relating to fraud and misrepresentation; and (3) advertising manager was entitled to either refund of cash and return of notes he had given corporation in exchange for two shares of...

Title: Valley Finance, Inc. v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence of plain fraud, though not a prerequisite to disregarding the corporate form, is of probative value in determining whether a corporation is simply the alter ego of its owner.
Document Preview: Companion appeals from two judgments of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, Charles R. Richey, J., were consolidated for argument with consent of counsel. Both appeals arose from a jeopardy assessment for income taxes in excess of 4.5 million dollars made by the Internal Revenue Service against the individual taxpayer and against a corporation wholly owned by the taxpayer. The corporation initially sought return of its property and damages but the district court upheld that seizure after finding that the corporation was not a separate entity for tax purposes. Additionally, various creditors of the corporation which sought to challenge the seizure appealed from the dismissal of their separate action. The Court of Appeals, Gesell, District Judge, sitting by designation, held that: (1) the three general creditors of the corporation that was wholly owned by the delinquent taxpayer lacked standing to bring suit under the section which permits challenge to a...

Title: Chapman v. Field
Court: Supreme Court of Arizona, In Banc.
Headnote: Evidence that stockholders lent money to corporation without taking promissory notes, that they failed to file annual reports and failed to keep proper books of account was insufficient to prove that the corporation was the alter ego of the shareholders where there was no showing of fraud on the part of shareholders or any indication that parties who sold car wash to corporation were misled.
Document Preview: Secured sellers brought suit against corporation and shareholders seeking a deficiency judgment and contending that the corporation was merely an alter ego of the shareholders. The Superior Court of Maricopa County, Cause No. C-336609, Kenneth C. Chatwin, J., found that the corporation was not alter ego of the shareholders but allowed sellers to obtain a deficiency judgment against defendant corporation, and sellers and corporation appealed. The Supreme Court, Cameron, C. J., held that: (1) the evidence was sufficient from which the trial court could find that the corporation was a valid corporation and not merely the alter ego of the shareholders, and (2) sellers were entitled to a deficiency only after a setoff of the damage to the debtor for failure to make a commercially reasonable sale. Reversed and remanded.

Title: Crawford-Strauss Properties, Inc. v. Sagebrush Sales Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Evidence did not support finding of fraud but rather established that, in selling lumber, seller was dealing with corporate purchaser and not its alleged principal or businesses alleged to have been controlled by him.
Document Preview: Seller brought suit against corporate buyer, its alleged principal and other businesses alleged to have been controlled by him to recover payment for lumber purchased from seller. The 68th Judicial District Court, Dallas County, Owen Giles, J., entered judgment against defendants, and defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Ray, J., held that: (1) evidence was insufficient to justify disregarding corporate entity, and (2) evidence did not support finding of fraud but rather established that, in selling lumber, seller was dealing with corporate purchaser and not its alleged principal or other businesses alleged to have been controlled by him. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Title: Sturdivant v. Chapman
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: In action brought by independent insurance agent against corporate defendants and individual defendant-sole shareholder of all corporate defendants, for sum paid as premiums for insurance policies, no error occurred in not piercing corporate veil and entering judgment against individual defendant for total amount due for policy premiums, inasmuch as there was no evidence of fraud, misrepresentation or any other misconduct or abuse of corporate structure so as to compel trial court to disregard concept that corporation was generally viewed as separate entity from shareholders even where all shares are owned by one individual.
Document Preview: Independent insurance agent brought action against corporate defendants and individual defendant-sole shareholder of all corporate defendants to recover sum paid for premiums for insurance policies. The Gwinnett State Court, William J. Porter, Jr., Judge pro hac vice, entered judgment from which defendants appealed and agent cross-appealed. The Court of Appeals, McMurray, J., held that: (1) in determining which defendants were liable under which policies, trial court properly did not extend liability to those of defendants who did not in fact receive any actual coverage under those policies, even though all defendants were listed as insured parties under all policies; (2) corporate defendant, which had procured through its officer and agent all of subject insurance coverage, was liable for total earned premiums, and (3) no error occurred in not piercing corporate veil and entering judgment against individual defendant for total amount due for policy premiums, inasmuch as there...

Title: Ize Nantan Bagowa, Ltd. v. Scalia
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 2.
Headnote: In action against professional corporation in which plaintiff physician sought to pierce "corporate veil" and hold its sole officer and director personally liable for corporate debt, record failed to show that corporation was incorporated to do fraud to plaintiff, who at all times knew that she was dealing with a corporation, and there was no evidence to support conclusion that "corporate veil" should be pierced in order to impose personal liability on its sole officer and director. A.R.S. §§ 10-905, 10-908.
Document Preview: Physician brought action against professional corporation, seeking to pierce corporate veil and to impose personal liability on corporation's sole officer and director. The Superior Court, Pima County, Cause No. 154632, William N. Sherill, Court Commissioner, imposed personal liability and the officer and director appealed. The Court of Appeals, Howard, J., held that record failed to show that corporation was incorporated to defraud physician, who at all times knew that she was dealing with a corporation, and there was no evidence to support conclusion that corporate veil should be pierced in order to impose personal liability on corporation's sole officer and director. Reversed with directions.

Title: A. J. Rose & Son, Inc. v. Board of Funeral Directors and Embalmers
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil may be justified in order to prevent fraud in conduct of business or profession of funeral director or embalmer but there must be some evidence or at least reasonable possibility of fraud.
Document Preview: Judicial review was sought of order of the Board of Funeral Directors and Embalmers denying application for license to operate a funeral establishment and further ordering petitioners not to utilize certain name. The Court of Appeals, Johnson, J., held that nothing in record suggested any reason why applicant should be denied license pursuant to statute. Reversed and remanded.

Title: Alterio v. Biltmore Const. Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: In suit brought against corporate contractor and the president thereof by homeowners who alleged breach of a home improvement contract, entry of judgment against the contractor's president as an individual was improper, since the record contained no evidence to indicate that injustice would result unless the contractor's corporate identity was disregarded or that the individual defendant, by incorporating, was attempting to perpetrate a fraud, and since the trial justice was clearly wrong in finding that the individual defendant, who knew the plaintiffs, personally promised to perform the contract.
Document Preview: Homeowners brought suit against corporate contractor and the president thereof, alleging breach of a home improvement contract by use of defective materials and construction in an unworkmanlike manner. The Kent Superior Court, Shea, J., entered judgment against both defendants, and they appealed. The Supreme Court, Bevilacqua, C. J., held that (1) the estimate of repairs prepared by plaintiffs' expert and his testimony concerning it were inadmissible, (2) the record failed to support the trial justice's damages award of $3,069.88, and (3) entry of judgment against the contractor's president as an individual was improper. Reversed and remanded.

Title: Fowler v. Elm Creek State Bank
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: In actions by debenture buyers against corporate issuer of debentures and individual defendants for losses sustained on debentures on grounds of fraud and negligent mismanagement and dissipation of corporate assets, evidence supported findings that individual defendants held themselves forth to be stockholders and assumed responsibilities of board of directors and that their activities as "stockholders" were so flagrantly fraudulent that corporate structure had to be disregarded and individual defendants, including those not making misrepresentations, had to be held liable.

After the cases were consolidated and default judgment was entered against corporation, the District Court, Buffalo County, Weaver, J., entered judgment against individual defendants on both causes of action, and they appealed. The Supreme Court, McCown, J., held that: (1) evidence supported findings that individual defendants held themselves forth to be stockholders and assumed responsibilities of board of directors and that their activities as stockholders was so flagrantly fraudulent that corporate structure had to be disregarded and individual defendants had to be held liable; (2) an individual defendant could be held liable for...

Title: Matassa v. Temple
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: In view of evidence that corporation had been properly formed and that there was no illegal, immoral, or unethical conduct on the part of the officer shareholders, evidence was insufficient to justify piercing corporate veil so as to permit owner of building which corporation was constructing to obtain indemnity from the officer shareholders with respect to amounts recovered from the owner by a materialman.
Document Preview: Materialman brought action to enforce lien against owner and owner sought indemnity from corporation and its officer shareholders. The Twenty-third Judicial District Court, Parish of Assumption, Penrose C. St. Amant, J., entered judgment in favor of materialman and in favor of owner against the corporation but in favor of the officer shareholder and owner appealed. The Court of Appeal, Covington, J., held that: (1) evidence did not establish fraud on the part of the officer shareholders; and (2) the evidence did not justify piercing the corporate veil. Affirmed.

Title: L.C.L. Theatres, Inc. v. Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N. D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: In antitrust action by motion picture exhibitor against motion picture distributors and distributors' counterclaim against exhibitor and its principal corporate stockholder, alleging fraudulent underreporting of box office receipts, evidence established that principal stockholder was liable for his participation and for his abuse of corporate entity by manipulatively using it as tool of fraud in underreporting box office receipts.
Document Preview: Motion picture exhibitor brought action against ten motion picture distributors and their law firm alleging violations of the Sherman Act and distributors counterclaimed to recover film rental from the exhibitor and its principal stockholder. The District Court, Patrick E. Higginbotham, J., held that the evidence established that the exhibitor engaged in fraud and breached its license agreements with the distributors by underreporting box office receipts; that the exhibitor's affirmative concealment of the fraud tolled the running of the applicable Texas two-year statute of limitations; that damages to the motion picture distributors were $429,200; and that the stockholder was personally liable for the damages for his participation and for his abuse of the corporate entity by manipulatively using it as a tool of fraud. Judgment for defendants.

Title: Scott Graphics, Inc. v. Mahaney
Court: Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Headnote: Evidence, in action seeking to hold officers and directors of defunct corporation personally liable for satisfaction of judgment against corporation, failed to support finding that defendants so manipulated corporation to further their own individual interests and to perpetrate fraud or injustice on creditors that corporation was alter ego of defendants.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from order of the District Court, Bernalillo County, James A. Maloney, J., entering judgment in favor of a plaintiff creditor in its suit to hold officers and directors of a defunct corporation personally liable for a judgment recovered against the corporation. The Court of Appeals, Hernandez, J., held that evidence failed to support the trial court's finding that the individual defendants had so manipulated the corporation to further their own individual interests and to perpetrate a fraud or injustice upon the creditor as to make the corporation the alter ego of the defendants. Reversed. Certiorari denied May 12, 1976.

Title: Holmes v. Clow
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Tyler.
Headnote: Plaintiff was not entitled to recover from individual defendant on theory that corporation which owed plaintiff money was alter ego of the individual and had been created for purpose of defrauding plaintiff and other creditors, where plaintiff raised nothing more than suspicion or surmise concerning the transactions which allegedly had effect of draining assets of corporation for individual defendant's own benefit.
Document Preview: Action was brought against corporation and its president to recover sum for blueprinting and design work for housing project to be constructed by defendant corporation. The 160th District Court, Dallas County, Leonard E. Hoffman, Jr., J., rendered judgment in favor of plaintiff against defendant corporation but rendered take nothing judgment against individual defendant and plaintiff appealed . The Court of Civil Appeals, Moore, J., held that plaintiff failed to show fraud in forming of corporation or in corporation's making other payments while plaintiff's bill was unpaid; that plaintiff failed to establish that individual defendant had used the corporation as a sham to perpetrate a fraud, or to avoid personal liability; and that finding that the corporate entity had not ceased to exist and had not become individual defendant's alter ego was not against overwhelming weight of evidence. Affirmed.

Title: Miles v. N. J. Motors, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Lucas County.
Headnote: Where there was no probative evidence that debtors relied to their detriment in any particular manner on public sale of their lawfully repossessed property, trial court properly found that creditor's practice of holding private sale of repossessed automobiles rather than public auction did not constitute fraud sufficient to justify piercing corporate veil. R.C. §§ 1309.46, 1309.47, 1309.48, 1319.07.
Document Preview: Debtors brought class action against secured creditor seeking injunctive and declaratory relief for alleged illegality in disposition of repossessed automobiles. Trial court rendered judgment for creditor and assessed costs against debtors, and debtors appealed. The Court of Appeals, Lucas County, Wiley, J., held that trial court erred in finding that creditor's disposition of repossessed automobiles complied with commercial code; that trial court erred in holding that creditor sold reposessed automobiles pursuant to proper notice; that trial court erred in finding that creditor had satisfied obligation to perform contract in good faith; that trial court properly found that debtors had not proven fraud on part of creditor sufficient to justify piercing corporate veil; that cognovit notes contained in creditor's contracts were not illegal at time entered into; that trial court erroneously ordered debtors to reimburse creditor for cost of notifying class of debtor plaintiffs; that...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Soderberg Advertising, Inc. v. Kent-Moore Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: Evidence on issue of whether corporate entity of debtor should be disregarded sustained finding that head of advertising agency, which sought to hold one corporation, which at one time had an option to purchase second corporation, liable for debts of optionor corporation had been given the impression that the resources of the optionee corporation would be available for full payment of advertising agency's services, thus allowing agency to recover the amount owed from the optionee corporation.
Document Preview: Advertising agency which had done work for one corporation brought action against that corporation and second corporation, which at one time had an option to purchase the first corporation. The Superior Court, King County, Frank D. Howard, J., entered judgment in favor of advertising agency and optionee corporation appealed. The Court of Appeals, Horowitz, J., held that evidence sustained finding that advertising agency had been led to believe that optionee corporation would be responsible for debts of the optionor corporation; that doctrine of disregarding the corporate entity was properly applied; and that statute of frauds provisions relating to agreements to answer for the debts of another were inapplicable. Affirmed.

Title: Babcock v. Houston
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Individual stockholder could not be held individually liable for real estate broker's commissions in connection with the sale of corporate property on theory that the corporation was the alter ego of its stockholders, in absence of showing that the stockholders disregarded corporate entity or used it to perpetrate fraud, circumvent a statute, or accomplish any wrongful or inequitable purpose.
Document Preview: Brokers brought suit against corporation and individuals to recover commissions under an exclusive agreement which lacked a definite termination date, in violation of statute. The Superior Court of Orange County, Mark A. Soden, J., entered judgment in favor of the brokers against the corporation but not against the individuals, and brokers appealed. The Court of Appeal, Tamura, J., held that despite lack of definite termination date, exclusive agreement was enforceable against individual who retained brokers, with respect to sales made by brokers prior to their discharge; that individual who retained brokers and who, with his wife, was sole stockholder of corporation could not escape liability on ground that services were rendered for the corporation, which owned the tract from which the sales were made; that description of the property in the agreement was sufficient to satisfy the statute of frauds; and that wife could not be held liable on theory that the corporation was the...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Cone v. Acme Markets, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: Where it was not shown that holder of 50 per cent of stock in corporate lessor of space in shopping center misused corporate form, disregarded corporate form in dealing with lessee, which operated market, or committed fraud or illegality, corporate veil would not be pierced so as to make binding on stockholder, who also owned controlling interest in corporations engaged in business of operating retail food stores, restrictive covenant precluding sale or lease of property within one mile of shopping center for sale of food for off-the-premises consumption.
Document Preview: Action was brought seeking declaration of rights under lease of space in shopping center. The Oneida Trial Term, Donald H. Mead, J., rendered judgment, from which cross appeals were taken. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Marsh, J., held that where it was not shown that holder of 50 per cent of stock in corporate lessor of space in shopping center misused corporate form, disregarded corporate form in dealing with lessee, which operated market, or committed fraud or illegality, corporate veil would not be pierced so as to make binding on stockholder, who also owned controlling interest in corporations engaged in business of operating retail food stores, restrictive covenant precluding sale or lease of property within one mile of shopping center for sale of food for off-the-premises consumption. In addition the Court held that phrase the herein involved premises, as used in restrictive covenant prohibiting lease, for competing purposes, of properties within one mile...
