Title: Dietel v. Day
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 2.
Headnote: Record established that corporation was guilty of numerous breaches of franchise contract and for that reason judgment in favor of franchisees against corporation should stand, but record failed to show fraud or mingling of funds or unity of interests of shareholder and director who subsequently became president of the corporation so as to justify holding him personally liable for the corporation's debts.
Document Preview: Action for infringement of trade names, trademarks and unfair competition, wherein a defendant filed a third-party complaint against a codefendant as the alter ego of the corporation for breach of contract. From a judgment of the Superior Court, Pima County, Cause No. 108404, Laurance T. Wren, J., the codefendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Krucker, C.J., held, inter alia, that record established that corporation was guilty of numerous breaches of franchise contract and for that reason judgment in favor of franchisees against corporation should stand, but record failed to show fraud or mingling of funds or unity of interests of shareholder and director who subsequently became president of the corporation so as to justify holding him personally liable for the corporation's debts. Judgment reversed as applied to codefendant personally.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Vogel v. Town of New Milford
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: In proceedings on application for change of name of automobile junkyard which was in restricted district in which further establishment of automobile junkyards was forbidden from that of a sole proprietorship to that of a corporation, in absence of evidence that sole proprietor was dominant shareholder of corporation or that, if he was, his control was being used to commit a fraud or to perpetuate a dishonest or unjust act, corporate form could not be disregarded as mere instrumentality or alter ego of sole proprietor. C.G.S.A. §§ 21-16 to 21-18, 21-20, 21-22, 21-24, 21-25, 21-26, 33-289(a) (2), (b), 33-291(c).
Document Preview: Owner of land adjoining junkyard appealed from action of town board of selectmen granting application for change of name of automobile junkyard from that of a sole proprietorship to that of a corporation. The Court of Common Pleas in Litchfield County, Martin, J., dismissed the appeal and the owner appealed. The Supreme Court, Shapiro, J., held that sole proprietor of automobile junkyard in a restricted district in which further establishment of automobile junkyards was forbidden could not transfer his license to corporation of which he was allegedly the dominant stockholder by seeking to change the name of existing junkyard to the corporation's name; corporation was required to apply as a new applicant for a license and board of selectmen, in ignoring separate identity of corporation and treating proceeding merely as one for name change, acted arbitrarily and capriciously. Error; judgment directed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Harris v. Curtis
Court: Court of Appeal, Fifth District, California.
Headnote: Evidence in action to recover from stockholders who allegedly were alter ego of corporation monies advanced corporation was insufficient to establish fraud, misconduct and overreaching on part of stockholders.
Document Preview: Action to recover monies advanced corporation from corporation and its shareholders who allegedly were alter ego of corporation. The Superior Court, Kings County, Robert R. Rosson, J., granted judgment against corporation but denied recovery from shareholders and lender appealed. The Court of Appeal, Coakley, J., held that individuals who were shareholders of corporation which had paid in capital of $1,000 of which $811.12 was used for expenses of incorporation were not alter ego of corporation and liable for monies advanced to corporation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Contractors Heating & Supply Co. v. Scherb
Court: Supreme Court of Colorado, In Department.
Headnote: Evidence that corporation was operated with lack of formality or attention to normal requirements of conducting affairs of corporation, but which showed total absence of fraud committed or contemplated by president as to plaintiff or other creditors was insufficient to justify piercing of corporate veil in attempt to hold president of corporation personally liable on corporation's debt.
Document Preview: Action against president of corporation and corporation for debt owing to plaintiff. By consent, judgment for $5,132 was entered in favor of plaintiff and against corporation and the District Court, City and County of Denver, Don D. Bowman, J., dismissed plaintiff's complaint against president of corporation on ground that evidence was insufficient to justify piercing corporate veil to hold president personally liable for corporation's debt to plaintiff. The Supreme Court, Hodges, J., held that evidence that corporation was operated with lack of formality or attention to normal requirements of conducting affairs of corporation but which failed to show fraud committed or contemplated by president as to plaintiff or other creditors, was insufficient to justify piercing corporate veil to hold president personally liable for corporation's debt to plaintiff. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Fink v. Montgomery Elevator Co. of Colo.
Court: Supreme Court of Colorado, In Department.
Headnote: Manager of corporate operator of parking facility could not be held personally liable for corporate obligations under a contract in regard to elevator work on such facilities, nor could manager be held liable as a stockholder, where there was no showing that corporate entity was used to defeat public convenience or that imposition of such personal liability was necessary to protect against wrong, fraud or crime.
Document Preview: Action by an elevator company to recover for services rendered by it under contract. The District Court, City and County of Denver, Mitchel B. Johns, J., entered judgment against an individual defendant, and he brought error. The Supreme Court, Sutton, C.J., held that evidence established that defendant against whom judgment was entered signed contract in question as agent for corporate owner of parking facility on which plaintiff performed its services. Reversed and remanded with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Leeb v. Read
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Findings in final judgment denying recovery on hull policy for fire damage to aircraft that insureds and their agent in procuring insurance coverage made material misrepresentations to insurer's agent, relied upon by insurer, as to value of insured aircraft, that insureds through their agent probably procured or deliberately caused aircraft to be intentionally destroyed or damaged, that proof of loss was false and known to be false in enumerated material matters, and that organization of corporation, controlled by insureds and their associates, to operate restaurant in aircraft was in furtherance of fraudulent scheme to collect insurance and others were supported by sufficient substantial evidence.
Document Preview: Action to recover on a hull insurance policy for fire damage to an aircraft. The Circuit Court for Dade County, Frances X. Knuck, J., entered a final judgment for defendants, and plaintiffs appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Swann, J., held that the findings in final judgment denying recovery were supported by substantial evidence and that any error in admission of evidence did not affect the substantial rights of plaintiffs. Affirmed.

Title: Hellenic Lines Limited v. Winkler
Court: United States District Court S.D. New York.
Headnote: Evidence established that corporation against which plaintiff had obtained judgment was a legally existing corporation, that it was not operated with complete disregard of corporate form and that individual controlling shareholder had not perpetrated any fraud on plaintiff, in action by plaintiff to recover amount of judgment from individual on basis of piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: Action against individual for amount of judgment that plaintiff had obtained against a corporation on basis that the corporate veil of corporation should be pierced through to defendant. The District Court, Feinberg, J., held that evidence established that corporation was a legally existing corporation, that it was not operated with complete disregard of corporate form and that defendant controlling shareholder had not perpetrated any fraud on plaintiff. Judgment accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Blond Lighting Fixture Supply Co. v. Funk
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: In absence of indication that corporation was formed as means of perpetrating fraud, that it was operated as mere tool or business conduit of another corporation or as alter ego of an individual, that corporate form was being used as means of evading existing obligations, to circumvent statute, to protect crime or to justify wrong, there was no justification for disregarding corporate entity, or piercing corporate veil in order to impose liability on two directors as to goods sold to corporation on open account. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21, subd. A.
Document Preview: Suit on open account to recover for goods sold and delivered to corporation and for attorney's fees, wherein plaintiff sought judgment against corporation and individual defendants. The 131st District Court, Bexar County, Delos Finch, J., entered summary judgment that plaintiff recover from corporation and that it take nothing against individual defendants and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Cadena, J., held that if incorporator had paid for his stock, as alleged in affidavit of counsel of plaintiff, incorporator could not be liable under section of Business Corporation Act providing that stockholder is under no obligation to corporation or shareholders other than obligation to pay corporation full amount of consideration for shares and that whether one of original incorporators had paid for such shares of stock personally, whether they had been paid for by another as gift to incorporator or whether they had been paid for by such other person and held by...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Platt v. Billingsley
Court: District Court of Appeal, Fifth District, California.
Headnote: Violation by stock sellers and buyer of representation to corporation commissioner that no proceeds of the sale would be used for benefit of corporation but that proceeds were for personal and individual benefit of the sellers evidenced intent to circumvent corporation law and revealed selling and buying stockholders' disregard for corporate entity for purpose of applying alter ego doctrine.
Document Preview: Action to hold stockholders personally liable for corporate indebtedness. The Superior Court, Orange County, Raymond Thompson, J., rendered judgment for remodeling contractor, and stockholders appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Stone, J., held that evidence supported finding that corporation was influenced, dominated, and controlled by sellers of part of stock and by buyer thereof who were sued on theory of alter ego and whose corporation was under-capitalized at all times. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Radio KBUY, Inc. v. Lieurance
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Amarillo.
Headnote: Evidence supported findings that plaintiff radio station had furnished advertising time to furniture corporation for at least two years on open account, that there had been no intermingling of funds of corporation and its president, that station had not relied on any representation of president in extending credit to corporation, that president, individually, had not agreed to pay debt and that there had been no false representations made by president or corporation to station, which contended that advertising had been furnished to president rather than to corporation and that president had agreed to pay for it.
Document Preview: Suit upon open account filed by radio station for advertising time furnished furniture corporation, wherein plaintiff sought personal judgment against president of corporation. The 108th District Court, Potter County, Mary Lou Robinson, J., rendered take-nothing judgment with respect to claim against president personally and station appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Chapman, J., held that where radio station had furnished advertising time to furniture corporation for two years on open account, there had been no intermingling of funds of corporation and its president, station had not relied on any representation or president in extending credit to corporation, president, individually, had not agreed to pay debt of corporation and there had been no false representations made by president or corporation to station, corporate entity of corporation would not be disregarded and president individually was not liable for any part of balance. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Sirmons v. Arnold Lumber Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Second District.
Headnote: Where it was not shown that dealings of corporation were not entirely corporate, that creditor dealt in anywise with president of such corporation or relied on any representations made by him, that creditor was victimized by fraud or bad faith or that corporation was alter ego of its president, execution on judgment against corporation could not be satisfied from personal assets of its president though he held 90% of the stock.
Document Preview: The Civil and Criminal Court of Record for Pinellas County, B. J. Driver, J., held that execution of a judgment against a defendant corporation could be satisfied from the personal assets of the corporate president. The president appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Barns, Paul D., Associate Judge, held that where it was not shown that dealings of the corporation were not entirely corporate, that the plaintiff creditor dealt in anywise with the president or relied on any representations made by him, that the creditor was victimized by fraud or bad faith or that the corporation was the alter ego of its president, execution on the judgment could not be satisfied from personal assets of its president though he held 90% of the stock. Reversed without prejudice to further like proceedings.

Title: Lesser v. Strubbe
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey Appellate Division.
Headnote: Evidence, on issue as to availability of defense of usury, sustained finding that note represented loan to individual rather than to corporation and that corporate cloak had been used to avoid defense of usury.
Document Preview: Two mortgage foreclosure actions, and mortgagor's suit to have guaranty agreements declared void as to her, were consolidated for trial. The Chancery Division, 56 N.J.Super. 274, 152 A.2d 409, rendered the judgment challenged by plaintiff's appeal. The Appellate Division, Sullivan, J.A.D., held that evidence would not sustain contention that plaintiff had known, or should have known, about such fraud as was committed on borrower's wife by her husband, or that notice of fraud had been brought home to plaintiff by circumstances under which borrower's wife agreed to guarantee loan and to secure same by mortgage on her property. Remanded with directions.

Title: Moore & Moore Drilling Co. v. White
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Evidence in action by driller of oil well to recover contract price from individual who owned corporation with which drilling contract was made failed to establish confidential relation between individual and driller, to show any fraud, or to show that individual was guilty of bad faith in forming corporation or was alter ego of corporation.
Document Preview: Action by the driller of an oil well to recover the contract price from the individual who was the sole owner of the corporation with which the drilling contract was made. The District Court, Dallas County, Paul Peurifoy, J., withdrew the case from the jury and rendered a judgment for the individual, and the plaintiff appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Williams, J., held that the plaintiff's evidence showed no more than a suspicion of fraud, that the individual was not the corporation's alter ego, and that the individual and the corporation were not mining partners where there was never any joint operation of the well and the contract between them required the cost of the development to be paid solely by the corporation. Affirmed.

Title: Cockrell v. Craugh
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: In action by payee-former stockholder against corporation and individual for amount of note containing corporation's typewritten signature and individual's written signature and for amount loaned corporation by payee-former stockholder, evidence was not sufficient to establish fraud on individual's part or to show that the corporate entity should be disregarded.
Document Preview: Action by payee-former stockholder against corporation and individual for amount of note containing corporation's typewritten signature followed by individual's written signature and for amount loaned corporation by payee-former stockholder. A trustee intervened claiming to own the note. The 101st District Court, Dallas County, Dallas A. Blankenship, J., rendered judgment for plaintiff and intervenor against corporation but denied recovery against individual, and plaintiff and intervenor appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals held that individual was personally liable on note because he had signed it without limitation, but action against him on note was barred by four-year-statute of limitations, and that claims against corporation were barred by the two-and-four year statutes of limitations. Motion of plaintiff and intervenor for rehearing overruled, motion of corporate defendant for rehearing granted, judgment affirmed as to individual defendant, and judgment reversed and...

Title: State v. Johnson
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: In action to determine whether profits received by taxpayer from sale of stock on deferred payment basis were subject to tax in year in which taxpayer had exchanged notes he had received for unpaid balance of stock for notes of his closely held corporation to which he transferred notes from sale of stock even though taxpayer had exercised option to pay taxes on installment basis, evidence sustained finding that taxpayer's sale of notes and related actions were not a subterfuge or a sham but were legitimate business transactions. Code 1942, §§ 690, 692, 9220-08(a); 26 U.S.C.A. (I.R.C.1954) § 453(a, b, d).
Document Preview: Action to determine whether profits received by taxpayer from sale of stock on deferred payment basis were subject to tax in year in which taxpayer had exchanged notes he had received for unpaid balance for notes of his closely held corporation to which he had transferred notes received from sale even though he had exercised option to pay taxes on installment basis. The Chancery Court, Hinds County, S. V. Robertson, Jr., Chancellor, rendered judgment for taxpayer and state appealed. The Supreme Court, Ethridge, J., held that where taxpayer transferred notes received on sale of stock to his merchandising corporation for purpose of enabling corporation to use notes as collateral in its business and as consideration taxpayer received substantially identical notes of corporation payable to him in installments, taxpayer's privilege of paying income tax on installment payments when received was not terminated. Affirmed. Kyle and Lee, JJ., dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Lesser v. Strubbe
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey Chancery Division.
Headnote: Evidence, on issue as to availability of defense of usury, compelled conclusion that corporation's note, secured by individuals' mortgages, represented loan to individual rather than to corporation and that corporate cloak had been used to avoid defense of usury. N.J.S.A. 31:1-6; General Business Law N.Y. § 374.
Document Preview: Two mortgage foreclosure actions and mortgages suit to have guaranty agreements and mortgage declared void as to her were consolidated for trial. The Chancery Division, Scherer, J.S.C., held that the loan represented by corporation's note secured by mortgages had been a loan to individual defendant rather than a loan to corporation and that defense of usury was thus available to defendants, and held that since constructive notice of fraud practiced upon defendant wife by her husband had been brought home to plaintiff by circumstances, doctrine of unclean hands should be applied. Judgment accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: American Tobacco Co. v. Goulandris
Court: United States District Court S.D. New York.
Headnote: In libel for loss and damage to goods carried on owners' vessel, evidence failed to establish that a corporation formed to re-establish a steamship passenger service under the Greek flag between North America and Greece was controlled by vessel owners or by a wholly-owned corporate agent of vessel owners, or that Greek flag corporation was organized to defraud creditors or to evade existing obligations, even though vessel owners owned some of the stock of Greek flag corporation.
Document Preview: Suits in admiralty for damage sustained to cargo shipped on defendants' vessel. Vessel owners filed a cross-libel for contribution in general average. The District Court, Ryan, J., held, inter alia, that vessel owners had the right and duty to file cross-libels to enforce collection from cargo interests of their contribution of their indebtedness to the general average fund, and vessel owners had such obligation even though on balance they might be debtors in general average. Decree in accordance with opinion. See also D.C., 134 F.Supp. 475.

Title: McAuliffe v. C & K Builders, Inc.
Court: Municipal Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.
Headnote: In action for breach of contract in sale of a house and alleged misrepresentations, evidence that the individual defendants maintained interest in other corporations was insufficient, standing alone, to establish that they were organized and dissolved for the purpose of perpetrating a fraud.
Document Preview: Action against the corporation and individual defendants for damages arising out of a contract for the purchase of a house. From an adverse judgment in the Municipal Court for the District of Columbia, Civil Division, Godfrey L. Munter, J., the plaintiffs appealed. The Municipal Court of Appeals, Rover, C. J., held that the evidence was insufficient to warrant disregarding the corporate entity so as to hold the individual defendants liable. Judgment affirmed.

Title: Critzer v. Oban
Court: Supreme Court of Washington, Department 2.
Headnote: In action brought by creditor of bankrupt corporation to recover from its stockholders, on theory that corporation had been merely alter ego of their partnership, amount owed to him, evidence would sustain finding that none of defendants had attempted to mislead or deceive plaintiff in regard to credit standing, resources, operation, management, responsibility or liability on accounts of corporation.
Document Preview: Action brought by creditor of bankrupt corporation to recover from its stockholders, on theory that corporation had been merely alter ego of their partnership, amount owed to him. The Superior Court, King County, F. A. Walterskirchen, J., rendered judgment for defendants, and the plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Donworth, J., held that evidence would not have supported finding that corporation had been used as a mere tool or instrument in carrying out defendants' plans and purposes and that there had been such confusion of identities and acts as to work a fraud upon third persons. Affirmed.

Title: Critzer v. Oban
Court: Supreme Court of Washington, Department 2.
Headnote: In action brought by creditor of bankrupt corporation to recover from its stockholders, on theory that corporation had been merely alter ego of their partnership, amount owed to him, evidence would not have supported finding that corporation had been used as a mere tool or instrument in carrying out defendants' plans and purposes and that there had been such confusion of identities and acts as to work a fraud upon third persons.
Document Preview: Action brought by creditor of bankrupt corporation to recover from its stockholders, on theory that corporation had been merely alter ego of their partnership, amount owed to him. The Superior Court, King County, F. A. Walterskirchen, J., rendered judgment for defendants, and the plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Donworth, J., held that evidence would not have supported finding that corporation had been used as a mere tool or instrument in carrying out defendants' plans and purposes and that there had been such confusion of identities and acts as to work a fraud upon third persons. Affirmed.

Title: Most Worshipful Sons of Light Grand Lodge Ancient Free and Accepted Masons v. Sons of Light Lodge No. 9
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: In quiet title action against building corporation which held title to property allegedly taken by lodge members who seceded from old lodge to form new lodge, which conveyed property to corporation, evidence sustained finding that corporation was alter ego of new lodge and that if corporation were treated as an entity completely separate and apart from new lodge, a great fraud would be perpetrated.
Document Preview: Action against lodge members, who had taken assets of old lodge and formed new lodge, for declaration of a constructive trust based on fraud and for an accounting, wherein plaintiffs moved to amend complaint to include quiet title action against corporation to which new lodge had transferred real property of old lodge. The Superior Court, City and County of San Francisco, Milton D. Sapiro, J., permitted complaint to be amended and rendered judgment for plaintiffs, and defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Bray, J., held that complaint alleging that fraternal lodge members who seceded from lodge and formed new lodge had taken all assets of old lodge including its properties and praying that property be restored and that title be quieted dealt with real property of lodge, and amending of complaint seven years later to include corporation which was alter ego of new lodge and to which real property of lodge had been conveyed, and to describe by metes and bounds that real...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Macfadden v. Macfadden
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey. Appellate Division.
Headnote: In action by widow against her deceased husband's estate and certain corporations for specific performance of separation agreement giving her use of home during her lifetime, evidence would sustain finding that there had been such equitable fraud as would justify piercing of corporate veil to extent of allowing wife to receive benefit of separation agreement even though legal title was in various corporations which her deceased husband controlled.
Document Preview: Action by widow against her deceased husband's estate and certain corporations for specific performance of separation agreement giving her use of home during her lifetime. The Superior Court, Chancery Division, 46 N.J.Super. 242, 134 A.2d 531, rendered judgment for plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Appellate Division, Per Curiam, held that evidence would sustain finding that there had been such equitable fraud as would justify piercing of corporate veil to extent of allowing wife to receive benefit of separation agreement even though legal title was in various corporations which her deceased husband controlled. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Bayou Drilling Co. of Tex. v. Baillio
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Houston.
Headnote: In action for foreclosure of chattel mortgage executed by one of corporate defendants to secure note, the payment of which had been guaranteed by the other corporate defendant, evidence would not sustain plaintiff's contention that corporate guarantor was alter ago of individual who had induced plaintiff to make loan and that to uphold such corporation's plea of ultra vires would thus promote fraud.
Document Preview: Action for foreclosure of chattel mortgage executed by one of corporate defendants to secure note, the payment of which had been guaranteed by the other corporate defendant. The Sixty-First District Court, Harris County, Ben F. Wilson, J., rendered judgment for plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Bell, C. J., held that evidence had, as a matter of law, entitled plaintiff to relief sought as against corporate mortgagor, but held that the record evidenced an incomplete development of facts in connection with liability of corporate guarantor. Affirmed in part and in part reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(7) Fraud or illegal acts in general >
Title: Wells v. Hiskett
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: In action by children of wife of first marriage to establish trust in community property of wife and second husband resulting from oil operations, evidence did not establish that corporation organized and maintained by the husband and another was in fraud of the wife and for the purpose of depriving her of her community property rights or that the husband was using the corporate entity to circumvent the community property laws.
Document Preview: Action by children of first marriage of wife in trespass to try title and in the alternative to claim that property was community property of the wife and her second husband or was acquired under circumstances giving rise to trust in favor of the wife and for an accounting. Judgment for plaintiffs in the District Court, Gregg County, Fred Erisman, J., and the defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Davis, J., held that the evidence failed to establish that a corporation organized by the husband and another to engage in oil operations was in fraud of the wife, that the corporate entity could not be disregarded, that findings of the jury that acquisition of property by the corporation resulted from the efforts of the wife were against the evidence, and that the property claimed was not held in trust for the wife and remained the separate property of the husband as a matter of law. Reversed and rendered.

Title: Pores v. Purity Milk Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, Third District. California.
Headnote: Evidence was not legally insufficient to support finding that facts and circumstances did not justify disregarding the corporate entity and holding majority stockholder of bankrupt corporation who had taken over management and operation of corporate business personally liable on agreements which another individual operating the business taken over by corporation had entered into prior to incorporation in absence of showing that majority stockholder had prospered at expense of plaintiffs or that they had been misled or materially damaged by conduct of corporate affairs.
Document Preview: Actions seeking to disregard the corporate entity and hold majority stockholder of bankrupt corporation personally liable on agreements which another individual conducting business taken over by corporation had entered into prior to incorporation were consolidated for trial. The Superior Court, San Joaquin County, George F. Buck, J., rendered judgments in favor of individual defendant, and plaintiffs appealed. The District Court of Appeals, Finley, Justice pro tem., held that the evidence was not legally insufficient to support finding that facts and circumstances did not justify disregarding the corporate entity and fixing personal liability on majority stockholder. Affirmed.

Title: Nuttall v. Lankford
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of Virginia
Headnote: Record warranted finding of trial court that evidence was insufficient to sustain complainant's contention that corporate lessee of oyster planting grounds in bed of Rappahannock River was a mere dummy corporation designed and chartered for purpose of enabling a foreign corporation or a nonresident to hold and operate oyster planting grounds contrary to statute. Code 1942, § 3193(2).
Document Preview: Appeal from Circuit Court, Lancaster County; E. Hugh Smith, Judge.

Title: Purvin v. Grey
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to show that transfer of assets from old corporation, which was partly owned by deceased judgment debtor, to new corporation was made in fraud of judgment debtor's creditors or that money subscribed by judgment debtor's son for his stock in new corporation really belonged to judgment debtor so as to authorize recovery by judgment creditor of premiums paid by new corporation for insurance on the life of judgment debtor.
Document Preview: Appeal from Supreme Court, New York County; Benjamin F. Schreiber, Justice. Action by William H. Purvin on behalf of himself and all other creditors of the estate of Louis L. Grey, deceased, against Harold N. Grey, and others, to recover premiums paid by the Gothic Jar Proof Watch Corp., for insurance on decedent's life. From a judgment of dismissal on the merits plaintiff appeals. Affirmed. See, also, 269 App.Div. 652, 53 N.Y.S.2d 185; 270 App.Div. 152, 59 N.Y.S.2d 176.

Title: Kulukundis v. Dean Stores Holding Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Errors of Connecticut.
Headnote: In action by purchasers of leased premises to recover rent for balance of term from cleaning company which had gone into possession of the leased premises with permission of the lessee company which had been organized to acquire realty and enter into leases for cleaning company, on ground that organization of lessee was a fraudulent device to hinder and delay creditors, evidence justified denial of recovery on ground that purchasers failed to prove that organization of lessee was a fraudulent device.
Document Preview: Appeal from Court of Common Pleas, Fairfield County; Dwyer, Judge. Action by Nicholas Kulukundis and others against Dean Stores Holding Company, Inc., and another, to recover damages for unpaid rent, brought to the Court of Common Pleas and tried to the court. From a judgment in favor of the plaintiffs against the named defendant only, the plaintiffs appeal. No error.

Title: H.A.S. Loan Service v. McColgan
Court: Supreme Court of California.
Headnote: Evidence sustained finding that corporate device was used by loan service corporation and finance company as means of thwarting usury and franchise tax laws, and that the two corporate entities were controlled by same persons, and were engaged in single business, so that corporate entities might be disregarded in determining whether loan service corporation was a "financial corporation" within state franchise tax law. Gen.Laws Act 8488, §§ 1, 2, 4, 4a (repealed. See Revenue and Taxation Code, § 23102 et seq.).
Document Preview: In Bank. Action by H. A. S. Loan Service, Inc., against Charles J. McColgan, as State Franchise Tax Commissioner, to recover amount paid under protest as franchise tax. From an adverse judgment, plaintiff appeals. Affirmed.

Title: Allman Hubble Tugboat Co. v. Reliance Development Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Washington.
Headnote: Evidence held to sustain the jury's finding that a corporation whose incorporators and directors were stenographers or clerks in the offices of two logging operators who dominated the corporation, which did practically nothing except to send a circular letter to creditors asking that charges be made to the corporation, was a mere shell organized to defraud creditors if logging operations proved unsuccessful, and hence those actually conducting such operations were liable on accounts for merchandise and services.
Document Preview: Department 1. Appeal from Superior Court, Grays Harbor County; J. M. Phillips, Judge. Action to collect accounts for merchandise sold and services rendered by the Allman Hubble Tugboat Company against the Reliance Development Corporation, the Lytle Logging & Mercantile Company, M. H. Myers, and Mrs. M. H. Myers and Robert E. Hatch, doing business as the Lytle Logging Company. Judgment for plaintiff, and the Lytle Logging & Mercantile Company, M. H. Myers, and Robert E. Hatch appeal. Affirmed.

Title: Yates v. St. Johns Beach Development Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Florida, Division A.
Headnote: In action against corporation on alleged assumption of second mortgage bonds pursuant to agreement of incorporator to create corporation to acquire land securing bonds, pay overdue interest and future principal and interest on bonds, protect bonds against first mortgage bonds, and make them payable in any event, evidence did not establish that corporation was fraudulently used by incorporator to avoid personal liability.
Document Preview: Error to Circuit Court, Duval County; Bayard B. Shields, Judge. Action by James A. Yates against the St. Johns Beach Development Company. To review a judgment for defendant, plaintiff brings error. Affirmed.

Title: Davis v. Perry
Court: District Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: Evidence negatived fraud in judgment debtor's conveyance to corporation after filing of supersedeas bond and subsequent conveyance by corporation to judgment debtor's subsequent judgment creditors. Code Civ.Proc. § 671 (repealed 1945).
Document Preview: Appeal from Superior Court, San Diego County; Lacy D. Jennings, Judge. Action by Le Compte Davis and others against William H. Perry and others. From an adverse judgment, named defendant appeals. Affirmed.

Title: Hayhurst v. Boyd
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho.
Headnote: Evidence held insufficient to show fraud, neglect, or misconduct by principal stockholder sufficient to disregard corporate entity and hold stockholder individually liable for judgment against corporation (C.S. § 4728; Const. art. 11, § 17).
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Twin Falls County; Hugh A. Baker, Judge. Action on judgment by Nathan Hayhurst against T. O. Boyd and others. Judgment for defendants, and plaintiff appeals. Affirmed.

Title: Sun River Stock & Land Co. v. Montana Trust & Savings Bank
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: Evidence held not to justify application of rule that court will look behind corporate cloak to circumvent fraud or accomplish justice.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Lewis and Clark County; W. H. Poorman and A. J. Horsky, Judges. Suits by the Sun River Stock & Land Company, by Charles B. Power, as guardian, by Charles B. Power individually, by Charles B. Power, as trustee for Gordon Lamey, by Charles B. Power, as trustee for Ella G. Lamey, and by Charles B. Power, as administrator of the estate of Mabel L. Power, deceased, all against the Montana Trust & Savings Bank, as executor of the last will and testament and estate of John H. Burke, deceased. Judgments for plaintiffs, and defendant appeals. Reversed, with direction, as to all judgments except judgment in suit brought by Charles B. Power individually; as to that affirmed.

Title: In re Kwok
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Individual Chapter 11 debtor's invocation of his Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination was cumulative evidence, supporting bankruptcy trustee's alter ego claim under Delaware law in adversary proceeding against entities seeking turnover of assets, since invocation buttressed plausibility of complaint's allegations. U.S. Const. Amend. 5; 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 541, 542, 544.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Chapter 11 bankruptcy trustee had standing to bring turnover claim on behalf of creditors at large.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Small v. Estate of Landesman
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Judgment creditor, who had prevailed in underlying action brought against judgment debtor company, failed to present sufficient facts to raise triable issue that warranted invocation of equitable doctrine of piercing corporate veil to allow judgment creditor to recover judgment from estate of judgment debtor's principal, regardless of whether New York or Delaware law applied; evidence submitted by judgment creditor indicated that principal, by himself, did not dominate and control company in that, at minimum, he consulted with others on financial and employee matters, principal owned 25% of judgment debtor, while founder and his grantor trust owned other 75% and had power to remove principal, and judgment creditor provided scant evidence of disregard of corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor failed to present sufficient facts to warrant piercing corporate veil to recover judgment from estate of debtor's principal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: U.S. Bank National Association v. MMCO, L.L.C.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: Evidence that a corporation and an individual are alter egos of each other alone is insufficient to pierce the corporate veil; all three prongs of the test from Belvedere v. R.E. Roark, 617 N.E.2d 1075, must be met for the court to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: TORTS  Damages. Tenant failed to present evidence of actual damages for fraud in addition to those claimed for breach of guaranty in action against co-trustee.

Title: Blizzard Energy, Inc. v. Schaefers
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 6, California.
Headnote: Statute authorizing a court to adopt any suitable process or mode of proceeding contemplates a noticed motion to amend judgment to add an additional judgment debtor as an alter ego, and the court is not required to hold an evidentiary hearing; evidence in the form of declarations or deposition testimony is sufficient. Cal. Civ. Proc. Code § 187.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was sufficient to support a finding that LLC was judgment debtor's alter ego.

Title: Shorter Brothers, Inc. v. Vectus 3, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Certificate of formation could not establish that corporation had a separate existence from its owners so as to preclude piercing corporate veil in action in which seller of delivery trucks and delivery routes to corporation was asserting claims of breach of contract, unjust enrichment, and conversion against both corporation and corporation's individual owners; certificate of formation merely showed that corporation existed as a legal entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was warranted so as to hold corporation's individual owners personally liable for breach of sales contract.

Title: Shorter Brothers, Inc. v. Vectus 3, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Single Form 1099-MISC, which revealed corporation's income, unspecified salary expenses, and minor tax and repair expenses over a two-month period, could not establish that corporation had a separate existence from its owners so as to preclude piercing corporate veil in action in which seller of delivery trucks and delivery routes to corporation was asserting claims of breach of contract, unjust enrichment, and conversion against both corporation and corporation's individual owners.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was warranted so as to hold corporation's individual owners personally liable for breach of sales contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: JNM Express, LLC v. Lozano
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Evidence was legally and factually sufficient to support jury's finding that individual owners, a married couple, were alter egos of trucking and brokerage companies, as required to pierce corporate veil and hold owners jointly and severally responsible for actions of companies, in tractor-trailer driver's action against companies and owners for negligence and gross negligence; evidence showed that owners controlled all decisions concerning companies including income and capital flow and that owners used corporate funds for personal purposes to pay off their home loan.
Document Preview: TRANSPORTATION  Carriers. Trucking companies that disregarded federal regulations concerning amount of rest driver was required to receive between trips were grossly negligent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Durham v. Accardi
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to establish that corporation's representatives were corporation's alter ego, and thus employee could not pierce corporate veil in action for negligence, negligence per se, and gross negligence, although representative testified that corporation did not do formal stuff, representative generally established her unfamiliarity with basic concepts of corporate structure and law, and corporation did not carry worker's compensation or other insurance that would have covered employee's injuries; lack of corporate formalities was not consideration when determining alter ego, and evidence that corporation was undercapitalized rather than simply small family business under financial stress after founder suffered heart attack was not enough to establish alter ego. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(a)(3).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was insufficient that corporation's representatives were corporation's alter ego and thus employee could not pierce corporate veil.

Title: Fuentes v. Zaragoza
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to establish that business entities and associated individuals named as co-respondents in wife's original divorce petition before being subsequently nonsuited were alter egos of the husband and therefore part of the community estate, although husband refused to participate in discovery process, where 120 out of the 133 named entities were located outside of the United States and no evidence was provided regarding their form and legal structure, all evidence that was presented about the remaining entities consisted of generalizations rather than specific references to any entity or aspect thereof, and wife did not move to compel husband or the entities themselves to produce any corporate records.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW  Community Property. Trial court's judgments against third party co-respondents nonsuited before trial in divorce case violated their due process rights.

Title: Richard Nugent and CAO, Inc. v. Estate of Ellickson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence did not justify imposition of liability on vendor's attorney-in-fact's corporation, as alter ego of attorney-in-fact, on claim by vendor's estate for breach of fiduciary duty arising out of attorney-in-fact's failure to notify estate of pending foreclosure sale of vendor's home, due to purchaser's default on payments to vendor in accordance with terms of sale negotiated by attorney-in-fact on vendor's behalf; evidence that attorney-in-fact was director, president, and sole owner of corporation, without more, did not show that corporation operated as mere tool or business conduit of attorney-in-fact, and holding attorney-in-fact solely liable would not result in injustice.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Limitations. Four-year limitations period governing claims for breach of fiduciary duty arising out of negotiations of terms of sale began to run on date of closing.

Title: 21st Century Financial Services, LLC v. Manchester Financial Bank
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: That a website presents affiliated entities as a single business carries no weight in proving alter ego liability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Partnerships. General partner of limited partnership that funded bank's pre-formation expenses was not alter ego of bank.

Title: In re Rouette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut, New Haven Division.
Headnote: Evidence that individual Chapter 7 debtors' wholly-owned corporation, while dominated by debtors and routinely used as piggy bank to pay debtors' personal expenses, had nonetheless observed corporate formalities by filing corporate tax returns, maintaining separate financial records, and filing required corporate documents with the Connecticut Secretary of State, was sufficient to show that it was corporation in more than just name only, and prevented corporate creditor from piercing corporate veil, on identity theory, in order to hold debtors' estate personally liable on corporate debt.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Corporate creditor had no claim against individual debtor-shareholders' Chapter 7 estate.

Title: Tutor Perini Corporation v. Banc of America Securities LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Evidence that four individuals involved in analyzing maximum rate waivers and liquidity risks in the auction rate securities (ARS) market were either employed by financial institution or jointly employed by financial institution and broker-dealer, who were both wholly-owned subsidiaries of the same parent corporation, failed to demonstrate that financial institution was liable for any misconduct committed by broker-dealer as a controlling person, in the absence of any evidence that financial institution actually exercised control over broker-dealer.

Title: Winderting Investments, LLC v. Furnell
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Second District.
Headnote: Unproven allegations containing terms such as "alter ego" and "fraud" are not a substitute for evidence necessary hold stockholders personally liable for corporate debts, namely that the corporation is in actuality the alter ego of the stockholders.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Discovery. Judgment creditors failed to show that nonparty was alter ego of judgment creditor and, thus, were not entitled to financial discovery from nonparty.

Title: Wells Fargo Bank, N.A. v. Weinberg
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Trial court's finding that lender did not know about the facts supporting attorney's alter ego liability for loan to law corporation until lender conducted the judgment debtor examination, in granting equitable amendment of judgment to add attorney as an additional judgment debtor under the statute authorizing courts to adopt any suitable process or mode of proceeding, was supported by substantial evidence, including evidence that attorney disbursed all the corporate assets to family members and himself, and that after dissolving the law corporation the attorney continued doing business as a sole proprietor under the same name, using the same offices, employees, equipment, website, and phone number. Title: Wells Fargo Bank, N.A. v. Weinberg
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Trial court's finding that attorney was alter ego for his law corporation, in granting equitable amendment of judgment to add attorney as an additional judgment debtor under the statute authorizing courts to adopt any suitable process or mode of proceeding, was supported by substantial evidence, including evidence that attorney disbursed all the corporate assets to family members and himself, and that after dissolving the law corporation the attorney continued doing business as a sole proprietor under the same name, using the same offices, employees, equipment, website, and phone number. Cal. Civ. Proc. Code § 187.
