Title: Rutherford Holdings, LLC v. Plaza Del Rey
Court: Court of Appeal, Sixth District, California.
Headnote: Failed mobile home park purchaser's pleading sufficiently alleged that corporate vendor and its vice-president were alter egos, as required to avoid a demurrer; purchaser alleged that vice-president dominated and controlled vendor, that a unity of interest and ownership existed between vice-president and vendor, that vendor was a mere shell and conduit for vice-president's affairs, that vendor was inadequately capitalized and failed to abide by the formalities of corporate existence, that vice-president used vendor's assets as her own, and that recognizing the separate existence of vendor would promote injustice.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Vendor and Purchaser. Vendor's failure to transfer deed potentially constituted a total failure of consideration which supported claim for money had and received.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Lego A/S v. Best-Lock Const. Toys, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, toy manufacturer failed to provide a specific averment of facts required to establish a prima facie case that competitor was alter ego of its chief executive officer (CEO) for purposes of piercing the corporate veil in order to obtain personal jurisdiction over the CEO for his allegedly defamatory statements regarding manufacturer; CEO's statements, and use of the word "I" when supporting competitor's motion for injunction did not indicate that he owned most of competitor's stock or had exclusive domination over it, and one incident where CEO was the only individual able to locate certain documents requested in discovery was insufficient to establish competitor as alter ego of CEO. C.G.S.A. § 52–59b.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Toy manufacturer was not the alter ego of its chief executive officer (CEO) for purposes of piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Endsley Elec., Inc. v. Altech, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Individual corporate officers were not individually liable, through implied finding of alter ego or some other abuse of the corporate structure, for subcontractor's breach of contract with general contractor, where there was less than a scintilla of evidence in support of such a finding.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subcontractor was not undercapitalized as would support the piercing of the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Flores v. Bodden
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, evidence exclusive of objected-to deposition was sufficient to support finding that corporate owner-president was "alter ego" of corporation and hence liable for default judgment against corporation on behalf of seaman employed by corporation and injured on-the-job on shrimp trawler owned by corporation; owner-president used corporation to unfairly and inequitably shield himself from risks he knew would arise in running undercapitalized shrimping business, owner-president admitted he made all major business decisions for corporation, corporate funds were commingled with other income sources, and corporate documentation was often incorrect.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported finding owner-president to be alter ego of corporation and liable for default judgment for seaman injured on shrimping trawler.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Sean Wood, L.L.C. v. Hegarty Group, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to show that agent of seller of industrial equipment was actually seller's owner and used seller as his alter ego, and thus agent could be personally liable, under doctrine of piercing the corporate veil, for seller's failure to pay equipment transporter for delivery of equipment to buyer; even though agent's wife was president of seller and owned seller's stock, agent testified that he had used his personal funds to purchase the equipment for re-sale, agent referred to seller and himself interchangeably in correspondence with transporter, and agent testified that he funded seller and admitted to generating income for seller that benefited his wife.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Agent of seller of industrial equipment could be personally liable for failure to pay transporter for delivering equipment to buyer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Ruffin v. New Destination, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, a party seeking to disregard the corporate entity and hold shareholders personally liable for corporation's obligations must prove by affirmative evidence that there is unity of ownership and interest and use of the corporate form to perpetuate fraud or wrong.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Contracts. Under District of Columbia law, company that provided counseling services breached its contracts with social worker and counselor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Genssler v. Harris County
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence did not support holding director of individually liable as the "alter ego" of businesses operating wastewater facilities that discharged hazardous wastewater pollution into county waters, even though trial court found that director had taken $10,000,000 per year from businesses, former and current employees testified he was "in charge," had decision making authority, and could control businesses' employees; no evidence showed businesses' profits were diverted for director's individual use, that there was failure to keep director's assets separate, that he individually owned any interest in businesses, or that he personally paid businesses' debts, and his status as officer or director was insufficient standing alone to support alter ego theory.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Officers and Directors. Evidence did not support holding director of individually liable as the alter ego of businesses.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Penhollow Custom Homes, LLC v. Kim
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: Evidence was not legally sufficient to support finding that owner of home building corporation was corporation's alter ego and thus to pierce corporate veil in homeowner's contract action against owner and corporation arising out of alleged defects in home, notwithstanding that owner was sole employee of corporation and that owner took owner's draw from corporate profits rather than receiving salary, where nothing indicated that corporation was organized as mere business conduit of owner, that corporate property was not kept separate from owner's personal property, or that corporation had been used for owner's personal purposes. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was not legally sufficient to find that owner of home building corporation was alter ego of corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Renee Unlimited, Inc. v. City of Atlanta
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support jury finding that alter ego relationship existed among owner and corporate entity, and that federal housing loan issued to corporate entity by city was commingled and confused, and that to adhere to the doctrine of corporate entity would have promoted injustice or protected fraud, where owner, on behalf of corporate entity, signed loan agreements, funds were disbursed to owner personally, and owner used the money for purposes other than improving property.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Limitations. Evidence was sufficient to support finding unjust enrichment claim had not accrued more than four years before city brought claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Daniels v. CDB Bell, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to establish, in action by seller of pizza business's assets against corporate buyer, that owners of buyer corporation exercised control over the corporation in such a way as to defraud or harm the seller, as a required element of instrumentality theory of piercing the corporate veil so as to hold owners individually liable to seller, for default judgment against their corporation on the contract of sale; there was no evidence owners exercised control over business in such a way as to harm sellers, or of any participation by owners or exercise of control over corporation and its president, who stole from corporation and resold the pizza assets which were seller's security for buyer's payment of the purchase price.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Whether to pierce the corporate veil is an equitable question to be decided by the trial court and not the jury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Anthony v. Gator Cochran Const., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Evidence warranted piercing of corporate veil of defendant entities related to individual defendant, as basis for holding defendant entities jointly and severally liable with individual defendant, in plaintiff's action on account and for fraud, alleging defendants' failure to pay for construction services provided by plaintiff; plaintiff's accountant testified that individual defendant personally, and related entities separately, "entwined" their finances and dealings with plaintiff, e.g., a related entity would ask plaintiff to do work that would be paid for by another related entity and invoices sent to one related entity were paid by another without any complaints about billing the wrong entity, accountant also testified that when individual defendant was asked why the invoices were not paid he explained, "Because I pay myself. Maybe I didn't want to pay at that time. Maybe I had to put it on some another [sic] company. Maybe I needed it somewhere else. I mean why do I have to take it out of this pocket and put it in that pocket?".
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Morreale v. Morreale
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence of closely held corporation's tax return, showing transfer of $1.7 million from the company to sole shareholder's personal account, supported finding that shareholder did not perform business affairs on a corporate footing, and, thus, was personally liable for alleged breach of deferred compensation agreement, in suit brought against corporation, and shareholder, by former chief executive officer (CEO). LSA-R.S. 12:93(B).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported finding that sole shareholder was personally liable damages caused by breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Roberts v. Shaw Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Richmond Division.
Headnote: The evidence was insufficient to pierce the corporate veil and hold a parent corporation liable to a former employee of its subsidiary for the alleged harassment of its subsidiary's employees. The former employee brought charges of employment discrimination after facing sexual harassment and retaliation for reporting such harassment at work. Although the parent corporation paid the former employee's paychecks, there was no evidence that the parent corporation exercised any control over the operation of its subsidiary corporation. Moreover, there was no evidence that the parent and subsidiary operated as a single entity since there was no evidence that the parent hired or fired any of the subsidiary's employees or routinely shifted employees between the two entities. 42 U.S.C. § 2000e.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. There was insufficient evidence of control for a parent corporation to be held liable for the alleged harassment of its subsidiary's employees.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Dick's Last Resort of West End, Inc. v. Market/Ross, Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Evidence was legally and factually sufficient to support jury's findings of alter ego, sham to perpetrate a fraud, and evasion of existing legal obligation in landlord's suit against former tenant, where former tenant and its affiliated corporations planned to use the corporations to ensure the landlord could not recover any assets in the event former tenant decided to vacate before the end of the lease term, concealed the plan from landlord while committing to a ten-year lease term, and evaded the contractual obligations to pay rent for the full term of the lease and to make payment under the guaranty. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Contractual disclaimer of extracontractual representations did not preclude landlord's proof of actual fraud for purposes of piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: In re Barnhill's Buffet, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Tennessee.
Headnote: Under Mississippi law, contractor that had performed construction repair work for corporation failed to establish that management company was corporation's alter ego; management company offered affidavit stating that it had never managed, owned, operated, or controlled corporation or any of corporation's restaurants, contractor's opposing affidavit, which indicated that contractor's counsel had found certain documents which contradicted management company's affidavit, was based on unsworn documents and was not sufficient to rebut the allegations of management company's affidavit, and even if counsel's affidavit were given any weight, it did not deny that all 29 invoices submitted by contractor for payment were submitted to and paid by corporation, not management company.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Any equitable lien against debtor's leasehold interests terminated upon debtor's bankruptcy filing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: N.L.R.B. v. Bolivar-Tees, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Determination of National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) that controlling shareholder and four corporations, which operated as single employer, failed to maintain separate identities, in ordering corporate veil pierced to allow enforcement of backpay order originally entered against defunct corporation against controlling shareholder, was supported by substantial evidence, including shareholder's control and ownership of all four corporations, his failure to operate offending corporation as a separate entity, failure to maintain adequate corporate records, failure to maintain an arm's-length relationship, failure to maintain corporate legal formalities, failure to avoid the commingling of funds, and failure to avoid the disposal of offending corporation's assets without fair consideration. National Labor Relations Act, § 1 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 151 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Unfair Labor Practices. Corporate veil could be pierced to enforce back pay order against controlling shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Rolls-Royce Corp. v. Heros, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Aircraft engine manufacturer failed to demonstrate that officer of parts sellers was corporate alter ego of sellers, for purposes of establishing officer's alter ego liability under Texas law; manufacturer's complaint and jurisdictional evidence were directed at blurring distinction between two sellers, not officer and sellers.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Judgment. Res judicata was inapplicable to aircraft engine manufacturer's RICO claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Scarff Bros., Inc. v. Bischer Farms, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Northern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, various individuals and companies were alter egos of feedlot corporation, and thus were liable to cattle broker for disappearance of cattle in breach of contract between corporation and broker, given extensive intercompany transactions, testimony by corporation's owner that separate treatment of entities was respected for accounting purposes but blurred for business purposes, and another owner's testimony indicating that he did not differentiate entity providing services to broker as separate from himself, his wife, his daughter, and his son-in-law.
Document Preview: AGRICULTURE - Animals. Course of dealing created implied contract between cattle broker and feedlot owners.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Schuster v. Seipel
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil to hold members of corporation's board of directors individually liable to attorney for fees he claimed he was owed in breach of contract action attorney filed against corporation and members was not justified, as there was insufficient evidence that members were the alter egos, instrumentalities, or agents of corporation, or that the corporate entity was used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience, justify a wrong, or perpetuate a fraud.
Document Preview: Background: Attorney filed breach of contract action against corporation that assisted people with their property tax issues before Department of Revenue and Tax Appeal Board, and two members of corporation's board of directors, alleging that defendants owed him approximately $41,000 for legal services he provided to corporation pursuant to two contracts. Members of board of directors filed motion for partial summary judgment. The District Court, Cascade County, Kenneth R. Neill, J., granted motion and dismissed members from suit. Attorney appealed. Holding: The Supreme Court, John Warner, J., held that piercing of corporate veil to hold members of corporation's board of directors individually liable was not justified. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Fletcher-Harlee Corp. v. Szymanski
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Evidence did not support conclusion that sole shareholder of concrete company substantially intermingled his corporate and personal affairs, which was factor considered in determining whether piercing company's corporate veil to hold shareholder liable for judgment general contractor had obtained against company was justified; rather, record suggested that there might have been some intermingling of funds between and among shareholders various corporations, and that shareholder stored his corporate and personal records together.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil to hold sole shareholder of company personally liable for judgment against company was justified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Sparks v. Booth
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Evidence was legally sufficient to support implied finding that operator was home building corporation's alter ego and thus to pierce the corporate veil in lot owners' action against home building defendants arising out of defects in home; operator testified he was the president, secretary, sole shareholder, and sole director of corporation, and operator stated that corporation had no assets because it was a subchapter S corporation so all benefits and detriments flowed to him and he personally rented building housing corporation's offices to the corporation. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Expert's testimony was legally sufficient to support award of damages for defects in home.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Bollore S.A. v. Import Warehouse, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence that judgment debtor had managerial control of gas station owned by his mother was insufficient under Texas law to support finding that gas station was alter ego of debtor; while debtor performed managerial duties at gas station and held a position on gas station's board of directors, the debtor did not own stock in the gas station and debtor's mother was sole shareholder of gas station.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Texas turnover statute could not be used to find that a store owned by judgment debtor's mother was debtor's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: East Market Street Square, Inc. v. Tycorp Pizza IV, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that corporate tenant had no business operation of any kind, as factor supporting piercing of corporate veil under instrumentality rule, in action by commercial landlord for breach of lease and damage to leased premises; sole shareholder testified that corporation "never had any operations" and was formed simply to hold the lease for the proposed franchised restaurant, which never opened.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil of commercial tenant was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Fontana v. TLD Builders, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: Trial court's finding in regards to the unity of interest and ownership prong of the piercing-the-corporate-veil-test that construction company did not follow corporate formalities was not against the manifest weight of the evidence, where there were no corporate resolutions authorizing notes to be paid to president and shareholder to satisfy the loans they purportedly made to the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of the corporate veil of construction company to hold president liable was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Fontana v. TLD Builders, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: Trial court's finding in regards to the unity of interest and ownership prong of the piercing-the-corporate-veil-test that construction company failed to keep and maintain corporate records was not against the manifest weight of the evidence, where there were no records of the amounts borrowed by company to purchase properties and build homes, and president admitted he never had a written contract with a subcontractor, never took bids from subcontractors, never issued written change orders, did not keep written work schedules for projects, and kept no financial records for any payments that company made except for draw schedules filed with title companies.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of the corporate veil of construction company to hold president liable was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Taylor Steel, Inc. v. Keeton
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Shareholder's statement at trial, in response to question from plaintiff's counsel, that she was a corporation, could not be used to support finding that shareholder claimed her personal identity was synonymous with her corporation, for purpose of piercing the corporate veil, in an action upon an account, under Ohio law, where shareholder was pointing out to the attorney that he had misspoken in asking her a question about the last time shareholder had spoken with her corporation, when he actually meant to refer to plaintiff.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil to make sole shareholder liable in action on account was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Chao v. Occupational Safety and Health Review Com'n
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Substantial evidence supported factual findings of Occupational Safety and Health Review Commission (OSHRC) that, under totality of circumstances, corporate respondents in Occupational Safety and Health (OSH) Act proceeding were not "alter egos" of individual respondent, the proprietor of worksite where workers were exposed to asbestos in course of building renovation, as would support "reverse corporate veil piercing" to hold corporations liable for debts of proprietor, their controlling shareholder; although corporation's truck was parked once at worksite and proprietor engaged in corporate borrowing between entities, corporations did not engage in asbestos removal activities at issue and were not employers of workers at site, and they maintained entirely separate corporate identities, tax identities, bank accounts, and legitimate business operations. Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, § 11(a), 29 U.S.C.A. § 660(a).
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Occupational Safety. Language of asbestos respirator standard unambiguously precludes per-employee, versus per instance, employer citations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: D. Klein & Son, Inc. v. Good Decision, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence in a breach of contract suit supported piercing the corporate veil to impose common liability on a manufacturer and distributor of luggage-related goods as alter egos of one another; the common owners of both corporations exercised complete domination over the businesses and used them interchangeably with no regard for their separate corporate identities, and the owners used their domination of both corporations to obfuscate their separate identities in dealing with a buyer both at the time the contractual relationship commenced and throughout their course of dealings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported piercing the corporate veil to impose common liability on manufacturer and distributor as alter egos.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Cementos de Chihuahua, S.A. de C.V. v. Intermodal Sales Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: Evidence was legally insufficient to establish that sister corporation of manufacturing corporation was liable to shipping corporation for debts owed by import services corporation; there was a lack of privity between the parties, shipping corporation had no contact with sister corporation until import services corporation defaulted on its obligations, sister corporation paid all of its debts and obligations owed, there was no evidence that sister corporation functioned as the "alter ego" of manufacturing corporation, and there was no evidence that a corporate fiction was maintained to evade legal obligations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Evidence was legally insufficient to establish that sister corporation was liable to shipping corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Lisanti v. Dixon
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to show that owner of corporation was its alter ego, making him liable for corporation's actions; evidence indicated that owner controlled corporation and exclusively made all decisions regarding its business, and micromanaged the corporation according to his own personal wishes, corporation lacked adequate capitalization and was not profitable, and its business was constantly intermingled with the business of owner's other companies.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Wrongful Discharge. Employee showed she was fired for refusing to commit insurance fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Signal Peak Enterprises of Texas, Inc. v. Bettina Investments, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support finding that game room tenant was controlling shareholder's alter ego, so as to make shareholder liable for tenant's conduct; there was evidence shareholder owned 70% of tenant's stock and his son owned remaining 30%, shareholder had detailed knowledge of tenant's daily deposits into its bank account relating to phone cards and knew which of tenant's bank accounts were used for expenses, shareholder conceded he "ran things" at tenant, shareholder testified in deposition that money collected in game rooms was "my money" and belonged him "personally for them to operate out of."
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Tenant committed fraud by understating revenue produced by game rooms.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Advanced Telephone Systems, Inc. v. Com-Net Professional Mobile Radio, LLC
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support trial court's refusal to pierce corporate veil of limited liability company (LLC) under alter ego theory, in breach of contract action triggered by LLC's inability to fulfill its contractual obligations after it failed to reach predicate agreement with third party; although evidence established lack of formalities in operating LLC, plaintiff knew that it was dealing with LLC, that LLC's liability was very limited, that LLC would have assets and adequate financing provided predicate agreement with third party was reached, and plaintiff demanded no guarantees for LLC's obligation in event agreement with third party was not reached.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. There is no right to jury trial for alter-ego claim seeking piercing of corporate veil of LLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Sanderson Farms, Inc. v. Gasbarro
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support trial court's finding that family exercised complete control over corporations so that corporations were no more than the alter ego of family in creditor's action seeking to pierce corporate veil, where family disregarded corporate formalities in making various loans, family diverted corporate funds for personal use, and family failed to keep various corporations separate in terms of assets, liabilities, products, equipment, supplies, personnel, and customers.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Creditor was entitled to pierce the corporate veil of family owned company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Sanderson Farms, Inc. v. Gasbarro
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support trial court's finding that father exercised significant control over family owned corporation so that corporation was considered an alter ego in creditor's action seeking to pierce the corporate veil, even though son's were the sole shareholders of the corporation, where father directed sons to make certain loans from corporate funds and took money and assets from corporation and funneled them through his own corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Creditor was entitled to pierce the corporate veil of family owned company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: DCA Advertising, Inc. v. The Fox Group, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Advertising company did not present evidence that defendant corporation's promises induced company to continue providing services to second defendant entity, so defendant corporation was not liable, although fact issues existed as to whether defendant corporation dominated second entity with contract with advertising company.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Novation elements of valid new contract and extinguishment of old one were not established.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Stypula v. Chandler
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh District, Geauga County.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that sole shareholder exercised complete control over corporation, satisfying alter ego prong of test authorizing piercing of corporate veil; shareholder set the salaries and benefits for employees, shareholder testified that he chose to close corporation and fire all of its employees, and shareholder used corporation as a means to channel large sums of money to shareholder as bonuses from other, non-related corporations, so as to save taxes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Sole shareholder used control over corporation to deprive creditor of ability to enforce judgment, piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: N.L.R.B. v. Evans
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Substantial evidence supported National Labor Relations Board's conclusion that partnership was corporation's alter ego, for purposes of NLRA, where partnership was started with interest-free loan from corporation, partnership frequently used corporation's telephone and equipment at no cost, both were based from same location for substantial portion of period at issue, both worked on many of same projects for same employers, there was significant intermingling of assets and little respect for formalities, and corporation's principal directly assisted in management and supervision of partnership in various capacities. National Labor Relations Act, § 8, 29 U.S.C.A. § 158.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Unfair Labor Practices. Partnership was corporation's alter ego for purposes of NLRA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Plastipak Packaging, Inc. v. DePasquale
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, evidence supported finding that soft drink bottler's corporate veil should be pierced to impose alter-ego liability on its sole shareholder for breach of contract; plaintiff manufacturer of plastic bottles produced significant evidence of the bottler's failure to observe corporate formalities and maintain corporate records.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported finding that corporate veil should be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Bridas S.A.P.I.C. v. Government of Turkmenistan
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: District court erred in determining that the government of Turkmenistan was not the alter ego of oil company that was wholly owned by the government, and therefore, that oil company lacked authority to bind government to joint venture agreement to conduct hydrocarbon operations in Turkmenistan, where Court premised its conclusion solely upon the existence of corporate formalities and an absence of comingling of funds and directors; Court failed to consider the totality of circumstances in which the oil company functioned.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Non-signatory Turkmenistan government could not be compelled to arbitrate a contract claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Estate of Lisle v. C.I.R.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Finding that corporation partly owned by taxpayer's family members was taxpayer's alter ego, and thus that corporation's income was attributable to taxpayer, was not supported by clear and convincing evidence needed to uphold fraud penalty; although taxpayer was corporation's sole manager, there was only minimal evidence that he used its assets for personal purposes. 26 U.S.C.A. § 7454(a); Tax Court Rule 142(b), 26 U.S.C.A. foll. § 7453.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Income. Income was attributed to taxpayer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Sellers v. Home Americair of California
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Check written for initial franchise fees before corporate franchisee was formed was not evidence supporting alter ego liability; fact that check made no reference on its face as to its purpose for paying fees in regard to corporation yet to be formed was irrelevant, given that evidence was otherwise uncontradicted that it was used for franchise fees of a then nonexistent corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Franchises. Franchisor could not establish any grounds for alter ego liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Schlueter v. Carey
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: Evidence was legally sufficient to support finding that sole shareholder was corporation's "alter ego" and could be held liable for injuries customer suffered when she fell in parking lot in front of property leased by corporation; shareholder signed lease to premises on behalf of corporation and while testifying at trial often referred to himself and corporation interchangeably.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholder was liable as corporation's alter ego for injury caused to customer by corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Scott Bros. v. Warren
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to pierce the corporate veil and hold owner of corporation personally liable for breach of contract damages; owner's corporations loaned him money even though they were insolvent, there was no evidence that owner ever repaid the corporations for the loans, owner ran his three corporations as one unit using the same management, bookkeeping and trade names for all three, and owner sold the assets of the three corporations for a lump sum figure without allocating the money between the entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was sufficient to pierce the corporate veil and hold owner personally liable for damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Hoffman v. Harmony Pictures, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that there was an alter ego relationship between employer and its parent company that justified piercing of employer's corporate veil in employee's action for breach of contract; employer and parent company failed to respect corporate formalities, majority of boards of directors overlapped, and employee received a letter on parent company's stationery regarding changes in his vacation pay.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of employer's corporate veil was justified in employee's action for breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Chang v. Sumec Hardware & Tools Co., Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Evidence failed to establish a unity of interest and ownership between judgment debtors and their subsidiaries, and thus judgment creditors could not prevail on their cause of action against subsidiaries for alter ego liability; each subsidiary had a separate board of directors and managers, separate bank accounts, and separate offices.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Creditors could not prevail on cause of action against subsidiaries of debtors for alter ego liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Atlantic Veneer Corp. v. Robbins
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Fourth District, Pike County.
Headnote: Evidence that debtors were sole shareholders, directors and officers of closely held corporation, that corporation participated in fraudulent transfers, that creditor had been unable to collect judgment from debtors due in part to their transfer of assets to corporation, constituted some competent, credible evidence supporting decision to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Some competent, credible evidence supported decision to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: First Bank & Trust v. Rothman
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 8.
Headnote: Substantial evidence supported determination that lawyer was the alter ego of corporation incorporated by him and was liable for corporation's loan; the lawyer prepared the articles of incorporation, listed himself as agent, incorporator, and initial director, and paid bills for the property, income was deposited in lawyer's accounts, and no stock certificates were issued.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence established lawyer's status as alter ego of borrower incorporated by him.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Litchfield Asset Management Corp. v. Howell
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support finding that judgment debtor's transfer of her personal funds to companies which she controlled proximately caused a loss for judgment creditor, and thus satisfy instrumentality rule for purposes of piercing the corporate veil; there was evidence that debtor, with knowledge that creditor was pursuing a claim against her that she chose not to defend, transferred cash value of her life insurance policies from herself to company, and that the transfer prevented creditor from securing collection of the judgment it eventually obtained against debtor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Companies were liable for personal debt through reverse piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: WorldCom, Inc. v. Arya Intern. Communications Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Jury's decision to pierce corporate veil and hold shareholder responsible for damages resulting from communications corporation's breach of settlement agreement with telecommunications services provider was against the weight of the evidence; while shareholder admittedly dominated corporation, there was no evidence of fraud or that corporation had been used as his alter ego, as required to disregard corporate entity, in that, shareholder did not use any personal promises or funds to induce provider to continue services.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Telecommunications. Communications corporation's shareholder was not personally liable for damages owed to provider.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Fairfield Development, Inc. v. Georgetown Woods Sr. Apartments Ltd. Partnership
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Evidence that corporation was formed by family for specific purpose of entering into joint venture but relied upon the experience and financial backing of family, that corporation had never been operated as a separate entity, that the father was the principal figure in corporation, that corporation was only able to enter into joint venture based on parents' personal guarantees, that corporation started and continued to operate with minimal financial resources, and that when joint venture soured, family funneled business to their other companies, was sufficient to establish that corporation was merely the alter ego of family members and misuse of corporate form promoted injustice, in action to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Construction corporation was alter ego of family.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Nat Katz & Associates, Ltd. v. Barber
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Construction company president's uncontradicted testimony that he repaid funds company had advanced to him during renovation of his condominium and that company owed him a significant debt could be used to refute creditor's assertion that president was alter ego of company and should be held personally liable for its debts, even without corroborative documentary proof.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. President was not liable for corporation's debts where he and corporation maintained separate bank accounts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Nat Katz & Associates, Ltd. v. Barber
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Since president of construction company simply denied creditor's allegations that he served as alter ego of company and thus should be held personally liable for company's debt, and did not raise an affirmative defense, creditor carried the burden of proving those allegations, and president was not required to disprove them.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. President was not liable for corporation's debts where he and corporation maintained separate bank accounts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Bomil, Inc. v. Hoffelder
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to support a finding that corporate president was corporation's alter ego, so as to allow judgment creditor to pierce the corporate veil to add president as defendant to collect $69,176.66 judgment debt, where only evidence creditor corporation offered was president's control of the litigation between the two corporations; there was no evidence that the president "raided" debtor corporation to make the funds owed unreachable, as speculated, nor was there any evidence of treatment by the president of a corporate asset as his own, failure to maintain proper corporate records, inadequate capitalization, or any act or condition showing that one entity was the alter ego of another.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate president was not corporation's alter ego for purposes of collecting judgment debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Folger v. Cottle
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Although owners of corporation engaged in the business of manufacturing parachute containers were friends and experienced skydivers who had developed the corporation's product, this was insufficient to establish unity of interest between the corporation and its owners, as required for alter ego liability on strict liability claim brought by wife of professional skydiver who was killed when his parachute malfunctioned.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Undercapitalization of corporation was insufficient, by itself, to invoke alter ego liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Folger v. Cottle
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Fact that shareholder had made numerous loans to corporation engaged in the business of manufacturing parachute containers was insufficient to support alter ego liability on strict liability claim brought by wife of professional skydiver who was killed when his parachute malfunctioned, absent evidence that shareholder was motivated by an intent to defraud when he made those loans.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Undercapitalization of corporation was insufficient, by itself, to invoke alter ego liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Ishak v. Lanier Contractor's Supply Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Sufficient evidence supported finding that vice president of construction company disregarded corporate entity and made corporation mere instrumentality for transacting own affairs, so as to support piercing corporate veil to hold vice president personally liable for corporation's failure to pay for building supplies, where testimony of former officer and employee of corporation and documentary evidence showed that during pendency of litigation vice president conveyed one of corporation's primary assets to himself without payment of adequate consideration to corporation and appropriated corporate funds to own personal use, and other evidence indicated that corporate assets were siphoned into pockets of both vice president and president, leaving corporation without means to pay debts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Sufficient evidence supported piercing of corporate veil in suit for nonpayment of building supplies.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Keaton v. Kingsburg Chamber of Commerce
Court: Court of Appeal, Fifth District, California.
Headnote: Individual board members were not liable on former employee's claims of breach of oral contract, promissory estoppel, account stated, and open book account related to his termination of employment, where individuals were not parties to employment contract, individuals were acting on behalf of employer, employee failed to show unity of interest in commingling funds, use of offices and employees, inadequate capitalization, disregard of corporate formalities, lack of segregation of corporate records, and resulting injustice to make a prima facie case that individuals were alter egos of employer
Document Preview: TORTS - Defamation. Individual directors on board were not liable to former employee for libel related to his termination.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Good v. Holstein
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Corporation was alter ego of sole owner, for purposes of sale of property on which corporation held second mortgage, even though corporation filed tax returns, where owner was, at all times, only officer and president, corporation was trucking company until 1993, when it sold rigs and trucking equipment to mortgagor in exchange for second mortgage, corporation's only asset was mortgage, and it was unclear whether corporation had any on-going business, corporation had no money, owner purchased first mortgage on property, corporation foreclosed on second mortgage, property was sold at sheriff's sale to owner's attorney and then transferred to sole owner and spouse, and to recognize corporate formality would promote injustice, as owner would be permitted to collect property through junior mortgage and maintain claim against surety on senior mortgage.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation was owner's alter ego for purposes of first and second mortgages owned by owner and corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Doe v. Unocal Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence that parent provides interest free loans without observing corporate formalities by documenting those loans with promissory notes supports finding that parent is subsidiary's alter ego.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Burmese plaintiffs did not show personal jurisdiction over French corporate defendant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: U.S. v. Boyce
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, corporate entities to which taxpayers had transferred their real property were alter egos of taxpayers; entities were created at the taxpayers' direction for holding and managing their property, and failure to pierce corporate veil would result in taxpayers' inequitable evasion of tax liability.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Income. Assessment of penalties and interest for unpaid taxes did not violate taxpayers' constitutional rights.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Longo Constr., Inc. v. ASAP Tech. Serv., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: Competent, credible evidence supported jury's decision to pierce corporate veil, and allow subcontractor hired to perform excavating work to recover amounts unpaid under contract in breach of contract action against principal of contracting corporation which had hired subcontractor; while principal was one of three shareholders, he acted as if corporation was his corporation, principal took $500,000 payment previously received by corporation and converted it to his personal use, and principal's decision to pay his wife rather than subcontractor, caused injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported jury's decision to pierce corporate veil and hold principal personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: LFC Marketing Group, Inc. v. Loomis
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Evidence, that individual debtor, despite not owning single share of corporation, held himself out as its president, CEO, and primary owner, acted as ultimate authority for all of corporation's dealings, and allowed corporation's bills to be paid by related entity owned by his wife, showed sufficient unity of ownership and interest to support determination that corporation was alter ego of individual.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter ego doctrine permitted reaching corporate assets to satisfy judgment against controlling individual.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Bracken v. Earl
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that trust manager was alter ego of trust, and thus was liable to investor for funds received from trust, where trustees violated fiduciary duty and gave manager unlimited and exclusive power to manage trust, manager was solely responsible for obtaining loans from investors and investing in proposed business, trustees were not involved with day-to-day operation or management of trust, defendant could not identify who trustees were, manager had little contact with trustees, and there were no records of meetings other than alleged meeting in which manager was appointed.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Trust manager, as alter ego of trust, was liable to investor for funds received by trust.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Medders v. Smith
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that corporation was not alter ego of its sole owner for purposes of housing construction project; owner, project developer, and bank's agent all testified that corporation played no part in the financing or the construction of the four houses in the project.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Contractor was estopped from denying coverage as a statutory employer to subcontractor's employee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: State v. Markowitz
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Record was insufficient to support treating employee as alter ego of corporation that operated gas station on property where petroleum discharge occurred, as was required to permit treating him as a party inseparable from corporation.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - Oil and Gas. Individual noncorporate defendants were not personally liable for cleanup costs of oil spill.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Simon v. Circle Associates, Inc.
Court: District of Columbia Court of Appeals.
Headnote: Evidence did not support entry of monetary judgment against corporation's principal based on alter-ego theory; plaintiffs never proved either unity of interest on part of principal and corporation, nor did they prove that considerations of justice and equity would justify piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Settlements. Settlement agreement was ambiguous regarding whether principal was included within term landlord.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: S.T. Hudson Engineers, Inc. v. Camden Hotel Development Associates
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that corporate president who executed contract on behalf of general partnership was corporation's alter ego and thus, trial court properly pierced "corporate shield" in breach of contract action against president, corporation, and partnership; corporation was controlling partner of partnership, which operated under no formal partnership agreement at any time, president was corporation's sole shareholder, officer, and employee, and some payments made under subject contract were tendered by personal checks drawn on president's personal account.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported decision to pierce corporate veil under alter ego doctrine.

Title: In re Marriage of Morris
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Wife was not entitled to $5,000 from husband as reimbursement for medical expenses that were owed to her by corporation solely owned by husband, absent any evidence to show that corporation was husband's alter ego or that husband's actions as sole owner were made to perpetrate a fraud or other injustice on wife.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Spousal Debts. Wife was not entitled to $5,000 from husband for expenses owed by corporation solely owned by husband.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Commodity Futures Trading Com'n v. Topworth Intern., Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Finding that corporation was alter ego of its two corporate shareholders and that funds wired by director of one of those shareholders could be treated as funds from corporation was supported by evidence of extreme undercapitalization and immediate transfers of corporation's funds out of its accounts.
Document Preview: Commodities Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) brought suit against related companies for violations of Commodities Exchange Act (CEA). The United States District Court for the Central District of California, A. Andrew Hauk, J., granted injunction and disgorgement, and ordered turnover of funds held in trust account of defense attorney. On appeal, the Court of Appeals, Boochever, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) evidence supported district court's decision to ignore corporate form and conclude that funds allegedly held by shareholders were actually corporation's; (2) individual investor who was not party before district court had standing to challenge method of apportionment; (3) CFTC had jurisdiction; and (4) district court was within its discretion in adopting receiver's distribution plan. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Hall v. Timmons
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Evidence that all funds for employer were forwarded from chairman's personal operating account, that chairman personally approved or denied funds for employer, that employer's only means of acquiring funds for operation or purchases was to request them from chairman under his line of credit, that chairman countermanded decisions made by employer's personnel, that employer's registered address was chairman's personal office, and that chairman had a lien on all of employer's assets, constituted some evidence in support of finding that employer was alter ego of chairman, in injured employee's negligence action against corporate employer and its chairman.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Incomplete instruction on alter ego probably caused rendition of improper judgment.

Title: Hall v. Timmons
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Evidence that employee worked directly for an employee of corporate employer's chairman and not for employer, that employer's registered address was chairman's personal office, that all funds for employer were forwarded from chairman's personal operating account, that only method employer had of acquiring funds was to request them from chairman under his line of credit, that chairman had a lien on all of employer's assets, and absence of evidence that employer's operations ever generated any profits constituted more than a scintilla of evidence to support jury's finding that a single business enterprise existed between employer and chairman, in employee's negligence action for injuries sustained at work.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Incomplete instruction on alter ego probably caused rendition of improper judgment.

Title: Rose Ocko Foundation, Inc. v. Lebovits
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Evidence that shareholder, who negotiated purchase of not-for-profit foundation's property on behalf of corporation completely dominated corporation, used corporation to further personal interests, and disregarded corporate formalities, supported conclusion that piercing corporate veil was required to avoid permitting shareholder, to whom corporation transferred property, to claim that he was not bound by determination nullifying sale of property to corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Non-profit Entities. Sale of nonprofit corporation's chief asset was subject to judicial scrutiny.

Title: Doe v. Unocal Corp.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Evidence that parent provides interest free loans without observing corporate formalities by documenting those loans with promissory notes supports finding that parent is subsidiary's alter ego.
Document Preview: Burmese citizens brought class action asserting various claims against United States oil corporation and French corporation. On French Corporation's motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction, the District Court, Paez, J., held that: (1) claimants effected proper service of process over French corporation; (2) claimants, who did not serve process pursuant to Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO), could not rely on corporation's national contacts under RICO to establish personal jurisdiction; (3) corporation's direct contacts with California were insufficient to warrant exercise of personal jurisdiction; and (4) contacts of corporation's subsidiaries could not be imputed to corporation to establish minimum contacts. Motion granted.

Title: Bellairs v. Mohrmann
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Second District.
Headnote: Under alter-ego theory of long arm jurisdiction, complaint need only allege facts sufficient to pierce corporate veil of resident corporation. West's F.S.A. § 48.193.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Seller adequately alleged alter-ego theory for asserting personal jurisdiction over buyer's out-of-state shareholders.
