Title: White v. Midwest Office Technology, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Former employee's evidence was insufficient to raise a serious question about the separate corporate identity of her employer, or to establish that the employer's owner or general manager used the employer's corporate status to perpetrate fraud, evade existing obligations, or circumvent the law, and thus, the corporate veil would not be pierced on an alter ego theory; evidence revealed a properly capitalized, substantial business enterprise with operations in several metropolitan areas.
Document Preview: Employee brought action against her employer, its owner, and its general manager, asserting claims of sexual harassment and retaliation in violation of the Kansas Act Against Discrimination (KAAD) and Title VII, and state common-law claims for tort of outrage, tort of retaliation for filing a workers' compensation claim and breach of implied employment contract. On defendants' motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Saffels, J., held that: (1) employee made sufficient showing of continuing course of conduct to avoid summary judgment as to incidents that allegedly occurred prior to Title VII's 300day limitations period; (2) manager's alleged conduct was not sufficiently severe or pervasive to objectively alter terms, conditions or privilege of employee's employment; (3) employee failed to establish a claim of constructive discharge; (4) employee failed to establish a claim of retaliatory discharge; (5) employee failed to establish that she was subjected to disparate...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Menetti v. Chavers
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: In considering "no evidence" or legal sufficiency point in alter ego claims, reviewing court considers only evidence favorable to decision of trier of fact, disregards all evidence and inferences to contrary, and will uphold finding if there is any evidence of probative force to support it, even though jury was instructed to consider all evidence surrounding corporate entity and its relationship with plaintiff.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was insufficient to prove actual fraud as required to pierce corporate veil and hold shareholders personally liable for corporation's faulty construction of addition to home.

Title: AL Tech Specialty Steel Corp. v. Allegheny Intern. Credit Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Without sufficient facts of record to warrant veil-piercing, such as facts of sufficient dominance of affairs of subsidiary by parent corporation, subsidiary and its parent had to be considered separate entities.
Document Preview: Environmental Claim. Evidence did not support bankruptcy court's determination of Chapter 11 debtor's equitable share of environmental cleanup costs.

Title: 381651 Alberta, Ltd. v. 279298 Alberta, Ltd.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Competent evidence supported trial court's findings that family trust corporation was alter ego of judgment debtor, that debtor had evaded personal liability by titling personal assets in name of family trust corporation, and that mortgages on debtor's condominiums to debtor's brother's company were fraudulent conveyances.
Document Preview: CIVIL PROCEDURE - Jury. No right to jury trial attached in action to have transfers set aside as fraudulent conveyances, since action was equitable in nature.

Title: In re Terrific Seafoods, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: There was no evidence of confused intermingling of activity between Chapter 7 debtor and its owners or substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, as would justify piercing corporate veil and holding owners personally liable for debtor's unsecured debts under Massachusetts law.
Document Preview: Preferences. Chapter 7 debtor's preference period transfers to secured creditor-bank were not preferential, despite debtor's insolvency and benefit to debtor's owners, who guarantied bank's loan.

Title: Gundle Lining Const. Corp. v. Adams County Asphalt, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Signature of owner of Pennsylvania contractor on master security agreement and on contractor's checks to Texas subcontractor were insufficient, under Texas law, to establish that contractor's owner was its alter ego, as would permit piercing corporate veil and attributing contacts of contractor, which was subject to jurisdiction, to owner.
Document Preview: Texas subcontractor brought suit against contractor's surety in state court, seeking to recover on payment bond.  Suit was removed to federal district court where surety filed third-party complaints against Pennsylvania contractor, affiliated corporation and owner of the two corporations, claiming that it was entitled to recover all amounts paid to plaintiff from third-party defendants as indemnitors.  Following settlement between subcontractor and surety, the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas, Lynn N. Hughes, J., granted summary judgment to surety, and third-party defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Robert M. Parker, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) district court had jurisdiction over contractor; (2) jurisdiction was lacking as to other third-party defendants; (3) district court properly denied contractor's motion to transfer venue; and (4) surety paid subcontractor's claim against payment bond in...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Northern Tankers (Cyprus) Ltd. v. Backstrom
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Evidence in prior decision involving corporate defendants, even if considered only for its evidentiary value and not for purposes of collateral estoppel, when taken together with other submissions in actions to hold individuals and corporations jointly and severally liable for arbitration award, was sufficient to establish probable cause that defendants were alter egos of corporation for purposes of application to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: Company brought action seeking to hold individuals and corporations jointly and severally liable for arbitration award and moved for prejudgment order to attach real property.  The District Court, Goettel, J., held that: (1) decision in an earlier case involving the same defendants, which squarely considered alleged alter ego status of particular property owning defendants was sufficient to establish alter ego status in current case; (2) there was probable cause that plaintiff had valid claim for breach of contract; and (3) where alter ego status was established and some defendants did not contest jurisdiction, jurisdiction was established over alter ego defendants who contested jurisdiction. Ordered accordingly.

Title: O'Brien-Kreitzberg & Associates v. K.P., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Judgment creditor failed to offer adequate proof to justify piercing corporate veil of judgment debtor to reach funds in possession of alleged successor or its principal; creditor failed to set forth evidence that corporation was a dummy for its individual stockholder who was in reality carrying on the business in his personal capacity for purely personal rather than corporate ends.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor was not entitled to pierce corporate veil to reach alleged successor of judgment debtor.

Title: Keys Jeep Eagle, Inc. v. Chrysler Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Under Florida law, automobile dealership and its owner had not established that creditor which provided floor plan financing to dealership was alter ego of dealership's franchisor, and, thus, corporate veil would not be pierced to hold franchisor liable for creditor's alleged wrongdoings, even though two employees of creditor stated that franchisor was pushing to consolidate dealerships, where there was no evidence supporting contention that franchisor directed creditor to commit alleged wrongful acts, and, even assuming that employees' statements were true and admissible, there was no showing how those statements established that creditor was franchisor's "mere instrumentality" or how creditor was device or sham that was designed to mislead creditors or that existed for fraudulent purposes.
Document Preview: Automobile dealership, its owner, and others brought action against automobile manufacturer and creditor that provided floor plan financing for dealership, alleging fraud, breach of fiduciary duty, violation of Automobile Dealer's Day in Court Act (ADDCA), and breach of contract.  Manufacturer and creditor filed motions for summary judgment.  The District Court, James Lawrence King, J., held that: (1) manufacturer could not be held liable for creditor's alleged wrongful acts under alter ego or agency theories; (2) Florida's economic loss doctrine precluded recovery against creditor under fraud and breach of fiduciary duty theories; (3) plaintiffs failed to establish that creditor breached contract; (4) plaintiffs did not establish that creditor was manufacturer's actual or apparent agent, and, thus, creditor could not be held liable under ADDCA, which provides cause of action against manufacturer for violation of duty of good faith. Motions...

Title: Parker v. Parker
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: Finding that corporations owned by husband were alter ego of husband, as basis for awarding wife damages from corporate assets in divorce action, was supported evidence.
Document Preview: Punitive Damages. Husband's electronic eavesdropping on attorney of wife warranted $1,000,000 punitive damage award.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Gorsich v. Double B Trading Co., Inc.
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. IV.
Headnote: In suit by farmers against agricultural warehouse facility and buyer of pinto beans and its owners for, inter alia, negligence, conversion, and theft, finding that buyer was alter ego of one of its owners was supported by evidence that, instead of hiring other owner as its own employee, first owner agreed to form buyer so that other owner would be able to stay in Colorado and not have to move to California where first owner was located, that first owner provided 90% of initial capital and owned 90% of the stock, that officers were the same with exception of second owner, that buyer's employees were covered by first owner's retirement plan, that first owner paid for pinto beans sold to buyer, processed insurance claim on behalf of buyer and received proceeds from sale of buyer and, when buyer closed, continued its business as first owner's business.
Document Preview: Agriculture. Farm Products Act created private right of action by farmers against dealers under circumstances of case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Bingham v. Goldberg. Marchesano. Kohlman. Inc.
Court: District of Columbia Court of Appeals.
Headnote: Corporate entity will be respected and its obligations will not be imposed on particular individual unless party seeking to disregard corporate entity had proved by affirmative evidence that there is unity of ownership and that considerations of equity and fairness justify piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: Company brought breach of contract action against corporation, which was general partner in limited partnership, and its president, who was limited partner, to recover amounts due under contract for advertising and marketing services.  The Superior Court, Harriett R. Taylor, William C. Gardner, and Stephen F. Eilperin, JJ., entered judgment against corporation and president, and they appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Wagner, J., held that: (1) partnership was not mere continuation of corporation and, thus, was not liable for corporation's debt under contract, and (2) there was no basis for piercing corporate veil to impose personal liability on president. Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded with instructions.

Title: Ted Harrison Oil Co., Inc. v. Dokka
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fourth District.
Headnote: Trial court's decision to pierce corporate veil and to hold shareholder personally liable for corporation's debt to creditor was supported by evidence of failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, nonfunctioning directors, and absence of corporate records, evidence that corporation was mere facade for operation of dominant shareholders, shareholder was personally receiving monetary benefits from corporation, including cash payments, at time when corporation was defaulting on its debt to creditor.
Document Preview: Piercing Corporate Veil. Trial court's judgment that shareholder was personally liable for corporation's debt was supported by evidence.

Title: First Downtown Development v. Cimochowski
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Lessor failed to show that physician who was sole shareholder, officer and director of professional medical corporation should be held individually liable for corporation's debts under alter ego doctrine; physician hired attorney to set up corporation as a corporate entity, corporation hired business manager to whom physician delegated tasks such as payment of bills, overseeing construction of office space and plans for moving, handling mail, etc., and there was no evidence that corporation disregarded corporate formalities in the transaction of its affairs.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LEASE - Breach. President of professional medical corporation was not individually liable to lessor for corporation's breach of premises lease.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Terren v. Butler
Court: Supreme Court of New Hampshire.
Headnote: Evidence supported trial court's finding that corporate declarant of condominium was mere alter ego of its sole shareholders and, thus, that shareholders could be held individually liable for misrepresentations made by declarant to purchasers of condominium units; sole shareholders never paid consideration for their shares and received significant compensation from declarant, shareholders sold land to declarant for significantly more than they had paid for it, declarant was to assume shareholders' existing mortgage, and shareholders received stock distributions and repayment of shareholder loans at time when declarant's sole asset was single unit in complex, valued at $100,000. RSA 356–B:65.
Document Preview: Condominium association and puchasers of individual unit brought action against condominium declarant and its shareholders for breach of warranty and misrepresentations.  The Superior Court, Belknap County, Dickson, J., entered judgment against the declarant and its sole shareholders.  Appeals were taken. The Supreme Court, Horton, J., held that: (1) the one-year life of warranties given by developers is not a statute of limitations, but rather, requires that the defect giving rise to the breach of warranty claim manifest itself within one year; (2) the evidence supported the trial court's decision to pierce the corporate veil and hold the shareholders liable for misrepresentations; and (3) the statute permitting an award of attorney fees to a purchaser in a rescission action did not apply. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Riggins v. Dixie Shoring Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence supported trial court's conclusion that corporation engaged in construction business was alter ego of its principal shareholder, and corporate veil could consequently be pierced to allow homeowners claiming negligent levelling of their house to reach principal shareholder's assets; no minutes of meeting were kept, corporation's cash and equipment were commingled with those of shareholder, and stock certificate was never issued.
Document Preview: Homeowners sued for damages arising from allegedly negligent levelling of house.  The Civil District Court, Parish of Orleans, Max N. Tobias, Jr., J., entered judgment for owners against individuals involved with corporation which had provided services.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeal, Becker, J., held that: (1) corporate veil was properly pierced to reach individual assets of major shareholder of corporation; (2) corporate veil could not be pierced to reach assets of person who was mere employee; and (3) homeowners were entitled to mental anguish damages. Affirmed in part; reversed in part. Armstrong, J., dissented and filed written reasons.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Cotazino v. Basil Development Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate vendor's vice-president and one-third shareholder could not be held personally liable to purchasers for corporation's breach of contract and/or warranty and negligence, where evidence did not establish that vice-president used corporation to transact his personal business or that there was sufficient fraud, illegality or wrongdoing to warrant disregard of corporate entity; evidence only showed that corporation never held meetings, operated from vice-president's home, shared legal fees with vice-president, failed to be identified on some contract documents, was managed exclusively by vice-president, and was used by vice-president to avoid personal liability, and that amount directly paid for purchase of land from corporation was deposited in joint bank account of vice-president and his wife.
Document Preview: Purchasers brought action against vendor contractor and its vice-president, seeking damages for breach of contract and/or warranty and negligence.  The Supreme Court, Albany County, Prior, J., entered judgment for purchasers pursuant to jury verdict, and defendants appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Yesawich, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support jury's $20,000 verdict for breach of contract and/or warranty; (2) evidence did not support jury's $17,000 negligence verdict; (3) personal liability should not have been imposed upon vice-president for corporate vendor's acts; and (4) interest would be computed on warranty and contract awards from date of closing, and on negligence award from date that suit was presumably commenced. Affirmed as modified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Trilogy Communications, Inc. v. Comm Scope Co.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. North Carolina, Statesville Division. .
Headnote: While some defendants owned stock in alleged infringer, there was no evidence that any of these defendants used alleged infringer as agent or instrumentality or that alleged infringer was somehow an alter ego of any of these defendants, as would permit piercing of corporate veil or finding of liability on part of any of these defendants.
Document Preview: Owner of patents for metallic sheath cables with foam cellular polyolefin insulation brought suit alleging patent infringement. Defendants counterclaimed, seeking declaratory judgment of invalidity, unenforceability and noninfringement. The District Court, Woodrow Wilson Jones, J., held that: (1) claims were, in large part, not infringed, and (2) patents were invalid. Judgment for defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Derbyshire v. United Builders Supplies, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Sufficient evidence supported finding that individual defendant employed corporations as his alter egos or business conduits, such that corporate veil could be pierced and individual and corporations could be held liable under lease upon which only one corporation was signatory; individual referred to his corporations in interchangeable manner, corporations appeared not as separate units but as amalgamated whole in their dealings with lessor, corporations functioned together to produce common product, and used same address and were housed in same building, i.e., leased premises.
Document Preview: Landlord sued corporations and individual corporate official to recover under a lease agreement and for damages to the leased premises.  The Muscogee State Court, Johnson, J., entered judgment on a jury verdict for landlord, and defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Beasley, J., held that: (1) the court erred in entering judgment without fulfilling its responsibility to decide the jurisdictional question raised by defendant's motion to dismiss; (2) it was proper to pierce the corporate veil to hold the individual defendant and the nonsignatory corporations liable under the lease; and (3) landlord could not recover attorney fees. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded with direction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Baatz v. Arrow Bar
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: Plaintiffs in dramshop action failed to offer evidence of how shareholders of incorporated tavern treated corporation as their alter ego, as was necessary to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: Husband and wife, who were seriously injured when vehicle operated by drunk driver struck and crushed them, brought action against tavern which served alcoholic beverages to drunk driver.  The Circuit Court, Second Judicial Circuit, Minnehaha County, Robert C. Heege, J., granted summary judgment to tavern.  Husband and wife appealed.  The Supreme Court, 426 N.W.2d 298, reversed and remanded.  On remand, individual shareholders of incorporated tavern were dismissed as defendants.  Husband and wife appealed.  The Supreme Court, Sabers, J., held that: (1) employee status alone was insufficient to sustain cause of action against individual defendants, and (2) plaintiffs failed to establish that corporate veil should be pierced. Affirmed. Henderson, J., dissented and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: In re McConnell
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Evidence failed to show that corporate purchaser of property was alter ego of vendor, where trial witnesses were unable to state from their own knowledge or even speculate as to whether purchaser was in fact the alter ego of vendor.
Document Preview: Assignee of note and deed of trust filed complaint for declaratory judgment in Chapter 7 cases, seeking determination that its liens on property were valid and enforceable, notwithstanding fact that security interest was not granted by record title holder.  The Bankruptcy Court, Letitia Z. Clark, J., held that: (1) assignee did not have standing to assert causes of action alleging that debtor perpetrated fraud by misrepresenting true state of record title to property, that debtor purchaser was alter ego of debtor vendor and intended through conveyance to cause harm to assignee's predecessor-in-interest, and that conveyance from debtor vendor to debtor purchaser should be voided due to lack of consideration, and (2) assignee was not entitled to equitable lien on property. Judgment for defendant.
