Title: William Wrigley Jr. Co. v. Waters
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under New York law, evidence was insufficient to establish that corporation that purchased trademark registration agent's business was an alter ego of the agent, making decision to pierce corporate veil and impose personal liability on the agent improper; agent merely assured customers that he would continue to have personal responsibility and control over trademark renewal work following sale of business.
Document Preview: Principal brought action against trademark registration agents for breach of contract and negligent performance of services.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Charles E. Stewart, Jr., J., entered judgment in favor of principal, and agents appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Dearie, District Judge, sitting by designation, held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to establish that agent had not paid foreign associates hired to assist in registration of principal's trademarks in other countries and had implicitly promised to pay those associates on principal's behalf, supporting imposition of constructive trust upon principal to ensure payment of the associates; (2) under New York law, evidence was insufficient to establish that corporation that purchased trademark registration agent's business was an alter ego of the agent, making decision to pierce corporate veil and impose personal liability on the agent improper;...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Mancorp, Inc. v. Culpepper
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to show that corporation was alter ego of its sole shareholder and president, even though president did not remember details of corporate formalities, checks used to pay for construction merely listed president's name and did not designate that president was agent of corporation, and president's business card appeared to state that president was the corporation.
Document Preview: Contractor brought action against corporate owner and its sole shareholder and president for breach of contract.  Defendants counterclaimed for breach of contract, breach of warranty, and deceptive trade practices.  The 272nd District Court, Brazos County, John Delaney, J., entered judgment against owner, and judgment non obstante veredicto for owner's president.  Contractor and owner appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Cohen, J., held that: (1) evidence did not show that corporation was president's alter ego; (2) contractor's failure to timely identify expert witness did not preclude trial court from allowing expert witness to testify; (3) trial court's refusal to submit special issues concerning breach of contract and deceptive trade practices claims was harmless error, where damages issues requested by owner did not include proper measure of actual damages; (4) owner was entitled under Deceptive Trade Practices Act to collect...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Commercial Escrow Co. v. Rockport Rebel, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Evidence did not support jury's determination that sole shareholder, director, and officer of escrow company was alter ego of escrow company; no evidence was presented that amount with which escrow company was capitalized was insufficient capitalization for that type of business or that escrow company was either unable to pay its debts or even that it would be unable to pay present claimant, and there was no evidence that corporate records and minutes did not exist or that corporate formalities were not followed.
Document Preview: Vendor that placed funds in escrow to assist purchaser in obtaining financing for purchase of motel brought action against escrow company and its sole shareholder for improperly releasing funds to financing company and for refusing to return funds to vendor.  The 156th District Court, Aransas County, Rachel Littlejohn, J., entered judgment in favor of vendor, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Utter, J., held that: (1) evidence supported determination that escrow company's failure to adhere to representations was producing cause of vendor's damages; (2) evidence supported determination that escrow company engaged in unconscionable course of conduct; (3) evidence supported finding of negligence; and (4) shareholder could be held personally liable for knowingly participating in corporate wrongdoing. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Casson v. Hartford Fire Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Physician, her radiological services corporation, and insurer failed to establish that corporation was physician's alter ego, that corporate veil could be pierced, and that release of physician applied to corporation.
Document Preview: Patient brought malpractice action against hospital, physician, her radiological services corporation, and their insurers to recover for failure to diagnose fractured vertebrae.  Patient, physician, and insurer entered settlement agreement.  Hospital sought indemnity from physician, corporation, and insurer.  The 10th Judicial District Court, Parish of Natchitoches, John B. Whitaker, J., entered summary judgment against hospital on claims for indemnity or contribution.  Hospital appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Guidry, J., held that: (1) physician, radiological services corporation, and insurer failed to establish that corporate veil could be pierced and that release of physician applied to corporation; (2) whether hospital was guilty of independent negligence and was entitled to recover indemnity from physician and corporation was question of fact precluding summary judgment; and (3) settlement agreement between patient and...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Hernandez v. Westoak Realty & Inv., Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Four.
Headnote: Evidence did not establish that construction contractor was alter ego of mortgagee such that cancellation of mortgage note and deed of trust was appropriate after it was determined that contractor breached its duty to perform in workmanlike manner, notwithstanding that one individual was president of both entities and that trustee on deed of trust was director of both entities.
Document Preview: Home buyers brought action against building contractor based on contractor's alleged failure to perform work on construction of shell of home in workmanlike manner and against mortgagee that financed construction work.  The St. Genevieve County Circuit Court, James H. Kelly, J., awarded buyers damages and prejudgment interest against contractor but entered judgment in favor of mortgagee.  Contractor and buyers appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Satz, J., held that: (1) buyers pleaded and proved viable contract claim; (2) evidence did not support damages award; (3) buyers were not entitled to prejudgment interest on damages award; and (4) contractor and mortgagee could not be considered alter egos such that mortgage note and deed of trust could be cancelled due to contractor's conduct. Affirmed as modified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Jack C. Keir, Inc. v. Robinson & Keir Partnership
Court: Supreme Court of Vermont.
Headnote: Evidence supported trial court's finding that corporation, which advanced funds to partnership and whose board of directors was chaired by one of the partners, was not the partner's alter ego.
Document Preview: Corporation brought action against partnership to recover sums due on loans.  Following remand, 552 A.2d 403, the Washington Superior Court, James L. Morse, J., entered judgment for corporation, and one of the partners appealed.  The Supreme Court, Allen, C.J., held that: (1) evidence supported trial court's finding that advances were loans; (2) evidence supported finding that corporation was not alter ego of partner who chaired its board of directors; and (3) evidence was insufficient to support finding that repayment was subject to condition precedent that there be funds available from partnership's operation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Chuck Wagon Feeding Co., Inc. v. Davis
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: No evidence of probative force was presented to support jury's affirmative answer to issue concerning alter ego theory of individual liability for corporate obligation.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from a judgment of the 210th District Court, El Paso County, Sam Paxson, J., in actions for breach of contract and on theories of corporate alter ego and guaranty.  The Court of Appeals, Koehler, J., held that: (1) admission into evidence of collateral note bill of sale and submission of issues concerning that note were erroneous where that note was not the contract sued on and no trial amendment was requested, and (2) failure to raise objection to submission of issues due to legal insufficiency of defense of no evidence or by motion to disregard jury's answers to those issues and instead moving for judgment in accordance with jury verdict constituted waiver of any appellate evidentiary complaint as to submission of those issues. Reversed and rendered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Pacesetter Real Estate, Inc. v. Fasules
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 3, Panel Three.
Headnote: Shareholders-officers failed to meet burden of establishing that corporation was merely alter ego of its shareholders such that corporate veil could be pierced to find that loan transactions were primarily for consumer purposes for purposes of statute providing exception to usury defense if purposes of loan are primarily for agricultural, commercial, investment, or business purposes. West's RCWA 19.52.080.
Document Preview: Corporation and its shareholders-officers brought action seeking injunctive relief from nonjudicial foreclosure, determination that loan was usurious, and attorney fees.  The Superior Court, Stevens County, Frederick Stewart, J., found that loans were usurious.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Munson, J., held that: (1) corporation lacked standing to bring action; (2) shareholders-officers had standing to bring action; and (3) loans were commercial loans within meaning of statute providing exception to usury defense when purposes of loans are commercial purposes. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Crolley v. Crow-Childress-Mobley No. 2
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to authorize finding that corporate tenant was merely its president's alter ego, as required to hold president liable for breach of lease when tenant ceased making payments and vacated the premises.
Document Preview: In action against corporate tenant and its president for accrued and future rents, the Cobb State Court, McDuff, J., rendered judgment for landlord, and defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Deen, P.J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to authorize finding that corporate tenant was merely its president's alter ego, as required to hold president liable for breach of lease; (2) landlord did not accept abandonment of the premises by tenant; and (3) evidence was insufficient to show fraudulent misrepresentation by landlord. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Southern Lumber & Coal Co. v. M.P. Olson Real Estate and Const. Co., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Creditor of corporation failed to adduce sufficient evidence to show that corporation was insolvent at time debt to creditor was incurred or that corporation was a mere facade for the personal dealings of its president and sole shareholder, who carried on the operations of the corporate defendant in disregard of the corporate entity, notwithstanding shareholder's alleged treatment of a personal investment as a corporate asset.
Document Preview: Creditor of corporation brought action alleging that the president and sole shareholder was the alter ego of the corporation.  The District Court, Douglas County, Donald J. Hamilton, J., dismissed action, and plaintiff appealed.  The Supreme Court, Caporale, J., held that: (1) plaintiff failed to show that corporate defendant was undercapitalized at time of formation, and (2) creditor failed to show that shareholder improperly diverted corporate assets or funds to his own uses so as to warrant imposition of personal liability on shareholder. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Miles v. CEC Homes, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Wyoming.
Headnote: Evidence that inadequate corporate records and minutes were maintained, that funds were commingled, that president majority shareholder used corporation to procure labor and services for himself, and that there was unauthorized diversion of funds or assets to other than corporate uses provided sufficient basis for trial court to find absence of individuality or separateness between corporation and president, warranting piercing corporate veil; moreover, adherence to limited liability concept under circumstances would promote injustice.
Document Preview: First developer and surveying company brought action against second developer and its president majority shareholder seeking to recover payment on common improvements contract and on surveying company's account.  The District Court of Fremont County, Elizabeth Kail, J., entered judgment for first developer and surveying company, and second developer and president appealed.  The Supreme Court, Cardine, J., held that: (1) evidence supported piercing corporate veil of second developer; (2) first developer's failure to provide second developer with specifications for common improvements did not excuse second developer's performance; (3) first developer failed to establish amount of attorney fee award to which it was entitled; and (4) prejudgment interest on award to surveying company would be at statutory rate rather than at rate provided on invoice. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and modified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Lambert v. Farmers Bank, Frankfort, Ind.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana, First District.
Headnote: Sufficient evidence supported finding that corporation was a debtor's alter ego and that the corporate entity should be disregarded; there was testimony that bank had dealt with debtor for several years before execution of promissory note, debtor submitted an individual financial statement in which he included both personal and corporate assets and stated that he owned all the stock in the corporation, and bank's vice-president testified that at the time of the loan he believed debtor owned all of the corporate stock, although debtor testified that stock had been transferred to his children, and minutes of shareholder meetings and other documentation supported conclusion that president was the sole stockholder at time of loan.
Document Preview: Creditor bank brought an action on a promissory note against debtor and corporation of which debtor was president.  The Hamilton Circuit Court, Judith S. Proffitt, J., found that corporation was the debtor's alter ego.  The debtor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Ratliff, C.J., held that sufficient evidence supported finding that the corporation was the alter ego of the debtor and that corporate assets were subject to execution and satisfaction of the debtor's personal liabilities. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Drilcon, Inc. v. Roil Energy Corp., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: Even if jury instruction regarding piercing the corporate veil was erroneous with respect to that portion stating that jury could find president of corporation was alter ego and personally liable on drilling contract if there was showing corporation was utilized as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience, corporate veil could be pierced; jury was presented with substantial evidence of fraud and justifying wrongs to pierce corporate veil under alternate theory stated in instruction.
Document Preview: Drilling company brought action against corporation which hired it and corporation's president alleging breach of contract, negligence, and constructive fraud.  The District Court, Flathead County, Leif Erickson, J., entered judgment in favor of drilling company.  Corporation and president appealed.  The Supreme Court, Gulbrandson, J., held that: (1) special circumstances existed which supported jury finding of constructive fraud on part of defendant corporation and its president; (2) there was sufficient evidence to support theories to pierce corporate veil; and (3) substantial evidence supported finding that corporation breached drilling contract. Affirmed. Sheehy, J., filed a dissenting opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Drilcon, Inc. v. Roil Energy Corp., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: There was substantial evidence that corporate president was alter ego of corporation, for purposes of piercing corporate veil; corporation was not capitalized, president was majority shareholder and was officer and director, president took all actions for corporation without consulting other named officers and directors, corporate formalities were not adhered to, and president used his personal funds to pay corporate debt.
Document Preview: Drilling company brought action against corporation which hired it and corporation's president alleging breach of contract, negligence, and constructive fraud.  The District Court, Flathead County, Leif Erickson, J., entered judgment in favor of drilling company.  Corporation and president appealed.  The Supreme Court, Gulbrandson, J., held that: (1) special circumstances existed which supported jury finding of constructive fraud on part of defendant corporation and its president; (2) there was sufficient evidence to support theories to pierce corporate veil; and (3) substantial evidence supported finding that corporation breached drilling contract. Affirmed. Sheehy, J., filed a dissenting opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Jack Farenbaugh & Son v. Belmont Construction, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 7, California.
Headnote: Evidence established that president and 50% shareholder had unity of interest and ownership with corporation, that inequitable result would follow, if alter ego doctrine were not applied, and that president was alter ego of corporation, which went out of business and which lost its assets for payment of outstanding debts of shareholders to parties other than judgment creditor.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor moved to amend judgment against judgment debtor in order to add corporate president as judgment debtor, even though president was not named in original complaint or original judgment.  The Superior Court, Los Angeles County, Robert P. Schifferman, J., granted motion.  President appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Roberson, J., held that: (1) amendment to judgment to add president as judgment debtor did not deprive president of due process; (2) trial judge was not required to disqualify himself; and (3) evidence established that president was alter ego of judgment debtor. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Mo-Kan Teamsters Pension Fund v. Creason
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Evidence established that corporation formed out of sole proprietorship was alter ego of proprietor and that corporation was liable for proprietor's obligations to union pension funds, even though corporation had not signed contract stipulation requiring proprietor to make payments to fund. Labor Management Relations Act, 1947, § 302, 29 U.S.C.A. § 186; Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 3, 29 U.S.C.A. § 1002.
Document Preview: Union pension funds brought action against employer and owner of employer to recover for unpaid contributions.  Employer and owner brought action against former attorney for failure to terminate liability to funds.  Motions for summary judgment were filed against funds, employer, owner, and attorney.  The District Court, Saffels, J., held that: (1) Kansas five-year statute of limitations for written contract did not bar recovery of delinquent contributions for more than five years before filing of lawsuit; (2) employer was liable for unpaid contributions incurred by its owner and prior proprietorship; and (3) Kansas two-year statute of limitations for tort did not bar action of owner and employer against attorney for failure to terminate liability to funds. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Steinhardt v. Banks
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Substantial competent evidence that corporation was individual's alter ego was not alone sufficient to establish "improper conduct" that would allow individual to be held liable for corporation's acts.
Document Preview: The Circuit Court, Palm Beach County, Walter N. Colbath, Jr., J., determined that corporation had breached contract, and that damages were to be recovered against it, and held individual defendant responsible for corporation's acts.  On appeal by individual and corporation, the District Court of Appeal held that substantial competent evidence that corporation was individual's alter ego was not alone sufficient to establish improper conduct that would allow individual to be held liable for corporation's acts. Reversed and remanded in part with direction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: In re Landbank Equity Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division. .
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that particular corporation was instrumentality of corporate debtor used by family related to debtor for fraudulent purposes, and thus supported piercing of that corporation's veil in bankruptcy trustee's action; testimonyrevealed that properties developed by corporation were financed by loans from corporate debtor placed in names of corporate debtor's employees, that corporation was known by several different names, that family used corporation to collect all rent f or rental property in everyone's name, including rent on properties held by other corporations, and that family relatives were beneficiaries of gratuitous transfers from corporation in form of real estate and cash bonuses.
Document Preview: Trustee brought action seeking to recover from relatives and entities related to debtor funds trustee believed went to them illegally.  The Bankruptcy Court, 66 B.R. 949, Hal J. Bonney, Jr., J., awarded trustee monetary damages against various defendants, and defendants appealed.  The District Court, Clarke, J., held that: (1) evidence supported piercing of veils of various corporations; (2) loans made to officers or employees of corporate debtor and its affiliates with no payment or nominal payment of points violated debtor's policy and deprived debtor and its creditors of assets that would have been available if loans been made to public, and accordingly, points not paid were allowable item of damages; (3) loans received from debtor by individuals who were officers and employees of debtor and its affiliates were recoverable on grounds they were fraudulently obtained; and (4) threefold damages were properly awarded against various...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Earnest v. Merck
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: President of both vendor corporation and real estate company was not liable, in his individual capacity, for breach of contract to sell home with adequate water supply, absent evidence that president was mere alter ego of corporation, that president made corporate assets vehicles for his own private affairs or that there was such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and president did not exist.
Document Preview: Purchaser brought action against vendor corporation, real estate company and officer who was president of both corporations, seeking to rescind contract for sale of home and to recover damages, on ground of inadequate water supply.  The Putnam Superior Court, Prior, J., entered summary judgment for president in his individual capacity, and purchaser appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Birdsong, C.J., held that: (1) president's puffing to purchaser as to capacity of well did not render him individually liable, and (2) whether president had sued well digger in individual or representative capacity was irrelevant in determining whether president was individually liable to purchaser. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Falcone v. Night Watchman, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Evidence supported conclusion that there was such a unity of interest and ownership between corporation and sole shareholder that independence of corporation had in effect ceased or never existed and that justice and equity required corporate shield to be disregarded in order to impose personal liability on shareholder; shareholder completely dominated corporation which owned no assets, corporation was able to operate restaurant only as a result of assets made available by shareholder, and shareholder promised creditor that he would be responsible for debt owed to him by corporation.
Document Preview: Supplier of wholesale fruit and other produce brought suit against corporation which operated restaurant and its sole shareholder for goods sold and delivered.  The Superior Court in the Judicial District of Litchfield, Missal, J., rendered stipulated judgment for plaintiff against corporation.  Thereafter, the Court, Allen, J., rendered judgment against sole shareholder, and he appealed.  The Appellate Court, Berdon, J., held that evidence supported conclusion that there was such a unity of interest and ownership between corporation and sole shareholder that independence of corporation had in effect ceased or never existed and that justice and equity required corporate shield to be disregarded in order to impose personal liability on shareholder. No error.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Robbins v. Robbins
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Eastland.
Headnote: Evidence was factually insufficient to establish that there was such a unity between corporation and intestate that separate existence of corporation had ceased and, hence, was insufficient to establish that corporation was intestate's alter ego so as to entitle his widow to a community interest in shares of stock gained in a trade during course of marriage; assets of corporation were never intermingled with intestate's personal assets and, aside from fact that corporation did not furnish any personal services or goods to intestate, corporation owned all assets used in business, corporate bank accounts were kept separate from intestate's individual bank accounts, corporation paid its own taxes, and employees were employed by corporation and not by intestate.
Document Preview: Widow of intestate brought suit against children from previous marriage to determine status of stock owned by intestate.  The County Court at Law No. 2, Smith County, Cynthia Stevens Kent, J., entered judgment granting widow a community interest in stock, and children appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Raleigh Brown, J. (ret.), sitting by assignment, held that evidence was factually insufficient to establish that there was such a unity between corporation and intestate that separate existence of corporation had ceased and, hence, was insufficient to establish that corporation was intestate's alter ego so as to entitle his widow to a community interest in shares of stock gained in a trade during course of marriage. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: A.B.C. Home & Real Estate Inspection, Inc. v. Plummer
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana, Third District.
Headnote: Principal's advertising of himself as owner of corporation in home inspection business and fact that contractor's licenses that he advertised were held in his name alone supported conclusion that individual was doing business as sole proprietorship and not as corporation, and thus supported piercing of corporate veil of corporation which never issued corporate stock. IC 23-1-3-5 (1982 Ed.).
Document Preview: Purchasers brought suit against home inspector and its principal.  The Marion Superior Court, Betty Barteau, J., entered judgment in favor of purchasers, and inspector and its principal appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Hoffman, J., held that: (1) evidence supported piercing corporate veil to hold principal personally liable; (2) purchasers' failure to comply with notice requirements of Deceptive Consumer Sales Act precluded their recovery from home inspector under Act, but did not preclude recovery for breach of contract to inspect; but (3) evidence supported finding that inspector and its principal were grossly negligent in performing inspection, thus warranting award of punitive damages. Reversed in part and affirmed in part. Garrard, J., filed dissenting opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: McCracken v. Olson Companies, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fifth Division.
Headnote: Evidence of corporations' and officer/director's unity of interest, failure of officer/director to comply with requisite corporate formalities, and that corporations were grossly undercapitalized supported trial court's finding that corporation should not be allowed to shield officer/director from liability for attorney fees for work performed for corporations and that corporate veil should be pierced.
Document Preview: Attorney brought action against corporate client and its officer/director to recover attorney fees pursuant to written contract.  The Circuit Court, Cook County, Dean M. Trafelet, J., entered judgment in favor of attorney.  The officer/director appealed.  The Appellate Court, Lorenz J., held that: (1) evidence supported trial court's finding that corporation should not be allowed to shield officer/director from liability; (2) declaration that officer/director promised to pay debt, accompanied by his personal initial, constituted sufficient writing from which trial court could determine his intent to bind himself personally; and (3) trial court's finding that officer/director ratified attorney fee contract was not against manifest weight of the evidence. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: In re Coors of North Mississippi, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Mississippi.
Headnote: Evidence was not sufficient to establish that principal shareholder-seller of debtor corporation, or shareholder-seller's wife, were engaged in self-dealing, or that debtor corporation was "alter ego" of either, so as to justify piercing corporate veil for purposes of applying doctrine of marshaling assets.
Document Preview: Debtor corporation brought action against former principal shareholder-seller of corporation and third corporation to set aside allegedly fraudulent conveyances and avoid allegedly preferential transfers, as did another debtor corporation.  Debtor corporation also moved for marshaling of assets. The Bankruptcy Court, David W. Houston, III, J., held that: (1) promissory note executed by debtor corporation, as well as principal shareholder-seller of corporation and his wife, in favor of lender, was legitimate corporate obligation that would not be set aside as fraudulent conveyance; (2) shareholder-seller was not insider to debtor corporation at any time subsequent to date he conveyed his stock to buyers of corporation and resigned as officer and director of corporation, for purposes of determining time frame applicable to allegedly preferential transfers; and (3) evidence was not sufficient to establish shareholder-seller, or his...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: U.S. v. Sutton
Court: Temporary Emergency Court of Appeals.
Headnote: Finding that individual was jointly and severally liable with corporate resellers for crude oil miscertifications because corporations were individual's alter egos and because individual personally engaged in tortious conduct such as noncompliance with corporate formalities and nonpayment of dividends was supported by substantial evidence in record. Emergency Petroleum Allocation Act of 1973, § 5(a)(3, 4), 15 U.S.C.A. § 754(a)(3, 4); Economic Stabilization Act of 1970, § 209, as amended, 12 U.S.C.A. § 1904 note.
Document Preview: Action was instituted by the United States to obtain restitution from crude oil resellers for alleged miscertifications of crude oil sales.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma entered judgment for the United States, and resellers appealed.  The Temporary Emergency Court of Appeals, Wesley E. Brown, J., held that: (1) regulations under which old oil receipts by refiners were artificially reduced if price controlled crude oil was miscertified as uncontrolled oil were not invalid as having been adopted or amended without proper notice or opportunity for oral comment; (2) finding of miscertifications was supported by substantial evidence; (3) corporate veil was properly pierced to hold controlling shareholder liable for corporate violations; and (4) remedy and nature of restitution were proper in requiring payment of $423,050,902.92 to the United States for distribution to the states for use in energy related...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Man-Gas Transmission Co. v. Osborne Oil Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: Evidence in action alleging purchaser's breach of gas purchase contract was sufficient to support trial court's finding piercing the corporate veil and finding that defendants were alter egos of each other and liable jointly and severally to sellers for damages sustained by the breach of contract; trust account made up exclusively of money obtained from purchaser's resale of the gas was handled as if it was a private personal bank account made up of legitimate earnings from a trade or profession.
Document Preview: Sellers of natural gas brought action against purchaser and alleged alter egos of purchaser, alleging breach of contract and seeking damages for gas taken but not paid for.  They also sought a declaratory judgment that they were entitled to use certain gas-gathering and treatment facilities that served their wells.  The 293rd District Court, Maverick County, Ben Martinez, J., entered judgment awarding plaintiffs damages in excess of $1.7 million and declaring that they were entitled to use gas-gathering facilities.  Defendants were enjoined from interfering with such facilities.  On appeal, the Court of Appeals, Keith, J., Assigned, held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support finding that defendants breached contract; (2) evidence supported trial court's piercing of corporate veil finding that defendants were alter egos of each other and liable jointly and severally for damages sustained by breach of the contract; and (3) there...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Wheat v. Delcourt
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence that vendor's successor was director, president, treasurer and sole shareholder of corporation to which property was transferred and did not know who secretary or directors of such corporation were, that four months after successor transferred property to corporation in exchange for note, successor's father formed company which bought outstanding first lien on property and foreclosed on lien, and that at such time, successor transferred nonexistent funds to father's company, which then transferred funds to corporation and corporation to successor, thereby transferring all outstanding obligations to father's company, was sufficient to support jury's finding that successor was alter ego of corporation, particularly where father's company sold property with condition that closing take place only through title company owned by father, despite knowledge by successor and his father that lis pendens had been filed against property.
Document Preview: Purchaser brought action against vendor's successor for breach of contract to sell townhouse.  The 125th District Court, Harris County, Michael L. O'Brien, J., entered judgment on jury verdict awarding purchaser $36,000 damages, plus attorney's fees, and vendor's successor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Murphy, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support jury's finding that vendor's successor was alter ego of corporation to which property was transferred, and (2) admission of contract made between vendor and purchaser for construction and sale of townhouse was not abuse of trial court's discretion. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Factofrance Heller v. I.P.M. Precision Machinery Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, assignee of corporation's accounts receivable failed to show that shareholder who owned 100% of corporations stock was its "alter ego" to permit piercing of the corporate veil to subject shareholder to liability for corporation's debts.
Document Preview: French factor brought action to recover amounts allegedly due from American firm from assignment of accounts and moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Shadur, J., held that: (1) American firm failed to show proof of out-of-pocket expenses for repairing machinery prior to resale to offset those against its debt; (2) breach of warranty claim accrued before notice of assignment, and thus could be asserted against factor; and (3) American firm's claim for trade show expenses as an offset accrued after notice of assignment, and thus could not be asserted. Judgment accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Aztec Management and Inv. Co., Inc. v. McKenzie
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil to attach personal liability to president of corporation was not justified, where record contained no evidence of any commingling of funds or other improprieties such as the disregarding of corporate formalities, and there was no evidence that corporation was formed to perpetuate fraud.
Document Preview: President of corporation appealed from a judgment against himself, individually, and corporation in the 293rd District Court of Dimmit County, Ben Martinez, J., which awarded money damages and attorney fees for breach of a contractual duty to furnish water to residential lots.  The Court of Appeals, Seerden, J., held that: (1) statements made by president at trial were consistent with his controlling the corporation and acting as its president, and did not constitute admission that the corporation was president's alter ego, and (2) piercing the corporate veil to attach personal liability to corporate president was not justified. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Dow Chemical Pacific Ltd. v. Rascator Maritime S.A.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: District court's decision to pierce corporate veil to hold shareholder personally liable for carrier's unauthorized deviation of cargo was supported by evidence that shareholder both treated corporation as his alter ego and used it for fraudulent purposes.
Document Preview: Shippers brought action against carrier subtime charterer and its agents to recover damages for impermissible deviation of the vessel for purpose of asserting a lien on the cargo.  Following entry of judgment by the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, 594 F.Supp. 1490, vessel owner, carrier, and carrier's agent moved for reargument, amendment, or vacator, and the District Court, Kevin Thomas Duffy, J., affirmed in part and vacated in part, 609 F.Supp. 451.  Carrier and agents appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Kearse, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) vessel and carrier were liable to plaintiffs for impermissible deviation of the vessel; (2) agents were liable to plaintiffs for damages and to vessel owner and time charter for indemnification; and (3) defendants were not liable for attorney fees. Affirmed in part and vacated and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Loomis Land & Cattle Co., Inc. v. Wood
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support finding that corporation was stockholder's alter ego; although sale of cattle ranch was to corporation, the six promissory notes representing part of the purchase price were signed by stockholder without any corporate indication, manager of ranch testified that he had never heard of corporation and that stockholder told him that he personally owned ranch, and sellers testified that they relied on stockholder's personal financial statements of net worth in making sale, and looked to him for payment of notes even though deed was to corporation.
Document Preview: In cross action by sellers of cattle ranch against corporation and its sole stockholder to recover balance due on promissory notes given by the stockholder, filed after oral announcement of nonsuit in action in which cross action was brought, the 71st Judicial District Court, Harrison County, David Moore, J., entered judgment against corporation and stockholder for $66,211.70 and ordered foreclosure of purchase money lien on cattle ranch.  Appeals were taken.  The Court of Appeals, Cornelius, C.J., held that: (1) pleading of cross action contained all essentials of separate claim and could be maintained as independent suit even though nonsuit was effective at time cross action was filed; (2) evidence was sufficient to support finding that corporation was stockholder's alter ego; and (3) evidence was sufficient to support finding that sellers did not fraudulently misrepresent their interest in property. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: In re Western World Funding, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Managing director and his partner, also an officer and director, failed to rebut prima facie case that they were engaged in a joint venture partnership, and that such partnership, as well as individual partners, were the alter egos of the corporations and as such were liable for the corporations' debts, where they had at the time of their involvement, an explicit, present agreement to share profits, they did in fact share the profits, they had an understanding between themselves that they could each freely use funds generated by the corporations and those funds were not taken as interest on loans, salary, rent or any of the exceptions set out in section of Nevada's Uniform Partnership Act, N.R.S. 87.070.
Document Preview: Debtor corporations' trustee brought suit against officers and directors of corporations for, inter alia, conversion of corporation funds.  The Bankruptcy Court, Robert Clive Jones, J., held that: (1) officers and directors breached fiduciary duty to corporation by converting corporate funds to their own use; (2) managing director was not entitled to set off against his liability for conversion a credit for the reasonable value of his services; (3) doctrines of ratification, estoppel and waiver did not apply; and (4) evidence supported finding that officers and directors were engaged in a joint venture partnership, and that the partnership, as well as the individual members, were the alter egos of the debtor corporations, and as such were liable for the corporations' debts. Judgment accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: In re Western World Funding, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Even absent rule that receipt of share of profits is prima facie evidence of partnership, pursuant to Nevada statute, N.R.S. 87.070, subd. 4, evidence supported finding that officers and directors of corporations were engaged in a joint venture partnership which, along with the individual members, was liable for the corporations' debts as their alter egos; officers and directors had present agreement and intent to share profits whenever such profits were generated and to that end each made a contribution; first officer and director contributed her time, assets, and credit, while second officer and director contributed his purported management abilities.
Document Preview: Debtor corporations' trustee brought suit against officers and directors of corporations for, inter alia, conversion of corporation funds.  The Bankruptcy Court, Robert Clive Jones, J., held that: (1) officers and directors breached fiduciary duty to corporation by converting corporate funds to their own use; (2) managing director was not entitled to set off against his liability for conversion a credit for the reasonable value of his services; (3) doctrines of ratification, estoppel and waiver did not apply; and (4) evidence supported finding that officers and directors were engaged in a joint venture partnership, and that the partnership, as well as the individual members, were the alter egos of the debtor corporations, and as such were liable for the corporations' debts. Judgment accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Houston Oil & Minerals Corp. v. SEEC, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Louisiana, Lafayette-Opelousas Division.
Headnote: Evidence that officer advanced $100,000 to corporation, but debt instrument was not issued to him because it would have been disadvantageous for his personal tax situation, indicated self-dealing by officer which supported finding that corporation was sham.
Document Preview: Action was filed alleging that defendants tortiously induced corporate employee to breach agreement not to disclose trade secrets and certain confidential and proprietary information.  On various motions, the District Court, Duhe, J., held that: (1) Texas law governed the claim of tortious inducement of the breach; (2) whether the document signed by the employee which set forth the corporation's trade secrets policy was a contract was a genuine issue of material fact, precluding summary judgment; (3) it was appropriate to pierce the veil of a Louisiana corporation where there had been commingling of personal and corporate assets; and (4) an officer of the purported corporation was subject to jurisdiction in Louisiana as the proprietor of a Louisiana business. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Bischofshausen, Vasbinder, and Luckie v. D.W. Jaquays Min. and Equipment Contractors Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 2, Department A.
Headnote: Owners of closely held corporation were not individually liable for torts of corporation based on piercing of corporate veil, as evidence did not give rise to inference or create doubt as to whether there was such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and owner ceased to exist.
Document Preview: Action was brought for personal injuries allegedly caused by exposure to asbestos particles.  The Superior Court, Gila County, Cause Nos. 22,270, 23,278, 24,457, James E. Don, J., entered summary judgment in favor of defendant equipment company and officers of equipment company, and plaintiffs appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Howard, J., held that there existed genuine issues of material fact, precluding summary judgment. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: DeSantis v. Piccadilly Land Corp.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: In action to recover damages for breach of contract for construction of house and for fraudulent misrepresentation, evidence supported finding that corporation was corporation in name only and that it was operated as instrumentality or alter ego of person who was president, treasurer, director and majority shareholder, subject to his sole control, so that there was no error in imposing liability on that person individually.
Document Preview: Action was brought to recover damages for breach of contract for construction of house, fraudulent misrepresentation and wrongful disbursement of funds.  The Superior Court, Judicial District of Fairfield, George A. Saden, State Referee, entered judgment for plaintiff, and defendant appealed.  The Appellate Court, Daly, J., held that: (1) there was clear and satisfactory evidence to conclude that corporate president was liable on basis of fraud; (2) evidence supported findings that corporation was corporation in name only and that it was operated as alter ego of corporate president; (3) it was proper to impose punitive damages; (4) trial court did not abuse discretion in allowing plaintiffs to amend their complaint many months after trial had ended; and (5) trial court did not abuse its discretion in allowing plaintiffs to introduce evidence on issue of punitive damages several months after conclusion of trial. No error.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Harris v. Best of America Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Totality of facts did not support finding that corporation had ceased to exist as an entity, separate and distinct from its sole shareholder, so as to warrant piercing corporate veil to hold shareholder liable on corporation's contract with plaintiff.
Document Preview: Contractor and its president appealed from the Twenty-Second Judicial District Court, Parish of Washington, James R. Strain, Jr., J., which determined that owner was entitled to recover certain damages for faulty work under construction contract.  The Court of Appeal, Carter, J., held that: (1) stipulated damages provided in contract did not limit award of damages to owner for faulty workmanship; (2) trial court properly relied upon testimony of plaintiff's experts in determining award of damages; and (3) totality of facts did not support a finding that corporation had ceased to exist as an entity, separate and distinct from its sole shareholder, so as to pierce corporate veil to hold shareholder liable on contract with plaintiff. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Abbott Foods of Georgia, Inc. v. Elberton Poultry Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: In creditor's action to hold corporate president and principal shareholder personally liable for corporate debt, evidence was sufficient to support finding that president had utilized corporate entity as mere instrumentality or business conduit for transaction of his own personal business.
Document Preview: Creditor brought action seeking to hold corporate president and principal shareholder personally liable for corporate debt.  The Coffee Superior Court, Lott, Senior Judge, entered judgment for creditor, and president and corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Banke, C.J., held that evidence was sufficient to support finding that president had utilized corporate entity as mere instrumentality or business conduit for transaction of his personal business. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Pepsi-Cola Metropolitan Bottling Co., Inc. v. Checkers, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: In suit on a corporate debt, evidence from which jury could find that an individual defendant failed to observe corporate formalities, siphoned funds, kept no records, and used corporation for his own personal transactions sustained piercing of the corporate veil.
Document Preview: In suit by a bottling company on account, and for, inter alia, alleged violation by several corporate and individual defendants of Massachusetts fair practices statutes, the bottling company prevailed in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts, A. David Mazzone, J.  The defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Levin H. Campbell, C.J., held that: (1) evidence warranted the jury in piercing the corporate veil; (2) summaries of checks issued by debtor, tending to show that after July 1980 certain funds of corporations were used interchangeably for personal benefit of the individuals, were admissible though debt to plaintiff had been incurred in June 1980 before the payments in question were made; and (3) evidence permitted trial court to believe that defendants which had withheld payments of sum due on contract, as a wedge to enhance the corporate defendant's bargaining power for more product had simply...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: In re WWG Industries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Rome Division.
Headnote: In action by debtor's assignee to collect on accounts allegedly owed debtor, proof failed to show that defendant was "alter ego" of other party which had done business with debtor, notwithstanding that debtor's accounting procedures kept both entities on single account number.
Document Preview: Debtor's assignee brought action to collect on accounts allegedly owed debtor.  Defendant objected to Bankruptcy Court's findings as to jurisdiction and venue, certain setoffs and rebates and its liability for debts incurred by related corporation.  The District Court, Harold L. Murphy, J., held that: (1) District Court had ancillary personal jurisdiction over nonresident defendant, even though defendant lacked minimum contacts with forum state; (2) change of venue would serve no useful purpose;  and (3) proof failed to show that defendant was alter ego of related corporation. Order accordingly.

Title: Akzona Inc. v. E.I. Du Pont De Nemours & Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Choice of words of a foreign layman untutored in subtleties of American corporate law is of little independent significance in establishing an agency relationship between a subsidiary and a parent corporation, although it may corroborate other evidence.
Document Preview: Foreign manufacturers of aramid fibers, including parent corporation of a domestic subsidiary, brought action for a declaratory judgment that six patents relating to aramid fibers were invalid, unenforceable and noninfringed. Foreign manufacturers also sought treble damages and injunctive relief for alleged antitrust violations and unfair competition by patent owner.  Patent owner counterclaimed for patent infringement.  On patent owner's motion to dismiss claims concerning two patents, patent owner's motion to bifurcate trial of patent validity and noninfringement issues from remaining issues in case, and on motion of one of manufacturers, an unserved foreign parent corporation, to dismiss patent owner's counterclaim for lack of jurisdiction, the District Court, Longobardi, J., held that: (1) with respect to the two patents at issue, the District Court did not have jurisdiction over declaratory judgment action; (2) District Court declined to...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: B.J. Howard Corp. v. Skinner, Wilson & Strickland
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: In action to recover unpaid legal fees for services performed at direction of individual in connection with personal business, corporate business, and business involving corporate employee, evidence, including proof that individual did not treat his closely held corporation and other corporations as separate entities, but rather treated his various business and personal interests together, that individual used corporate funds to pay personal debts, and that he closed office of one corporation without holding directors' meeting or obtaining prior consent of any other persons involved, provided sufficient basis for jury to find that corporate veil had been pierced.
Document Preview: Action was brought against closely-held corporation and its controlling shareholder to recover fees for legal services.  The DeKalb State Court, Seeliger, J., entered judgment against defendants, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Carley, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient for jury to find original undertaking by controlling shareholder individually in incurring subject debt and to find that individual was furthering his own interest rather than underwriting debt of another, so that fact that there was no writing did not mean that action was barred by statute of frauds, and (2) evidence was sufficient for jury to find that corporate veil had been pierced. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Deer Creek, Inc. v. Clarendon Hot Springs Ranch, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Idaho.
Headnote: Evidence that individual's affidavit referred to transaction entered into between himself and another as if a corporation which he owned were one and the same, that a counterclaim filed by the corporation asserted a right to recover on agreements actually entered into by the individual, and that individual consistently took the position that he owned real estate which stood in the name of the corporation was sufficient to show a complete unity of interest between the individual and the corporation, eradicating their separate personalities and justifying a finding that the corporation was the alter ego of the individual.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from order of the District Court, Fifth Judicial District, Blaine County, James M. Cunningham, J., entered in dispute over title to land.  The Court of Appeals, Swanstrom, J., held that: (1) letter sent by one party to the other was not an offer for unilateral contract; (2) court did not err in declining to join individual as an indispensable party; (3) corporation was alter ego of individual; and (4) evidence sustained finding that trust agreement permitted trustee to transfer property upon the instructions of the transferee alone. Vacated and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Stein v. Cherokee Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: On record in suit against individual defendant and corporate defendant, there was no error in trial court's ruling that individual defendant was alter ego of corporate defendant of which he was president, director, and sole stockholder.
Document Preview: In an action for recovery of insurance premiums collected but never remitted to insurance company, a judgment was entered against individual and corporate defendants after bench trial in the Fulton State Court, Moran, J.  On appeal by such defendants, the Court of Appeals, Shulman, C.J., held that: (1) where defendant objected to validity of subpoena because it was served less than 24 hours before he was supposed to appear and trial court offered continuance and defendant refused, choosing to proceed with trial, defendant waived 24hour notice requirement by refusing offer of continuance and by voluntarily testifying at trial; (2) it was individual defendant's burden as appellant to show affirmatively by the record that judgment was erroneous and to support by the record his contention that the loan was prior in time to incurrence of debt to appellee and was therefore superior to appellee's claim; and (3) on record, there was no error in trial...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Candy H. v. Redemption Ranch, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: Although evidence that officer and employees of corporation who had requisite minimum contacts with forum state were mere alter egos of corporation might sustain assertion of personal jurisdiction over officers and employees in forum state, absence of such evidence does not necessarily compel conclusion that personal jurisdiction over officers and employees is lacking when claim is based on alleged tortious conduct in forum state.
Document Preview: A civil rights conspiracy action was filed alleging an agreement among the defendants and their agents to bring girls to a home for girls, to impose their home's rules on the girls and to enforce those rules by strict supervision and by corporal punishment in violation of the girls' right to travel.  On the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction and two motions to dismiss, the District Court, Myron H. Thompson, J., held that: (1) the defendants had sufficient contacts with Alabama to permit the exercise of jurisdiction over them; (2) the plaintiffs stated an actionable civil rights conspiracy; (3) the plaintiffs would be permitted to pursue class certification, despite the mootness of their individual claims; and (4) preliminary injunctive relief was not warranted. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Rowland v. Lepire
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Although evidence did show that construction corporation was undercapitalized and that there was little existence separate and apart from the two officers, directors and shareholder, evidence was insufficient to support finding that latter were alter ego of corporation so as to justify piercing of corporate veil.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from a judgment of the First Judicial District Court, Carson City, Michael E. Fondi, J., in favor of homeowners in suit against builders alleging breach of contract and slander of title.  The Supreme Court, held that: (1) substantial evidence supported findings of trial court and did not require conclusion as matter of law that express contract was abandoned; (2) evidence failed to establish element of malice, and therefore owners could not recover under theory of slander of title; (3) owners were not entitled to award of attorney fees; and (4) evidence was insufficient to support finding that the two officers, directors and shareholders of construction corporation were its alter ego so as to justify piercing corporate veil. Affirmed in part, reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Larson v. Unlimited Business Exchange of North Dakota, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of North Dakota.
Headnote: In lessor's action against individual for payment of rent due from corporation, evidence that individual was sole owner and received sole benefit of corporation, and considered it as sole proprietorship, supported finding that corporation was alter ego of individual, rendering him personally liable for its debts and obligations.
Document Preview: Lessor brought action against corporation and individual for payment of rent due from corporation, and, after trial to court, individual was held personally liable for corporation's debt.  The District Court, Ward County, Jon R. Kerian, J., subsequently denied individual's motion for judgment notwithstanding verdict or, in alternative, for new trial, and individual appealed.  The Supreme Court, Sand, J., held that: (1) motion for judgment notwithstanding verdict was improper in bench trial, and (2) evidence supported finding that corporation was alter ego of individual, rendering him personally liable for its debts. Affirmed.

Title: Karl and Kelly Co., Inc. v. McLerran
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Officers of corporation which entered into house construction contract with plaintiffs were improperly held individually liable for alleged defects in the house in plaintiffs' action in which postanswer "default" judgment was entered against corporation and its officers, since there was no evidence in the record that corporation was the alter ego of either corporate officer; in the interest of justice, the case was to be remanded for a new trial rather than rendered for defendants.
Document Preview: Plaintiffs brought an action under the Deceptive Trade Practices Act due to alleged defects in a new house purchased from corporation.  The Eleventh Judicial District Court, Dallas County, Hoffman, J., rendered judgment for plaintiffs against corporation and its officers in their individual capacities, and the Eastland Court of Civil Appeals, Eleventh Supreme Judicial District, McCloud, J., affirmed.  On appeal, the Supreme Court held that the trial court erred in holding the corporate officers individually liable as part of the postanswer default judgment where there was no evidence in the record that corporation was the alter ego of either corporate officer; in the interest of justice the case was to be remanded for a new trial rather than rendered for defendants. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Majestic Floor Coverings, Inc. v. Lawson
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Record, in suit to recover money owed on an open account, showed that defendant at all times indicated he was acting on behalf of corporation and was not acting in his personal capacity, and, therefore, the corporate veil would not be pierced. LSA-C.C. arts. 435, 437; LSA-R.S. 12:93(B).
Document Preview: Suit was brought to recover money owed on an open account.  The Twenty-Fourth Judicial District Court, Parish of Jefferson, James H. Lockhart, Jr., J., entered judgment in favor of defendant, and plaintiff appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Dufresne, J., held that: (1) record contained sufficient evidence to establish the existence of a corporation, and (2) record revealed that defendant at all times indicated he was acting on behalf of the corporation and was not acting in a personal capacity and, therefore, the corporate veil would not be pierced. Affirmed.

Title: Matter of Allbrand Appliance & Television Co., Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that corporate lessee was merely dummy corporation of debtor, and that landlord was aware of that fact, thereby supporting conclusion that lease existed between landlord and debtor, even though lease was made between landlord and corporation.
Document Preview: Creditors' committee sought declaration that lease between landlord and corporate lessee was a lease of the debtors. The Bankruptcy Court, Joel Lewittes, J., held that: (1) creditors' committee had standing to maintain proceeding; (2) lease was made with dummy corporation of debtor, and thus lease was between landlord and debtors; and (3) lease was no longer property of estate. Ordered accordingly.

Title: Lettinga v. Agristor Credit Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: While defendant, whose security interest covered cows owned by farm corporation, claimed that it had a security interest in all cows on the farm, including those owned by the farmers individually, because the farmers used the corporation merely as an alter ego of themselves, there was sufficient evidence from which a reasonable jury could conclude that the farmers and their corporation were separate debtors; moreover, it was the defendant that required incorporation to protect itself, yet now wanted to set that status aside.
Document Preview: Suit was brought for wrongful destruction of dairy cows in which plaintiff had an unperfected purchase money security interest. The United States District Court for the Western District of Michigan, Benjamin F. Gibson, J., entered judgment for plaintiff, and defendant appealed, claiming that the court erred in denying its motions for judgment n.o.v. and for a new trial. The Court of Appeals, Cornelia G. Kennedy, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) while defendant, whose security interest covered cows owned by farm corporation, claimed that it had a security interest in all cows on the farm, including those owned by the farmers individually, because the farmers used the corporation merely as an alter ego of themselves, there was sufficient evidence from which a reasonable jury could conclude that the farmers and their corporation were separate debtors; (2) no security interest was intended by farmers' voluntary turnover to defendant, which had a security interest in cows owned by farm...
