Title: Carver v. Battey Machinery Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: In action to hold defendant individually liable for judgment rendered against his corporation, trial court did not err in denying defendant's motions for directed verdict and for judgment notwithstanding verdict where plaintiff alleged that corporate entity was being used as mere instrumentality for transaction of defendant's affairs with such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities no longer existed and where there was evidence to support such finding.
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought action against defendant to hold him individually liable for a judgment rendered against his corporation.  Following jury verdict in favor of plaintiff, defendant moved for a new trial and for judgment notwithstanding the verdict.  The Superior Court, Floyd County, Royal, J., denied the motion, and defendant appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Banke, J., held that: (1) trial court did not err in denying defendant's motions where plaintiff alleged that corporate entity was being used as mere instrumentality for transaction of defendant's affairs with such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities no longer existed and where there was evidence to support such finding, and (2) return of execution nulla bona respecting prior judgment against corporation was not condition precedent to filing of suit on the judgment against defendant in his individual capacity where attempted execution would have been fruitless. Affirmed.

Title: Forester & Jerue, Inc. v. Daniels
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: No basis was shown for judgment against officers and stockholders of corporation as individuals, where affidavits and pleadings showed no more than a debt owed by the corporation and did not allege that the individuals were the alter ego of the corporation or any other cognizable action for personal liability.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from denial by the Circuit Court, Autauga County, Walter C. Hayden, J., of motion to alter, amend or vacate judgment and motion to supplement the first motion. The Supreme Court, Faulkner, J., held that: (1) there was no abuse of discretion in refusing to grant the motion to supplement where movants offered no showing why they failed to raise issue in first motion and where additional legal ground asserted in the motion to supplement could not succeed, but (2) no basis was shown for judgment against officers and stockholders of corporation as individuals, where affidavits and pleadings showed no more than a debt owed by the corporation and did not allege that the individuals were the alter ego of the corporation or any other cognizable action for personal liability. Affirmed in part; reversed in part; and remanded.

Title: City of Austin v. Schonfeld
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: City's claim that individual plaintiffs changed names only to avoid or evade payment of their utility bills was without support in record, there being no evidence to show that plaintiffs and a corporation were alter egos or that corporation was plaintiffs' partner or any evidence showing any basis for holding plaintiff individuals vicariously liable for debts incurred by corporation.
Document Preview: The 126th Judicial District Court, Travis County, Pete Lowry, J., granted temporary injunctive relief to plaintiffs, prohibiting city from terminating electric and water service. The city appealed. The Court of Appeals, Phillips, C. J., held that: (1) when customer of public utility presents good-faith claim, based upon reasonable grounds, that he does not owe amount claimed by public utility, then utility may not terminate service prior to judicial determination of correctness of its decision, and temporary injunction may properly be issued to prevent termination of service, and (2) paying third party's debt in order to prevent termination of electrical service, where termination is against defendant city's regulations, and then suing to recover that amount is not adequate remedy at law precluding temporary injunctive relief. Affirmed.

Title: Jones v. Maghdoussian
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: In action by tailor against drycleaner to recover for tailoring services rendered under an arrangement whereby the drycleaner would take in tailoring orders, collect the charges therefor, and pay the tailor the amounts so collected, less an administrative fee, there was sufficient evidence to support jury's finding that the drycleaner and his corporation operated as one person.
Document Preview: Tailor brought action against drycleaner to recover for tailoring services rendered under an arrangement whereby the drycleaner would take in tailoring orders, collect the charges therefor, and pay the tailor the amounts so collected, less an administrative fee.  The DeKalb State Court, Carlisle, J., entered judgment in favor of the tailor, and the drycleaner appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Birdsong, J., held that: (1) trial court properly informed the jury of the legal aspects of money had and received; (2) evidence supported trial court's charge on the theory of bad faith in refusing to acknowledge an indebtedness; and (3) trial court properly entered judgment joint and severally against the drycleaner and his corporation, in view of jury's finding that they operated as one person. Judgment affirmed.

Title: Ailetcher v. Beneficial Finance Co. of Hawaii
Court: Intermediate Court of Appeals of Hawai'i.
Headnote: In the absence of anything to contradict affidavit of defendants which established that one defendant was not the alter ego of the others, motion to dismiss that defendant was proper.
Document Preview: Automobile dealership and one of its employees brought action against finance company to recover for damages allegedly suffered as a result of finance company's refusal to make loans to dealership's customers until the employee paid off a delinquent loan. The Third Circuit Court, Hawaii County, Ernest Kubota, J., entered judgment in favor of finance company, and dealership and its employee appealed. The Intermediate Court of Appeals, Padgett, J., held that: (1) evidence was insufficient to permit recovery on theories of defamation, unlawful methods of debt collection, invasion of privacy, or conspiracy; (2) evidence was sufficient to permit a finding of intentional infliction of mental suffering; (3) finance company was not a collection agency; (4) lender of domestic currency is not a merchant for purposes of statutes regulating unfair trade practices; (5) evidence was sufficient for jury to find that the finance company's action was an unfair act; and (6) evidence was sufficient...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Pederson v. Dillon
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.) .
Headnote: In action for damages for tortious interference with business agreement, which was pled and presented to jury as case of individual capacity versus corporate capacity, case based on alter ego theory would be under separate and distinct theory of law, which must be pled and proven; where theory was not pled and trial amendment attempting to plead it was disallowed, it was waived.
Document Preview: Action was brought against owners of marine center in both their individual and corporate capacity for tortious interference with business agreement. The District Court, Harris County, Thomas J. Stovall, Jr., J., entered final judgment, and two individuals, owners and corporate officers of marine center, appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Doyle, J., held that: (1) trial court erred in submitting special issues which dealt with defendants' individual capacity because there was no evidence that defendants performed any wrongful acts in their individual capacities; (2) there was no evidence to support jury's findings that plaintiff suffered actual damages in form of lost profits; and (3) exemplary damages could not be awarded in absence of actual damages. Reversed and rendered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Preston Farm & Ranch Supply, Inc. v. Bio-Zyme Enterprises
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Although seller pointed out several instances where individual buyer and corporate buyer failed to observe corporate formalities and failed to keep separate their respective affairs, where seller failed to point out how such failure made seller fall victim to some basically unfair device by which corporate form of business organization had been used to achieve inequitable result, trial court did not err in failing to impose liability of corporation on individual.
Document Preview: Corporation and individual appealed from judgment rendered in the 116th District Court, Dallas County, James F. McCarthy, J., in favor of seller in suit on sworn account. The Court of Civil Appeals, Carver, J., held that: (1) both corporate buyer and individual buyer agreed to service charge imposed by seller; (2) service charge of one percent per month, equivalent to 12% per annum, was greater than, but not double, highest lawful rate, therefore, seller would be penalized forfeiture of twice interest charged and reasonable attorney fees; (3) corporation was charged less than lawful interest rate therefore, usury was not shown; and (4) trial court correctly denied joint and several judgment against individual and corporation in absence of pleading of proof that corporation was used by individual to work fraud or injustice. Affirmed.

Title: Crawford-Strauss Properties, Inc. v. Sagebrush Sales Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: In action brought by seller against corporate buyer, its alleged principal, and other businesses alleged to have been controlled by him to recover payment for lumber purchased from seller, evidence adduced at trial was insufficient to establish that several business entities were the alter egos of principal.
Document Preview: Seller brought suit against corporate buyer, its alleged principal, and other businesses alleged to have been controlled by him to recover payment for lumber purchased from seller. The 68th Judicial District Court, Dallas County, Owen Giles, J., entered judgment for plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, 598 S.W.2d 1, affirmed in part and reversed in part. On appeal, the Supreme Court, 605 S.W.2d 857, reversed and remanded. On reconsideration, the Court of Civil Appeals, Ray, J., held that: (1) evidence adduced at trial was insufficient to establish that several business entities were alter egos of principal; (2) evidence was factually insufficient to justify jury in reaching conclusion that principal intended one business to rely upon his financial statement in extending credit to another business; and (3) evidence was insufficient to support jury's verdict that principal intended that one business rely upon belief that principal and another business...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Sagebrush Sales Co. v. Strauss
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: In action brought against corporate buyer, its alleged principal, and other businesses alleged to have been controlled by the principal to recover payment for lumber purchases from seller, there was more than a scintilla of evidence to support jury findings that affairs of the various business entities, which were all owned and controlled by principal, were indistinguishable from his personal affairs and that he acted in such a manner as to lead seller to reasonably believe that the entities in question had reference to himself, and thus Court of Civil Appeals erred in sustaining principal's no evidence points and rendering take-nothing judgment as to him.
Document Preview: Seller brought suit against corporate buyer, its alleged principal, and other businesses alleged to have been controlled by him to recover payment for lumber purchased from seller. The 68th Judicial District Court, Dallas County, Owen Giles, J., entered judgment for plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Ray, J., 598 S.W.2d 1, affirmed in part and reversed in part. On appeal, the Supreme Court, Barrow, J., held that there was more than a scintilla of evidence to support jury findings that affairs of the various business entities, which were all owned and controlled by principal, were indistinguishable from his personal affairs and that he acted in such a manner as to lead seller to reasonably believe that the entities in question had reference to himself, and thus Court of Civil Appeals erred in sustaining principal's no evidence points and rendering a take-nothing judgment as to him. Reversed and remanded.

Title: U. S. Nat. Bank of Omaha v. Rupe
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: In action to set aside husband's allegedly fraudulent conveyance to wife of undivided one-half interest in realty, wherein intervenor, corporation's creditor alleged that corporation was the alter ego of husband and that he was liable for the corporate debt to intervenor, evidence supported conclusion that, during period the debt was incurred, the corporation had been husband's alter ego.
Document Preview: Bank brought creditor's action to set aside husband's allegedly fraudulent conveyance to wife of an undivided one-half interest in realty. Another creditor of husband was permitted to intervene and asked for similar relief. The District Court, Douglas County, Samuel P. Caniglia, J., granted the relief prayed for and the defendants appealed. While the appeal was pending, the wife paid bank's claim and took assignment of lien and upon motion the bank was dismissed as party to the appeal. The Supreme Court held that: (1) upon finding that the conveyance was fraudulent as to creditors, court erred in annulling deed rather than merely making property subject to lien of defrauded creditors, and (2) where at time the corporate debt was incurred, corporation was merely husband's alter ego, it was immaterial that husband at later date, after fraudulent conveyance of an undivided one-half interest in realty to wife, executed guarantee of corporation's indebtedness to creditor since the...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Torregrossa v. Szelc
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Where there was no evidence of sham corporate structure and automobile purchaser knowingly made deal with corporate dealer, where there was nothing to indicate that dealer's vice-president personally was owner of business, where vice-president, who owned only 50 percent of the stock, was not shown to dominate corporation in any way, where there was no direct evidence that corporate formalities were not involved, and where there was no showing that capitalization of corporation for minimum statutory amount was an unfair device, corporate dealer was not alter ego of vice-president so as to make him personally liable in suit for breach of implied warranty of title of automobile purchased from dealer.
Document Preview: Suit was brought by automobile buyer against corporate dealer and its vice-president after automobile was seized by bank upon prior lien. The District Court No. 190, Harris County, John H. Miller, P. J., rendered judgment for buyer, and dealer and vice-president appealed. The Houston Court of Civil Appeals, Fourteenth Supreme Judicial District, Miller, J., 596 S.W.2d 299, affirmed, and vice-president petitioned for relief. The Supreme Court, Barrow, J., held that evidence did not support finding that dealer was alter ego of vice-president so as to make him personally liable for judgment. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Village Press, Inc. v. Stephen Edward Co., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of New Hampshire.
Headnote: Evidence, which failed to establish that controlling stockholder suppressed fact that his businesses were incorporated, that he made any agreement to hold himself personally responsible for his corporations' debts or that he used corporate entities to promote his own personal business, was insufficient to hold controlling stockholder personally liable for debts of two corporations which he controlled.
Document Preview: Creditor brought suit against two corporations and their controlling stockholder for monies due under an agreement. The Superior Court, Merrimack County, Johnson, J., entered judgment against both corporations and stockholder individually, and reserved and transferred stockholder's exceptions. The Supreme Court, Brock, J., held that evidence, which failed to establish that controlling stockholder suppressed fact that his businesses were incorporated, that he made any agreement to hold himself personally responsible for his corporations' debts or that he used corporate entities to promote his own personal business, was insufficient to hold controlling stockholder personally liable for debts of two corporations which he controlled. Exceptions sustained; judgment against stockholder in individual capacity vacated.

Title: In re Enforcement of a Money Judgment
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Judgment creditor did not adequately establish that corporation was "alter ego" of another defendant; however, inasmuch as there was some indication in record that judgment creditor could establish such fact, judgment creditor was entitled to leave to renew that branch of application seeking recovery against corporation.
Document Preview: Appeal and cross appeal were taken from an order of the Supreme Court, New York County, Helman, J., which, inter alia, denied judgment creditor's application for judgment against various defendants. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that assignee of agreement was liable under subsequent indemnity agreement for unsatisfied judgment obtained by judgment creditor against indemnitee. Ordered in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Matter of Twin Lakes Village, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Claimant judgment creditor, having failed to establish, by a preponderance of the evidence, either the second or third elements of the McCleary alter ego test, could not satisfy its claim against any of the debtors, whom claimant alleged to be the alter ego of its corporate judgment debtor and to be liable to claimant for property transferred to them by claimant's judgment debtor.
Document Preview: On debtors' objections to certain claims filed by a corporation's judgment creditor in the instant bankruptcy and Chapter XI arrangement proceedings, the Bankruptcy Court, Lloyd D. George, C. J., held, inter alia, that: (1) in respect to judgment creditor's claim that the debtors were obligated to the corporate judgment debtor and that the judgment creditor could therefore assert against the debtors the judgment debt owing it from the corporate entity, both a legal and a factual foundation was lacking to support claimant's right to recovery in bankruptcy court, and (2) claimant judgment creditor, having failed to establish by a preponderance of the evidence either the second or third elements of the McCleary alter ego test, could not satisfy its claim against any of the debtors, whom claimant alleged to be the alter ego of its corporate judgment debtor and to be liable to claimant for property transferred to them by claimant's judgment debtor. Objections sustained.

Title: Ramsey v. Adams
Court: Court of Appeals of Kansas.
Headnote: In action brought by merchants seeking to hold sole stockholder of corporation personally liable for debt incurred in name of the corporation, there was not substantial competent evidence produced at trial to establish basis for liability either on theory of alter ego or reliance on personal guarantee of the shareholder.
Document Preview: Merchants brought action against sole stockholder of corporation seeking to hold him personally liable for debts incurred in the name of the corporation. The District Court, Edwards County, C. Phillip Aldrich, J., entered judgment holding stockholder personally liable, and stockholder appealed. The Court of Appeals, Parks, J., held that there was not substantial competent evidence produced at trial to establish a basis for liability either on theory of alter ego or reliance on personal guarantee of the shareholder. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Chapman v. Field
Court: Supreme Court of Arizona, In Banc.
Headnote: Evidence that stockholders lent money to corporation without taking promissory notes, that they failed to file annual reports and failed to keep proper books of account was insufficient to prove that the corporation was the alter ego of the shareholders where there was no showing of fraud on the part of shareholders or any indication that parties who sold car wash to corporation were misled.
Document Preview: Secured sellers brought suit against corporation and shareholders seeking a deficiency judgment and contending that the corporation was merely an alter ego of the shareholders. The Superior Court of Maricopa County, Cause No. C-336609, Kenneth C. Chatwin, J., found that the corporation was not alter ego of the shareholders but allowed sellers to obtain a deficiency judgment against defendant corporation, and sellers and corporation appealed. The Supreme Court, Cameron, C. J., held that: (1) the evidence was sufficient from which the trial court could find that the corporation was a valid corporation and not merely the alter ego of the shareholders, and (2) sellers were entitled to a deficiency only after a setoff of the damage to the debtor for failure to make a commercially reasonable sale. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Grayson v. Nordic Const. Co., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Washington, En Banc.
Headnote: Finding that individual defendant operated as corporate defendant's alter ego, thus justifying piercing corporate veil on an alter ego theory, was not supported by substantial evidence.
Document Preview: Suit was instituted for breach of contract to repair a home. The Superior Court, King County, Frank J. Eberharter, J., entered judgment for plaintiffs, and individual defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, 22 Wash.App. 143, 589 P.2d 283, reversed, and plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, Williams, J., held that: (1) individual defendant could be held personally liable as a corporate officer who participated in a violation of Consumer Protection Act by directing the mailing of a deceptive advertising brochure received by plaintiff, and (2) statutory provision authorizing attorney fees for a person who is injured in his business or property by violation of Consumer Protection Act is a sufficient basis for imposition of fees on an individual who is personally liable as a corporate officer by participating in the violation of Act. Decision of the Court of Appeals reversed and judgment of the Superior Court reinstated.

Title: Wolf v. Little John Corp. of Liberia
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: In holder's suit on promissory note against corporate maker and shareholders-officers for whom corporation was alleged "alter ego," evidence was factually sufficient to support findings by jury that the corporation was not such "alter ego" so as to permit personal liability to be imposed on the shareholders-officers.
Document Preview: Holder brought suit on promissory note against corporate maker and shareholders-officers for whom corporation was alleged alter ego. The District Court, Harris County, Richard Millard, J., entered judgment on jury verdict, and holder appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Wallace, J., held that: (1) where person who signed note was president of both corporations with same name, he and his two sisters were only directors of both corporations, resolution of the board of directors of one of the corporations authorized such person to execute note, the note was executed by all three directors, holder acknowledged reading such resolution, such person was authorized to sign the note as president of one of the similarly named corporations, and thus holder could not recover from such person on basis that there existed two principals with identical names and the note did not indicate one intended to be named so as to be equivalent to naming no principal and rendering person...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: William B. Roberts, Inc. v. McDrilling Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi.
Headnote: In suit brought by drilling contractor against corporate property owner and the president thereof, seeking to recover damages for breach of written contract or, alternatively, for fraud relating to the drilling of two wells, entry of judgment against the individual defendant was improper for the reason that there was no evidence to justify invoking the alter ego doctrine.
Document Preview: Drilling contractor brought suit against corporate property owner and the president thereof, seeking to recover damages for breach of written contract or, alternatively, for fraud relating to the drilling of two wells. The 23rd District Court, Wharton County, Neil Caldwell, J., rendered judgment for plaintiff, and defendants appealed. Title: Minich v. Gem State Developers, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho.
Headnote: In action against corporate developer and contractor and directors and controlling shareholders of corporation for specific performance of contract to sell suburban lot and custom-built house, substantial and competent evidence supported finding that directors treated developer corporation as their alter ego to warrant casting aside separate corporate existence.
Document Preview: Purchasers brought action for specific performance of contract to sell suburban lot and custom-built house against developer and contract corporations and the directors and controlling shareholders of the corporations. The District Court, Fourth Judicial District, Ada County, J. Ray Durtschi, J., rescinded the entire transaction and restored the parties to their precontract positions, and appeal was taken. The Supreme Court, McFadden, J., held that: (1) judgment imposing personal liability on directors and controlling shareholders of contractor corporation was proper; (2) developer corporation was liable for obligations incurred by directors in transaction as alter ego of directors, and (3) attorney fees were properly awarded in trial court but would not be awarded on appeal. Affirmed. Bakes, J., concurred specially and filed opinion. Bistline, J., concurred specially and filed opinion. Donaldson, J., concurred in part and dissented in part.

Title: Dwyer v. Burrell Leasing Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: In suit for alleged breach of employment contract, evidence was insufficient to support finding of jury that unincorporated defendants were alter ego of corporate defendant in their dealings with plaintiff.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from a judgment of the Circuit Court, Dade County, William A. Herin, J., dismissing the suit for alleged breach of an employment agreement. The District Court of Appeal, Pearson, J., held, inter alia, that the trial court erred in excluding evidence of a contract with a former employer containing restrictive covenants and obligations on the employee which had effect even after termination of his former employment. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Headnote: Evidence in action by Texas manufacturer against French corporations was not sufficient to substantiate claim that second French corporation was alter ego of first corporation for purposes of establishing prima facie breach of contract action against second corporation, notwithstanding dealings by manufacturer with individual who was director of both corporations.

Title: Bone Const. Co., Inc. v. Lewis
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Evidence in action against construction company and its president for failure to perform contract to build house was sufficient to raise issue requiring charge on liability of president on the contract due to commingling of assets or merger of the entities of the corporation and the president as individual.
Document Preview: Property owner brought action against construction company and its president for failure to perform contract to build house. The Clarke Superior Court, Gaines, J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of the property owner, and the president alone appealed. The Court of Appeals, Quillian, P. J., held that evidence was sufficient to raise issue requiring charge on liability of the president on the contract due to commingling of assets or merger of the entities of the corporation and the president as individual. Affirmed.

Title: Federal Ins. Co. v. Maritime Shipping Agencies, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Second Division.
Headnote: In supplementary proceeding, pleadings, depositions and affidavits on file established that there was such a unity of interest in ownership among judgment debtor, related corporation, and corporate owners that their individual identities had ceased to exist and that related corporation and owners were alter egos of judgment debtor and, as such, were liable for judgment debtor's obligations. S.H.A. ch. 110, § 73.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor sought to obtain satisfaction of judgment against corporate judgment debtor in supplementary proceeding against related corporation and owners of corporations. The Circuit Court, Cook County, Richard Samuels, J., granted judgment creditor's motion for summary judgment, finding a unity of interest and ownership among defendants and that related corporation and owners were alter egos of judgment debtor. On appeal, the Appellate Court, Downing, J., held that: (1) defendants were not denied their right to a trial on petition for turnover order by entry of summary judgment; (2) trial court did not err in striking portions of affidavit of owner filed in support of response to judgment creditor's motion for summary judgment; (3) related corporation and owners were alter egos of judgment debtor and were liable for its obligations, and (4) judgment creditor was entitled to recover reasonable costs and attorney fees incurred in defending frivolous appeal. Title: Mosa v. Wilson-Bates Furniture Co.

Headnote: Application of alter ego doctrine so as to hold stockholder and sole contributing investor liable for corporate debts was supported by substantial evidence.

Hoyt, J., found stockholder and sole contributing investor liable for corporate debt. On appeal, the Supreme Court held that application of alter ego doctrine so as to hold stockholder and sole contributing investor liable for debts of corporation was supported by substantial evidence. Affirmed.

Title: Inesco, Inc. v. Sears

Headnote: There was probative evidence to support finding that corporate board chairman, who was only shareholder to contribute money to corporation which purchased barge, who controlled financial matters of purchasing corporation and its transferee subsidiary, who told shareholders-directors that he would pay entire purchase price of barge, who admitted that he originally intended to acquire title to barge in his own name, who exchanged his stock in corporations for barge, and who admitted he was aware of indebtedness on vessel at time of transfer, but claimed that it was corporate obligation was alter ego of corporations and was personally liable for unpaid purchase price of barge.

Title: Hicks v. Wright

Headnote: Evidence was legally and factually insufficient to warrant piercing corporate veil, in suit to recover money paid to extinguish promissory note signed by two individual defendants as payor and guarantor, wherein it was contended that defendant corporations were alter egos of the individual defendants.

Title: Wikelund Wholesale Co., Inc. v. Tile World Factory Tile Warehouse

Headnote: Evidence indicating that individual defendant used accounts of his various corporations to pay debts of any one corporation and that money received by one corporation in which he had an interest might come to rest in accounts of another sustained trial court's disregard of corporate entity and judgment holding individual defendant, as principal and "alter ego" of various corporations, liable for unlawful exercise of dominion and control over merchandise belonging to plaintiff.

Title: Roy A. Schnebelen & Associates v. American Bank & Trust Co.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: In action in which, after completion of construction and closing of FHA insured, permanent loan on partnership's apartment project, partnership sought to recover against corporate mortgage broker and corporate interim-financing bank for amount paid bank as interest and "yield fees" during construction on theory that such amount was usurious and contrary to partnership's financing commitments with broker and FHA, evidence supported finding to effect that neither broker nor bank, both of which had, as a director, an attorney within law firm that handled the loan closings and legal work, was the alter ego of the other. National Housing Act, § 236 as amended 12 U.S.C.A. § 1715z-1.

Title: Amoco Chemicals Corp. v. Bach
Court: Supreme Court of Kansas.
Headnote: In action against president and principal stockholder of corporation for debt of corporation, evidence failed to establish basis for liability either on theory of alter ego or on theory of active participation by officer in fraud practiced against creditor.

Coffman, J., entered judgment in favor of plaintiff, and defendant appealed. Title: Fowler v. Elm Creek State Bank
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: In actions by debenture buyers against corporate issuer of debentures and individual defendants for losses sustained on debentures on grounds of fraud and negligent mismanagement and dissipation of corporate assets, evidence supported findings that individual defendants held themselves forth to be stockholders and assumed responsibilities of board of directors and that their activities as "stockholders" were so flagrantly fraudulent that corporate structure had to be disregarded and individual defendants, including those not making misrepresentations, had to be held liable.

The Supreme Court, McCown, J., held that: (1) evidence supported findings that individual defendants held themselves forth to be stockholders and assumed responsibilities of board of directors and that their activities as stockholders was so flagrantly fraudulent that corporate structure had to be disregarded and individual defendants had to be held liable; (2) an individual defendant could be held liable for...

Title: Kight v. Harris
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: President and sole owner of corporation was not liable for goods sold and delivered to the corporation absent evidence showing that president and sole owner treated corporation as a mere alter ego.
Document Preview: Action was brought for goods allegedly sold and delivered. The District Court, Dare County, Grafton G. Beaman, D. J., dismissed with prejudice complaint against corporate defendant's president and found that some, but not all, invoices proved debts and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, Arnold, J., held that (1) invoices which were not signed by officers, directors or agents of corporation did not establish debts and (2) president and sole owner of corporation could not be held liable for debts found to exist absent evidence that he treated the corporation as a mere alter ego. Affirmed.

Title: Scott Graphics, Inc. v. Mahaney
Court: Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Headnote: Evidence, in action seeking to hold officers and directors of defunct corporation personally liable for satisfaction of judgment against corporation, failed to support finding that defendants so manipulated corporation to further their own individual interests and to perpetrate fraud or injustice on creditors that corporation was alter ego of defendants.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from order of the District Court, Bernalillo County, James A. Maloney, J., entering judgment in favor of a plaintiff creditor in its suit to hold officers and directors of a defunct corporation personally liable for a judgment recovered against the corporation. The Court of Appeals, Hernandez, J., held that evidence failed to support the trial court's finding that the individual defendants had so manipulated the corporation to further their own individual interests and to perpetrate a fraud or injustice upon the creditor as to make the corporation the alter ego of the defendants. Reversed. Certiorari denied May 12, 1976.

Title: Holmes v. Clow
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Tyler.
Headnote: Plaintiff was not entitled to recover from individual defendant on theory that corporation which owed plaintiff money was alter ego of the individual and had been created for purpose of defrauding plaintiff and other creditors, where plaintiff raised nothing more than suspicion or surmise concerning the transactions which allegedly had effect of draining assets of corporation for individual defendant's own benefit.
Document Preview: Action was brought against corporation and its president to recover sum for blueprinting and design work for housing project to be constructed by defendant corporation. The 160th District Court, Dallas County, Leonard E. Hoffman, Jr., J., rendered judgment in favor of plaintiff against defendant corporation but rendered take nothing judgment against individual defendant and plaintiff appealed . The Court of Civil Appeals, Moore, J., held that plaintiff failed to show fraud in forming of corporation or in corporation's making other payments while plaintiff's bill was unpaid; that plaintiff failed to establish that individual defendant had used the corporation as a sham to perpetrate a fraud, or to avoid personal liability; and that finding that the corporate entity had not ceased to exist and had not become individual defendant's alter ego was not against overwhelming weight of evidence. Affirmed.

Title: Cooperman v. Unemployment Ins. Appeals Bd.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 5, California.
Headnote: In unemployment insurance case, finding that corporate president and sole shareholder was alter ego of corporation was not erroneous as matter of law and was supported by substantial evidence including evidence that his activities were directed toward self-employment and that he received no compensation as president because corporation had no assets other than right to supply to others his services as cameraman-director. West's Ann.Unempl.Ins.Code, §§ 401-411, 1252.
Document Preview: A referee determined that a corporate president and sole shareholder was eligible for unemployment insurance benefits when the corporation was inactive, though ineligible when the corporation was active. The Department of Human Resources, later the Employment Development Department, appealed. The Unemployment Insurance Appeals Board reversed the referee. The Superior Court, Los Angeles County, Campbell M. Lucas, J., upheld the referee's decision. The Board appealed. The Court of Appeal, Loring, J., held that a finding that the corporate president and sole shareholder was the alter ego of the corporation was supported by substantial evidence and was not erroneous as matter of law, and where the activities of the president and sole shareholder were directed towards self-employment and the alter ego doctrine was applicable, he was unemployed and eligible for benefits for the period while the corporation was inactive. Judgment of trial court affirmed.

Title: G. M. Leasing Corp. v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence showing, inter alia, that taxpayer had exclusive control over corporation whose directors had no duties and were merely figureheads, that corporation which was allegedly engaged in automobile leasing business, in fact, leased no automobiles, had no employees, issued no stock and had no stockholders' meetings and that automobiles allegedly owned by corporation were used by taxpayer for personal business established that corporation was taxpayer's alter ego so that its assets could be seized to satisfy taxpayer's federal income tax liability; thus, trial court's finding to the contrary, in action by corporation seeking damages arising out of seizure of its assets, was clearly erroneous.

Title: Chick v. Tomlinson

Headnote: Evidence which established, inter alia, that owner of lumber corporations was running a one-man show was sufficient to establish that identity of owner and corporations had indeed merged for purposes of doctrine authorizing disregard of corporate identity.
Document Preview: Lumber company managers brought action against employer lumber corporation and its owner seeking to collect sums allegedly due them under salary bonus contracts. The First Judicial District Court, of Kootenai County, James G. Towles, J., entered judgment for plaintiffs, and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Donaldson, J., held that evidence was sufficient to establish that identities of lumber corporation owner and corporation had merged; that record was sufficient to establish that disregard of corporate identity would procude equitable results; that acceptance of corporate checks by plaintiffs did not operate to estop plaintiffs from seeking satisfaction of judgment against corporation owner; that evidence was sufficient to establish oral salary bonus agreement providing for division between plaintiffs of 40 percent of the net profits over the first $25,000; that inventory adjustment which resulted in understatement of profits was correctly rejected by trial court as...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: National Marine Service, Inc. v. C. J. Thibodeaux & Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence in suit by shipyard to recover value of repairs performed upon vessel owned by partnership supported finding that corporate entity to which vessel was chartered was a mere alter ego of owners; that the bareboat charter was a fiction and that repairs which were ordered by person hired to run the vessel were performed for the benefit of owners with their actual and constructive knowledge.
Document Preview: Shipyard brought action against owners of vessel to recover for repairs performed upon vessel at instance of person hired by charter party. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas at Houston, Woodrow B. Seals, J., 380 F.Supp. 1076 entered judgment requiring owners to pay the fair cost of repairs and owners appealed. The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that evidence supported finding that corporate charter party was a mere alter ego of owners; that bareboat charter was a fiction and that repairs were performed for benefit of owners; and that shipyard's failure to discover relationship between charter party and owners before starting on repairs did not affect any in personam rights the shipyard acquired. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Inland Sec. Co., Inc. v. Kirshner's Estate
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Western Division.
Headnote: Under evidence, president, director and controlling stockholder of bankrupt corporation was alter ego of bankrupt. Bankr.Act, § 67, subs. d, d(1)(e), (2)(a), 11 U.S.C.A. § 107(d), (d)(1)(e), (2)(a).
Document Preview: A referee in bankruptcy concluded that the transfer of a note secured by deed of trust was fraudulent and void under the Bankruptcy Act. The estate of the deceased transferee, who had been the president, director, managing officer and controlling stockholder of the bankrupt corporation at the time of the transfer, appealed. The District Court, William H. Becker, Chief Judge, held that there was not a present fair equivalent given for the transfer, that an antecedent debt from the bankrupt had not been satisfied in an amount fairly proportionate in value to the note transferred and that the transfer, made within one year prior to filing of the bankruptcy petition, was not made in good faith. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Lipschutz v. Gordon Jewelry Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Evidence in action against corporation which had substantial ownership and substantial commonality of boards of directors with jeweler to which New York diamond dealer had sent merchandise under "all-risk" memorandum was sufficient to establish that corporation and jeweler were not separate and distinct and corporation could be held jointly and severally liable.
Document Preview: Action against jewelry store and corporation which had substantial ownership interest therein by New York diamond dealer for damages sustained as result of loss of merchandise sent by dealer to jeweler under all-risk memorandum. The District Court, Carl O. Bue, Jr., J., held that New York law applied, that under custom and practice in diamond industry jeweler was liable for memorandum price plus interest but not punitive damages, and that corporation having substantial ownership of jeweler was jointly and severally liable. Judgment accordingly.

Title: Metropolitan St. Louis Sewer Dist. v. Zykan
Court: Supreme Court of Missouri, Division No. 1.
Headnote: Evidence in action to compel defendants to construct drainage ditch in subdivision, warranted finding that all defendants were the alter ego and under domination and control of one individual defendant, and that all defendants were liable and responsible to plaintiffs for the individual's acts.
Document Preview: Sewer district and owners of homes in subdivision brought action to compel developers of subdivision to construct drainage ditch and for damages. The Circuit Court, St. Louis County, John J. Kelly, Jr., J., ordered developers to construct drainage ditch and awarded damages to homeowners, and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Higgins, C., held that even though costs of building storm water drainage ditch had risen between date in 1962 that subdivision developers contracted with homeowners in subdivision to construct ditch and date of 1967 action to compel construction of ditch, where developers regularly represented that drainage improvement would be constructed but did nothing toward proposed construction and met inquiries as to when ditch was to be built with stall and delay tactics, delay of sewer district and individual homeowners in bringing action to compel construction of ditch did not cause developers to change their position of doing nothing and developers during...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: House of Koscot Development Corp. v. American Line Cosmetics, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence in action against defendant corporations and individual defendant for breach of contract between plaintiff corporation and one of the defendant corporations relating to the selling of subfranchises supported inference that the cancellation of sold subfranchise by one of the defendant corporations was ordered by individual defendant to protect his own interest and those of the other defendant corporations and that in cancelling sale defendant corporation operated under the domination and control of the other defendants.
Document Preview: Diversity action for breach of contract. The United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida, at Orlando, Duncan, J., entered judgment for plaintiff corporation and the defendant corporations and individual appealed. The Court of Appeals, Clark, Circuit Judge, held, inter alia, that evidence in action against defendant corporations and individual defendant for breach of contract between plaintiff corporation and one of the defendant corporations relating to the selling of subfranchises supported inference that the cancellation of sold subfranchise by one of the defendant corporations was ordered by individual defendant to protect his own interest and those of the other defendant corporations and that in cancelling sale defendant corporation operated under the domination and control of the other defendants. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Arnold v. Browne
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Evidence supported inferences that there was not such unity of interest between individuals and corporation, which was formed for purpose of transferring to it the existing assets and liabilities of partnership, via standard promoter's agreement with intent and consequences thereof known and understood by all parties, and affairs of which were conducted in normal corporate fashion, with no corporate assets converted to personal use of individuals and no corporate funds commingled with private funds, as to destroy individuality of corporation.
Document Preview: From that portion of the judgment of the Superior Court, Santa Clara County, George H. Barnett, J., denying recovery in action against individual defendants on ground of alter ego, plaintiffs appealed. Certain individual defendants appealed from portion of judgment denying them attorney's fees. The Court of Appeal, Taylor, P.J., held that evidence supported inferences that there was not such unity of interest between individuals and corporation, which was formed for purpose of transferring to it the existing assets and liabilities of partnership, via standard promoter's agreement with intent and consequences thereof known and understood by all parties, and affairs of which were conducted in normal corporate fashion, with no corporate assets converted to personal use of individuals and no corporate funds commingled with private funds, as to destroy individuality of corporation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Dietel v. Day
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 2.
Headnote: Record established that corporation was guilty of numerous breaches of franchise contract and for that reason judgment in favor of franchisees against corporation should stand, but record failed to show fraud or mingling of funds or unity of interests of shareholder and director who subsequently became president of the corporation so as to justify holding him personally liable for the corporation's debts.
Document Preview: Action for infringement of trade names, trademarks and unfair competition, wherein a defendant filed a third-party complaint against a codefendant as the alter ego of the corporation for breach of contract. From a judgment of the Superior Court, Pima County, Cause No. 108404, Laurance T. Wren, J., the codefendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Krucker, C.J., held, inter alia, that record established that corporation was guilty of numerous breaches of franchise contract and for that reason judgment in favor of franchisees against corporation should stand, but record failed to show fraud or mingling of funds or unity of interests of shareholder and director who subsequently became president of the corporation so as to justify holding him personally liable for the corporation's debts. Judgment reversed as applied to codefendant personally.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: People ex rel. Scott v. Pintozzi
Court: Supreme Court of Illinois.
Headnote: Evidence sustained trial court's findings that corporations which had operated retail liquor establishments and failed to pay retailers' occupation tax were alter egos of individuals and that such individuals were liable for tax. S.H.A. ch. 120, §§ 443, 444, 4521/212.
Document Preview: Action to collect retailers' occupation tax from individuals who were real parties in interest in various liquor establishments which failed to pay tax. The Circuit Court, Cook County, George M. Leighton, J., found for state and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Ryan, J., held that evidence sustained trial court's findings that corporations which had operated retail liquor establishments and failed to pay retailers' occupation tax were alter egos of individuals and that such individuals were liable for tax. The Court further held that where wives of parties who were real parties in interest in liquor stores which had failed to pay retailers' occupation tax had interests in real estate prior to period involved in collection of unremitted tax, wives' interests should not have been included in constructive trust imposed for purposes of collecting tax. Affirmed in part and reversed in part and remanded, with directions. Ward, J., took no part in consideration or decision of case.

Title: Kilpatrick Bros., Inc. v. Poynter
Court: Supreme Court of Kansas.
Headnote: Evidence in action against husband and wife to pierce corporate veil and to establish personal liability for corporate debt supported finding that corporations in question were alter ego of husband.
Document Preview: Action against husband and wife to pierce corporate veil and to establish personal liability for corporate debt. The Labette District Court, Hal Hyler, J., rendered judgment against husband and denied recovery against wife. Husband appealed and plaintiffs cross-appealed. The Supreme Court, Harman, C., held that where judgments had been entered against defunct defendant corporations in four separate suits and in each of such suits executions had been issued and returned unsatisfied, plaintiffs, who were aware that preliminary suits against such corporations would have been useless, were not required, under statute providing that suit cannot be brought against director or stockholder for any debt of corporation until judgment be obtained against corporation and execution thereon returned unsatisfied, in whole or in part, to bring suit against such corporations prior to institution of suit against directors and stockholders of corporations. Affirmed. Fontron, J., concurred in part...

Title: Harris v. Curtis
Court: Court of Appeal, Fifth District, California.
Headnote: Evidence failed to establish that stockholders of corporations were alter ego of corporations.
Document Preview: Action to recover monies advanced corporation from corporation and its shareholders who allegedly were alter ego of corporation. The Superior Court, Kings County, Robert R. Rosson, J., granted judgment against corporation but denied recovery from shareholders and lender appealed. The Court of Appeal, Coakley, J., held that individuals who were shareholders of corporation which had paid in capital of $1,000 of which $811.12 was used for expenses of incorporation were not alter ego of corporation and liable for monies advanced to corporation. Affirmed.

Title: Texas Industries, Inc. v. Dupuy & Dupuy Developers, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence on issue whether stockholder and officer of corporation used corporation for advancement of his personal affairs, whether he exercised control over its affairs or operations, or whether he received benefit therefrom did not warrant finding, in action in which shareholder and officer was sought to be held personally liable for corporate debt, of fraud, deception, or ill practices on part of stockholder and officer. LSA-C.C. arts. 435-437; LSA-R.S. 12:93, subd. B, 12:95.
Document Preview: Action by materialman to recover for materials sold and for recognition of its materialman's lien and privilege on property. Property owner brought third-party proceeding to recover for any amount for which it might be condemned from title insurer. Title insurer brought similar proceeding against corporation, which purchased materials, and two of corporation's stockholders. The 26th Judicial District Court, Parish of Bossier, O. E. Price, J., found for plaintiffs and found for title insurer in solido for amount awarded plaintiff against corporation. Stockholder appealed. The Court of Appeal, Ayres, J., held that evidence on issue whether stockholder and officer of corporation used corporation for advancement of his personal affairs, whether he exercised any control over its affairs or operations, or whether he received benefits therefrom did not warrant finding of fraud, deception or ill practices on part of stockholder and officer. Reversed and rendered.

Title: Baer v. Amos J. Walker, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Evidence, in suit on note against corporation and its manager, was insufficient to support finding that corporation was manager's alter ego.
Document Preview: Suit on note against corporation and its manager. The Second Judicial District Court, Washoe County, John E. Gabrielli, J., entered judgment in favor of plaintiff, and appeal was taken. The Supreme Court, Zenoff, J., held that evidence was insufficient to support finding that corporation was manager's alter ego. Affirmed in part, reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Erlin-Lawler Enterprises, Inc. v. Fire Ins. Exchange
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 5, California.
Headnote: Evidence, in action on policies covering loss by fire to equipment and stock in trade of corporate plaintiff, was insufficient to support determination that corporate plaintiff was merely alter ego of individual plaintiffs who had been convicted of arson for setting fire. West's Ann.Civ.Code, § 3517; West's Ann.Insurance Code, § 533.
Document Preview: Action to recover on policies covering loss by fire to equipment and stock in trade of corporate plaintiff. Insurer cross-complained. The Superior Court of Los Angeles County, Harold W. Schweitzer, J., denied recovery on complaint and granted judgment on cross complaint, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeal, Aiso, J., held that evidence was insufficient to support determination that corporate plaintiff was merely alter ego of individual plaintiffs who had been convicted of arson for setting fire. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Worldwide Carriers, Limited v. Aris S. S. Co.
Court: United States District Court S.D. New York.
Headnote: Plaintiff which sued steamship company for breach of charter party and joined other defendants as steamship company's alter egos made out prima facie case that other defendants were alter egos of steamship company so as to warrant a piercing of the corporate veil and plaintiff should be given opportunity by discovery to ascertain other facts in support thereof.
Document Preview: Action for breach of charter party with steamship company, wherein other defendants were joined as company's alter egos. The defendants other than steamship company moved to set aside certain attachments, dismiss complaint, increase plaintiff's bond, and, in alternative, set reasonable bond for release of their assets from attachment. The District Court, Tenney, J., held that plaintiff made out prima facie case that other defendants were alter egos of steamship company so as to warrant a piercing of the corporate veil and plaintiff should be given opportunity by discovery to ascertain other facts in support thereof; that genuine issues as to intercorporate relationships between steamship company and other defendants and as to scope of settlement agreement entered into by other defendants and plaintiff and general releases from plaintiff were presented, precluding summary judgment for defendants other than steamship company. Motions denied. See also D.C., 290 F.Supp. 860; 301...

Title: Kaminsky v. Kahn
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Finding that corporation was controlled by buyer of stock and that it was his alter ego was supported by evidence.
Document Preview: Accounting proceeding in which cross appeals were taken from judgment of the Supreme Court, Trial Term, New York County, Matthew M. Levy, J., in favor of seller. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that under contract for sale of a corporation's stock providing that if buyer desired to sell any of stock purchased he was required to submit written evidence of a bona fide purchase offer to seller who had right and option to purchase the shares upon the terms set forth in the offer, buyer who also owed other stock not subject to option, had duty upon selling stock in that corporation to first sell stock sold him by seller, even though buyer was not a fiduciary. The Court further held that where sale of unregistered stock, such as that transferred to buyer, was worth about 30 to 60% Less than registered stock traded on the exchange, holding buyer accountable for market price, less cost of registering stock, was error and judgment was modified to charge buyer only with actual...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Sirloin Room, Inc. v. American Emp. Ins. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence in garnishment proceedings in aid of execution on judgment supported judgment of District Court that garnishee corporations were virtually the alter ego of individual defendant, the judgment debtor, and were liable as garnishees for the specified amounts rendered.
Document Preview: Garnishment proceedings in aid of execution. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana, Herbert W. Christenberry, J., entered a judgment against corporations as garnishees and the garnishees appealed. The Court of Appeals held that evidence in garnishment proceedings in aid of execution on judgment supported findings of District Court that garnishee corporations were virtually the alter ego of individual defendant, the judgment debtor, and were liable as garnishees for the specified amounts rendered. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Linco Services, Inc. v. DuPont
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: In view of proof that there was such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities no longer existed, individual could not avoid piercing of corporate veil on claim of lack of showing that corporation and individuals were business conduits of one another.
Document Preview: Action against corporation and two individuals on alter ego theory on note made by corporation. The Superior Court, County of San Mateo, Frank W. Rose, J., rendered judgment against all defendants and one of the individual defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Draper, P. J., held that where appellant by written agreement, active participation and guaranty to bank clothed corporation with indicia of financial stability, secured its reentry into active business after dormancy caused by financial weakness, entered upon active participation in its affairs as director and officer, from which positions he attempted to resign when finances toppled, and he shared responsibility for failure of corporation to issue any stock, court could properly hold him individually liable on a note given to corporation in connection with purchase of an airplane on ground that corporation was his alter ego. Affirmed.

Title: Milton Meyer & Co. v. Curro
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Evidence in broker's action against individual and corporate defendants to recover commission on sale of corporate real estate was such that trier of fact could find that corporation was in reality the alter ego of particular defendant and that corporate entity should be disregarded so that a personal liability could be imposed upon her.
Document Preview: Broker's action against corporate and individual defendants to recover real estate commission on sale of property. The Superior Court, County of San Francisco, H. A. van der Zee, J., granted motions of defendants for nonsuit and the plaintiff broker appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Agee, J., held that on granting of respective motions, which would be treated as motions for judgment, trial court was required to make findings in accordance with statute and failure to do so required reversal of judgment, and appeal on minute orders was nonappealable. Judgment vacated and set aside, purported appeal from minute orders dismissed, and cause remanded with instructions.

Title: Linsenmeyer v. MGM Laboratories, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence in action against corporate and individual defendants to recover for services rendered in reproduction of film supported finding that defendant corporations were alter ego of individual defendant.
Document Preview: Diversity action against corporate and individual defendants to recover for services rendered in reproduction of film. The United States District Court for the District of Arizona, Walter M. Bastian, J., entered judgment for the plaintiff, and one individual defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals held that evidence supported finding that defendant corporations were alter ego of individual defendant. Affirmed.

Title: Carey v. Glenco Citrus Products Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, Fourth District, California.
Headnote: Evidence in quiet title action supported finding that individual and two corporate defendants were one and the same legal entity.
Document Preview: Action by owners of orange groves to quiet title thereto against several defendants including one which had purchased crop from plaintiff's tenants prior to declaration of default in leases. The Superior Court of Orange County, William S. Lee, J., rendered judgment for plaintiffs on the complaint and in favor of the defendant buyer of crop on cross complaint, finding that plaintiffs had converted orange crop, and awarding damages. Plaintiffs appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Coughlin, J., held that where, while lease was in effect and prior to tenant's default in payment of taxes and rent, tenant made sale of growing orange crop, title of buyer of crop and its right to go on land for harvesting purposes were not affected by termination of lease because of default, and landlord's refusal to permit buyer to harvest it constituted conversion. Affirmed in part and reversed in part with instructions.

Title: Blond Lighting Fixture Supply Co. v. Funk
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: In absence of indication that corporation was formed as means of perpetrating fraud, that it was operated as mere tool or business conduit of another corporation or as alter ego of an individual, that corporate form was being used as means of evading existing obligations, to circumvent statute, to protect crime or to justify wrong, there was no justification for disregarding corporate entity, or piercing corporate veil in order to impose liability on two directors as to goods sold to corporation on open account. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21, subd. A.
Document Preview: Suit on open account to recover for goods sold and delivered to corporation and for attorney's fees, wherein plaintiff sought judgment against corporation and individual defendants. The 131st District Court, Bexar County, Delos Finch, J., entered summary judgment that plaintiff recover from corporation and that it take nothing against individual defendants and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Cadena, J., held that if incorporator had paid for his stock, as alleged in affidavit of counsel of plaintiff, incorporator could not be liable under section of Business Corporation Act providing that stockholder is under no obligation to corporation or shareholders other than obligation to pay corporation full amount of consideration for shares and that whether one of original incorporators had paid for such shares of stock personally, whether they had been paid for by another as gift to incorporator or whether they had been paid for by such other person and held by...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: B & R Const. Co. v. Duvigneaud
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Substantial evidence supported finding that officer of corporation who appropriated joint adventure property and corporation which was beneficiary of joint venture agreement were indistinguishable in the law.
Document Preview: Suit for breach of contract for construction and sale of houses and for equal division of profits. The Twenty-Fourth Judicial District Court in and for the Parish of Jefferson, Division C, No. 75553, Robert G. Hughes, J., entered a judgment for the plaintiff building contractor, and the defendants appealed. The Court of Appeal, Regan, J., held that plaintiff building contractor who was engaged in joint venture with defendant lot owners to construct two houses and sell them for a profit which would be equally divided was entitled to one-half of the profits of the venture as of date defendant owners terminated it by moving into completed dwellings and encumbering them with excessive mortgages. Affirmed. See also, La.App., 168 So.2d 468.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Financial Counsellors, Inc. v. Securities and Exchange Commission
Court: United States Court of Appeals Second Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence sustained finding of Securities and Exchange Commission that corporate broker and dealer in securities was nothing more than alter ego of individual and that his informal but complete and effective control of corporation was in no way disclosed in corporation's registration application to Securities and Exchange Commission or in any application for amendments to it. Securities Exchange Act of 1934, § 15(b), 15 U.S.C.A. § 78o(b).
Document Preview: Proceeding to review order of Securities and Exchange Commission revoking Registration of corporation as broker and dealer in securities. The Court of Appeals held that where corporate broker and dealer in securities was nothing more than alter ego of individual who had imformal but complete and effective control of corporation and such control was in no was disclosed in corporation's application to Securities and exchange Commission or in application for amendments to it, revocation by Commission of registration of corporation as broker and dealer in securities was warranted. Affirmed.

Title: Obermer v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court D. Hawai‘i.
Headnote: On basis of evidence presented in tax refund case, court disagreed with government's contention that husband-and-wife fully-owned investment corporation was simply alter-ego of taxpayer and his spouse and that value of decedent's shares should be determined by using full market value on stock exchange of stocks held by corporation. 26 U.S.C.A. (I.R.C.1954) § 2031(a, b).
Document Preview: Action to recover estate tax paid. The District Court, Tavares, J., held that evidence established that fair market value of decedent's shares in husband-and-wife fully-owned investment corporation was figure determined by deducting 33 1/3% Of adjusted book value. Order accordingly.
