Title: Farmers Warehouse of Pelham, Inc. v. Collins
Court: Supreme Court of Georgia.
Headnote: To establish alter ego doctrine, it must be shown that stockholders' disregard of corporate entity made it mere instrumentality for transaction of their own affairs and that there is such unity of interest in ownership that separate personalities of corporation and owners no longer exist and that to adhere to doctrine of corporate entity would promote injustice or protect fraud.
Document Preview: Action to enjoin sale of assets of corporation, for appointment of receiver, for breach of stock purchase agreement between plaintiff and sole stockholders of corporation, and for reformation of stock purchase agreement. The Superior Court, Mitchell County, Carl E. Crow, J., overruled the defendants' demurrers to the amended petition, and the defendants brought error. The Supreme Court, Mobley, J., held that petition failed to state cause of action for breach of contract but that it did state cause of action against defendant corporation under theory of quantum meruit. Judgment affirmed in part; reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Sirmons v. Arnold Lumber Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Second District.
Headnote: Where it was not shown that dealings of corporation were not entirely corporate, that creditor dealt in anywise with president of such corporation or relied on any representations made by him, that creditor was victimized by fraud or bad faith or that corporation was alter ego of its president, execution on judgment against corporation could not be satisfied from personal assets of its president though he held 90% of the stock.
Document Preview: The Civil and Criminal Court of Record for Pinellas County, B. J. Driver, J., held that execution of a judgment against a defendant corporation could be satisfied from the personal assets of the corporate president. The president appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Barns, Paul D., Associate Judge, held that where it was not shown that dealings of the corporation were not entirely corporate, that the plaintiff creditor dealt in anywise with the president or relied on any representations made by him, that the creditor was victimized by fraud or bad faith or that the corporation was the alter ego of its president, execution on the judgment could not be satisfied from personal assets of its president though he held 90% of the stock. Reversed without prejudice to further like proceedings.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Auer v. Frank
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: In action against corporation and individual defendants on obligations incurred by corporation on construction contract, evidence warranted trial court's conclusion that there was no unity of interest and ownership in corporation and defendants and that separate personalities of corporation and individuals continued to exist.
Document Preview: Action wherein plaintiff general contractor sought to hold individual defendants responsible for obligations incurred by the corporate defendant on a construction contract. From a judgment of the Superior Court, Alameda County, C. Stanley Wood, Judge pro tem., in favor of the individual defendants, the general contractor appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Molinari, J., held that the application of the alter ego doctrine was an issue in the case and that a finding of the court upon it was implied. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Radio Electronics Supply Co. v. Smith
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that president and principal owner of inactive corporation was carrying on sole proprietorship within corporate shell during period of time in which corporate note was executed.
Document Preview: Suit on note. The Circuit Court, Wexford County, William R. Peterson, J., entered judgment for the plaintiff, and the individual defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Adams, J., held that president and principal owner of inactive corporation, who failed to respond to letters of Corporation and Securities Commission advising him of deficiencies in annual reports of corporation and who failed to complete such reports, was liable individually on corporation's note. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Lange v. Liberty Nat. Ins. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence sustained finding that corporation which allegedly collected premiums after selling policies but had not paid amount collected to insurer was an entity separate and apart from plaintiff sued on cross claim by defendant insurer for amount of premiums on basis that corporation was alter ego or instrumentality of plaintiff.
Document Preview: Suit by stockholder against corporation for subscription price paid for stock. The United States District Court for the District of Idaho, Chase A. Clark, J., entered judgment adverse to plaintiff, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Madden, Judge, held that stockholder failed to establish fraud and misrepresentation with respect to his payment of some $50,000 to corporation for purchase of stock on basis that he attached certain conditions to his subscription and payment, that conditions were agreed to by defendant corporation, but were never fulfilled and that defendant took plaintiff's money and refused to return it. Order dismissing plaintiff's suit affirmed and order dismissing defendant's cross claim affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: McKee v. Peterson
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Findings that there existed such unity of interest and control between corporate automobile dealer and officers thereof that corporation was alter ego of those persons and corporate entity should be disregarded, and that individuals be made liable to seller of automobile, which received a worthless corporation check in payment thereof, were supported by substantial evidence.
Document Preview: Automobile seller's action against chattel mortgagee and others. The Superior Court, County of San Mateo, Edmund Scott, J., entered a judgment in favor of the mortgagee and the seller and one of the individual defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Bray, P. J., held that seller of automobile to dealer, which gave check that was dishonored, was estopped to claim ownership of automobile as against bona fide mortgagee who had relied on indicia of ownership, except possession of automobile, furnished by seller to dealer which mortgagee had no reason to suspect would give a check that would be dishonored. Judgment reversed and cause remanded with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Wilson v. Roppolo
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Inference that corporate purchaser of land from vendor was merely instrument of purchaser whom broker, suing for commissions on sale, procured was supported by evidence.
Document Preview: Real estate broker's action against vendor for commissions on sale of real property. The Superior Court, County of Sonoma, Hilliard Comstock, J., entered a judgment for the broker and the vendor appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Bray, P. J., held that the broker who brought purchaser and vendor together while open listing agreement was still in effect was entitled to commission on sale even though the exact terms of the sale were not completely arrived at during time of listing and the vendor took all negotiations out of broker's hand during the listing period. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Houston-American Life Ins. Co. v. Tate
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Waco.
Headnote: Evidence in action against finance company, holding company, and life insurance company for damages for conduct in collecting loan supported finding that finance company and insurance company were mere departments of holding company, and justified disregarding corporate entity to render judgment against all three. Vernon's Ann.Civ.St. arts. 7426, 7429; V.A.T.S. Insurance Code, art. 3.53, § 4.
Document Preview: Action by husband and wife against finance company, life insurance company, and their common holding company for damages on account of wrongful conduct in seeking to enforce usurious contract. Wife as executrix was substituted for husband upon suggestion of his death. The 44th District Court, Dallas County, Sam B. Hall, J., rendered judgment for plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Tirey, J., held that the husband's cause of action for exemplary damages survived, and that the judgment was proper except that exemplary damages awarded were excessive. Judgment reformed in conformity with remittitur and affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Holloway v. International Bankers Life Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: Evidence in corporation's suit against its former officers and directors warranted conclusion that another corporation was alter ego of two defendants, employed by them for their own purposes, and activities which were carried out for their private benefit warranted piercing its corporate veil.
Document Preview: Corporation's action against former officers and directors for fraud and conspiracy. The District Court, Tarrant County, Harold Craik, J., rendered a judgment for the plaintiffs and two defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Massey, C. J., held that evidence was sufficient to support findings that defendants had manipulated affairs of company so as to derive personal profits from transaction by which land was acquired for company but would not sustain findings that they had prevented registration of stock. Affirmed in part and reversed in part and rendered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: McCombs v. Rudman
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Evidence sustained finding that there was no alter ego relationship between general contracting company and any of individual defendants, except one, and corporations formed by such individuals to take title to lots on which homes were built by company and that electrical contractor could not obtain judgment against such individuals and corporations for amount due for electrical work.
Document Preview: Action by electrical contractor against general contractor and others for amount due for electrical work in housing subdivision and for foreclosure on mechanics' lien. From a judgment of the Superior Court, Los Angeles County, Ray P. Brockmann, J., in favor of electrical contractor against general contractor alone, and denying foreclosure of lien, the electrical contractor appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Shinn, P. J., held that evidence established that general contracting company was the alter ego of sole stockholder, who served as president and who turned over all of his individual business to the company upon incorporation and conducted the affairs of the corporation as principal officer, rendering president liable for amounts owing by company to electrical contractor. Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: McCombs v. Rudman
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Evidence established that general contracting company was alter ego of sole stockholder, who served as president and who turned over all of his individual business to company upon incorporation and conducted affairs of corporation as principal officer, rendering president liable for amounts owing by company to electrical contractor.
Document Preview: Action by electrical contractor against general contractor and others for amount due for electrical work in housing subdivision and for foreclosure on mechanics' lien. From a judgment of the Superior Court, Los Angeles County, Ray P. Brockmann, J., in favor of electrical contractor against general contractor alone, and denying foreclosure of lien, the electrical contractor appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Shinn, P. J., held that evidence established that general contracting company was the alter ego of sole stockholder, who served as president and who turned over all of his individual business to the company upon incorporation and conducted the affairs of the corporation as principal officer, rendering president liable for amounts owing by company to electrical contractor. Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Wheeler v. Superior Mortg. Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: Evidence sustained findings in action to recover treble interest payments made on usurious loan transactions, that loans were made by defendants with usurious intent, that corporations involved were alter egos for each other and for individual defendants, and that loans were in fact made by defendants, and not by other parties. West's Ann.Civ.Code, § 1916-1 et seq.; West's Ann.Const. art. 20, § 22.
Document Preview: Action to recover treble interest payments made on two usurious loan transactions. From a judgment of the Superior Court, Los Angeles County, David Coleman, J., for the plaintiff, the defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Balthis, J., held that the evidence sustained the findings, and that the lender's bidding in the property securing the loans at the trustee's sale for an amount including the interest claimed was the equivalent of payment by the borrower and justified application of the treble damage provision of the Usury Act. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Minton v. Cavaney
Court: Supreme Court of California, In Bank.
Headnote: Evidence, including testimony that defendant was not only secretary and treasurer of a corporation, but also a director, and was to receive one-third of shares to be issued in the corporation, and that there was no attempt to provide adequate capitalization for the corporation, sustained finding that defendant was an equitable owner of the corporation.
Document Preview: Action to hold a corporate director personally liable upon a judgment recovered against a corporation. Subsequent to commencement of the action, the director died and executrix of his estate was substituted as defendant. The Superior Court, Los Angeles County, Frederick F. Houser, J., entered judgment adverse to defendant and she appealed. The Supreme Court, Traynor, J., held that corporate director could not be held personally liable upon a judgment against the corporation for negligence, without an opportunity to relitigate issues of corporation's negligence and amount of damages, where director was not a party to action against the corporation and did not control the litigation leading to the judgment against the corporation. Judgment reversed. Schauer and McComb, JJ., dissented in part. Opinion, 12 Cal.Rptr. 86, vacated.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: City Bank Farmers Trust Co. v. Macfadden
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: In action by the trustee and wife to hold foundation for income deficiency under separation agreement, evidence did not establish that foundation, a membership corporation, was the alter ego of the husband in the sense of making it responsible for his debts and obligations.
Document Preview: Action for a judicial settlement of the account of plaintiff as trustee under a deed of trust. From an interlocutory judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term, Edgar J. Nathan, Jr., J., 25 Misc.2d 125, 198 N.Y.S.2d 782, the defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Eager, J., held that the evidence did not establish that transfers of funds and property by husband in his lifetime to a foundation were fraudulent as to the former wife or in violation of the Debtor and Creditor Law and that a prior New Jersey judgment was not res judicata. Judgment modified. Stevens and McNally, JJ., dissented in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Moore & Moore Drilling Co. v. White
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Evidence in action by driller of oil well to recover contract price from individual who owned corporation with which drilling contract was made failed to establish confidential relation between individual and driller, to show any fraud, or to show that individual was guilty of bad faith in forming corporation or was alter ego of corporation.
Document Preview: Action by the driller of an oil well to recover the contract price from the individual who was the sole owner of the corporation with which the drilling contract was made. The District Court, Dallas County, Paul Peurifoy, J., withdrew the case from the jury and rendered a judgment for the individual, and the plaintiff appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Williams, J., held that the plaintiff's evidence showed no more than a suspicion of fraud, that the individual was not the corporation's alter ego, and that the individual and the corporation were not mining partners where there was never any joint operation of the well and the contract between them required the cost of the development to be paid solely by the corporation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Fontainebleau Hotel Corp. v. Crossman
Court: United States Court of Appeals Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that individual and corporation in whose name lease was executed were treated by the parties as inseparable and interchangeable.
Document Preview: Action by an individual, who operated stores under several different names, to restrain the landlord from evicting her and for specific performance of a lease which was renewable for five years at the tenant's option and was taken by the individual in the name of one of her stores. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, John D. Martin, Sr., J., rendered judgment for the individual, and the landlord appealed. The Court of Appeals, Wisdom, Circuit Judge, held that although the individual was not named as a party to the lease, the order was not erroneous where there was no prejudicial delay by the individual in asserting her rights and no showing that the individual intended to deceive the landlord, or that the landlord was concerned whether individual operated the premises individually, under a trade name, or as a separate corporate entity. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Walker v. Townsend
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence sustained findings in garnishment proceedings that the garnishee was not the employer of the debtor but that he was an employee of a corporation in which the garnishee was the principal stockholder where there was nothing to justify the conclusion that the corporation was wholly owned by the garnishee or that it was an alter ego for the garnishee.
Document Preview: Garnishment proceedings. From an adverse judgment in the Ninth Judicial District Court, Parish of Rapides, William A. Culpepper, J., the judgment creditors appealed. The Court of Appeal, Hood, J., held that the garnishee was not the employer of the debtor and that the answer filed by the garnishee was not invalid as not a sufficient compliance with the law. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Smith v. Royal Mfg. Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: The "alter ego" doctrine can apply only if corporation's existence is established by evidence.
Document Preview: Garnishment proceeding wherein garnishor sought to recover from garnishees an amount held under a liquidated damages provision of a contract with judgment debtor. The Superior Court, City and County of San Francisco, Clarence W. Morris, J., rendered judgment for garnishor, and garnishees appealed. The District Court of Appeal, McGoldrick, J. pro tem., held that evidence supported finding that liquidated damages provision, in a contract for sale of coffee machines to judgment debtor, was invalid as a penalty. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Shaw v. Bailey-McCune Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Utah.
Headnote: In action against corporation and its stockholders for unpaid rents under lease between plaintiffs and corporation and money due upon open account between plaintiffs and corporation, evidence sustained trial court's findings that corporation was not a sham or stockholders' alter ego.
Document Preview: Action against corporation and its stockholders for unpaid rents under lease between plaintiffs and corporation and for money due on open account between plaintiffs and corporation. The Fifth District Court, Juab County, Joseph E. Nelson, J., entered a judgment against corporation but dismissed action as to individual defendants, and plaintiffs appealed as to such dismissal. The Supreme Court, Callister, J., held that evidence sustained trial court's findings that corporation was not a sham or stockholders' alter ego. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Idaho Livestock Auction, Inc. v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court, D. Idaho, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In action for income and excess profit taxes paid pursuant to deficiency assessments determined for fiscal years beginning in September 1950 and ending in March 1955, wherein it appeared that government had determined that a partnership, in which partners were men who were owners of stock of plaintiff corporation, was not a bona fide partnership, recognizable for tax purposes and had combined its income with that of plaintiff corporation and taxed plaintiff on the total, evidence sustained finding that plaintiff and partnership were separate and distinct entities with legitimate business purposes and that dealings between them were conducted at arm's length. 26 U.S.C.A. (I.R.C.1939) § 45; 26 U.S.C.A. (I.R.C.1954) § 482.
Document Preview: Action by corporation to recover income and excess profit taxes for fiscal years beginning in September 1950 and ending in March 1955. The District Court, Fred M. Taylor, J., held that where three officers and principal stockholders of corporation worked from 12 to 14 hours a day, seven days a week, devoting a majority of their time to corporation's business, and they established a livestock market which ranked among highest in nation in an unnatural environment which was substantially devoted to farming and not to raising of livestock, average salary of each officer for fiscal years involved $31,500, based on 16 2/3% Of annual net profit of corporation, was reasonable and corporation was entitled to deduct those salaries in determining income and excess profit taxes. Judgment for corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Talbot v. Fresno-Pacific Corp.
Court: District Court of Appeal, Fourth District, California.
Headnote: In action to recover the price of lumber sold to a corporation where the individual defendant's liability was based on the alter ego theory, evidence sustained findings that the corporate entity should be disregarded and that the corporation should be regarded as a mere alter ego of the defendant and that defendant was personally liable.
Document Preview: Action to recover the price of lumber sold. From a judgment of the Superior Court of Fresno County, Matt Goldstein, J., the individual defendant appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Griffin, P. J., held that where the individual defendant's liability was based on the alter ego theory, evidence sustained findings that the corporate entity should be disregarded and that the corporation should be regarded as a mere alter ego of the defendant and that defendant was personally liable. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Temple v. Bodega Bay Fisheries, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: In action by corporation's creditors against the corporation, another corporation, and several individuals, evidence supported finding that the debtor corporation had never been organized and operated as a true corporate enterprise, but was the alter ego of the other defendants.
Document Preview: Action by corporation's creditors against debtor corporation, several individuals, and another corporation. The Superior Court, Sonoma County, Hilliard Comstock, J., rendered judgment against all defendants, and they appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Van Dyke, P. J., held that evidence supported finding that the debtor had never been organized and operated as a true corporate enterprise, but was the alter ego of the other defendants. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: American Tobacco Co. v. Goulandris
Court: United States District Court S.D. New York.
Headnote: In libel for loss and damage to goods carried on owners' vessel, evidence failed to establish that a corporation formed to re-establish a steamship passenger service under the Greek flag between North America and Greece was controlled by vessel owners or by a wholly-owned corporate agent of vessel owners, or that Greek flag corporation was organized to defraud creditors or to evade existing obligations, even though vessel owners owned some of the stock of Greek flag corporation.
Document Preview: Suits in admiralty for damage sustained to cargo shipped on defendants' vessel. Vessel owners filed a cross-libel for contribution in general average. The District Court, Ryan, J., held, inter alia, that vessel owners had the right and duty to file cross-libels to enforce collection from cargo interests of their contribution of their indebtedness to the general average fund, and vessel owners had such obligation even though on balance they might be debtors in general average. Decree in accordance with opinion. See also D.C., 134 F.Supp. 475.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Riddle v. Leuschner
Court: Supreme Court of California.
Headnote: In action by creditor of one corporation against that corporation, a second corporation and shareholders, officers and directors of both corporations for amount due, evidence established that woman who was stockholder of debtor corporation and man who was stockholder of both corporations operated corporations as their alter egos and that as to them there was such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporations and individuals no longer existed.
Document Preview: Action by creditor of one corporation against that corporation, a second corporation and shareholders, officers and directors of both corporations for amount due. The Superior Court, Stanislaus County, David F. Bush, J., rendered judgment for creditor and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Gibson, C. J., held that where one corporation's assets were intermingled with those of a second to suit convenience of parties who controlled both corporations and to assist them in evading payment of their obligations, and manipulations of affairs of corporations were designed to foster controlling parties' own purposes to disadvantage of first corporation and its creditors, separate entity of first corporation would be disregarded with respect to creditor of first corporation, but that man, who was managing employee of both corporations but who did not hold a single share of stock of either corporation, could not be held liable. Judgment reversed as to managing employee and affirmed as...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Riddle v. Leuschner
Court: Supreme Court of California.
Headnote: In action by creditor of one corporation against that corporation, a second corporation and shareholders, officers and directors of both corporations for amount due, evidence sustained findings that two corporations were controlled, dominated, managed, and operated by two members of family, and that there was no separateness between them and corporations.
Document Preview: Action by creditor of one corporation against that corporation, a second corporation and shareholders, officers and directors of both corporations for amount due. The Superior Court, Stanislaus County, David F. Bush, J., rendered judgment for creditor and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Gibson, C. J., held that where one corporation's assets were intermingled with those of a second to suit convenience of parties who controlled both corporations and to assist them in evading payment of their obligations, and manipulations of affairs of corporations were designed to foster controlling parties' own purposes to disadvantage of first corporation and its creditors, separate entity of first corporation would be disregarded with respect to creditor of first corporation, but that man, who was managing employee of both corporations but who did not hold a single share of stock of either corporation, could not be held liable. Judgment reversed as to managing employee and affirmed as...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Bishop v. Bishop
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: In supplementary proceeding by judgment creditor, testimony consisting of hearsay statements of the respective attorneys as to the alleged personnel and stock ownership of the third-party defendant was insufficient to support court's determination that third-party defendant was the alter ego of the judgment debtor.
Document Preview: Supplementary proceeding by judgment creditor. The third-party defendant moved to vacate a third-party subpoena served upon another, and judgment creditor cross-moved for order directing payment to judgment-creditor of amount due. The Supreme Court, Special Term, affirmed the report of the official referee, and third-party defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that evidence consisting of hearsay statements of the respective attorneys as to alleged personnel and stock ownership of the third-party defendant was insufficient to support determination that third-party defendant was the alter ego of the judgment debtor. Order modified and case remitted with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Petersen v. Cloverdale Egg Farms
Court: District Court of Appeal, Fourth District, California.
Headnote: In action for balance due for eggs delivered, evidence would sustain finding that defendant corporation was not the alter ego of the individual defendants, as well as finding that plaintiffs were estopped to take advantage of corporation's failure to obtain permit for issuance of its shares.
Document Preview: Action for balance due for eggs delivered. The Superior Court of San Diego County, Dean Sherry, J., rendered judgment in favor of individual defendants, and plaintiffs appealed. The District Court of Appeal, McCabe, J. pro tem., held that evidence would sustain finding that defendant corporation was not the alter ego of the individual defendants, as well as finding that plaintiffs were estopped to take advantage of corporation's failure to obtain permit for issuance of its shares. Affirmed.

Title: Critzer v. Oban
Court: Supreme Court of Washington, Department 2.
Headnote: In action brought by creditor of bankrupt corporation to recover from its stockholders, on theory that corporation had been merely alter ego of their partnership, amount owed to him, evidence would not have supported finding that corporation had been used as a mere tool or instrument in carrying out defendants' plans and purposes and that there had been such confusion of identities and acts as to work a fraud upon third persons.
Document Preview: Action brought by creditor of bankrupt corporation to recover from its stockholders, on theory that corporation had been merely alter ego of their partnership, amount owed to him. The Superior Court, King County, F. A. Walterskirchen, J., rendered judgment for defendants, and the plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Donworth, J., held that evidence would not have supported finding that corporation had been used as a mere tool or instrument in carrying out defendants' plans and purposes and that there had been such confusion of identities and acts as to work a fraud upon third persons. Affirmed.

Title: Critzer v. Oban
Court: Supreme Court of Washington, Department 2.
Headnote: In action brought by creditor of bankrupt corporation to recover from its stockholders, on theory that corporation had been merely alter ego of their partnership, amount owed to him, burden of proving facts that would warrant court in holding that corporate veil should be pierced and that defendants should be held liable for corporate debt was upon plaintiff; and, on record presented, it could not be said that such burden had been sustained.
Document Preview: Action brought by creditor of bankrupt corporation to recover from its stockholders, on theory that corporation had been merely alter ego of their partnership, amount owed to him. The Superior Court, King County, F. A. Walterskirchen, J., rendered judgment for defendants, and the plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Donworth, J., held that evidence would not have supported finding that corporation had been used as a mere tool or instrument in carrying out defendants' plans and purposes and that there had been such confusion of identities and acts as to work a fraud upon third persons. Affirmed.

Title: Most Worshipful Sons of Light Grand Lodge Ancient Free and Accepted Masons v. Sons of Light Lodge No. 9
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: In quiet title action against building corporation which held title to property allegedly taken by lodge members who seceded from old lodge to form new lodge, which conveyed property to corporation, evidence sustained finding that corporation was alter ego of new lodge and that if corporation were treated as an entity completely separate and apart from new lodge, a great fraud would be perpetrated.
Document Preview: Action against lodge members, who had taken assets of old lodge and formed new lodge, for declaration of a constructive trust based on fraud and for an accounting, wherein plaintiffs moved to amend complaint to include quiet title action against corporation to which new lodge had transferred real property of old lodge. The Superior Court, City and County of San Francisco, Milton D. Sapiro, J., permitted complaint to be amended and rendered judgment for plaintiffs, and defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Bray, J., held that complaint alleging that fraternal lodge members who seceded from lodge and formed new lodge had taken all assets of old lodge including its properties and praying that property be restored and that title be quieted dealt with real property of lodge, and amending of complaint seven years later to include corporation which was alter ego of new lodge and to which real property of lodge had been conveyed, and to describe by metes and bounds that real...

Title: Bayou Drilling Co. of Tex. v. Baillio
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Houston.
Headnote: In action for foreclosure of chattel mortgage executed by one of corporate defendants to secure note, the payment of which had been guaranteed by the other corporate defendant, evidence would not sustain plaintiff's contention that corporate guarantor was alter ago of individual who had induced plaintiff to make loan and that to uphold such corporation's plea of ultra vires would thus promote fraud.
Document Preview: Action for foreclosure of chattel mortgage executed by one of corporate defendants to secure note, the payment of which had been guaranteed by the other corporate defendant. The Sixty-First District Court, Harris County, Ben F. Wilson, J., rendered judgment for plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Bell, C. J., held that evidence had, as a matter of law, entitled plaintiff to relief sought as against corporate mortgagor, but held that the record evidenced an incomplete development of facts in connection with liability of corporate guarantor. Affirmed in part and in part reversed and remanded.

Title: Bariffi v. Longridge Development Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: In action for money paid on contract for purchase of parcel of realty by reference to unrecorded map of land, which was conveyed in trust to escrowee, which executed declaration of trust naming defendants as beneficiaries and providing that trustee would hold title in trust to convey real property to beneficiary or such person or corporation as directed by certain of defendants, evidence sustained finding that corporation which was created for purpose of making sales of lots, but which issued no stock was alter ego of joint venturers.
Document Preview: Action for money paid on contract for purchase of a parcel of realty by reference to an unrecorded map of land, which was conveyed in trust to escrowee, which executed a declaration of trust naming defendants as beneficiaries and declaring respective interests of beneficiaries. From adverse judgment and orders of the Superior Court, Los Angeles County, John G. Barnes, J., certain of the defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Valleé, J., held that evidence sustained finding that persons named as beneficiaries in declaration of trust entered into joint venture for purpose of purchasing realty and dealing with the same for profit, and that employment of engineering company to prepare subdivision map, organization of investment company by certain of beneficiaries, and sale of lots to public were in furtherance of joint venture. Judgment and orders affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: In re Zipco, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California, Central Division.
Headnote: In proceedings on assigned wage claims against bankrupt corporation, evidence would not sustain finding that bankrupt corporation had been alter ego of original assignee and that money advanced to corporation's employees by him had constituted a capital investment.
Document Preview: Proceedings on petition for review of an order of the referee denying allowance of a priority claim. The District Court, Irving R. Kaufman, J., held that it was immaterial to priority right of assigned wage claims that original assignment had been made by employees to individual who was president, sole shareholder and general manager of bankrupt corporation. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Central Fibre Products Co. v. Lorenz
Court: Supreme Court of Iowa.
Headnote: In proceeding on creditor's bill, evidence supported finding that corporation and business in whose names bank accounts were outstanding were in fact judgment debtor's individual businesses, and that the corporation was merely a cloak for debtor's individual operations.
Document Preview: Action to subject to plaintiff's judgment certain bank accounts and interest of judgment debtor in his deceased wife's estate. The Woodbury District Court, L. B. Forsling, J., held that bank accounts were property of judgment debtor but made no ruling relative to debtor's interest in wife's estate. Children of deceased wife appealed and plaintiff cross-appealed. The Supreme Court, Wennerstrum, J., held, inter alia, that where it was established that bank account in corporation's name was debtor's property and subject to judgment against him, amount which debtor, who had been appointed and then relieved as administrator of estate, had withdrawn from account and deposited as administrator's bond would likewise be subject to judgment, subject to any liability arising from his services as administrator. Affirmed on appellant's appeal; reversed in part on cross-appellant's appeal and remanded with direction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Hiehle v. Torrance Millworks
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: In action against two incorporators to recover moneys advanced to corporation, evidence justified finding that incorporators had formed the corporation pursuant to an agreement that it would be a mere agency or instrumentality through which they would conduct their co-partnership business and that it had been in fact their alter ego.
Document Preview: Action against corporation and its two incorporators to recover for money advanced to corporation. The corporation was adjudicated a bankrupt on its voluntary petition and the trustee in bankruptcy intervened. The Superior Court, Los Angeles County, Alfred L. Bartlett, J., entered judgment for plaintiff and incorporators appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Shinn, P. J., held that evidence sustained finding that corporation had been formed pursuant to an agreement that it would be a mere agency or instrumentality through which incorporators would conduct their co-partnership business and that corporation had been in fact their alter ego and held that incorporators were personally liable for corporation's debts. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Wilson v. Stearns
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: In action by broker to recover commissions for sale of tract properties, wherein it was contended that individual defendant with whom broker had contracted had transferred his interest in the properties to a corporation which was his alter ego, evidence sustained finding that corporation was in fact the alter ego of the individual defendant.
Document Preview: Action by broker to recover commissions on sale of tract properties. The Superior Court of Los Angeles County, George Francis, J., entered judgment from which plaintiff appealed. The District Court of Appeal, White, P. J., held that statute having effect of prohibiting practice by brokers of procuring exclusive employment agreements not having a definite termination day did not preclude recovery on contract of such character, not shown to have been procured pursuant to a practice of the broker who had fully performed. Judgment reversed and remanded as to all but two defendants, as to whom judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: P.S. & A. Realties v. Lodge Gate Forest
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York, Special Term, Part VI.
Headnote: In action to rescind purchase of realty from corporation on ground of false representations, evidence established that corporation was a mere agency or instrumentality through which defendant sole owner carried on business enterprises with assistance of his individual codefendants in complete disregard of corporate organization and corporate form and that individual defendants were joint adventurers engaged in carrying on as individuals the common enterprise of effecting sale to plaintiffs, and hence individual defendants were all jointly and severally liable for repayment of cash consideration paid by plaintiffs.
Document Preview: Action by purchasers for rescission of contract of purchase of realty after conveyance of realty to plaintiffs. The Supreme Court at Special Term, Walter, J., held that false representations as to tenants, terms of their leases and rentals payable thereunder, made by vendor and relied on by purchasers, were so material and substantial as to constitute adequate ground for rescission. Judgment for plaintiffs in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Taylor v. Newton
Court: District Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: In action to have a corporation declared the alter ego of plaintiff's judgment debtor and to recover from them amount due on judgment, evidence supported trial court's finding and conclusion that corporation was such debtor's alter ego and that adherence to fiction of corporation's separate existence would promote injustice to plaintiff and other creditors of judgment debtor.
Document Preview: Action to have a corporation and a copartnership declared alter egos of plaintiff's judgment debtor and to recover the amount due plaintiff on the judgment. From a judgment of the Superior Court, Butte County, McGregor, J., declaring the corporation the debtor's alter ego and both of them jointly and severally liable for the judgment debt, they appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Schottky, J., held that the complaint stated a good cause of action and that the evidence supported the trial court's conclusion that the corporation was the debtor's alter ego. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Stillman Pond, Inc. v. Watson
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: In proceeding for writ of mandate to compel real estate commissioner to vacate his order revoking real estate brokers' licenses, issued to individual and corporate brokers, evidence sustained finding that the corporate broker was the alter ego of the individual broker. Business and Professions Code, §§ 10176, 10177.
Document Preview: Proceeding for writ of mandate to compel real estate commissioner to vacate his order revoking petitioners' real estate brokers' licenses. The Superior Court, Los Angeles County, Frank G. Swain, J., entered judgment denying writ, and petitioners appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Wood, J., held that evidence justified revocation of licenses. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Cooper v. Industrial Commission
Court: Supreme Court of Arizona.
Headnote: Evidence established that corporation engaged in farming operations was not organized to be the alter ego of the sole stockholder nor did the operations manifest any characteristics of such alter ego.
Document Preview: Workmen's compensation proceeding. The Industrial Commission of Arizona denied petitioner compensation as an injured employee, and employee appealed by certiorari. The Supreme Court, La Prade, J., held that where carpenter was employed to do carpentry work in employer's home, and employer was not engaged in construction business, the employee was a person whose employment was casual and not in the usual course of trade, business, or occupation of the employer, and employer was not subject to the Workmen's Compensation Law. Award affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Thomson v. L. C. Roney & Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Evidence sustained finding that corporation sought to be added as judgment debtor had in fact been alter ego of initial defendant against which judgment had been rendered.
Document Preview: Proceedings on a petition filed by Walter P. Thomson and Walter P. Thomson, doing business under the fictitious firm name and style of Texas Tank Company, for an order to show cause why the court should not add to the files and records of an action previously tried between the petitioner and L. C. Roney & Company, by inserting as a judgment debtor the name of Southwestern Development Company, the alleged alter ego of the initial defendant. The Superior Court, Los Angeles County, Caryl M. Sheldon, J., entered an order granting the relief sought, and the Development Company appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Fox, J., held that the evidence sustained the finding that the Development Company was in fact the alter ego of the initial defendant. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Consolidated Photographic Industries v. Marks
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: In actions against individual and corporation to enforce covenant by individual, made in connection with sale by individual of photo-finishing concern, that he would not engage in the photo-finishing business in the county for five years, evidence was insufficient to establish that individual and corporation were effectually the same. Business and Professions Code, §§ 16600, 16601.
Document Preview: Consolidated Photographic Industries, Inc., and others and Winston E. Griffith and John W. Hooper, copartners, doing business under the fictitious name and style of Griffith Photo Service, brought action against Robert Marks, the Atlas Photographic Industries, Inc., and others to enforce covenants by Robert Marks in contract for sale of photo-finishing concern that he would not engage in the photo-finishing business in the county for five years. The Superior Court of Los Angeles County, William R. McKay, J., entered judgments adverse to the named defendants, and they appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Moore, P. J., held that plaintiffs were entitled to enforce the covenant as to Robert Marks. Judgments modified and, as modified, affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Warner Bros. Theatres v. Cooper Foundation
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: A charitable corporation was not, under the evidence, a mere device through which its creator transacted private business, though creator was its sole donor and trustees looked to him for advice and employed him to manage its property.
Document Preview: Warner Bros. Theatres, Inc., sued Cooper Foundation, and others, to impose a constructive trust upon a ten-year theater lease. The District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma, Edgar S. Vaught, J., 91 F.Supp. 277, rendered judgment for defendants and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Pickett, Circuit Judge, held that since the alleged fiduciary relationship between plaintiff and one Cooper, who created the charitable corporation and managed its property, arose out of a pooling arrangement which was invalid under the anti-trust laws, a constructive trust based upon such fiduciary relationship could not be enforced, and that the charitable corporation was not the mere alter ego of Cooper. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Garden City Co. v. Burden
Court: United States Court of Appeals Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: In action by a farmer against a corporation owning an irrigation ditch and parent corporation of irrigating company, evidence sustained finding of jury that irrigation company was the mere alter ego of its parent.
Document Preview: Action by J. L. Burden agasinst the Garden City Company, a corporation, and another for damages to plaintiff's land caused by the negligence of defendants in the operatinon of an irrigation canal crossing plaintiff's land. The United States District Court for the District of Kansas, Delmas C. Hill, J., entered judgment for plaintiff after jury verdict and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Huxman, Circuit Judge, held that the evidence was sufficient to sustain finding that defendants were negligent in the maintenance and operation of the irrigation ditch and that such negligence was the proximate cause of damage to plaintiff's land. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Gill v. Smith
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Galveston.
Headnote: In action for damages for alleged conversion by defendants of a written contract which purported to obligate defendants to plaintiff, evidence sustained finding that individual defendant was mere alter ego of corporate defendant and that transactions between defendants were mere bookkeeping transactions and not separate individual undertakings.
Document Preview: Action by Clayton N. Smith against Ned Gill, and others for damages for alleged conversion by defendants of a written contract which purported to obligate corporate defendant to plaintiff. The District Court, Harris County, Dan W. Jackson, J., entered judgment for plaintiff and defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, T. H. Cody, J., held that evidence, while insufficient to support a finding of a contract for joint adventure was sufficient to support jury finding that parties entered upon a joint adventure, and pursued it until it was abandoned and that plaintiff was given the contract sued upon. Affirmed.

Title: Johnson v. Merry Go Round, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Florida, Special Division B.
Headnote: In proceedings supplementary to execution, evidence sustained finding of commissioner that corporate debtor was alter ego of certain individuals sought to be held personally liable. F.S.A. § 55.52.
Document Preview: Action by Ralph P. Johnson against Merry Go Bround, Inc., for injuries from assault and beating by defendant's employee. Plaintiff recovered judgment and after execution was instituted thereon procured order directing corporate defendant, by and through Morris M. Brown, to appear before a commissioner and submit to an examination concerning its property in proceedings supplementary to execution in which commissioner found that corporate defendant was alter ego of Browns and recommending that they be impleaded to show cause why order should not be entered finding corporate defendant to be the alter ego of Browns and that they should be liable to plaintiff for unpaid balance of judgment. The Circuit Court, Duval County, Claude Ogilvie, J., ordered supplementary proceedings dismissed and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Tillman, J., held that evidence sustained finding of commissioner that corporation was alter ego of the Browns. Order reversed with directions to enter...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Judelson v. American Metal Bearing Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: To justify disregarding the corporate entity, affirmative proof or direct inference from proof must be present to establish that there is such unity of interest and ownership as indicates a cessation of individuality and separateness of the person and corporation.
Document Preview: Appeal from Superior Court, Los Angeles County; Charles E. Haas, Judge. Action by A. L. Judelson against the American Metal Bearing Co., a corporation, to recover compensation for services claimed to have been rendered by plaintiff's assignor as an attorney at law. From the judgment, defendant appeals. Judgment reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Greenbaum v. Keil
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware.
Headnote: Evidence that plaintiff's predecessor, who was one of four stockholders who originally owned equal amounts of all outstanding stock in small corporation, actually knew of and consented to issuance by corporation of eight shares of stock to each of the originators other than himself for advances made by them to corporation, with resulting disparity in stock interest, precluded disregarding of corporate aspect of the corporation treating of additional amounts advanced to corporation by other origninators as loans to be repaid, on ground that corporation was merely vehicle whereby four joint adventurers sought to exploit property held by the corporation.
Document Preview: Action by Herman Greenbaum, administrator de bonis non, cum testamento annexo, of the estate of Samuel Greenbaum, deceased, against Max Keil and others to have plaintiff, as successor in interest to one of four stockholders who originally owned equal amounts of all outstanding stock in a small corporation, restored to a position of stock equality by having court set aside or modify issuance of additional shares to original stockholders other than plaintiff's predecessor in interest. Decree advised denying relief sought.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Western Cas. & Surety Co. v. Birmingham Contracting Co.
Court: District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Where owner initially leased machinery to corporation and thereafter to successor partnership, and owner sought to hold individual defendant personally liable for rent on an alter ego theory for debts of corporation and partnership of which individual defendant was a stock holder and member, but owner did not prove that such individual was the real recipient of assets or income of either entity, or that either entity was dominated or operated by him as his alter ego, the individual defendant was not liable for such debts.
Document Preview: Actions by Western Casualty & Surety Company against the Birmingham Contracting Company and another, by Charles F. McCurdy against Claud A. Phelps and E. Glenn Phelps, jointly, severally, and as copartners doing business as the Birmingham Construction Company, and another by Charles F. McCurdy against the Birmingham Contracting Company, wherein the Western Casualty & Surety Company and others intervened, and by the Western Casualty & Surety Company against Harry Phelps, all predicated upon financial transactions arising out of construction contracts performed by certain of the defendants, seeking the appointment of a receiver and other relief for the ultimate purpose of securing payment of plaintiffs' claims in connection with such contracts. Judgments for plaintiffs.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Home News, Inc. v. Goodman
Court: Court of Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: Evidence established that a corporation organized at instance of partners to publish a shopping paper in order to provide work for a printing press owned and operated by partnership was really the partners and that the partners were really the corporation, as respects liability for commission on advertising secured for paper.
Document Preview: Appeals from Circuit Court No. 2 of Baltimore City; Samuel K. Dennis, Chief Judge. Bill by Seymour P. Goodman against Home News, Inc., Joseph Goldstein and Walter Goldstein for an accounting to determine amount due plaintiff as commissions under a verbal contract of employment to solicit advertising and for an order directing payment of the amount found to be due. From a decree adjudging complainant entitled to commissions at certain rates on designated business and referring papers to court auditor to state an account and from a decree on the audit, defendants appeal. Decrees affirmed in part and reversed in part, and cause remanded for further proceedings in accordance with opinion. GRASON, J., dissenting.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Gardner v. Rutherford
Court: District Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: Evidence that president who was also general manager owned 89 per cent. of corporation's stock, that corporation was operated in its corporate capacity for over 12 years when it made an assignment for benefit of creditors and that its corporate entity was preserved in all of its transactions failed to show that corporation was merely the "business conduit" or "alter ego" of the president.
Document Preview: Appeal from Superior Court, Napa County; Percy S. King, Judge. Action by G. C. Gardner against J. Wesley Rutherford as assignee, etc., to recover money lent, rental on real property and salary and also on a note. From a judgment for plaintiff on certain causes of action, defendant appeals. Affirmed.

Title: Armour & Co. of Delaware v. B. F. Bailey, Inc.
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: In action against corporation to apply lands conveyed to corporation by individual to satisfaction of notes executed by such individual, evidence sustained finding that corporation was not "alter ego" of such individual and hence not responsible for personal debts of individual.
Document Preview: Appeal from the District Court of the United States for the Southern District of Florida; John W. Holland, Judge. Action by Armour and Company of Delaware against B. F. Bailey, Inc., to recover upon certain promissory notes executed by B. F. Bailey, individually, and for other relief. From a judgemtn dismissing the bill plaintiff appeals. Affirmed.

Title: Sineath v. Katzis
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: In action by purchasers of dry cleaning and laundry company to enjoin defendant company from engaging in newly organized laundry and dry cleaning business on ground that defendant was the alter ego of former president of dry cleaning and laundry company, who had covenanted not to engage in the dry cleaning business within the county, evidence was insufficient to show that former president was defendant's alter ego.
Document Preview: Appeal from Superior Court, Wayne County; H. A. Grady, Emergency Judge. Action by W. P. Sineath and A. G. Hearon, partners, trading as the Goldsboro Dry Cleaners & Hatters, and W. P. Sineath and A. G. Hearon, individually, against Nick J. Katzis, Letha White, White's Laundry & Cleaners, Inc., and the Bank of Wayne, trustee, wherein the Mechanics & Farmers Bank and R. L. McDougald, trustee, were later made parties defendant, to restrain Nick J. Katzis from violating a noncompetitive agreement, to restrain Letha White and White's Laundry & Cleaners, Inc., from conspiring or participating with Nick J. Katzis in breach of the agreement, to cancel, because of failure of consideration and breach of contract, certain notes executed by defendants, in which defendants, banks and trustee, claim an interest, and to recover of Nick J. Katzis, Letha White and White's Laundry & Cleaners, Inc., damages for breach of contract, wherein Nick J. Katzis filed a crossaction....

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Markell v. Hilpert
Court: Supreme Court of Florida.
Headnote: The finding that defendant corporation was alter ego of individual defendant was proper, where evidence showed that defendant organized corporation, supplied practically all the property acquired by corporation, and became its president, that defendant held 510 of the 1,000 shares of stock issued by the corporation, and that balance of stock was held by defendant's daughter and granddaughter.
Document Preview: En Banc. Suit by Anna I. Hilpert, a widow, and others, against Frank E. Markell, a widower, and others to have a deed executed by plaintiffs to defendants declared a mortgage. From decree for plaintiffs, the defendants appeal. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(8) Alter ego, instrumentality, or agency in general >
Title: Madden v. Mac Sim Bar Paper Co.
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: In suit to recover balance of plaintiff's claim against bankrupt, evidence sustained determination that bankrupt was not an agent or instrumentality of defendant and that bankrupt was not a sham or dummy created by defendant to protect itself against liabilities.
Document Preview: Appeal from the District Court of the United States for the Western District of Michigan, Southern Division; Fred M. Raymond, Judge. Suit by George M. Madden, doing business as the Kohl & Madden Printing Company, against the Mas Sim Bar Paper Company to recover $12,611.84 and interest.  From an adverse decree, plaintiff appeals. Affirmed.

Title: Erskine v. U.S.
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: That in proceeding in customs court concerning corporation's liability as owner for additional or increased customs duties court found corporation's president to be its proprietor held not to establish, as against evidence, that president owned only about half of preferred stock, that president was alter ego of corporation, and, as such, was liable for customs duties assessed against corporation. Tariff Act of 1922, § 485(d), 19 U.S.C.A. § 355.
Document Preview: WILBUR, Circuit Judge, dissenting. Upon Appeal from the District Court of United States for the Northern District of California, Southern Division; Harold Louderback, Judge. Action by the United States against W. W. Erskine.  Judgment for plaintiff, and defendant appeals. Reversed.

Title: Pann v. U.S.
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: In action against stockholders to collect tax assessed on returns of corporation, evidence justified finding that defendant executing returns conducted business through corporation.
Document Preview: Appeal from the District Court of the United States for the Central Division of the Southern District of California; Paul J. Mccormick, Judge. Action by the United States against William P. Pann and others. From an adverse judgment (23 F.(2d) 714), defendant named appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Small v. Estate of Landesman
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Judgment creditor, who had prevailed in underlying action brought against judgment debtor company, failed to present sufficient facts to raise triable issue that warranted invocation of equitable doctrine of piercing corporate veil to allow judgment creditor to recover judgment from estate of judgment debtor's principal, regardless of whether New York or Delaware law applied; evidence submitted by judgment creditor indicated that principal, by himself, did not dominate and control company in that, at minimum, he consulted with others on financial and employee matters, principal owned 25% of judgment debtor, while founder and his grantor trust owned other 75% and had power to remove principal, and judgment creditor provided scant evidence of disregard of corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor failed to present sufficient facts to warrant piercing corporate veil to recover judgment from estate of debtor's principal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Sikousis Legacy Inc. v. B-Gas Limited
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Arbitration award-creditors failed to demonstrate that arbitration award-debtor was the alter ego of the company that had been one of debtor's parent companies at the time creditor chartered to debtor a vessel, whose owner was a subsidiary of parent, as would support attachment of vessel as security to satisfy $7.5 million arbitration award for debtor's breach of charter agreement; creditors merely made the conclusory assertions that parent exercised complete control of its corporate entities, and that parent's control of debtor was indisputable, but director of debtor testified that debtor's shareholder agreement provided minority shareholder protections to prevent the majority shareholder, which was controlled by parent, from exerting total control over debtor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Parent and Subsidiary. Arbitration award-creditors failed to show that award-debtor was the alter ego of its parent company, as would support attachment of vessel.
