Title: Lloyd's Syndicate 457 v. American Global Maritime Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Social-media profiles of individuals who described themselves as working at foreign parent corporation or foreign family of corporations associated with parent had little probative value on issues of inter-corporate control or independence, in personal jurisdiction analysis of whether contacts from resident corporation could be imputed to nonresident corporate defendants in manner consistent with due process under Texas long-arm statute, since there was no basis to infer that companies dictated what employees represent on personal web pages or that their self-descriptions reflected corporate structure, and record did not reveal whether employees listed their employer as parent because it was shorthand for resident corporation or because they were employees of single global entity. U.S. Const. Amend. 14; V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.041 et seq.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Maritime warranty surveyor owed duty to insurers of all-risk commercial liability insurance policy to use reasonable care and competence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: SBC v. Cutler
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support bench trial finding that purported principal of judgment debtor corporation did not have actual control over debtor, as would be required to pierce veil to hold purported principal's estate liable for judgment; accountant testified meeting regarding formation of debtor was driven by purported principal's son, and purported principal gave deposition testimony that he did not even know debtor existed, that he had absolutely no knowledge of its business dealings, and that his signatures on documents related to debtor were result of his son telling him to sign documents.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported finding that purported principal did not have actual control over judgment debtor corporation, as could allow piercing veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Lego A/S v. Best-Lock Const. Toys, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, toy manufacturer failed to provide a specific averment of facts required to establish a prima facie case that competitor was alter ego of its chief executive officer (CEO) for purposes of piercing the corporate veil in order to obtain personal jurisdiction over the CEO for his allegedly defamatory statements regarding manufacturer; CEO's statements, and use of the word "I" when supporting competitor's motion for injunction did not indicate that he owned most of competitor's stock or had exclusive domination over it, and one incident where CEO was the only individual able to locate certain documents requested in discovery was insufficient to establish competitor as alter ego of CEO. C.G.S.A. § 52–59b.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Toy manufacturer was not the alter ego of its chief executive officer (CEO) for purposes of piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Heisz v. Galt Industries, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Evidence did not support trial court's finding that buyer's president misused his control over buyer, related companies, and president's investment company as required for seller to pierce the corporate veil in action alleging breach of contract and fraud, although president negotiated the terms of transactions between investment company and companies that were related to buyer, and an entity related to buyer made a $52,000 payment to the investment company, where evidence that president directed transfers between the companies was not itself evidence of misuse, but, related to the first element of the alter ego analysis, namely, whether he controlled the companies, and president testified that the payments were for consulting services performed by the investment company, and there was no evidence that such services were not performed or that they were billed at an excessive rate.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Circumstantial evidence regarding intent to deceive as required for fraud claim is not limited to events after misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Aekyung Co., Ltd. v. Intra & Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to show that a corporation's director exercised sufficient domination over the corporation to support a finding that the corporation was the director's alter ego. Therefore, the plaintiff's motion for summary judgment against the director was denied. Although the director was the sole shareholder, director, officer and executive of the corporation, New York law under which the corporation was incorporated permitted a corporation to have a single person as sole shareholder, sole director and sole officer. McKinney's Business Corporation Law § 702(a).
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Judgment. Evidence was insufficient to show that a corporation's director exercised sufficient domination over the corporation to support a finding that the corporation was the director's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Goldman v. Chapman
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Evidence tending to demonstrate that corporation's sole shareholder exercised dominion and control over corporation, and conclusory allegations that corporation was shareholder's alter ego, were insufficient to establish a prima facie case for piercing the corporate veil, so as to hold shareholder personally liable for money judgment against corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Lewis v. DR Sawmill Sales, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: Testimony of corporate automobile dealership's sole shareholder that an asset-only sale of dealership was conducted at his sole discretion, that he made the decision to transfer to himself the resulting proceeds, and that he decided to leave no remaining assets to provide for known liabilities and claims was sufficient to support reasonable inference that shareholder exercised such control over the corporation that corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, for purposes of piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: Background: Buyer of new automobile sued dealership and its sole shareholder, alleging breach of contract, violation of the Consumer Sales Practices Act (CSPA), and violation of the Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act, after she was unsuccessful in obtaining a refund of purchase price of supplemental warranty she had purchased. The Municipal Court, Franklin County, entered judgment in favor of plaintiff. Defendant appealed. Holdings: The Court of Appeals held that: 2(1) evidence supported finding that dealership violated CSPA; 4(2) awarding buyer attorney fees of $8,062.50, under CSPA, was not an abuse of discretion; and 5(3) evidence supported piercing dealership's corporate veil and holding shareholder personally liable.  Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Lewis v. DR Sawmill Sales, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: Evidence that corporate automobile dealership's sole shareholder stripped corporation of assets, thereby removing any reasonable possibility for residual corporation to pay extended service plan (ESP) purchase price refund owed to buyer, knowing that residual corporation had incurred a written contractual liability with no stated expiration date, created a reasonable inference that shareholder approved and controlled these corporate maneuvers in furtherance of an illegal act, for purposes of piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: Background: Buyer of new automobile sued dealership and its sole shareholder, alleging breach of contract, violation of the Consumer Sales Practices Act (CSPA), and violation of the Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act, after she was unsuccessful in obtaining a refund of purchase price of supplemental warranty she had purchased. The Municipal Court, Franklin County, entered judgment in favor of plaintiff. Defendant appealed. Holdings: The Court of Appeals held that: 2(1) evidence supported finding that dealership violated CSPA; 4(2) awarding buyer attorney fees of $8,062.50, under CSPA, was not an abuse of discretion; and 5(3) evidence supported piercing dealership's corporate veil and holding shareholder personally liable.  Judgment affirmed.

Title: East Market Street Square, Inc. v. Tycorp Pizza IV, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that sole shareholder of corporate tenant, which had been organized to operate franchised restaurant, had total autonomy over the corporation so that it had no independent identity and no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, as factor supporting piercing of corporate veil under instrumentality rule, in action by commercial landlord for breach of lease and damage to leased premises; sole shareholder testified that he made all decisions regarding corporation's finances, policies, and business practices, and that he was corporation's sole director, president, and sole officer.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil of commercial tenant was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: East Market Street Square, Inc. v. Tycorp Pizza IV, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that sole shareholder of corporate tenant, which had been organized to operate franchised restaurant, was the only individual to "answer to" in transactions of business on behalf of corporation, as factor supporting piercing of corporate veil under instrumentality rule, in action by commercial landlord for breach of lease and damage to leased premises; sole shareholder testified that he was responsible for all contracts made by corporation except those made by franchisor for its franchises and that he managed details of lease negotiations rather than his attorneys, sole shareholder presented no evidence of a board of directors to oversee his decisions, and landlord's president testified that all of his interactions regarding lease negotiation were with sole shareholder and that he never heard of the corporation during the negotiations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil of commercial tenant was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: East Market Street Square, Inc. v. Tycorp Pizza IV, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that sole shareholder of corporate tenant, which had been organized to operate franchised restaurant, controlled and had total autonomy of four related corporations in family of corporations organized to own and operate franchised restaurants, as factor supporting piercing of corporate veil under instrumentality rule, in action by commercial landlord for breach of lease and damage to leased premises; sole shareholder testified that he was president, director, and sole common shareholder of the four related corporations and another corporation that acted as management company for all corporations in corporate family, and that he continually reviewed information with staff and as sole shareholder digested information and made decisions, and shareholder presented no evidence of any other individual or entity with authority to conduct the business of the corporations in the corporate family.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil of commercial tenant was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Bartkowski v. Lemcke
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Evidence failed to support decision to pierce corporate veil and hold corporation's president personally liable for a mortgage broker's portion of fee earned by broker and corporation, but paid to corporation at closing; no evidence addressed the president's dominion over the corporation.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Agents and Brokers. Broker was liable to co-broker for its share of fee paid to one broker at closing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Fontana v. TLD Builders, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: Trial court's finding in regards to the unity of interest and ownership prong of the piercing-the-corporate-veil-test that sole shareholder of construction company was a nonfunctioning director was not against the manifest weight of the evidence, where shareholder believed that she and her husband were co-owners and directors of company, she did not know how much money was loaned to company, and she had no real decision-making role in company.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of the corporate veil of construction company to hold president liable was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: State v. Tri-State Group, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh District, Belmont County.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support trial court's finding that sole shareholder of flyash disposal company exercised complete control over the company's activities so as to support piercing the corporate veil and holding shareholder personally liable for company's disposal permit violations; company did not conduct any significant corporate meetings, there were no corporate records, shareholder funneled company's assets to himself personally, his daughters, and to other companies he owned, and he ignored corporate forms when deciding how to finish a particular task.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - Hazardous Waste. Flyash disposal company was subject to a civil penalty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: State v. Tri-State Group, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh District, Belmont County.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support trial court's finding that sole shareholder's control over flyash disposal company led to disposal permit violations so as to support piercing the corporate veil and holding shareholder personally liable for company's violations; shareholder did not authorized reconstruction of holding tanks in accordance with permits, he failed to replace ground water monitoring wells, and he failed to have a corporate officer sign monthly operating reports on ground water monitor wells.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - Hazardous Waste. Flyash disposal company was subject to a civil penalty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Connolly v. Malkamaki
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh District, Lake County.
Headnote: Evidence did not warrant piercing of corporate veil so as to hold principal liable in real estate agent's action against principal and corporations for breach of contract, partial performance, fraud, promissory estoppel, and unjust enrichment arising from breach of employment contract; record did not establish that principal acted other than in agency capacity for corporate entities with respect to his dealings with agent, and there was no indication that principal had manipulated corporate accounts in a manner that would prevent agent from recovering on judgment entered against entities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Establishment of promissory estoppel claim overcame statute of frauds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Litchfield Asset Management Corp. v. Howell
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support finding that judgment debtor dominated and controlled companies to which she transferred assets, for purposes of satisfying instrumentality rule and piercing the corporate veil; there was evidence that she used company funds to pay personal expenses, that she owned 97 percent of first company and along with that company owned all of second company, that she was general manager of both companies, that both companies operated out of same office space over her garage, and that first company retained revenue obtained through sale of second company's inventory.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Companies were liable for personal debt through reverse piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Litchfield Asset Management Corp. v. Howell
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support finding that judgment debtor used control and dominance of companies to perpetrate a wrong, and thus satisfy instrumentality rule for purposes of piercing the corporate veil; there was evidence that debtor created first company with her own money after creditor started action to obtain judgment, that she caused first company to use part of that money to start-up second company after creditor obtained judgment, that debtor continued to use those funds as if they were her own, and that companies did not pay her a salary but rather paid her expenses directly.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Companies were liable for personal debt through reverse piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Bomil, Inc. v. Hoffelder
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to support a finding that corporate president was corporation's alter ego, so as to allow judgment creditor to pierce the corporate veil to add president as defendant to collect $69,176.66 judgment debt, where only evidence creditor corporation offered was president's control of the litigation between the two corporations; there was no evidence that the president "raided" debtor corporation to make the funds owed unreachable, as speculated, nor was there any evidence of treatment by the president of a corporate asset as his own, failure to maintain proper corporate records, inadequate capitalization, or any act or condition showing that one entity was the alter ego of another.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate president was not corporation's alter ego for purposes of collecting judgment debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Gilbert v. James Russell Motors, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Alabama.
Headnote: Evidence that automobile seller dealt only with non-defendant shareholder when it engaged in business with corporate automobile broker, that non-defendant shareholder conducted broker's day-to-day operations, and that defendant shareholders controlled only expenditures from broker's bank accounts did not support conclusion that defendant shareholders had complete control of corporation, that they misused any control that they had, or that any misuse they allegedly exerted proximately caused harm to seller, so as to support piercing corporate veil, absent evidence defendant shareholders knew of non-defendant shareholder's inappropriate activities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Creditor failed to establish grounds for piercing corporate veil of automobile broker.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Lifshutz v. Lifshutz
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: Husband's alleged dominance of corporations and disregard of corporate entities did not justify piercing corporate veil in divorce action, as husband's conduct enhanced the community at the expense of corporations; husband paid personal expenses through the corporations, and purchased notes for himself and wife in contravention of his fiduciary duty.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Wife could not pierce corporate veil as husband's disregard of corporate entity benefited community.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: U.S. v. Ming Hong
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence in prosecution for negligently violating pretreatment requirements of the Clean Water Act (CWA) "as a responsible corporate officer," was sufficient to prove that defendant's relationship to corporation was such that he possessed authority to prevent the illegal discharges; the evidence indicated that although defendant went to great lengths to avoid being formally associated with the corporation, in fact he substantially controlled corporate operations, that he was involved in the purchase of the insufficient filtration system, and that he was in control of corporation's finances and refused to authorize payment for additional filtration media. Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972, §§ 309(c)(1)(A), (c)(6), 502(5), 33 U.S.C.A. §§ 1319(c)(1)(A), (c)(6), 1362(5).
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - Clean Water. Conviction for violating Clean Water Act as responsible corporate officer did not require formal designation as officer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: McCormick v. City of Dillingham
Court: Supreme Court of Alaska.
Headnote: Evidence supported holding corporation's principal personally liable for corporation's failure to pay license fees and sales taxes, even though principal's wife owned all of corporation's stock; corporation never had adequate capital, corporation owned no significant property, corporation used principal's equipment, principal controlled the corporation as if he were the sole owner, and principal and wife used corporate checking account to conduct non-corporate business.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Principal was personally liable for corporation's failure to pay license fees and sales taxes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Playboy Enterprises, Inc. v. Terri Welles, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: Corporate veil would not be pierced, under California law, to impute to model that controlled corporation obligation of corporation not to use magazine's designation of model as "Playmate of the Year 1981" without magazines consent; there was no indication that relationship was any different from that of other small corporations and their controller, and there was no evidence that model used corporation for any improper purpose.
Document Preview: Magazine publisher sued model it designated as Playmate of the Year 1981 from using that phrase and others involving its trademarks on her Internet website. Model and her prior and present website webmasters moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Keep, J., held that: (1) fair use defense precluded liability for trademark infringement and related unfair competition counts; (2) fair use defense precluded liability for use of trademarks on advertising banners; (3) fair use defense precluded liability for using trademarks as metatags to guide search engines seeking out websites for Internet users; (4) determination that there was no trademark violation precluded claim for trademark dilution; (5) holder could not sue dissolved corporation for breach of contract under which model was precluded from using trademarks without holder's permission, (6) corporate veil would not be pierced to allow suit against model who controlled corporation; and (7) lack of liability...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Hall v. Timmons
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Evidence that all funds for employer were forwarded from chairman's personal operating account, that chairman personally approved or denied funds for employer, that employer's only means of acquiring funds for operation or purchases was to request them from chairman under his line of credit, that chairman countermanded decisions made by employer's personnel, that employer's registered address was chairman's personal office, and that chairman had a lien on all of employer's assets, constituted some evidence in support of finding that employer was alter ego of chairman, in injured employee's negligence action against corporate employer and its chairman.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Incomplete instruction on alter ego probably caused rendition of improper judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Rose Ocko Foundation, Inc. v. Lebovits
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Evidence that shareholder, who negotiated purchase of not-for-profit foundation's property on behalf of corporation completely dominated corporation, used corporation to further personal interests, and disregarded corporate formalities, supported conclusion that piercing corporate veil was required to avoid permitting shareholder, to whom corporation transferred property, to claim that he was not bound by determination nullifying sale of property to corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Non-profit Entities. Sale of nonprofit corporation's chief asset was subject to judicial scrutiny.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Mars Electronics of N.Y., Inc. v. U.S.A. Direct, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Evidence established that sole shareholder dominated and controlled every aspect of corporation's business affairs such as to render corporation shareholder's alter ego under New York law; sole shareholder was only officer and director of corporation, made all material decisions concerning the operation of the business, commingled business and personal funds in his personal checking account, took money out of corporation at will, never made any serious attempts at maintaining corporate formalities, and ran corporation out of his home without charging it rent.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor of corporation sought to hold corporation's sole shareholder personally liable for the judgment. Upon creditor's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Trager, J., held that: (1) evidence established that sole shareholder dominated and controlled every aspect of corporation's business affairs such as to render corporation shareholder's alter ego under New York law, and (2) shareholder's domination of corporation, with respect to two specific transactions, was used to perpetrate a fraud against judgment creditor so as to warrant piercing corporate veil and holding shareholder personally liable under New York law. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Hutchison v. Anderson
Court: Court of Appeals of Idaho.
Headnote: Evidence supported piercing corporate veil to find farming corporation's president personally liable for unpaid wages owed to workers, where president was in complete control of corporation, all shareholders were members of his immediate family, there was only limited evidence of activity by board of directors, president held himself out as owner of business, he used his name interchangeably with corporation's when dealing with third party vendors, and corporation was undercapitalized, so that any attempt to collect on judgment against corporation would likely be futile. I.C. § 30–1–25 (Repealed).
Document Preview: Former employees of farming corporation sued corporation and corporation's president for unpaid wages.  The District Court, Cassia County, R. Barry Wood, J., entered judgment for former employees, awarding back wages, treble damages, prejudgment interest, costs, and attorney fees. President and corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Perry, J., held that: (1) evidence supported piercing corporate veil to find president personally liable; (2) evidence supported finding that first employee worked one month longer than claimed by employer, and that his suit for unpaid wages was filed within six-month statute of limitations; (3) evidence supported finding that employment agreement was hourly; (4) employer was not entitled to credit for insurance benefits and horses provided to employees as bonus; (5) district court did not award employees credit for hours they did not work; but (6) wage claim statute was exclusive section under which attorney fees could be...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Thrift Drug, Inc. v. Universal Prescription Adm'rs
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Record supported finding that sole shareholder exercised complete domination over corporation, for purposes of determining whether to pierce corporate veil under New York law to reach shareholder's personal assets; corporation never held formal shareholders' meetings and maintained no records of directors' meetings, shareholder was also director of corporation and could locate no records of stock issued by corporation to him, corporation was inadequately capitalized and issued over $700,000 in loans to shareholder without any identified corporate purpose, and corporation loaned over $5 million shareholder's other corporations.
Document Preview: Pharmacy sued prescription benefits plan administrator and administrator's sole shareholder for breach of contract, alleging that defendants failed to reimburse pharmacy for dispensed prescriptions.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Whitman Knapp, J., 890 F.Supp. 319, granted summary judgment for pharmacy, and held that pharmacy could pierce administrator's corporate veil to reach shareholder's personal assets. Administrator and shareholder appealed.  The Court of Appeals held that: (1) district court's findings with respect to piercing of corporate veil were insufficient; (2) pharmacy showed that it timely submitted claims to administrator; and (3) ERISA did not preempt action. Affirmed in part, vacated and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Garcia v. Coffman
Court: Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Headnote: Requirement for piercing corporate veil, that shareholder dominate corporation, was shown despite lack of evidence that corporate formalities were ignored, that corporation was under-capitalized or that corporate and individual funds were commingled; shareholder was sole shareholder, he established policies governing how business of corporation, chiropractic services, would be conducted, board was all family members, shareholder's salary of $600,000 was one third of payroll in one year, and in one year's time salary of his wife went from $2,308 to $660,000.
Document Preview: Patient sued chiropractor and his corporation, alleging scheme to provide excessive services and charge excessive fees.  The District Court, Bernalillo County, Susan M. Conway, D.J., awarded nominal damages and punitive damages for fraudulent misrepresentation and breach of fiduciary duty, and awarded attorney fees.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Flores, J., held that: (1) patient could pierce corporate veil and recover directly from chiropractor; (2) patient could not recover for both breach of fiduciary duty and fraudulent misrepresentation; (3) punitive damages were recoverable; and (4) attorney fees were recoverable. Affirmed in part; reversed ion part. Hartz, C.J., concurred specially and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Northern Tankers (Cyprus) Ltd. v. Backstrom
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to conclude that individual principals of large group of shipping and real estate companies dominated such companies and disregarded their corporate forms, and therefore, plaintiff seeking to collect arbitration award from one shipping company could pierce corporate veil and recover award from principals or from any of their companies; shareholdings of all companies were identical and shares were beneficially owned by principals, companies had same directors and officers and used same office, companies were nominally capitalized and provided funding for each other, parent and subsidiary companies filed consolidated income tax returns, and parent companies made decisions for subsidiaries.
Document Preview: Company brought action against individual principals of large group of shipping companies, and against shipping and real estate entities created by such principals, seeking to collect arbitration award for breach of sub-charter agreement.  The District Court, Goettel, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to conclude that principals dominated their companies and disregarded their corporate forms, as required to pierce corporate veil; (2) bad faith breach of contract claim was barred by res judicata; (3) plaintiff could not prevail on fraudulent nondisclosure claim; (4) plaintiff was entitled to recover on claim alleging conspiracy to fraudulently transfer mortgage; but (5) plaintiff could not establish claims for conspiracy to defraud against individuals and partnerships who were alter egos of other alleged participants in conspiracy. Ordered accordingly.

Title: Wilmot v. Bulman
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District, Division One.
Headnote: Record did not contain sufficient competent evidence to warrant piercing employer's corporate veil and holding individual who pledged assets for employer's debts personally liable for workers' compensation benefits; individual lacked ability to control business practices of employer during time period when it failed to provide workers' compensation insurance to cover claimant's death.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Corporate veil would not be pierced, since individual who pledged assets for employer's debts lacked ability to control employer's business practices.

Title: In re Nutri/System of Florida Associates
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Finding that prospective purchaser of Chapter 11 debtor corporations did not completely dominate debtors, and thus that postpurchase veil piercing by administrative rent claimants was not warranted, was supported by evidence.
Document Preview: LEASES AND EXECUTORY CONTRACTS. landlords could not recover administrative rents from purchasers of Chapter 11 debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Ferguson v. Strader
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Twelfth District, Clermont County.
Headnote: Majority shareholder of corporate owner of horses could be held personally liable for breach of alleged contract with owner of land on which horses were pastured, even though landowner presented no evidence as to grounds for piercing corporate veil; shareholder's own testimony supported finding that he dominated and controlled corporation so completely that it had no mind, will, or existence of its own, shareholder never attempted to rebut any such conclusion, and shareholder never requested specific findings of fact from trial court. Rules Civ.Proc., Rule 52.
Document Preview: Corporations-Veil Piercing. Sufficient evidence supported finding that grounds existed for piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: F.C. Imports, Inc. v. First Nat. Bank of Boston, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Evidence failed to establish that bank exercised such domination and control over operations of retail seller of appliances that it should be held liable to wholesale supplier under instrumentality doctrine; there was no evidence that the bank controlled the seller and supplier failed to establish that bank's actions proximately caused their harm through misuse of its control of seller.
Document Preview: Wholesale supplier of appliances and owners of wholesale supplier brought action against bank seeking to hold bank liable for debts owed by retail seller to supplier for appliances supplier sold on credit to seller.  Bank brought motion for summary judgment.  The District Court, Pieras, J., held that: (1) bank could not be held liable to supplier for fraud, and (2) bank could not be held liable on theory that it had control over seller. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Swall v. Custom Automotive Services, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that president and vice president dominated and controlled corporation as required to meet first part of two-pronged test for determining whether corporate veil should be pierced where corporation's sole shareholder was its accountant, president and vice president made all decisions concerning operation of corporation and controlled monies paid out by corporation, were to receive compensation for their services as they determined appropriate, authorized disbursement of funds, determined which contracts corporation executed, determined which creditors were paid, controlled corporation's checking account, and withdrew from corporation's account amounts of money they deemed appropriate for themselves after consignor's goods began selling and much of authority exercised by president and vice president was not routinely exercised by corporate officers generally without supervision.
Document Preview: President and vice president of corporation were held personally liable for corporate debt to consignor in the Clay County Circuit Court, Frank D. Connett, Jr., J., and president and vice president appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Ulrich, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient for finding that president and vice president dominated and controlled corporation as required for piercing corporate veil, and (2) evidence supported findings that corporation was undercapitalized and that president and vice president stripped corporation's assets in reckless disregard of consignor's legal rights as required for piercing corporate veil. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Postell v. B & D Const. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Evidence established that shareholder exercised complete control over general contractor and that corporate form was sham, and, thus, evidence supported piercing of corporate veil to impose personal liability on shareholder for workers' compensation for framing carpenter; there was no payment of dividends, contractor was insolvent due to liability to carpenter, there was siphoning of funds by dominant shareholders, other officers and directors were nonfunctioning, and there was inadequate capitalization.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from decision of the Industrial Commission releasing landowner from liability, but upholding finding of liability of general contractor and shareholder for workers' compensation to carpenter.  The Court of Appeals, Wynn, J., held that: (1) evidence supported calculation of carpenter's average weekly wage; (2) landowner was not cogeneral contractor and was not employer of carpenter; and (3) evidence supported piercing of contractor's corporate veil to impose personal liability on shareholder. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Lawson v. Athens Auto Supply & Elec. Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Evidence that sole shareholder of corporate debtor operated and managed all related corporations, and commingled and confused funds of all, including making numerous unrepaid loans to himself and from one corporation to another, so as to have been acting as alter ego for all corporations when transfers were made out of corporate debtor's assets, authorized finding that corporate veil had been pierced in particular facts of fraudulent conveyance action.
Document Preview: After creditor obtained consent judgment against corporate debtor for amounts owed on accounts, creditor brought action against corporate debtor's sole shareholder and other corporations in which sole shareholder or his family had interest, for fraudulent conveyance of assets of corporate debtor in avoidance of judgment debt.  The Clarke Superior Court, Gaines, J., granted directed verdicts to two corporations, and entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of creditor and against shareholder and remaining corporation, and appeals were taken.  The Court of Appeals, Birdsong, P.J., held that: (1) evidence supported verdict against shareholder and one related corporation; (2) liability of another corporation presented question for jury; and (3) award of punitive damages was not excessive. Affirmed in part and reversed in part; motions for reconsideration denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Evans v. Multicon Const. Corp.
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Hampden.
Headnote: Subcontractor did not meet burden of pointing to specific property of judgment debtor corporation that was in hands of controlling shareholders and directors or had at some time been fraudulently conveyed to one of them, for purposes of determining assets susceptible of being reached and applied to judgment debt. M.G.L.A. c. 109A, § 4; c. 214, § 3(6, 8).
Document Preview: On appeal from judgment of the Hampden Superior Court, John F. Murphy, Jr., J., on, inter alia, subcontractor's motion in aid of judgment against corporation, the Appeals Court, Kass, J., held that: (1) it would not pierce corporate veil and look beyond corporate liability to parent or controlling officers, directors, or shareholders to satisfy judgment; (2) subcontractor was only incidental beneficiary of indemnity obligation taken on by controlling directors and shareholders as part of sale of corporate stock and thus could not recover as third-party beneficiary; and (3) subcontractor also could not recover against limited partnership created to own apartment development upon which work was done, of which corporation was the general partner. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: K.C. Roofing Center v. On Top Roofing, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Substantial evidence supported trial court's finding that shareholder dominated corporation, for purposes of determining whether shareholder could be held personally liable on corporate debts; shareholder and his wife were only shareholders of corporation and shareholder was president and chief operating officer who made all corporate decisions.
Document Preview: Creditor brought action against corporation and shareholder, seeking to recover on corporate debt and to hold the shareholder personally liable.  The Circuit Court, Jackson County, John I. Moran, J., entered judgment in favor of creditor and pierced the corporate veil.  Shareholder appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Kennedy, J., held that: (1) the evidence supported the findings that the shareholder dominated the corporation's activities, and that he organized series of corporations when he became unable to pay one corporation's creditors and, therefore, the evidence supported piercing the corporate veil, and (2) evidence of the shareholder's activities with respect to the multiple corporations was relevant and admissible. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Ohio Bur. of Workers' Comp. v. Widenmeyer Elec. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Medina County.
Headnote: It was error to pierce corporate veil to hold employees and officers of corporation personally liable for workers' compensation lien; although evidence established that officer and employee exerted excessive domination and control over corporation, their dominance was not used to commit a fraud or wrong upon the Bureau of Workers' Compensation; record did not indicate that failure of corporation to pay workers' compensation premiums resulted from failure to observe corporate formalities, or that inability to collect earlier judgment from corporation resulted from ignoring corporate form.
Document Preview: After Bureau of Workers' Compensation obtained a judgment against corporation for unpaid workers' compensation premiums and penalties, it filed complaint alleging that second corporation was successor to first corporation, and that employee and officer were alter egos of first corporation, rendering them liable for judgment.  The Court of Common Pleas, Medina County, found defendants liable on earlier judgment, and they appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Baird, J., held that: (1) trial court did not err in finding that second corporation was merely a continuation of first corporation, and in imposing successor liability upon second corporation, and (2) it was error to pierce corporate veil to hold officer and employee of first corporation personally liable for workers' compensation lien. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Title: Rothermel v. Ermiger
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: One of two shareholders was improperly held liable for corporate debt absent evidence of shareholder's control over corporation or that any fraud or misrepresentation was perpetrated; there was no evidence in record to support trial court's purely conclusory remark that shareholder and corporation were alter egos.
Document Preview: Creditors of corporation brought action against shareholder. The County Court, Warren County, Moynihan, J., affirmed town court judgment in favor of creditors, and shareholder appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Kane, J., held that shareholder was improperly held liable for corporate debt absent evidence of shareholder's control over corporation or that any fraud or misrepresentation was perpetrated. Reversed.

Title: Cascade Energy and Metals Corp. v. Banks
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: District court's factual findings that individual dominated boards of directors and management of four entities, that he was "single-handedly" able to transfer assets among various entities and did so and that he commingled the funds of the various entities, in the sense that when he transferred funds from one entity to another, the funds were deposited in the receiving entity's general bank account and were mixed with other funds there were supported by sufficient evidence that individual wielded almost total control over entities, as shown particularly by his control over each entity's finances and evidence that he freely transferred cash from any entity that had it to any entity that needed, whenever he wanted, under a bookkeeping system that made it nearly impossible to provide a precise accounting of transferred funds.
Document Preview: In a diversity case involving a dispute over gold mine between the mine's principal promoters and a group of investors, the United States District Court for the District of Utah, A. Sherman Christensen, J., found that promoter and affiliated corporation which was managing agent for joint venture breached fiduciary duties owed to joint venture, decided to reverse pierce entity veils of related entities, and found working interests in gold mine were not securities.  Individual and affiliated entities appealed and investors appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Ebel, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) evidence supported finding that owner and manager of gold mine breached fiduciary duty to investors who purchased working interests in gold mine; (2) decision to reverse pierce corporate veil among related entities was improper; (3) investors' interest in mine were securities under federal and state securities laws;...

Title: In re Daily
Court: United States District Court, D. Hawai'i.
Headnote: Evidence supported conclusion that debtor controlled corporations of which he was not shareholder and should be viewed as beneficial owner of corporations, so bankruptcy trustee was entitled to assert claims on proceeds from sale of property owned by corporations. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. § 541.
Document Preview: Chapter 7 trustee filed adversary complaint against partnership and corporations in individual's bankruptcy case, seeking ruling that proceeds from sale of lands in which corporations held ownership interest be turned over. The Bankruptcy Court found that debtor's son, as custodian of records of business entities, had failed to produce court-ordered documents, ruled that allegations contained in complaint would be deemed established as facts, and ordered partnership to pay over all proceeds from sale of property.  On appeal, the District Court, Pence, J., held that: (1) partnership and corporations would be collaterally estopped from asserting positions inconsistent with those of debtor and son in adversary proceeding and bound by Bankruptcy Court order; (2) deeming facts contained in complaint established was justified; (3) Bankruptcy Court was justified in viewing debtor as beneficial owner of partnership and corporate enterprises and...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: NEC Electronics Inc. v. Hurt
Court: Court of Appeal, Sixth District, California.
Headnote: In regard to attempt by party who obtained default judgment against corporation to add corporation's sole shareholder as judgment debtor, there was insufficient evidence to show that shareholder controlled defense of litigation; after corporation filed its general denial, it conducted no discovery, and did not appear at trial. West's Ann.Cal.C.C.P. § 187.
Document Preview: After a default judgment was entered against corporation, plaintiff filed a motion to amend its judgment against corporation to add corporation's sole shareholder as a judgment debtor.  The Santa Clara County Superior Court, Peter G. Stone, J., granted plaintiff's motion, and shareholder appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Elia, J., held that: (1) there was sufficient evidence to show that shareholder was the alter ego of corporation; (2) shareholder's interests were not represented in the underlying action; and (3) there was insufficient evidence to show that shareholder controlled the defense of the litigation. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Aero Planning Intern., Inc. v. Air Associates, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon.
Headnote: In action by corporations' judgment creditor to pierce corporate veil and hold individual shareholders liable for judgment, creditor failed to make prima facie showing of improper conduct of shareholders in exercise of control over corporations, and thus could not prevail in action, where evidence regarding commingling of corporations' funds did not show that as between shareholders and corporations, shareholders disregarded corporate entities, where assertions that shareholders failed to provide sufficient unencumbered capital for corporate defendants to meet foreseeable business liabilities was not sufficient basis on which to conclude that corporations were undercapitalized, and where judgment creditor's assertions that shareholders milked corporations' assets were not substantiated.
Document Preview: After judgment creditor received judgment against corporations for breach of contract, and was unable to collect upon it, creditor amended its complaint to add corporation's shareholders as parties.  The Circuit Court, Multnomah County, Donald Londer, J., granted shareholders' motion to dismiss and entered judgment in their favor, and creditor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Newman, J., held that creditor failed to make prima facie showing of improper conduct by shareholders in exercise of control over corporations, and thus corporations' corporate veil would not be pierced to hold shareholders liable for judgment against corporations. Affirmed.

Title: Mother & Unborn Baby Care of North Texas, Inc. v. State
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: Determinations that principal of incorporated antiabortion group controlled and dominated group's corporate affairs, that separateness of corporate identity had ceased, and that harm was caused by principal's actions were supported by sufficient evidence, and thus, trial court was justified in assessing civil penalties against principal under Deceptive Trade Practices Act, even though jury only assessed penalties against group; evidence indicated that principal started business, had group incorporated under two names, placed all advertising, was president of corporations, and participated in counseling women who sought abortion, and that patients were angry and emotionally distressed at being "mislead" into believing that they could obtain abortions at clinic. V.T.C.A., Bus. & C. §§ 17.41-17.50.
Document Preview: State brought suit against antiabortion group and its principal for alleged violations of Deceptive Trade Practices Act.  The 67th District Court, Tarrant County, George A. Crowley, J., entered judgment enjoining certain conduct, mandating disclosures in advertising, and assessing civil penalties.  Group and principal appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Lattimore, J., held that: (1) antiabortion group which advertised in yellow pages under abortion information and services and medical clinics headings and which provided pregnancy testing, antiabortion counseling, arrangement of financial assistance, aid in adoption procedures and help in obtaining legal aid, was engaged in trade or commerce within meaning of Deceptive Trade Practices Act; (2) Act was not overbroad as applied to group and principal; and (3) determination that principal of group controlled and dominated group's corporate affairs was supported by...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Consumer's Co-op. of Walworth County v. Olsen
Court: Supreme Court of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to establish that corporate formalities were so egregiously ignored with respect to closely held corporation, or that control was so pervasively exercised by two shareholders, so as to warrant piercing of corporate veil, even though there existed record of only two formal corporate meetings and even though majority shareholder infused considerable capital; corporate officers were elected and meetings, albeit informal, were regularly held, and financial transactions between majority shareholder and corporation were approved informally by corporation board of directors.
Document Preview: Corporate creditor brought action against two shareholders, seeking to impose personal liability for an unsatisfied judgment against the corporation.  The Walworth County Circuit Court, Robert D. Read, J., entered judgment in favor of creditor, and shareholders appealed.  Upon certification of action by the Court of Appeals, the Supreme Court, Ceci, J., held that: (1) evidence was insufficient to warrant piercing of corporate veil, and (2) creditor by its actions was precluded from asserting inadequacy of capitalization as basis to pierce corporate veil. Reversed and remanded.

Title: Harding v. Lucero
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. I.
Headnote: Evidence supported conclusion that president of vendor exercised complete control over vendor's affairs, commingled personal and corporate assets, undertook in personal capacity to sell property, was alter ego of vendor, and, therefore, was jointly and severally liable in individual capacity for brokers' commissions.
Document Preview: Brokers brought action against vendor and vendor's president to recover brokers' commissions.  The District Court, City and County of Denver, Harold D. Reed, J., entered judgment in favor of brokers.  Vendor and president of vendor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Sternberg, J., held that: (1) oral listing agreement which entitled brokers to 7% commission upon producing ready, willing and able buyer and which was subsequently modified in writing to provide for payment of $100,000 commission upon sale of 100% of property was source of brokers' employment, and governed two separate and unrelated transactions by which property was sold to purchaser procured by brokers, and (2) evidence supported conclusion that president of vendor was alter ego of vendor, and, therefore, was jointly and severally liable in individual capacity for brokers' commissions. Affirmed.

Title: Salem Tent & Awning Co. v. Schmidt
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon.
Headnote: Lessor presented prima facie case for disregarding corporate form and piercing the corporate veil so as to hold shareholders liable on lease contract given evidence shareholders controlled corporation, they engaged in improper conduct in their exercise and control over corporation, corporation was undercapitalized, and misconduct of shareholders caused lessor to have inadequate remedy against corporation.
Document Preview: Lessor of tents brought action against lessee, corporation, and its shareholders to recover damages sustained when tents were damaged and destroyed.  The Circuit Court, Marion County, Clarke C. Brown, J., entered judgment against the corporation only.  Lessor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Van Hoomissen, J., held that: (1) evidence supported finding of damages, and (2) lessor presented prima facie case for disregarding the corporate form and piercing the corporate veil. Affirmed and remanded and reversed and remanded.

Title: Tennessee Racquetball Investors, Ltd. v. Bell
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Middle Section, at Nashville.
Headnote: Finding that owner of corporation was liable, under "alter ego" theory, to contractual creditor of corporation was not sufficiently supported by evidence, though owner exercised dominance over corporation, in that owner's only improper act was to instruct corporation to prefer one creditor over others, in violation of Bankruptcy Act, which impropriety was remedied by trustee's suit for return of preferential payment.
Document Preview: Creditor of corporation brought action to recover contractual debts from corporate director, under alter ego theory, following release of corporate director by trustee in bankruptcy from further liability to bankruptcy estate.  The Chancery Court, Davidson County, Robert S. Brandt, Chancellor, entered judgment on jury verdict for creditor, and director appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Todd, P.J. (M.S.), held that: (1) corporate director was not liable to contractual creditor of corporation where director's only impropriety was to induce corporation to pay one creditor to exclusion of another; (2) no right of action remains in any creditor against corporate director released by trustee of bankruptcy except for special wrong committed against particular creditor to exclusion of creditors in general; and (3) corporate director was not liable for abuse of process absent showing of proximate harm to creditor. Reversed, dismissed and...

Title: Dorton v. Dorton
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Evidence of sale of property belonging to corporation by president of corporation who was also a director and 51% shareholder to president's mother for less than fair market value was insufficient to support decision to disregard corporate entity, where nothing in record showed sale was commercially unreasonable, that there was usurpation of corporate opportunity, or that there was any overreaching on president's part.
Document Preview: Equitable distribution order was entered by District Court, Durham County, David Q. LaBarre, C.J., after earlier actions concerning custody, alimony, and child support, and divorce were consolidated by stipulation of husband and wife.  Wife appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Webb, J., held: (1) husband's dental license was separate property and must be considered as one of factors affecting equitable distribution; (2) husband who knew of existence of family corporation and shared in duty to observe corporate formalities would not be allowed to disregard corporate entity on basis of noncompliance with formalities; (3) trial court erred in terminating writ of possession regarding marital home contained in earlier child support order; and (4) trial court did not improperly consider marital fault as factor in distributing marital property. Judgment vacated and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Rice v. Oriental Fireworks Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon.
Headnote: Shareholder having complete control over officer and director decisions through his roles as president, treasurer and chairman of board of corporation, and with his wife, control over shareholder decisions, was prima facie in control of operation of corporation for purposes of shareholder control criterion used in part to determine whether corporate entity should be disregarded and personal liability imposed upon shareholder.
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought action against Maryland corporation and its controlling shareholder for personal injuries suffered while discharging fireworks distributed by corporation or shareholder.  The Circuit Court, Multnomah County, Clifford B. Olsen, J., dismissed action against shareholder for lack of personal jurisdiction, and plaintiff appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Warren, J., held that: (1) shareholder's single promotional visit to Oregon was insufficient basis for asserting personal jurisdiction over him; (2) since Oregon had undisputed jurisdiction over corporation, it could assert jurisdiction over shareholder if plaintiff made prima facie showing that circumstances justified piercing corporate veil as to shareholder; and (3) plaintiff had made prima facie showing that piercing corporate veil was justified, which allowed assertion of personal jurisdiction over shareholder. Reversed and remanded.

Title: LaFond v. Basham
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. I.
Headnote: In homeowners' action against corporate remodeling contractors and their president for damages for breach of contract, findings that president dictated all policy and activity on part of corporations and dominated stockholders with respect to corporate policy, activities, funds, and other corporate matters, supported imposition of personal liability on president for corporations' breach based on common-law theory. C.R.S. 7–5–114(9).
Document Preview: Homeowners brought action against corporate construction contractors and their president and his son, individually, for damages for breach of contract.  The District Court, Arapahoe County, M.O. Shivers, Jr., J., entered judgment against corporate contractors and president, individually, and president appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Metzger, J, held that: (1) pleadings gave president adequate notice of claim against him for personal liability based on equitable principles; (2) findings supported imposition of liability on president based on common-law theory; and (3) prejudgment interest was properly awarded. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Crabtree
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Tennessee.
Headnote: Evidence that debtors owned 100% of shares of corporation since it was incorporated, that he had been in total control of it, that he shared the same business address with the corporation, that he had provided personal guarantee for debts of the corporation, that loans made to the corporation were used to pay off the debtor's individual obligations, that corporate formalities were not observed, that corporation was not independently creditworthy, and that almost all creditors of the corporation were creditors of the debtor demonstrated that the corporation was the alter ego and instrumentality of the debtor.
Document Preview: Creditors sought to have corporation added to caption of involuntary petition filed against individual debtor.  The Bankruptcy Court, Clive W. Bare, J., held that: (1) corporation was alter ego of the individual debtor; (2) court could permit inclusion of the corporation in the caption of the petition pursuant to motion; (3) court had jurisdiction to grant leave to amend involuntary petition nunc pro tunc to show that debtor was known as and doing business as corporation; and (4) fact that relief had already been granted did not preclude the amendment. Ordered accordingly.

Title: Church of Scientology of California v. Blackman
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Psychiatrist who established only that incorporators of the committee organized for the protection of patients' rights, which picketed hospital where psychiatrist worked, carrying placards and leaflets condemning psychiatrist's use of electro-convulsive therapy, were members of the Scientologist faith, and that the California Church of Scientology gave the committee advice on public relations, use of a hotel's mailing address, was listed as sponsor on some committee material, and agreed with the committee's opposition to electro-convulsive therapy for mental illness, failed to adduce competent evidence at defamation trial from which a jury could reasonably conclude that the California church dominated the committee; thus, there was no justification for piercing the corporate veil and holding the California church liable for actions of the committee.
Document Preview: Psychiatrist brought defamation action against an incorporated committee organized for the protection of patients' rights, the Church of Scientology of California, and against a minister of the Church of Scientology of Florida and a member of the committee, arising from demonstration outside hospital in which psychiatrist worked condemning his use of electro-convulsive therapy.  The Circuit Court, Broward County, William Clayton Johnson, J., entered judgment for psychiatrist, and the California church timely appealed.  The District Court of Appeal, Hurley, J., held that psychiatrist failed to adduce competent evidence from which jury could reasonably conclude that the California church dominated the committee; thus, trial court committed reversible error in piercing the corporate veil and holding the California church liable for defamatory remarks made by the committee when it picketed hospital where plaintiff worked. Reversed and remanded. Downey, J.,...

Title: Zanoni v. 855 Holding Co., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: There was no evidence in record from which it could be determined that individual defendant, who was neither shareholder in, nor director of, corporation, exercised such total domination over that entity as would justify piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: In action, inter alia, for equitable rescission of contract for sale of stock based upon fraud, and to determine interests of parties in escrow account, plaintiffs appealed from portions of judgment of the Supreme Court, Suffolk County, McInerney, J., which, inter alia, dismissed their complaints against defendants and directed that funds in escrow account be paid to vendor, and individual defendant cross-appealed from so much of same judgment as was in favor of vendor and against him on vendor's cross claim to recover unpaid down payment due under contract of sale.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) one contract vendee was liable for fraud; (2) one plaintiff was entitled to judgment against individual guarantors; (3) individual defendant was not liable on vendor's cross claim to recover amount of down payment still due and owing; (4) there was no evidence from which it could be determined whether such individual defendant...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Talen's Landing, Inc. v. M/V Venture, II
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit. Unit A
Headnote: In action brought by operator of boat store against vessel owner to recover for fuel and other services provided the vessel, evidence that individual defendant totally dominated both corporate defendants, confused corporate records and finances, and failed to follow usual corporate formality supported trial court's action in piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Owner of boat store brought action against vessel owner and others to recover for fuel and other services provided vessel. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana, Edward J. Boyle, Sr., J., entered judgment for plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Brown, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) trial court properly admitted testimony explaining that meter tickets from plaintiff's store were based on tenths of a gallon liability, and there was no error factually or legally with trial court's conclusion that the tickets and invoices together constituted a contract between the parties, and (2) evidence that individual defendant totally dominated both corporate defendants, confused corporate records and finances, and failed to follow usual corporate formality supported trial court's action in piercing the corporate veil. Affirmed.
