Title: Martin v. Pilot Industries
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to show that two shareholders of corporation so dominated the finances and practices of the corporation so as to justify piercing of the corporate veil to impose liability on the shareholders for violation of the North Carolina's Business Opportunity Sales Act by the corporation. N.C.G.S. §§ 66-94 to 66-100.
Document Preview: Buyer of business brought action against seller to recover for violations of the North Carolina Business Opportunity Sales Act. The United States District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina, Hiram H. Ward, J., entered judgment in favor of the buyer, but declined to award attorney fees, and seller appealed. The Court of Appeals, James Dickson Phillips, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) the evidence demonstrated that there had been a sale of a business opportunity; (2) the Act was violated notwithstanding disavowal of the profit guarantee contained in the actual sales contract; (3) it was error to grant summary judgment imposing personal liability on shareholders of the seller; and (4) attorney fees were properly denied. Affirmed in part, vacated and remanded in part.

Title: Valley Finance, Inc. v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence that taxpayer who founded corporation and was its president and sole shareholder thereafter used corporate funds and staff for his own private purposes on a regular basis and wrote checks on the corporation's bank accounts to cover unrelated personal and business expenses, that the sole owner manipulated the few ventures in which the corporation was involved in order to advance his own distinct business or financial interests, that he used corporation's employees to manage his domestic staff and run personal errands for him and that no Major corporate decision was ever made by anyone other than the sole owner supported trial court in finding that the corporation was a mere alter ego of the taxpayer and was not a separate entity for tax purposes.
Document Preview: Companion appeals from two judgments of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, Charles R. Richey, J., were consolidated for argument with consent of counsel. Both appeals arose from a jeopardy assessment for income taxes in excess of 4.5 million dollars made by the Internal Revenue Service against the individual taxpayer and against a corporation wholly owned by the taxpayer. The corporation initially sought return of its property and damages but the district court upheld that seizure after finding that the corporation was not a separate entity for tax purposes. Additionally, various creditors of the corporation which sought to challenge the seizure appealed from the dismissal of their separate action. The Court of Appeals, Gesell, District Judge, sitting by designation, held that: (1) the three general creditors of the corporation that was wholly owned by the delinquent taxpayer lacked standing to bring suit under the section which permits challenge to a...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: G. M. Leasing Corp. v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence showing, inter alia, that taxpayer had exclusive control over corporation whose directors had no duties and were merely figureheads, that corporation which was allegedly engaged in automobile leasing business, in fact, leased no automobiles, had no employees, issued no stock and had no stockholders' meetings and that automobiles allegedly owned by corporation were used by taxpayer for personal business established that corporation was taxpayer's alter ego so that its assets could be seized to satisfy taxpayer's federal income tax liability; thus, trial court's finding to the contrary, in action by corporation seeking damages arising out of seizure of its assets, was clearly erroneous.
Document Preview: Corporation filed suit against federal government and certain government employees seeking return or destruction of photocopies of documents seized, return of seized automobile, release of levy against its property and damages arising out of levy and seizure by internal revenue service agents of its assets to satisfy income tax liability of individual taxpayer. Taxpayer's son intervened seeking return of seized stock and federal government filed counterclaim for foreclosure of tax liens. The United States District Court for the District of Utah, Central Division, Ritter, Chief Judge, entered judgment for plaintiff and intervenor, and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Hill, J., held that evidence established that corporation over which taxpayer had exclusive control and which had no business and no employees was alter ego of taxpayer so that its assets could be seized to satisfy taxpayer's tax liability; that search conducted pursuant to statutorily valid levy was legal;...

Title: Capital Tel. Co., Inc. v. F.C.C.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit.
Headnote: Substantial evidence that corporate applicant was wholly owned by one individual who was also the president and manager of the corporation and that the same individual operated and controlled from the same office another business that was substantially identical to the corporation's supported decision of Federal Communications Commission to pierce the corporation's corporate veil in order to carry out mandate of the Communications Act to provide fair, efficient and equitable distribution of radio service in allocation of high-band radio channels for paging services. Communications Act of 1934, § 307(b), 47 U.S.C.A. § 307(b).
Document Preview: The Federal Communications Commission denied corporate applicant's application for authority to construct and operate a one-way radio-paging station and the corporate applicant appealed. The Court of Appeals, MacKinnon, Circuit Judge, held that the Federal Communications Commission validly exercised its discretion in piercing the corporate veil of corporation applicant for highband radio-paging channel, in treating the corporate applicant and its individual owner as one applicant, and in only granting the individual applicant's application. Affirmed.

Title: Metropolitan St. Louis Sewer Dist. v. Zykan
Court: Supreme Court of Missouri, Division No. 1.
Headnote: Evidence in action to compel defendants to construct drainage ditch in subdivision, warranted finding that all defendants were the alter ego and under domination and control of one individual defendant, and that all defendants were liable and responsible to plaintiffs for the individual's acts.
Document Preview: Sewer district and owners of homes in subdivision brought action to compel developers of subdivision to construct drainage ditch and for damages. The Circuit Court, St. Louis County, John J. Kelly, Jr., J., ordered developers to construct drainage ditch and awarded damages to homeowners, and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Higgins, C., held that even though costs of building storm water drainage ditch had risen between date in 1962 that subdivision developers contracted with homeowners in subdivision to construct ditch and date of 1967 action to compel construction of ditch, where developers regularly represented that drainage improvement would be constructed but did nothing toward proposed construction and met inquiries as to when ditch was to be built with stall and delay tactics, delay of sewer district and individual homeowners in bringing action to compel construction of ditch did not cause developers to change their position of doing nothing and developers during...

Title: House of Koscot Development Corp. v. American Line Cosmetics, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence in action against defendant corporations and individual defendant for breach of contract between plaintiff corporation and one of the defendant corporations relating to the selling of subfranchises supported inference that the cancellation of sold subfranchise by one of the defendant corporations was ordered by individual defendant to protect his own interest and those of the other defendant corporations and that in cancelling sale defendant corporation operated under the domination and control of the other defendants.
Document Preview: Diversity action for breach of contract. The United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida, at Orlando, Duncan, J., entered judgment for plaintiff corporation and the defendant corporations and individual appealed. The Court of Appeals, Clark, Circuit Judge, held, inter alia, that evidence in action against defendant corporations and individual defendant for breach of contract between plaintiff corporation and one of the defendant corporations relating to the selling of subfranchises supported inference that the cancellation of sold subfranchise by one of the defendant corporations was ordered by individual defendant to protect his own interest and those of the other defendant corporations and that in cancelling sale defendant corporation operated under the domination and control of the other defendants. Affirmed.

Title: Vogel v. Town of New Milford
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: In proceedings on application for change of name of automobile junkyard which was in restricted district in which further establishment of automobile junkyards was forbidden from that of a sole proprietorship to that of a corporation, in absence of evidence that sole proprietor was dominant shareholder of corporation or that, if he was, his control was being used to commit a fraud or to perpetuate a dishonest or unjust act, corporate form could not be disregarded as mere instrumentality or alter ego of sole proprietor. C.G.S.A. §§ 21-16 to 21-18, 21-20, 21-22, 21-24, 21-25, 21-26, 33-289(a) (2), (b), 33-291(c).
Document Preview: Owner of land adjoining junkyard appealed from action of town board of selectmen granting application for change of name of automobile junkyard from that of a sole proprietorship to that of a corporation. The Court of Common Pleas in Litchfield County, Martin, J., dismissed the appeal and the owner appealed. The Supreme Court, Shapiro, J., held that sole proprietor of automobile junkyard in a restricted district in which further establishment of automobile junkyards was forbidden could not transfer his license to corporation of which he was allegedly the dominant stockholder by seeking to change the name of existing junkyard to the corporation's name; corporation was required to apply as a new applicant for a license and board of selectmen, in ignoring separate identity of corporation and treating proceeding merely as one for name change, acted arbitrarily and capriciously. Error; judgment directed.

Title: Kilpatrick Bros., Inc. v. Poynter
Court: Supreme Court of Kansas.
Headnote: Evidence in action against husband and wife to pierce corporate veil and to establish personal liability for corporate debt supported finding that wife had not exercised any control over corporations in question.
Document Preview: Action against husband and wife to pierce corporate veil and to establish personal liability for corporate debt. The Labette District Court, Hal Hyler, J., rendered judgment against husband and denied recovery against wife. Husband appealed and plaintiffs cross-appealed. The Supreme Court, Harman, C., held that where judgments had been entered against defunct defendant corporations in four separate suits and in each of such suits executions had been issued and returned unsatisfied, plaintiffs, who were aware that preliminary suits against such corporations would have been useless, were not required, under statute providing that suit cannot be brought against director or stockholder for any debt of corporation until judgment be obtained against corporation and execution thereon returned unsatisfied, in whole or in part, to bring suit against such corporations prior to institution of suit against directors and stockholders of corporations. Affirmed. Fontron, J., concurred in part...

Title: Texas Industries, Inc. v. Dupuy & Dupuy Developers, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence on issue whether stockholder and officer of corporation used corporation for advancement of his personal affairs, whether he exercised control over its affairs or operations, or whether he received benefit therefrom did not warrant finding, in action in which shareholder and officer was sought to be held personally liable for corporate debt, of fraud, deception, or ill practices on part of stockholder and officer. LSA-C.C. arts. 435-437; LSA-R.S. 12:93, subd. B, 12:95.
Document Preview: Action by materialman to recover for materials sold and for recognition of its materialman's lien and privilege on property. Property owner brought third-party proceeding to recover for any amount for which it might be condemned from title insurer. Title insurer brought similar proceeding against corporation, which purchased materials, and two of corporation's stockholders. The 26th Judicial District Court, Parish of Bossier, O. E. Price, J., found for plaintiffs and found for title insurer in solido for amount awarded plaintiff against corporation. Stockholder appealed. The Court of Appeal, Ayres, J., held that evidence on issue whether stockholder and officer of corporation used corporation for advancement of his personal affairs, whether he exercised any control over its affairs or operations, or whether he received benefits therefrom did not warrant finding of fraud, deception or ill practices on part of stockholder and officer. Reversed and rendered.

Title: Peet v. Rose City Dodge, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Oregon, En Banc.
Headnote: In suit brought by Department of Employment Commissioner to recover taxes assessed against corporation for unemployment insurance, sufficient evidence was elicited in support of allegation that two individual defendants had so manipulated and dominated corporate defendant as to render the corporation their alter ego for purpose of defeating claims of plaintiff, thus entitling individual defendants to an involuntary nonsuit.
Document Preview: Action brought by Department of Employment Commissioner to recover taxes assessed against corporation for unemployment insurance. Motion of two individual defendants for an involuntary nonsuit was granted by the Circuit Court of Clackamas County, Howard L. Blanding, J., and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, O'Connell, J., held that no sufficient evidence was elicited in support of allegation that the two individual defendants had so manipulated and dominated corporate defendant as to render the corporation their alter ego for purpose of defeating claims of plaintiff, thus entitling individual defendants to an involuntary nonsuit. Affirmed.

Title: Kaminsky v. Kahn
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Finding that corporation was controlled by buyer of stock and that it was his alter ego was supported by evidence.
Document Preview: Accounting proceeding in which cross appeals were taken from judgment of the Supreme Court, Trial Term, New York County, Matthew M. Levy, J., in favor of seller. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that under contract for sale of a corporation's stock providing that if buyer desired to sell any of stock purchased he was required to submit written evidence of a bona fide purchase offer to seller who had right and option to purchase the shares upon the terms set forth in the offer, buyer who also owed other stock not subject to option, had duty upon selling stock in that corporation to first sell stock sold him by seller, even though buyer was not a fiduciary. The Court further held that where sale of unregistered stock, such as that transferred to buyer, was worth about 30 to 60% Less than registered stock traded on the exchange, holding buyer accountable for market price, less cost of registering stock, was error and judgment was modified to charge buyer only with actual...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Palmer v. Stokely
Court: United States District Court W.D. Oklahoma.
Headnote: Evidence of ownership, control, and conduct of companies and owners established that individual defendants in trustee in bankruptcy's action to set aside transfer maintained each of several corporations involved in transactions which drained bankrupt of assets as alter egos. Bankr.Act, § 67, sub. d(2), 11 U.S.C.A. § 107(d) (2).
Document Preview: Action by trustee in bankruptcy against individuals and company owned by them to recover amounts allegedly fraudulently transferred to defendants. The District Court, Daugherty, J., held, inter alia, that cancellation of amount owed bankrupt by corporation controlled by persons who controlled bankrupt was void where it occurred within one year prior to bankruptcy, there were creditors of bankrupt existing at time of cancellation, there were others who subsequently became creditors of bankrupt, bankrupt was insolvent at time of cancellation and was engaged in business for which property remaining in its hands after cancellation was unreasonably small capital, cancellation was made by owners in behalf of bankrupt and they believed it would incur debts beyond its ability to pay as debts matured, and was also made with actual intent to hinder, delay or defraud existing creditors and particularly premium stamp holders. Judgment for trustee.

Title: Finazzo v. Mid-States Finance Co.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that corporate employer's assets had been dispersed into corporate maze controlled by principal stockholder of employer, in suit by former employee to recover on contract providing he was to be paid percentage of employer's net earnings.
Document Preview: Suit by former employee against employer to recover under contract providing that employee was to be paid percentage of net earnings of employer. The Circuit Court, Madison County, I. H. Streeper, III, J., entered judgment adverse to defendant and defendant appealed. The Appellate Court, Goldenhersh, J., held that evidence supported finding that change of employer's accounting system reducing its net income had been made without plaintiff's approval and had been inconsistent with employer's prior accounting practices, but that there was no showing that employer's practice of making loans to affiliates without interest had been a change of employer's practice. Judgment for plaintiff in reduced amount entered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Platt v. Billingsley
Court: District Court of Appeal, Fifth District, California.
Headnote: Evidence supported findings that corporation was influenced, dominated, and controlled by sellers of part of their stock and buyer thereof who were sued on theory of alter ego for balance due remodeling contractor and whose corporation was under-capitalized at all times.
Document Preview: Action to hold stockholders personally liable for corporate indebtedness. The Superior Court, Orange County, Raymond Thompson, J., rendered judgment for remodeling contractor, and stockholders appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Stone, J., held that evidence supported finding that corporation was influenced, dominated, and controlled by sellers of part of stock and by buyer thereof who were sued on theory of alter ego and whose corporation was under-capitalized at all times. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Moore v. Savage
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Waco.
Headnote: Evidence permitted finding that president and controlling stockholder of loan company, exercising complete and independent control thereof, was its alter ego, personally liable for judgment for unreasonable collection efforts.
Document Preview: Action for unreasonable collection efforts brought against loan company by borrower and her employer. The 134th District Court, Dallas County, Charles E. Long, Jr., J., rendered judgment in favor of the defendant as against the borrower but in favor of her employer as against the defendant, and the defendant appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, McDonald, C. J., held that evidence including showing that loan company's employees telephoned plaintiff's business 15 times a day for some three months, in effort to collect employee's debt, demanding that employer pay it and came to her place of business and made demands for payment in person supported verdict for employer for actual damages for unreasonable collection efforts. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Fong v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Because government, suing for breach of contract for scrapping of surplus vessels sold to defendant so well pleaded facts showing that corporations were under complete domination and control of individual defendant in view of answer striking and default order no further evidence was required to hold defendant individually liable for damages, even though government's factual allegations were on information and belief because they stated facts primarily within defendant's knowledge. 31 U.S.C.A. §§ 231, 232; Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949, § 1 et seq., 40 U.S.C.A. § 471 et seq.
Document Preview: Action by government against purchaser of surplus vessels for purchaser's alleged failure to perform contract calling for the scrapping of the vessels. The United States District Court for the Northern District of California, Southern Division, Goodman, Chief Judge, 182 F.Supp. 446, entered a default judgment for the government and both the government and the defendant appealed from those portions of judgment which were adverse to them. The Court of Appeals, Bowen, District Judge, held that the court properly refused to enter a judgment for actual damages when the petition was not amended before default judgment to ask for more than liquidated damages under the contract. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Vavricka v. Mid-Continent Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Evidence that company engaged in purchase of oil royalties for profit and company engaged in selling its stock were organized and dominated by the same person who profited from the purchase of royalties, warranted finding that sales company was the "agent" of the royalties purchasing company in the sale of the latter's stock, so that in action against royalties purchasing company to rescind contract for purchase of its stock, such company should be held answerable for representations made by sales company's stock salesman.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Lancaster County; Shepherd, Judge. Action at law by Joseph J. Vavricka against the MidContinent Company and others to rescind contract for purchase of corporate stock on the ground of fraud and recover the purchase price. Judgment for plaintiff, and the named defendant appeals. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: People v. Allen
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: In prosecution for violation of the Corporate Securities Act, evidence that defendant and two others owned all authorized stock of the corporation, that defendant and another completely dominated the corporation and that the defendant and the other had given corporation practically nothing in return for 375,000 shares of stock, justified finding that the corporation was the alter ego of defendant and the other and that the corporation was simply a means used by them to assist them in selling worthless stock to the public. St.1917, p. 673 (repealed. See Corporations Code, § 25000 et seq.).
Document Preview: Appeal from Superior Court, Alameda County; Edward J. Tyrrell, Judge. George O. Allen was convicted of grand theft and of violating the Corporate Securities Act, and he appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Wiseman v. Sierra Highland Mining Co.
Court: Supreme Court of California.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to establish liability on part of dominant stockholder to minority stockholders on theory that dominant stockholder was alter ego of corporation and that he used corporate entity for his own enrichment to detriment of other stockholders.
Document Preview: Department 1. Quiet title action by A. L. Wiseman and others against the Sierra Highland Mining Company and others, wherein Julia M. Thorne and others intervened. From a judgment for defendants, plaintiffs and interveners appeal. Plaintiffs' appeal dismissed, and judgment against interveners affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(9) Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: U.S. Farm Land Co. v. Bennett
Court: District Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: In an action against one assuming to act as president and director of a corporation for goods sold and delivered, evidence held to show that the corporate business was wholly controlled and run by and under the direction and for the sole use, benefit, and behoof of defendant, and that the corporate name and style was employed by him to conveniently conduct his business, and that defendant was in fact conducting his own personal and private business under the corporate name.
Document Preview: Appeal from Superior Court, Madera County; W. M. Conley, Judge. Action by the United States Farm Land Company against R. F. Bennett. Judgment for plaintiff, and defendant appeals. Affirmed in the District Court of Appeal, and hearing denied in Supreme Court.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Schoeps v. Sompo Holdings, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Sparse allegations were insufficient to disregard the corporate form, and impute minimum contacts among non-resident company and its affiliates under an agency theory, for purposes of specific jurisdiction, in action brought by alleged heirs of German Jewish art collector, alleging conversion and other state law claims, seeking to recover collector's painting that was relinquished in era of Nazi regime's persecution; although heirs pointed to company-wide branding strategy, no facts were offered to show the essential integration of the company and its affiliates, and according to declarations, company and affiliates were not involved in each other's activities with respect to the conduct at issue in action, and heirs failed to rebut those declarations.
Document Preview: ESTATE PLANNING AND PROBATE  Parties. Alleged heirs of German art collector had standing to sue to recover a painting under Illinois law, based on their apparent standing under German law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Lowery v. Noodle Life, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Evidence sufficient to establish one relationship between corporate parties may not be sufficient to establish another; likewise, business relationships and interdependency of one corporation and another, alone, are insufficient to establish liability under alter ego, joint venture, and agency theories.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Owner of restaurant with same name as restaurant that served customer a package of hot soup that burned her was not liable under the alter ego doctrine.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: City of Dana Point v. New Method Wellness, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support finding that drug treatment facility operator and owner of residential properties housing facility patients operated as single enterprise; property owner's marketing, branding, and most of its clientele were all directly dependent on operating as part of the treatment facility, and entities had the same owners and same chief executive officer.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Nuisance. Residential properties were being operated as part of drug treatment facility, and thus constituted nuisances per se under city zoning ordinance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Volentine v. Raeford Farms of Louisiana, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence that chicken manufacturing company and its parent entity had similar names, two common managing officers, and participated in meeting between common managing officers, principal owner of parent entity, and interim complex manager of parent entity at parent entity's headquarters, was insufficient to demonstrate that company and parent entity comprised a single business enterprise, and thus entities were not subject to in solido liability in breach of contract action by breeder farmer.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Chicken manufacturing company's abrupt termination of breeder contract constituted bad faith breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Licea v. Curacao Drydock Company, Incorporated
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas' alter ego doctrine, organizational charts found on non-resident garnishees' website were not evidence sufficient to justify jurisdictional veil piercing of non-resident garnishees, and thus federal court lacked personal jurisdiction; charts did not depict corporate structure and ownership, and charts did not show functional relationship among entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Organizational charts were not evidence sufficient to justify jurisdictional veil piercing of non-resident garnishees.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Hasso v. Hapke
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Trial court's finding that there was a lack of unity of interest between hedge fund's managing member and the managing member's managing principal's investment management company, such that the investment management company was not liable for the debts of the managing member on the basis of single enterprise liability, was supported by substantial evidence, including forensic accountant's expert testimony that there was no evidence the two entities commingled assets, that they maintained their own legal formalities, that dealings between the two entities involved written contracts, and that the entities were each represented in such transactions by separate counsel.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION  Fraud. Trustee could not reasonably rely on any material misrepresentations about hedge fund investment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Capmark Financial Group Inc. v. Goldman Sachs Credit Partners L.P.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Public relations copy from company's website referring to its different practice areas as "business segments" and statements that employees were compensated based on the performance of the firm as a whole were insufficient to veil-pierce.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Reorganized debtors seeking to recover insider preferences failed to adequately allege elements for veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Allegheny Energy Supply Co., LLC v. Wolf Run Min. Co.
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Buyer of coal did not produce evidence that could have supported either a finding that seller did not observe corporate formalities or that piercing of the corporate veil was required to prevent fraud or other wrongdoing, although there was evidence of corporate control, where the record was devoid of evidence of self-dealing by parent corporation or evidence that subsidiary functioned as a shell corporation to assume liability without sufficient assets or capital.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Underperformance by seller of coal was not excused by the terms of force majeure clause.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Carlton Energy Group, LLC v. Phillips
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support jury's finding that company was an alter ego of defendant company; company's director was paid by defendant company, both companies shared an address, and corporate formalities were not followed by owner of the companies.
Document Preview: TORTS - Tortious Interference. Evidence supported damages award of $66.5 million to investor in natural gas project on tortious interference with contract claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Carlton Energy Group, LLC v. Phillips
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support finding that company was an alter ego of defendant company; defendant company's president, secretary/treasurer, and sole director was the general manager of company, and the two company names were used interchangeably in contracts and communications with multiple parties.
Document Preview: TORTS - Tortious Interference. Evidence supported damages award of $66.5 million to investor in natural gas project on tortious interference with contract claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: BBA Aviation PLC v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: Evidence of statements English parent company made in its consolidated annual reports and website, referring to its subsidiaries as "we," describing itself as a business in the aviation services industry, and failing to state that it was a holding company, was not substantial evidence supporting trial court's finding that parent company was not a holding company, in finding that parent company was subject to personal jurisdiction under the representative services doctrine, where the consolidated reports also contained references to "our portfolio of businesses" when describing actual operations and services. West's Ann.Cal.C.C.P. § 410.10.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Jurisdiction. Representative services doctrine did not support general jurisdiction over employer's parent company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Ramcke v. Georgia Power Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Parent corporation could not be held liable for any negligence on part of subsidiary that owned property and subsidiary that engineered and designed property's construction project on property regarding alleged failure to keep premises safe during project; there was insufficient evidence to pierce corporate veil, and there was no indication that parent corporation participated in a joint venture with its subsidiaries or acted as their agent or alter ego. West's Ga.Code Ann. § 51–3–1.
Document Preview: TORTS - Premises Liability. Property owner and its agent had no duty to keep work premises safe for construction company's invitees.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Carreras v. PMG Collins, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Although it is possible to pierce corporate veil in order to attribute contacts or actions of subsidiary to parent corporation, so as to support exercise of general jurisdiction over it, such judicial act requires as prerequisite that plaintiff show by clear evidence that parent in fact controls activities of subsidiary.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Jurisdiction. Vendors did not purposefully avail themselves of privilege of conducting business activities in Puerto Rico, thereby precluding specific personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Smith v. Louisiana Farm Bureau Cas. Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: There was insufficient evidence that owner operated all his businesses as a single business enterprise, as required to support finding that his personal automobile policy for the pickup truck he used on his farm, rather than the commercial automobile policy carried by his corporation, provided primary liability coverage on day pickup was used as a temporary substitute vehicle for corporation; corporation was a wholesale business that purchased, sold, and delivered crawfish, while farm was a sole proprietorship that farmed crawfish and sold them mostly to the corporation, entities filed separate tax returns, and owner held informal shareholder meetings for corporation.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Automobile. Pickup truck qualified as a covered temporary substitute automobile under corporation's commercial automobile policy.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Service Corp. Intern. v. Guerra
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi–Edinburg.
Headnote: Evidence was legally sufficient to show that corporate parent of operator of cemetery committed trespass against decedent's widow and children when operator's general manager moved decedent's remains without permission; manager's paychecks did not clearly differentiate between operator and parent, both of whose names and corporate logo contained the letters "SCI," and supervisor of operator's grounds crew that had moved decedent's body stated generally that he was employed by the "SCI company".
Document Preview: TORTS - Emotional Distress. Evidence was legally sufficient to support mental anguish damages award for children of decedent whose body cemetery operator had wrongfully moved.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Greer v. Natl. City Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Fifth District, Delaware County.
Headnote: Evidence was not sufficient to support a finding that a parent corporation was liable for the acts of a subsidiary bank in an account holders claim for breach of contract and defamation. The evidence indicated the parent and subsidiary were separate legal entities, the account holders entered into the account agreement with the subsidiary bank, all of the pertinent correspondence came directly from the subsidiary. Because the evidence did not indicate the parent corporation was involved in any of the events leading up to the dispute between the parties, the claims against the parent were dismissed as a matter of law.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Evidence was not sufficient to support a finding that a parent corporation was liable for the acts of a subsidiary bank in an account holders claim for breach of contract and defamation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Nautilus Ins. Co. v. Reuter
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to support finding under either Illinois or Indiana law that small corporations that had contracted with magazine clearinghouse to conduct door-to-door sales were shell corporations of clearinghouse, so as to permit treating small corporations as alter egos of clearinghouse for all purposes; there was conflicting testimony as to whether small corporations' employees were employees of clearinghouse, as to whether clearinghouse controlled small corporations' operations, and as to whether small corporations had places of business separate from clearinghouse's.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Choice of Law. Addresses on insurance-policy materials were insufficient to raise fact question as to choice of law in declaratory action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: N.L.R.B. v. Bolivar-Tees, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Determination of National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) that controlling shareholder and four corporations, which operated as single employer, failed to maintain separate identities, in ordering corporate veil pierced to allow enforcement of backpay order originally entered against defunct corporation against controlling shareholder, was supported by substantial evidence, including shareholder's control and ownership of all four corporations, his failure to operate offending corporation as a separate entity, failure to maintain adequate corporate records, failure to maintain an arm's-length relationship, failure to maintain corporate legal formalities, failure to avoid the commingling of funds, and failure to avoid the disposal of offending corporation's assets without fair consideration. National Labor Relations Act, § 1 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 151 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Unfair Labor Practices. Corporate veil could be pierced to enforce back pay order against controlling shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Country Village Homes, Inc. v. Patterson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to prove the Single Business Enterprise theory to pierce the corporate veil as the theory was presented in the jury charge, in home purchasers' breach of contract and fraud action against builder, developer, related businesses and common owner; there was evidence that the corporations shared common employees, common officers and a common accounting firm, and that one corporation paid another corporation's employees, employee of corporations testified that she transferred funds from the project of one corporation to the project of another corporation, and home purchasers' expert testified that funds were transferred between the corporations without sufficient documentation and that transfers between corporations for consulting fees were unclear allocations of profits and losses. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Error in failing to instruct actual fraud was an element of Single Business Enterprise theory was not preserved for appeal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Softbank Content Services Inc. v. MPO Canada Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: District court's finding that judgment debtor and its alleged alter-ego, a Canadian corporation, used a corporate reorganization to evade a judgment was supported by evidence that Canadian corporation placed all of its assets beyond judgment creditor's reach by a sale of shares and by encumbering its remaining shares with a lien, that judgment debtor was able to preserve its investment interest in those shares unburdened by the judgment, that Canadian corporation had no directors of its own, and that the reorganization was accomplished just in time to evade the judgment.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Costs. Attorney fee award of more than $1 million was proper in judgment creditor's civil action against judgment debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: In re Energy Smart, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Chapter 7 trustee failed to establish that debtor and related corporate entity, both of which were dominated and controlled by same sole shareholder, and both of which had their office at same address, were alter egos of each other, and was not entitled to pierce corporate veil in order to avoid, for benefit of debtor's bankruptcy estate, transfers made by this other corporate entity, where entities appeared to maintain separate bank accounts, and trustee did not present evidence as to whether funds from accounts were intermingled, whether corporate formalities were observed, or whether each entity maintained corporate records, and did not establish that other entity was mere device or sham to accomplish some ulterior purpose or was mere instrumentality or agent of debtor.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Party had no immediate right to possession of estate property, as required to support conversion claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Town Hall Estates-Whitney, Inc. v. Winters
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Waco.
Headnote: Evidence was legally insufficient to pierce the corporate veil and establish corporation that owned nursing home was vicariously liable to nursing home employee on her retaliation complaint; employee merely alleged that corporation was the parent company of nursing home and provided nursing home with its personnel policies.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Wrongful Discharge. Nursing home would not have terminated employee but for her report concerning resident's abuse allegation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: LinkAmerica Corp. v. Cox
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: Parent company of trucking company did not exert greater control over the subsidiary than was normally associated with common ownership and directorship so as to overcome the presumption that the two companies were independent entities, and thus, trucking company's contacts with Indiana could not be attributed to parent company for purposes of exerting personal jurisdiction over parent company in truck driver's action, even though subsidiary and parent shared the same board of directors and their shareholder meetings occurred in the same location and on the same day; although subsidiary and parent maintained their home office at the same address in Oklahoma, subsidiary conducted its daily business operations, including the transaction with driver, through separate employees from its separate business location in Indiana, and subsidiary's president and subordinates were not employees of parent. Trial Procedure Rule 4.4(A).
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Analysis of personal jurisdiction turned on whether exercise of personal jurisdiction was consistent with constitution.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: LinkAmerica Corp. v. Cox
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: Imprint on check that subsidiary trucking company gave to driver, which imprint indicated that the trucking company was part of parent company's corporate family, did not suggest that subsidiary was the same entity as parent or acting as an agent for parent so as to overcome the presumption that the two companies were independent entities, and thus, trucking company's contacts with Indiana could not be attributed to parent company for purposes of exerting personal jurisdiction over parent company in truck driver's action, where the checks were written by subsidiary to pay driver, who contracted only with subsidiary, and the checks were drawn on subsidiary's separate account. Trial Procedure Rule 4.4(A).
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Analysis of personal jurisdiction turned on whether exercise of personal jurisdiction was consistent with constitution.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Gish v. ECI Services of Oklahoma, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 1.
Headnote: Whether a corporation is vicariously liable for the acts of another corporation, based either on principles of agency or on the doctrine of "piercing the corporate veil", is a question of fact.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Parol evidence was admissible in a fraud trial.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Baize v. Eastridge Companies, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: The trial court's finding, in amending judgment to add corporation as a judgment debtor, that corporation was an alter ego of judgment debtor corporations, was supported by evidence of common ownership, officers and/or directors, and that within the family of entities, accounting entries were made to shift revenue profits freely for the tax and corporate benefit of the entities and their owners.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Alternative Dispute Resolution. Arbitration award was not reviewable for errors of law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Intelnet Intern. Corp. v. ITT Corp.
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: Parent company was not liable for acts of subsidiary upon contract and tort claims brought by telecommunications company, even though subsidiary was a mere instrumentality of the parent and was created for the purpose of limiting potential losses to the parent company in its contract dealings with telecommunications company, where there was insufficient evidence to show that subsidiary was created for an illegal purpose, given that subsidiary was created with as much capital as currently needed, and telecommunications company knew subsidiary's purpose, and there was no agency relationship between parent and subsidiary.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Parent company did not ratify contract signed by subsidiary, even though officers' mistakenly believed parent was bound.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Moses Lake Const. Co., Inc. v. Johnson
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 3.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to support truck lessor's contention that construction companies, which shared the same officers, employees, and address but which observed corporate formalities by carefully keeping separate books, abused the corporate form with the intent to violate or evade a duty to truck lessor under leases between lessor and first company such that it was necessary to disregard the corporate form and hold second company liable for harm done to lessor by sublease of trucks from first company to second company; first company attempted to purchase the trucks, which undercut lessor's argument that first company intended to default or evade its duties under the lease, and there was no evidence that sublease of trucks to second company was intended to harm lessor.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Company specifically waived in lease agreement any claim against truck lessor for damages due to repossession of trucks.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Sahu v. Union Carbide Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Evidence failed to establish that United States parent acted in concert with Indian subsidiary so as to subject parent to concerted action liability under New York law for injuries to Indian plaintiffs stemming from pollution resulting from subsidiary's general plant operations.
Document Preview: TORTS - Equitable Relief. Victims of pollution were not entitled to recovery on claims for medical monitoring and remediation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Montes Serrano v. New York Times Co., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Plaintiff failed to prove that trucking company's parent corporation so controlled the trucking company's operations as to warrant holding the parent corporation liable for delivery truck driver's negligence.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Parent corporation did not control subsidiary's operations as to warrant holding parent liable for subsidiary's negligence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Motorola Credit Corp. v. Uzan
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: By allowing judgment to be enforced against 130 companies purportedly controlled by the borrowers' principals, district court improperly pierced the corporate veils of those companies without a sufficient factual basis that they were alter egos of the principals.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Exercise of supplemental jurisdiction after dismissal of federal claims was not erroneous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Reers v. Deutsche Bahn AG
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: With respect to marketing policies, the fact that subsidiaries share a logo, or that the parent decides to present several corporations on a website in a unified fashion, is insufficient to show lack of formal separation between two entities for purposes of establishing that parent corporation assumed jurisdictional status of subsidiary based on theory that subsidiary is a "mere department" of parent.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Dismissal. Suit arising from train accident in France would be dismissed on forum non conveniens grounds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Collette v. Unique Vacations, Inc.
Court: Massachusetts Appellate Division, District Court Department, Northern District.
Headnote: Reservation booking company would not be designated vacation resort's "alter ego," so as to render it liable for resort's breach of hurricane guarantee, absent evidence regarding who owned and ran the two companies, whether reservation company"s employees had any say in how the resort was run, or whether resort actively participated in the daily operations of the reservation company.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Joint Ventures. Reservation company was not liable for resort's breach of contract as participant in joint venture.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: U-Can-II, Inc. v. Setzer
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, First District.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient that appellant, a corporation, was the alter ego of certain non-parties and that, on that basis, its corporate veil could be pierced; appellees did not present any evidence showing improper conduct by appellant or that appellant was organized or used to mislead creditors, record contained no express contract of agency with respect to non-parties and appellees presented no evidence of apparent authority, and trial court did not make requisite specific findings of improper conduct by appellant.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence did not support piercing of appellant's/corporation's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Von Grabe v. Sprint PCS
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: That parent corporation and subsidiary have common officers is not prima facie evidence of alter ego relationship supporting personal jurisdiction over parent corporation based on subsidiary's forum contacts.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Consumer Protection. Customer did not satisfy notice requirements of California's Consumers Legal Remedies Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Harris Rutsky & Co. Ins. Services, Inc. v. Bell & Clements Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: To satisfy the agency exception to the general rule that a subsidiary and its parent are separate entities for purposes of personal jurisdiction, the plaintiff must make a prima facie showing that the subsidiary represents the parent by performing services sufficiently important to the parent that if it did not have a representative to perform them, the parent would undertake to perform substantially similar services.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Agents and Brokers. Exercise of personal jurisdiction over English insurance broker was reasonable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Amoco Production Co. v. Texaco, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence supported trial court's piercing of corporate veil and holding corporate parent liable to gas production company for the exploration company subsidiary's breach of reassignment clauses of mineral subleases; corporate parent invested $37,000,000 to buy gas and gas properties which it put into subsidiary's name, corporate parent had discretion over subsidiary's profits, corporate parent divested subsidiary of all its assets and funds, terminated subsidiary's employees, and ceased all subsidiary operations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate parent was liable to gas production company for subsidiary's breach of mineral subleases.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: DVI, Inc. v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Deposition testimony by officer of creditor's parent corporation, in which officer stated that the same people served as directors of creditor and parent corporation and that parent corporation wasn't really concerned "too much with the legal subsidiary lines," did not establish alter ego or that parent exercised such a degree of control over creditor that creditor could be described as only a means through which parent acted, and thus was insufficient to establish general jurisdiction over parent corporation in action by borrower for breach of contract and tort claims.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Foreign parent corporation of subsidiary was not subject to general jurisdiction in California.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Central de Fianzas, S.A. v. Bridgefarmer & Associates, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Judgment creditor failed to show that, under Texas law, judgment debtor and its purported parent company were not separate entities, for alter ego purposes, and so failed to pierce the corporate veil; judgment creditor neither pled nor made a suggestion of fraud, and the only clearly substantiated "facts" included that judgment debtor was undercapitalized, that invoices reflecting work for the project at issue were not sent by judgment debtor to the outside customer, but were incorporated into purported parent's billings to the customer, asking that payments be made to purported parent, that tax treatment was that of a consolidated corporate return, and that purported parent's office showed no outward indicia that judgment debtor was its separate subsidiary. V.T.C.A., Bus. & C. § 2.21.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Parties. Judgment debtor was indispensable party in action to enforce Panamanian judgment against its purported parent company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Lee v. International Data Group
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to disregard separate identities of alleged employer and other company in employee's action against alleged employer for damages from at-work injury; there was evidence alleged employer and company both paid employee's salary, company's major funding was provided by a source other than alleged employer, and correspondence between company's executive director and alleged employer's agent did not indicate company was carrying out tasks pursuant to alleged employer's command or that alleged employer's permission was sought before director took action on company's behalf.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Superior Court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to hear action for injuries suffered at work.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Electro Lock, Inc. v. Core Industries, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Evidence supported conclusion that parent and grandparent corporations were seller's alter egos and were liable to buyer in suit seeking to pierce seller's corporate veil and recover damages for breach of warranty.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent and grandparent corporations were seller's alter egos and were liable to buyer for breach of warranty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Eure v. Norfolk Shipbuilding & Drydock Corp., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Virginia.
Headnote: Evidence that parent corporation did not have a board of directors, and evidence that parent corporation was listed as the applicant in an application for a letter of credit securing subsidiary corporation's obligations under agreement to provide health care to surviving spouse of subsidiary's president, through subsidiary's health care plan, for surviving spouse's lifetime, did not establish that parent was mere alter ego of subsidiary, and thus, parent was not liable for subsidiary's obligations.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Agreement was ambiguous as to continuation of officers' medical expense reimbursement plan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Gonchar v. Samsung Deutschland GMBH
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Finding that Kazakh corporation that was operating copper and chemical extraction plant was not the alter ego of subsidiary of one of corporation's shareholders was supported by evidence showing various interests in Kazakh corporation, which was owned by the government of Kazakhstan and an assortment of private investors, including parent company-shareholder, and there was no evidence of a unity of interest and ownership between Kazakh corporation and shareholder's affiliate, such that their separateness as corporations had to be ignored.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Settlements. State court could adjudicate dispute over meaning of settlement agreement, especially given forum selection clauses.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Bagel Bros. Maple, Inc. v. Ohio Farmers, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Although representation allegedly made by common shareholders of separate corporate entities, each of which operated bagel and delicatessen store at separate localities in New York and Ohio, that company which supplied food products to Ohio stores would be paid by some nonexistent entity might provide a basis, under New York law, for holding shareholders personally liable as agents for nonexistent principal, it did not provide basis for holding corporation that operated New York store and that did not receive any produce from supplier liable on supplier's invoices, in absence of showing of facts sufficient to support a piercing of corporations' separate identities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Veil Piercing. Debtor-corporation could not be held liable for related corporate entities' debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Yankee Microwave, Inc. v. Petricca Communications Systems, Inc.
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Berkshire.
Headnote: Evidence that a clear corporate differentiation was kept in transactions between corporation which received transfer repaying past advances it made and corporation that was rendered insolvent by such transfer, and that there were additional owners in corporation receiving transfer besides two brothers who were the sole shareholders in transferring corporation, was sufficient to support finding that corporations were separate entities, despite evidence that brothers were dominant shareholders and played dominant role as directors and officers of both corporations, for purposes of claim by creditor that such transfer was not for fair consideration because brothers, acting as directors of insolvent corporation, were really paying monies to themselves as directors and themselves as shareholders. M.G.L.A. c. 156B, § 61; c. 109A, § 1 et seq. (Repealed).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Insolvent corporation's repayment of advances made by related corporation was not a fraudulent conveyance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Lonza AG v. Blum
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: In suit for wrongful termination brought by former employee of American subsidiary against Swiss parent corporation, evidence that subsidiary did not retain large profits and that parent company drew substantial revenues from subsidiary were insufficient to pierce the corporate veil; evidence did not show that subsidiary was judgment proof or a mere shell corporation.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. In suit filed by former employee of subsidiary corporation, jurisdiction did not reach parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Bestfoods v. Aerojet-General Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Parent corporation's actions regarding wholly owned subsidiary were not eccentric under norms of parental oversight, and thus government was not entitled to recover in its CERCLA cost recovery action against parent, although lawyer who coordinated parent's pollution programs attempted to dictate standards for subsidiary, where subsidiary did not comply with the standards and advice of the lawyer and the lawyer did not have authority to make demands of subsidiary. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107(a), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a).
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Corporation's oversight of subsidiary was within norms, defeating CERCLA cost recovery claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Bestfoods v. Aerojet-General Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Statement that one chemist or engineer from parent corporation came to wholly owned subsidiary's chemical manufacturing facility and directed the manufacturing at the facility was insufficient to support finding that parent corporation was an operator of facility that could be held liable in government's CERCLA cost recovery action; subsidiary's officials necessarily would have provided authorization for the run of synthetic leather. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107(a), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a).
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Corporation's oversight of subsidiary was within norms, defeating CERCLA cost recovery claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Graham Graphics, Inc. v. Baer Marketing Intern., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil to hold successor parent corporation liable for subsidiary's debt to graphics company was warranted, where original parent corporation had controlled subsidiary, business remained unchanged after successor took over using same name, management employees, and address, the same company and same nucleus of individuals controlled original parent corporation and successor, and the address on successor's checks matched the one on the invoices.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Successor parent corporation was liable for subsidiary's debt to printer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Apollo Plaza Ltd. v. Antietam Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil of judgment debtor's corporation was proper, where corporation intermingled transactions, property, employees, and funds with debtor's other corporations, corporation was organized for personal manipulation by debtor, and money placed in corporate account was placed there primarily to escape debtor's personal liability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing veil was appropriate for corporation exploited by judgment debtor.
