Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: North American Van Lines, Inc. v. Emmons
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Subsidiary of interstate carrier, which was using moving van leased by carrier from moving company pursuant to carrier's authority at time van was involved in a rear-end collision, was not an alter ego of carrier, as would permit corporate veil to be pierced in suit brought against carrier, subsidiary, moving company, and driver of van by passenger of rear-ended vehicle; while subsidiary was wholly owned by carrier, and there was evidence that it was insufficiently capitalized, no exceptional circumstances justified an alter ego determination.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Interstate carrier and its subsidiary were operated as a single business enterprise.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: North American Van Lines, Inc. v. Emmons
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Evidence supported jury finding that interstate carrier which had leased moving van from moving company, and subsidiary of carrier which was using van for one of its shipments under carrier's authority at time van was involved in rear-end collision, were operated as a single business enterprise, so that carrier and subsidiary could be held liable for each other's liability with respect to action arising from collision; with one exception all officers of subsidiary were also officers of carrier, and carrier performed essential administrative functions for subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Interstate carrier and its subsidiary were operated as a single business enterprise.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Middle Tennessee News Co., Inc. v. Charnel of Cincinnati, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence that three companies, through their shared president and sole shareholder, at all times held themselves out as and did business as one corporation was sufficient, under Indiana law, to hold them jointly liable to book seller for amounts allegedly due on prior book sales.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Debtor Protections. Judgment did not violate bankruptcy automatic stay.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Real Estate Investors Four, Inc. v. American Design Group Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Five.
Headnote: Corporate occupant of leased premises exercised complete control over corporate lessee, thus justifying piercing corporate veil in action by lessor for unpaid rent and property damage, where corporations' officers overlapped, officer of one corporation signed documents on behalf of other corporation, lessee had no capital, assets, revenues, business, or employees, lessee's only business was to pass rent from occupant to lessor, and occupant occupied premises as sublessee without written agreement, despite nonassignment clause in lease.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Actual occupant of premises leased to corporation was liable to lessor under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Real Estate Investors Four, Inc. v. American Design Group Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Five.
Headnote: Evidence established that occupant of leased premises used control over corporate lessee to commit fraud and to act in disregard of lessor's legal rights, justifying piercing corporate veil in lessor's action against occupant for unpaid rent and property damage; evidence that lessee had no money of its own, and received monthly payments from occupant merely to pass them along to lessor, showed lessee's undercapitalization, and evidence that corporate officer signed lease as officer but later testified he was not officer, that lessee never notified lessor that occupant occupied premises, and that lessee never occupied premises itself or conducted business there, showed fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Actual occupant of premises leased to corporation was liable to lessor under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Hamilton v. Carell
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Independent fiduciary of employee benefits trust fund failed to establish that corporation owned by former fund contract administrator was a shell, and thus there was no need to set aside its corporate form on grounds that it was used for fraudulent or improper purposes to avoid a legal obligation, where corporation was solvent when it settled with independent fiduciary for $600,000, and there was no evidence that corporation could not have funded a judgment for full amount of plaintiffs' demands. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Former employee benefits fund contract administrator was not fiduciary of fund.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Smith v. McLeod Distributing, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: There was sufficient evidence that corporation which installed floor products and corporation which distributed floor products were effectively the same corporation, thus justifying a holding that distributor was merely an adjunct to or alter ego of installer and, thus, its corporate veil could be pierced to hold it liable for debt to distributor of floor coverings; only difference between corporations was that one dealt in all floor coverings while the other dealt in all floor coverings except mats, corporations had same president and office manager, operated at same address and used an identical telephone number, and engaged in virtually identical lines of business, and there was evidence that they intermingled their assets or that one corporation paid for obligations of the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced to hold another corporation liable for commercial debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Hamilton v. AAI Ventures, L.L.C.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence supported trial court's piercing of corporate veil and finding parent corporation liable for breach of contract debt of subsidiary, based on inadequate capitalization, common employees, common offices, and centralized accounting; subsidiary was formed for single purpose of performing asbestos removal in single project, organizational charts for various affiliated companies illustrated overlap and disregard for separate corporate entities, individuals testified they were unsure of co-workers' job titles or record employers, employees of one organization were housed at offices of other organizations, and subsidiary had no employees.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported trial court's piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Godwin Realty Associates v. CATV Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Evidence that corporate defendant had been treated as a shell corporation by its corporate and individual shareholders, that those shareholders had stripped the corporation of its assets, leaving insufficient assets to cover the claimed damages by building owners as to building damage and unauthorized use of electricity in connection with defendant's use, installation, and removal of cable television equipment, supported piercing of the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported piercing of the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Backuswalcott v. Common Ground Community HDFC, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, equity did not require court to pierce the corporate veil of defendant not-for-profit corporation or its other affiliates, so as to impose liability for corporation's efforts to collect rent arrears from hotel tenants under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA), despite the Act's so-called "affiliate exemption"; although corporation maintained offices at hotel, arguably held itself out as sharing some staff with hotel, comprehensively managed services at the premises, and for all intents and purposes was an owner of hotel, the two entities maintained separate payrolls and filed separate payroll taxes, and there was no evidence that the two entities intermingled funds or otherwise operated a single economic enterprise, that either was inadequately capitalized, or that either had not followed proper formalities. Consumer Credit Protection Act, § 803(6)(B), as amended, 15 U.S.C.A. § 1692a(6)(B).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Not-for-profit corporation fell within FDCPA's affiliate exemption.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: HealthOne, Inc. v. Columbia Wesley Medical Center
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: There was no evidence that maintaining separate corporate structures for defendant hospital and affiliated health care organization would work injustice on plaintiff corporation in its breach of contract action, precluding piercing of corporate veil under Kansas law in order to reach health care organization which was non-party to contract, since hospital possessed ample net worth to pay any judgment rendered in action.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Patients' third party liability claims did not refer to claims against patients' own insurers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers v. Springfield Terminal Ry. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to pierce corporate veil of wood products corporation that was owned and controlled by railway's owners and that performed switching work historically performed by railway's employees, and injunction thus was warranted, under RLA status quo provisions that were applicable to major disputes, to prevent corporation from switching; overlap in ownership between railway and corporation was almost total, and railway only invited corporation to perform switching for its customers after railway was unable to convince unions to accept wage concessions. Railway Labor Act, § 1 et seq., 45 U.S.C.A. § 151 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Transportation Workers. Injunction was warranted to prevent switching by corporation controlled by railway's owners.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Pennmark Resources Co. v. Oklahoma Corp. Com'n
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 3.
Headnote: Corporation Commission's determination that corporation that was incumbent unit operator was not alter ego of corporation to which part of operator's ownership interest was transferred, so that unit agreement provision prohibiting incumbent operator from voting in operator-removal election did not apply to transferee, was not supported by substantial evidence, where transferee was wholly owned subsidiary of operator, they had commonality of purpose, and operator's directors and officers controlled transferee.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Oil and Gas. Determination that unit operator was not alter ego of transferee was unsupported.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. Holliman
Court: Court of Appeals of Mississippi.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to find that two corporations were one entity or alter egos for purposes of determining which parties were liable to injured worker for payment of workers' compensation benefits, in light of fact that corporations had same owners, same business address, and same attorney, and where third party had received assignment forms and check that used name of first corporation with cover letter that used name of second corporation.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Insurance policy was cancelled, despite lack of notice, where employer had insurance through alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Harco Energy, Inc. v. Re-Entry People, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Amarillo.
Headnote: Evidence was legally insufficient to support finding that either of defendant corporations had defrauded oil service company based on theories of alter ego, common business enterprise, sham to perpetuate a fraud, or similar theories, absent any evidence that oil service company agent relied on representations made by defendant corporations, or on subsequently discovered document allegedly authorizing third corporation to misrepresent ownership of lease site, in making agreement for service company to work on project. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21, subds. A, B.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Corporate president who agreed to pay for job was individually liable for breach of contract and fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Paredes v. Abercrombie & Kent Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, passengers of cruise line and tour operator, who were allegedly injured during ground tour, failed to pierce the corporate veil so as to hold cruise line liable for tour operator's conduct; although cruise line allegedly failed to distinguish between itself and tour operator in its marketing materials, cruise line was not a sister corporation of tour operator, and there was no evidence of undercapitalization, commingling of funds, failure to comply with formalities, or failure to operate at arms-length.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Passengers failed to pierce the corporate veil so as to hold cruise line liable for tour operator's conduct.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Flint Elec. Membership Corp. v. Barrow
Court: Supreme Court of Georgia.
Headnote: Finding that subsidiary of electric membership corporation was the alter-ego of corporation and, thus, that it was precluded under the Electric Membership Corporation Act from furnishing or selling propane gas to corporation's members, was supported by evidence that subsidiary was wholly owned by corporation, that a majority of subsidiary's directors were officers or directors of corporation, and that subsidiary was incorporated just to enable corporation to do indirectly was the Act precluded corporation from doing directly. O.C.G.A. § 46-3-201(b)(7).
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Electricity. Electric membership corporation was precluded from selling propone gas to its members.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Velazquez v. P.D.I. Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to establish legitimacy of corporate structure, preventing piercing of the corporate veil for purposes of discrimination action brought by wholly-owned subsidiary's employee against parent corporation, despite evidence that there was an overlap of officers between the parent and its subsidiary; prior to parent's acquisition of subsidiary, parent purchased products from subsidiary, it continued to do so after the acquisition, money moved between parent and subsidiary was done as loan, and subsidiary was authorized distributor of product, but parent was not.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was sufficient to support legitimacy of corporate structure, preventing piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: 66, Inc. v. Crestwood Commons Redevelopment Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Missouri, En Banc.
Headnote: Making a corporation a supplemental part of an economic unit and operating it without sufficient funds to meet obligations to those who must deal with it would be circumstantial evidence tending to show either an improper purpose or reckless disregard of the rights of others, for purposes of determining whether corporate veil should be pierced.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Eminent Domain. Owners of uncapitalized redevelopment corporation were liable for damages to landowner when condemnation was abandoned.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Garden State Tanning, Inc. v. Mitchell Mfg. Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil on an alter-ego theory must establish that the controlling corporation wholly ignored the separate status of the controlled corporation and so dominated and controlled its affairs that its separate existence was a mere sham, or alternatively that the controlled corporation acted robot- or puppet-like in mechanical response to the controller's tugs on its strings or pressure on its buttons.
Document Preview: Creditor of corporate subsidiary sued parent, seeking to recover under guaranty and for alleged fraudulent transfer of assets of subsidiary to third party. Parent moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Katz, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) there were fact questions regarding scope of guaranty precluding recovery on breach of contract, unjust enrichment and quantum meruit theories; (2) transfer of assets was not fraudulent under Michigan statutes; (3) transfer was not fraudulent under Pennsylvania common law; (4) transfer was not fraudulent under Michigan common law; and (5) creditor failed to establish that subsidiary was alter ego of parent, under laws of Michigan or Pennsylvania. Motion granted in part, denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Material Supply Intern., Inc. v. Sunmatch Industrial Co ., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Evidence that subsidiary corporation was wholly owned by its parent and had the same president, secretary-treasurer, address and registered agent as the parent was insufficient to establish that the subsidiary was the alter ego of the parent under District of Columbia Law, absent evidence that parent and subsidiary had common business departments, that parent financed subsidiary, that subsidiary was inadequately capitalized, or that subsidiary was operated as a mere division of parent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Evidence was insufficient to establish that subsidiary was alter ego of parent corporation.

Title: Fontenot Petro-Chem & Marine Services, Inc. v. LaBono
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: There was sufficient evidence to support finding that two corporations were operating as a single business enterprise or alter ego; long-time employee testified that she thought the two corporations were the same company, another employee testified that she would be on one corporation's payroll one week and the other the next, and there was evidence that one corporation serviced customers which required use of union employees, while other employed non-union employees and serviced companies that had no preference.
Document Preview: TORTS - Defamation. Corporation was liable for slander of employee by a vice-principal during convention social.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Molenda v. Hoechst Celanese Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida, Miami Division.
Headnote: There was insufficient evidence to warrant holding subsidiary liable under Florida Whistle-Blower's Act for acts of another subsidiary of same parent after employee of subsidiary made statements about alleged falsification of corporate records and receipt of illegal kickbacks by officers of other subsidiary. West's F.S.A. § 448.102(3).
Document Preview: Former employee brought action against employer for wrongful discharge, defamation and breach of contract. On employer's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Seitz, J., held that: (1) whistleblower claim could not be based on actions of another subsidiary of same parent; (2) issues of fact precluded summary judgment on whistleblower claim based in actions of former supervisor; and (3) discharge was not based on age discrimination. Motion granted in part, and denied in part.

Title: Ansonia Associates Ltd. v. Quik Park Ansonia Garage Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Although there was strong indicia of domination and control by parent corporation over judgment debtor, judgment creditor failed, despite substantial discovery in judgment debtor's bankruptcy proceeding, to make showing, as was required to disregard of corporate form, that such domination and control was used for fraudulent ends, and was cause of debtor's insolvency and its inability to pay rent due to judgment creditor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Judgment creditor failed to establish basis to hold parent corporation liable for subsidiary's debt.

Title: Ansonia Associates Ltd. v. Quik Park Ansonia Garage Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Judgment creditor failed to establish claim that shareholder of parent corporation used debtor corporation for purely personal rather than corporate ends, as was required to hold shareholder liable for subsidiary's debt.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Judgment creditor failed to establish basis to hold parent corporation liable for subsidiary's debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Johnson Enterprises of Jacksonville, Inc. v. FPL Group, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Even if cable television company was "mere instrumentality" of it parent, there was no evidence that parent used its subsidiary for purpose of engaging in improper conduct, as required to pierce corporate veil and hold parent liable, under Florida law, for subsidiary's alleged breach of contract; there was nothing unlawful in subsidiary's franchising activity, which contractor alleged amounted to "greenmail" scheme carried out by parent and subsidiary.
Document Preview: Contractor sued cable television company and its parent company, alleging breach of contract for construction of cable television systems and fraud, racketeering, and tortious interference. The United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida, No. 89-893-CIV-J-16, Anthony A. Alaimo, J., granted defendants judgment as a matter of law on several claims, but entered judgment for contractor on contract claims against both defendants and for contractor on tortious interference claim against parent. Both parties appealed. The Court of Appeals, Tjoflat, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) alleged mileage guarantee was barred by parol evidence rule and was unsupported by consideration; (2) contract was not subject to Uniform Commercial Code's (UCC) duty of good faith; (3) contractor was not fraudulently induced to enter contract; (4) there was no evidentiary basis for racketeering claims; (5) corporate veil of parent would not be pierced to hold it liable for breach of contract...

Title: Laird v. Capital Cities/ABC, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: Former employee of subsidiary corporation failed to show that subsidiary was its parent corporation's alter ego, such that parent could be held liable for employment discrimination allegedly perpetrated against former employee; there was no evidence that parent exercised day-to-day control over subsidiary's employment decisions or that parent exercised greater control over subsidiary's operations than that which parent corporation would normally exercise over its subsidiary, and there was no showing of common management. West's Ann.Cal.Gov.Code § 12900 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Parent corporation was not liable for discrimination perpetrated against employee of subsidiary.

Title: Booker v. F.W. Woolworth Co.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Customer failed to establish that corporation was liable for actions of sister corporation, and thus customer could not maintain action against corporation on basis of sister corporation's alleged improper treatment of customer.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Venue. Trial court was justified in transferring venue to parish in which defendants were located and incident occurred.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: In re Minnesota Breast Implant Litigation
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Recipients of silicone breast implants manufactured by company which had purchased implant product line from its original manufacturer failed to show that manufacturer and company which purchased product line were operated as parent/subsidiary, as would allow recovery under Arizona law against manufacturer on products liability claims arising from implants, even though predecessor to company which purchased product line had been owned by original manufacturer.
Document Preview: Following transfer of previously consolidated actions asserted by recipients of silicone breast implants, company which had originally manufactured implants, but had divested itself of product line, moved for summary judgment with respect to claims asserted by Arizona recipients who purchased implants made by new owner of product line. The District Court, Magnuson, Chief Judge, held that: (1) Arizona law applied to products liability claims, while Minnesota law applied to fraud claims; (2) company could not be held strictly liable for defects in implants it did not manufacturer; (2) company owed no duty to recipients of implants made by new owner; (3) company could not be held liable on breach of warranty or consumer protection claims; (4) company owed no duty to recipients to disclose information, and thus was not liable under theory of fraudulent misrepresentation; (5) company was not alter ego of new owner of product line; and (6) transfer of product line following divestiture...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: AT & T Global Information Solutions Co. v. Union Tank Car Co.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Evidence established that grandparent company had sufficient dominion and control over subsidiary that subsidiary had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, which thus supported piercing corporate veil under Ohio law to hold grandparent liable for subsidiary's arranger liability under CERCLA; grandparent sold subsidiary to intermediate parent and then effectuated dissolution of both, effectively owned all capital stock in subsidiary, had overlapping employees, corporate directors and officers with subsidiary, commingled funds with subsidiary, effectively paid employee benefits and other miscellaneous expenses or losses of subsidiary, obtained all of subsidiary's funds upon liquidation, and subsidiary had minimally adequate capital. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107, 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607.
Document Preview: Potentially responsible parties (PRPs) who entered consent order with Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) concerning cleanup of solvent reclamation site brought contribution action under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) against subsidiary and grandparent corporations concerning alleged disposal of subsidiary's waste at site. On motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Holschuh, J., held that: (1) evidence that subsidiary created toxic waste and had it deposited at site supported imposition of arranger liability against subsidiary under CERCLA; (2) Ohio law would apply to issue of piercing corporate veil of grandparent company; and (3) evidence that grandparent company exercised dominion and control over subsidiary, that piercing of corporate veil was necessary to prevent injustice, and that subsidiary would have been liable in CERCLA contribution action if subsidiary had not been dissolved by grandparent, supported piercing...

Title: Rivera Rojas v. Loewen Group Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Evidence that subsidiary filed its own tax returns, kept its own minutes book, maintained separate financial records, held its own directors' meetings, filed its own corporate reports, and paid for its employees' workers' insurance funds was sufficient to support finding that subsidiary was not alter ego of parent corporation; record did not indicate that subsidiary's corporate identity had been violated.
Document Preview: Sellers of funeral home business brought breach of contract action against corporate buyer for alleged mismanagement of company, onerous loan agreement, and misappropriation of profits.  Buyer moved to dismiss for failure to join its subsidiary, allegedly a necessary party.  The District Court, Laffitte, J., held that: (1) subsidiary was an indispensable party, and (2) subsidiary was not alter ego of buyer. Motion granted.

Title: Aubert v. American General Finance, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Debtor failed to establish grounds for disregarding corporate formalities of parent corporation, subsidiary to which debtor owed debt, and subsidiary that attempted to collect debt, and hold them jointly responsible for alleged violation of Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA), given absence of evidence of inadequate capitalization or failure to observe legal requirement of separate corporate existences. Consumer Credit Protection Act, § 802 et seq., as amended, 15 U.S.C.A. § 1692 et seq.
Document Preview: Credit card debtor brought action under Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA) against corporation that sent him letter regarding delinquent account, related company that issued credit card, and those companies' parent corporation.  Defendants moved for summary judgment.  The United States District Court for the Western District of Wisconsin, Stephen Crocker, United States Magistrate Judge, granted motion.  Debtor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Flaum, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) corporation that attempted to collect debt was not debt collector; (2) creditor-company on whose behalf affiliated corporation was attempting to collect debt was not subject to FDCPA; (3) parent corporation was not subject to FDCPA; and (4) no grounds existed for piercing corporate veil of three companies. Affirmed.

Title: Harwood Tire-Arlington, Inc. v. Young
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: Evidence showed that subsidiary was operated as mere tool of parent and there was no separateness between them, and thus evidence was legally and factually sufficient to disregard corporate fiction and hold parent liable for injuries suffered by subsidiary's employee, even though subsidiary had its own articles of incorporation, by-laws, and federal tax identification number, where subsidiary was created by reorganization plan to limit liability of parent and subsidiary, subsidiary did business same after reorganization as it had before, sole shareholder and director of parent was given blanket authority to manage subsidiary, subsidiary paid mortgage of sister company, and parent's corporate name was used synonymously with name of subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was sufficient to disregard corporate fiction and hold parent liable for injuries suffered by employee of subsidiary.

Title: TNS Holdings, Inc. v. MKI Securities Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: There was no evidence that sister corporation acted as alter ego of subsidiary of parent corporation who had entered into contract containing arbitration clause for parent corporation, and, thus, sister corporation was not required to participate in arbitration proceedings arising out of contract dispute.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Parent corporation was required under alter ego theory to arbitrate dispute arising out contract involving subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Chrysler Corp. v. Ford Motor Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Evidence of alleged functional integration of subsidiary and parent, through interlocking boards of directors and common managers and employees, was not sufficient to pierce corporate veil and deem subsidiary alter-ego of parent so as to be liable for parent's pollution, absent additional showing that integration was done for wrongful purpose; evidence established that subsidiary's activation and relations with parent were for legal purpose of securing credit for performance of defense contracts, satisfying creditor-imposed requirements, and obtaining favorable tax consequences, without consideration of potential for environmental cleanup liability.
Document Preview: Successor to subsidiary filed action seeking declaratory judgment that it was not liable for response costs under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA) or Michigan Environmental Response Act (MERA), and various defendants filed counterclaims asserting liability of successor under CERCLA and MERA and under theories of public nuisance and undue enrichment.  The District Court, Feikens, J., held that: (1) issue of whether subsidiary was successor to parent's alleged environmental liabilities concerned external liability and thus would be determined under law of state having most significant relationship to lawsuit rather than law of state of incorporation; (2) Michigan law would guide application of theories of successor liability of subsidiary based on factors indicating that Michigan had most significant relationship to lawsuit; (3) evidence of alleged functional integration of subsidiary and parent was not sufficient to pierce...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Northern Tankers (Cyprus) Ltd. v. Backstrom
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to conclude that individual principals of large group of shipping and real estate companies dominated such companies and disregarded their corporate forms, and therefore, plaintiff seeking to collect arbitration award from one shipping company could pierce corporate veil and recover award from principals or from any of their companies; shareholdings of all companies were identical and shares were beneficially owned by principals, companies had same directors and officers and used same office, companies were nominally capitalized and provided funding for each other, parent and subsidiary companies filed consolidated income tax returns, and parent companies made decisions for subsidiaries.
Document Preview: Company brought action against individual principals of large group of shipping companies, and against shipping and real estate entities created by such principals, seeking to collect arbitration award for breach of sub-charter agreement.  The District Court, Goettel, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to conclude that principals dominated their companies and disregarded their corporate forms, as required to pierce corporate veil; (2) bad faith breach of contract claim was barred by res judicata; (3) plaintiff could not prevail on fraudulent nondisclosure claim; (4) plaintiff was entitled to recover on claim alleging conspiracy to fraudulently transfer mortgage; but (5) plaintiff could not establish claims for conspiracy to defraud against individuals and partnerships who were alter egos of other alleged participants in conspiracy. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Northern Tankers (Cyprus) Ltd. v. Backstrom
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Plaintiff seeking to collect arbitration award against shipping company from individual principals who controlled company offered sufficient evidence that such principals used their control over company to commit fraud and inequity, as would support piercing of corporate veil to allow collection of award from principals or from companies they owned; accounts receivable were retroactively dividended to parent companies in effort to avoid creditors, bad debt was transferred to company, company paid large management fees even though they were inactive, and critical discovery documents were intentionally withheld during early stages of litigation while company's assets were stripped to avoid creditors.
Document Preview: Company brought action against individual principals of large group of shipping companies, and against shipping and real estate entities created by such principals, seeking to collect arbitration award for breach of sub-charter agreement.  The District Court, Goettel, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to conclude that principals dominated their companies and disregarded their corporate forms, as required to pierce corporate veil; (2) bad faith breach of contract claim was barred by res judicata; (3) plaintiff could not prevail on fraudulent nondisclosure claim; (4) plaintiff was entitled to recover on claim alleging conspiracy to fraudulently transfer mortgage; but (5) plaintiff could not establish claims for conspiracy to defraud against individuals and partnerships who were alter egos of other alleged participants in conspiracy. Ordered accordingly.

Title: Oei v. Citibank, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Acts and knowledge of advising bank's employees, regarding the alteration of documents submitted by beneficiary in connection with its request for payment on letter of credit, could not be imputed to bank which actually issued and honored letter of credit, for purposes of holding issuing bank liable on applicant's fraud claim, absent any showing of facts sufficient to permit piercing of corporate veil to hold issuing bank liable for acts of advising bank, which was issuing bank's subsidiary.
Document Preview: Applicant for letter of credit brought suit against issuing and advising banks for their alleged wrongful honor of letter of credit, fraud in connection with letter of credit transaction, conversion, and aiding and abetting beneficiary in his own fraud.  On defendants' motions to dismiss, or in alternative, for entry of summary judgment and to dismiss applicant's jury trial demand, the District Court, Mukasey, J., held that: (1) issuer was liable to applicant on wrongful honor theory in light of significant discrepancies in documents submitted by beneficiary; (2) alleged fraud on part of beneficiary of letter of credit in failing to provide applicant with genuine United States blue jeans for which it had contracted was not intervening cause, such as would relieve issuing bank of liability to applicant for wrongfully honoring letter of credit; (3) absent evidence that applicant knew of substantial discrepancies in documents submitted by beneficiary, or at least...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Chicago Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. Vacala Masonry, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Evidence failed to establish that first construction company was effectively dependent on second construction company for materials it needed to stay in business, for purposes of determining second company's alter ego status; although companies admitted first company's employees who were leased to second company sometimes used second company's equipment, this type of sharing was typical in industry.
Document Preview: Pension and welfare funds and apprentice program (funds) brought action against construction companies, alleging breach of collective bargaining agreement as result of failure to make monetary contributions to funds for each hour worked by companies' employees and nonunion subcontractors and for refusing to allow funds access to company's books to verify compliance with terms of agreement.  Companies moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Ashman, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) companies lacked unlawful intent necessary to find first company alter ego of second company, for purposes of funds' claims against first company under alter ego theory; (2) material issue of fact as to whether second company under-reported hours worked and, therefore, owed contributions to funds precluded summary judgment for second company; and (3) evidence was insufficient to raise genuine issue of material fact as to first construction company's alter ego status...

Title: Beneficial Personnel Services of Texas, Inc. v. Rey
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: Testimony of officer of two companies established that the companies constituted "single business enterprise", where officer testified that common business purpose of both companies was employee leasing, that both companies used same address and telephone number, that companies had common officers, common employees and same shareholders, that companies kept records at same office, that companies used same accountants and checkbook, that one company paid wages of employees for both companies and that both companies were covered under same insurance policy for compensation of injured employees.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Employer Torts. Evidence supported jury's finding that employer committed fraud in misrepresenting type of workers' compensation benefits it would provide.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Gundle Lining Const. Corp. v. Adams County Asphalt, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, there was insufficient evidence to demonstrate that corporation was alter ego of affiliated corporation owned by same individual, as would permit piercing corporate veil and attributing contacts of latter corporation, which was subject to jurisdiction in Texas, to the former.
Document Preview: Texas subcontractor brought suit against contractor's surety in state court, seeking to recover on payment bond.  Suit was removed to federal district court where surety filed third-party complaints against Pennsylvania contractor, affiliated corporation and owner of the two corporations, claiming that it was entitled to recover all amounts paid to plaintiff from third-party defendants as indemnitors.  Following settlement between subcontractor and surety, the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas, Lynn N. Hughes, J., granted summary judgment to surety, and third-party defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Robert M. Parker, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) district court had jurisdiction over contractor; (2) jurisdiction was lacking as to other third-party defendants; (3) district court properly denied contractor's motion to transfer venue; and (4) surety paid subcontractor's claim against payment bond in...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: ADO Finance, AG v. McDonnell Douglas Corp.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under Swiss, Liechtenstein or California law, aircraft seller made prima facie showing that individual residing in Liechtenstein and Liechtenstein companies were alter egos of defendant Swiss corporation, which was subject to personal jurisdiction, and therefore were also subject to personal jurisdiction; there was substantial evidence of unity of interest and that owners of Swiss corporation continued to dominate it and had stripped it of its assets.
Document Preview: In action arising out of sale of aircraft, alleged alter egos of buyer moved to dismiss counterclaim against them for lack of personal jurisdiction.  The District Court, Wardlaw, J., held that seller made prima facie showing of alter ego liability, whether Swiss, Liechtenstein, or California law governing piercing the corporate veil or imposition of alter ego liability applied. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Joiner v. Ryder System Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Page from notes of task force created by parent company to improve safety throughout its subsidiaries, on which the words "build what we have carefully" and "design a better trailer" were hand written, did not by itself create a factual issue as to whether parent company was involved in subsidiary's manufacture of allegedly defective automobile transport trailer so as to be potentially liable in products liability action; task force consisted of individuals from all of parent's divisions, and there was no proof of who wrote note or why it was written.
Document Preview: Worker brought strict products liability and negligence action to recover for injuries sustained when he attempted to remove skids located at rear of automobile transport trailer.  Parent company of trailer's manufacturer moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Richard Mills, J., held that: (1) parent company did not exert improper control over subsidiaries so as to support argument that parent was alter ego of trailer manufacturer; (2) parent company did not hold itself out as manufacturer of trailer, for purposes of liability under apparent manufacturer doctrine; and (3) assuming parent company was aware prior to injuries in question that trailer was unsafe, parent did not have duty to order subsidiary to redesign trailer. Motion for summary judgment allowed.

Title: Joiner v. Ryder System Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Worker who was injured as he attempted to remove skids from automobile transport trailer failed to make requisite showing, for purposes of imposing liability on parent corporation of subsidiary that manufactured trailer, that adhering to the fiction of separate corporate identities would promote injustice; subsidiaries within parent's automotive carrier division were very profitable, and each could easily satisfy a large judgment against it, making the piercing of parent's veil unnecessary.
Document Preview: Worker brought strict products liability and negligence action to recover for injuries sustained when he attempted to remove skids located at rear of automobile transport trailer.  Parent company of trailer's manufacturer moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Richard Mills, J., held that: (1) parent company did not exert improper control over subsidiaries so as to support argument that parent was alter ego of trailer manufacturer; (2) parent company did not hold itself out as manufacturer of trailer, for purposes of liability under apparent manufacturer doctrine; and (3) assuming parent company was aware prior to injuries in question that trailer was unsafe, parent did not have duty to order subsidiary to redesign trailer. Title: Old Republic Ins. Co. v. EX-IM Services Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence of similar business activities, names, officers, and employees and of common use of one customs bond provided more than scintilla of evidence from which jury, in insurer's claim for repayment under another customs bond, could find that single business enterprise existed among insured import-export corporation and other import-export entities; accordingly, trial court improperly granted judgment n.o.v. against insurer.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Some evidence supported jury finding of single business enterprise in insurer's customs bond claim against insured import-export corporation and other import-export entities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Idylwoods Associates v. Mader Capital, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Evidence supported piercing of corporate veil to impose CERCLA owner liability against parent corporation of subsidiary corporation that owned hazardous waste site; parent commingled all of its funds with that of subsidiary in single bank account into which proceeds of sale of properties belonging to subsidiary were placed and from which all of subsidiary's expenses were paid, including property taxes on site, neither board of directors of subsidiary nor its shareholders ever met and any business relating to subsidiary was conducted at parent board of directors and shareholders meetings, no payroll existed for subsidiary, personnel working on subsidiary business were employees, agents, or independent contractors of parent, and subsidiary did not have its own office. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107(a), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a).
Document Preview: In action concerning cleanup of hazardous waste site, successor to prior owner filed cross-claims under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA) against other potentially responsible parties (PRPs). On motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Foschio, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) on issue of first impression, state statutes governing capacity of dissolved corporation to be sued were preempted by overall purposes of CERCLA; (2) on another issue of first impression, CERCLA did not impose liability for mere passive disposal; (3) owner was not entitled to rely on third party or innocent purchaser affirmative defenses absent exercise of due care after discovery of hazardous substances; (4) CERCLA liability could be imposed against dead corporation which had been dissolved, but whose assets had not yet been fully distributed; (5) evidence supported...

Title: Kasprzak v. American General Life & Acc. Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Beaumont Division.
Headnote: Evidence of lack of corporate separateness was insufficient to pierce corporate veil of life insurer to state claim against its parent for alleged misrepresentation in sales of insurance policies issued by insurer.
Document Preview: Insureds brought state-court action against life insurer and its corporate parent, alleging misrepresentation in sales of policies issued by insurer. Defendants removed. On insureds' motion to remand for lack of diversity, the District Court, Cobb, J., held that clear and convincing evidence showed that insureds fraudulently joined parent in effort to defeat diversity as jurisdictional basis for removal, and thus removal was proper, where there was no evidence to support disregarding corporate separateness of insurer and parent. So ordered.

Title: Mark Six Realty Associates, Inc. v. Drake
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Some evidence existed to show that two corporations disregarded their separate entities and engaged in a common business enterprise; since limited purpose corporation conducted no business and had no employees, it could take no action on its own behalf to enter into a contract, to mislead or to confuse its name and business with that of other corporation, but evidence as to other corporation showed some such action on its part, as publicity brochure referred route to common portion of names of both corporations, without any corporate designation other than references to limited purpose corporation, contracts prepared by agent on properties and subdivision identified limited purpose corporation as listing and selling broker, and there was some evidence that limited purpose corporation was created by other corporation exclusively for its convenience and benefit.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Employment Contract. Real estate brokerage retained sufficient control over agent's duties to make her employee not independent contractor.

Title: Mark Six Realty Associates, Inc. v. Drake
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Some evidence supported jury verdict in favor of piercing corporate veil; there was evidence that subsidiary was created solely for purpose of circumventing or avoiding certain regulations of Georgia Real Estate Commission, and there was some evidence of confusion between the two entities, including apparent confusion on part of employees of parent corporation.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Employment Contract. Real estate brokerage retained sufficient control over agent's duties to make her employee not independent contractor.

Title: Seasword v. Hilti, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: Corporation could not be held liable under parent-subsidiary theory in products liability action, even assuming that manufacturer of product was parent of corporation, where injured user alleged no facts and offered no proof that corporation and parent had abused their presumably separate and distinct corporate forms.
Document Preview: Corporations. Michigan declines to adopt apparent manufacturer doctrine.

Title: Walls by Walls v. Allen Cab Co., Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Four.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that cab company was not separate legal entity from bank such that Labor and Industrial Relations Commission could "pierce the corporate veil" of cab company in proceeding for workers' compensation death benefits; corporations owned by bank owned majority of cab company's stock, directors of corporations were officers of bank, and final decision making authority of cab company remained with bank employees.
Document Preview: Employee. Finding that worker was employee of bank was not erroneous.

Title: Elgin Sweeper Co. v. Melson Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Evidence that one subsidiary was used to funnel loan proceeds to second subsidiary, thereby leaving first subsidiary insolvent and committing fraud on creditor of that subsidiary was sufficient on the fraud element of piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Action was brought against Canadian bank and former officers, directors or shareholders of certain related corporations, alleging fraudulent conveyance, breach of contract and breach of fiduciary duty under New York law, arising out of bank loan and series of intercompany transfers and defaulted obligations. On motion of defendants to dismiss or for summary judgment, the District Court, Scullin, J., held that: (1) application of Canadian law would not divest court of subject matter jurisdiction; (2) application of foreign country's law by itself would not constitute grounds for dismissal under doctrine of forum non conveniens; (3) no difference was shown between Ontario and New York law with respect to fraudulent conveyance claims, and thus New York law would be applied as the choice of law; (4) failure of plaintiff to obtain permission to proceed with action from Ontario court that adjudicated bankruptcy of debtor corporation, as...

Title: French v. F.F.O. Financial Group, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, First District.
Headnote: Financial institutions were not liable for breach of employment contract between employee and their corporate subsidiaries based on theory of "piercing the corporate veil" absent evidence of the type of improper conduct required to entitle one to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: Corporations. Record lacked evidence of improper conduct required to warrant piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Chicago Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. Sunshine Carpet Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, evidence was insufficient to permit union pension funds to pierce corporate veil of two companies to find their principals individually liable for corporate ERISA obligations; although companies might have commingled assets, their assets were not commingled with personal assets of principals; moreover, companies complied with relevant corporate formalities and they were not undercapitalized. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: Union pension funds brought suit seeking to recover contribution payments owed as part of collective bargaining agreement and under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA).  On cross motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Norgle, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to find that second corporation was alter ego of corporate employer and that its veil should be pierced to hold it liable for pension obligations of employer, and (2) piercing of corporate veil was not warranted under Illinois law to hold individual shareholders responsible for delinquent contributions. Plaintiffs' motion granted in part and denied in part; defendants' motion granted in part and denied in part.

Title: In re Hillsborough Holdings Corp.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division..
Headnote: Finding that parent sold subsidiary's assets for legitimate business reasons, rather than to evade subsidiary's asbestos claim liability, was supported by evidence, thereby justifying court's refusal to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: VEIL PIERCING. veil piecing was not warranted absent showing that corporate parent committed misconduct with regard to subsidiary's creditors.

Title: In re Hillsborough Holdings Corp.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division..
Headnote: Finding that parent corporation's transfer of proceeds from sale of subsidiary's assets to satisfy intercompany payables was legitimate business decision, rather than attempt to evade subsidiary's asbestos claim liability, was supported by evidence, thereby justifying court's refusal to pierce corporate veil; parent's advances to subsidiary were more like loans than contributions of equity, and, although potential liability to asbestos claimants was known at time of transfer, parent did not then know of magnitude of liability or of inadequacy of insurance coverage.
Document Preview: VEIL PIERCING. veil piecing was not warranted absent showing that corporate parent committed misconduct with regard to subsidiary's creditors.

Title: In re Hillsborough Holdings Corp.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division..
Headnote: Finding that subsidiary was not mere alter ego of corporate parent, and thus that veil piercing was not justified, was supported by evidence; parent kept accurate accounting of moneys belonging to each of its subsidiaries, assessed subsidiary for service provided, and, although parent had close involvement in major business planning decisions of its subsidiaries, it had little involvement in their daily operations.
Document Preview: VEIL PIERCING. veil piecing was not warranted absent showing that corporate parent committed misconduct with regard to subsidiary's creditors.

Title: Crum & Forster, Inc. v. Monsanto Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Finding that corporate identities of liability insurers and their parent corporation should be disregarded was supported by evidence, in insured chemical company's action alleging that insurers and parent corporation wrongfully obtained financial interest in, and direct control of, previous litigation against insured; parent corporation and wholly owned subsidiary owned all of insurers' stock, insurers' shared use of corporation's "profit centers," letterhead, and forms, and directors and officers of insurers overlapped.
Document Preview: Liability. Liability insurers wrongfully obtained financial interest in, and direct control of, tort action against insured chemical company.

Title: Crum & Forster, Inc. v. Monsanto Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Imposition of punitive damages upon parent corporation of subsidiaries that were liability insurers was not due process violation, in insured chemical company's action against corporation and subsidiaries for wrongfully obtaining financial interest in, and direct control of, litigation against insured; evidence supported finding that parent corporation engaged in wrongdoing, parties engaged in joint venture to manipulate previous litigation, corporate identities of subsidiaries were to be disregarded, and damages did not exceed what was required to reasonably serve to punish or deter wrongful conduct. V.A.T.S. Insurance Code, art. 21.21, §§ 2(c), 16(b)(1); Vernon's Ann.Texas Const. Art. 1, § 19; U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14.
Document Preview: Liability. Liability insurers wrongfully obtained financial interest in, and direct control of, tort action against insured chemical company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Capital Parks, Inc. v. Southeastern Advertising and Sales System, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, optionee, which sought specific performance of agreement granting it right of first refusal with respect to purchase of stock or assets of subsidiary corporation, failed to establish that subsidiary corporation was alter ego of parent, as required to pierce corporate veil of subsidiary, so that offer to purchase stock and assets of parent was not offer to purchase stock and assets of subsidiary; piercing corporate veil of subsidiary would not have had bearing on option contract as contract was binding only upon parent, and there was no evidence that any of parent's shareholders created parent as corporate fiction to avoid any liability under option contract.
Document Preview: Optionee brought action against parent corporation for specific performance of agreement granting it right of first refusal with respect to purchase of stock or assets of subsidiary corporation.  The United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, Walter S. Smith, Jr., J., 1993 WL 735813, dismissed action and denied leave to amend complaint, and optionee appealed. The Court of Appeals, Robert M. Parker, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) offer to purchase parent's stock and all business assets used in connection with operation of parent's business did not trigger right of first refusal, and (2) optionee failed to establish that subsidiary was alter ego of parent. Affirmed.

Title: Horizon Resources Bethany Ltd. v. Cutco Industries, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 1, Department D.
Headnote: Evidence did not support lessor's claim that lessee-subsidiary was mere instrumentality of parent corporation and that parent should be held liable on lease; evidence only showed that subsidiary was owned by parent and that subsidiary and parent shared many of same officers.
Document Preview: Lessor filed suit against corporate parent of lessee for enforcement of lease guaranty agreement.  The Superior Court of Maricopa County, No. CV 9032000, Alan S. Kamin, J., granted summary judgment for corporation, and lessor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Gerber, J., held that: (1) corporation did not bind itself on lease by participating in negotiations on behalf of subsidiary; (2) evidence did not support lessor's claim that subsidiary was mere instrumentality of corporation; but (3) fact issue existed as to whether corporation consented to alteration of lease to allow extensions or consented to exercise of option to renew provided in original lease such that it was estopped from arguing that guaranty did not apply to extended term. Reversed and remanded.

Title: Stewart & Stevenson Services, Inc. v. Serv-Tech, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Absent evidence that first corporation had ownership interest in second corporation, or that second corporation was undercapitalized, no evidence supported jury finding that second corporation was alter ego of first in action against corporations alleging misappropriation of trade secrets.
Document Preview: Trade Secrets. No cause of action exists for misappropriation of nonsecret confidential information.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Smith v. Halliburton Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Headnote: Products liability plaintiffs failed to produce evidence sufficient to rebut parent corporation's prima facie showing of separateness from subsidiary, whose predecessor had manufactured well servicing unit, and thus, neither agency principle nor alter ego principle was applicable to find that corporate form could be disregarded for purposes of determining whether parent corporation was amenable to service of process in forum state by reasons of acts within that state by subsidiary. NMSA 1978, § 38-1-16.
Document Preview: Action alleging negligence, breach of warranty and products liability was brought against manufacturer of well servicing unit, corporation that merged with manufacturer after unit was sold, merging corporation's parent corporation, company that did repair work on unit, and insurance company. Company performing repair work filed cross claim against other defendants. The District Court, Lea County, Alvin F. Jones, D.J., granted summary judgment to parent corporation, merging corporation, and manufacturer.  Plaintiffs and company that did repair work appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Minzner, C.J., held that: (1) Delaware law controlled whether merging corporation, which was incorporated in Delaware, was amenable to suit following dissolution, and (2) New Mexico courts lacked personal jurisdiction over parent corporation. Affirmed.

Title: SCD Chemical Distributors, Inc. v. Medley
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Judgment creditor's failure to establish that either corporation to which assets of judgment debtor were transferred was used to commit fraud or wrong failed to make requisite showing necessary to permit piercing of corporate veil of corporation.
Document Preview: Fraudulent Conveyances. Transfer of assets of judgment debtor to other businesses was not fraudulent conveyance.

Title: Jiffy Lube Intern., Inc. v. Jiffy Lube of Pennsylvania, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, automobile lubricating service center franchisee failed to show that motor oil company was liable for actions of franchisor on alter-ego theory on franchisee's claims for breach of contract, fraud, misrepresentation, and breach of fiduciary duty, despite evidence of varying degrees of cooperation, coordination, and interdependence between company and franchisor, where company representation on franchisor's board of directors and company's acquisition of 80% of franchisor's common stock did not occur during relevant period, and contractual relationships between company and franchisor were not probative of day-to-day control of franchisor.
Document Preview: Automobile lubricating service center franchisor brought action against franchisee, alleging trademark infringement and unfair competition. Franchisee counterclaimed and brought third-party action against second franchisee and motor oil company, alleging, inter alia, fraudulent inducement to enter into franchisor-franchisee relationship, intentional interference with contractual relationship, conspiracy, and racketeering.  Plaintiffs and third-party defendants moved for summary judgment on counterclaim and third-party complaint.  The District Court, Van Antwerpen, J., held that: (1) under Maryland law, franchisee's release of franchisor in asset transfer agreement covered all of franchisee's claims against franchisor and second franchisee; (2) under Pennsylvania law, franchisee failed to show that company was liable for actions of franchisor on alter-ego theory on franchisee's claims for breach of contract, fraud, misrepresentation, and breach of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Analytical Measurements, Inc. v. Keuffel & Esser Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Parent corporation could not be held liable for pollution caused by subsidiary, under New Jersey Spill Compensation Control Act; parent was not "responsible" for pollution, in that it did not purchase subsidiary until 20 years after discharging had ceased, and there was no evidence that purchase was to perpetrate fraud or injustice such as would warrant piercing corporate veil. N.J.S.A. 58:10–23.11 et seq.
Document Preview: Property owner brought action against purchaser of former owner's assets, alleging state and federal law causes of action for recovery of amount spent on hazardous waste cleanup.  On defendant's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Debevoise, J., held that: (1) fact issue existed as to whether purchaser was liable as successor corporation; (2) fact issue existed as to whether suit was timely; (3) New Jersey Spill Act amendment for private right of contribution was retroactively applicable; and (4) fact issues existed as to whether purchaser was liable under CERCLA. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Title: Mitchell v. K.C. Stadium Concessions, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Evidence that parent corporation made two rent and one tax payment on building leased by subsidiary and insured building fell short of evidence necessary to prove parent corporation's domination of subsidiary corporation or to hold parent liable under lease under any other theory, particularly where there was no evidence that parent corporation was acting with any improper purpose.
Document Preview: Fire Policy. Fact that lessee and lessor declined to rebuild following fire did not relieve insurer of its obligation to pay replacement costs to lessor.
