Title: Airflow Houston, Inc. v. Theriot
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Court's finding that parent corporation and subsidiary had ignored their separate corporate status, for purposes of holding parent corporation responsible for debt of subsidiary, was supported by evidence that corporations were owned by same person, that parent corporation received some proceeds from loan to subsidiary, that companies participated in joint check payment arrangement with major creditors, and that corporations shared employees, logo, offices, and phone.
Document Preview: Separate Existence. Newly formed corporation was liable for liquidated corporations' debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Clark v. Matsushita Elec. Indus. Co., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Evidence that subsidiary may have been exclusive United States distributor of certain electronics products manufactured by Japanese parent was not sufficient to show that subsidiary was mere agent or alter-ego of parent, for purposes of personal jurisdiction.
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought products liability action against, inter alia, Japanese manufacturer of kerosene heater.  Manufacturer brought motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction.  The District Court, Rambo, Chief Judge, held that court did not have personal jurisdiction, even though wholly owned subsidiary of manufacturer had sufficient contacts with Pennsylvania to render it subject to court's jurisdiction. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Clark v. Matsushita Elec. Indus. Co., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Evidence that parent lumped together financial information for parent and its subsidiaries in its annual report was not sufficient to establish that independence of separate corporate entities had been disregarded, for purposes of establishing personal jurisdiction over parent on basis of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought products liability action against, inter alia, Japanese manufacturer of kerosene heater.  Manufacturer brought motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction.  The District Court, Rambo, Chief Judge, held that court did not have personal jurisdiction, even though wholly owned subsidiary of manufacturer had sufficient contacts with Pennsylvania to render it subject to court's jurisdiction. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Houston Cable TV, Inc. v. Inwood West Civic Ass'n, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence in homeowners' associations' breach of contract action against cable companies, was sufficient to establish that the companies were alter egos of each other; evidence indicated that the companies acted as one entity in dealing with customers and could not differentiate between each other.
Document Preview: CABLE TELEVISION - Right of Way. Evidence established that cable television companies breached right-of-way agreements with homeowners' associations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Everett v. St. Ansgar Hosp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: In absence of evidence to the contrary, where it had been determined that hospital was not acting as alter ego of its corporate parent in suspending physician's hospital privileges, it had to be concluded that hospital was not acting as alter ego of corporate "grandparent."
Document Preview: Physician brought action challenging summary suspension of his hospital privileges.  Following remand, 882 F.2d 1383, physician also challenged subsequent revocation of his privileges, and summary judgment for defendants was granted by the United States District Court for the District of North Dakota, Rodney S. Webb, J. Physician appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Bowman, Circuit Judge, held that under terms of application for hospital privileges, physician waived right to sue for breach of contract in connection with actions taken by hospital for purpose of achieving and maintaining acceptable level of patient care, absent bad faith or malice, and no malice was shown. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Dave Kolb Grading, Inc. v. Lieberman Corp.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Two.
Headnote: Evidence that corporation dominated related corporation's finances and its business practices with respect to construction project and that actions of corporation caused insolvency of related corporation justified piercing corporate veil for purposes of subcontractor's recovery. V.A.M.S. §§ 429.012, 429.100.
Document Preview: Contractors and subcontractors sought to recover from homeowners, trustees, and lending institution on liens in connection with subdivision construction project after contractor became insolvent.  The Circuit Court, St. Louis County, Robert L. Campbell, J., found for lien claimants, and appeal and cross appeal were taken.  The Court of Appeals, Crandall, J., held that: (1) profit and overhead could be included in the reasonable value of mechanics' liens; (2) lien claimants could be awarded prejudgment interest; and (3) subcontractors gave owners sufficient notice of mechanics' liens. Affirmed in part; remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: George v. Kramo Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Seaman seeking to collect unpaid wages did not establish that listed owner of vessel was shell corporation, so as to be able to reach assets of another corporation claimed to be actual owner; there was no evidence regarding stock ownership, board of directors, expenses paid on behalf of alleged shell corporation, corporation's other sources of business and its capitalization.
Document Preview: Seamen on vessel scheduled to travel from Houma, Louisiana to Seattle, Washington sued for wages lost when vessel was seized passing through Panama Canal.  The District Court, Sear, Chief Judge, held that seamen were entitled to double amount of wages under Seaman's Penalty Wage Statute. Motions for summary judgment granted in part, denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: People by Abrams v. Apple Health and Sports Clubs, Ltd., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: Trial court was justified in freezing bank account and imposing bond requirement on corporation that was allegedly related to health club that had allegedly engaged in fraud, despite contention that corporation was separate and distinct from health club; evidence that health club and corporation had same two shareholders, corporation offered to stand behind health club's debts, and corporation handled membership fees and cards for health club created substantial likelihood that it could be proved at trial that corporation and health club were interlocking corporations, and thus that corporation would be liable for any fraudulent and illegal activities pursued by health club. McKinney's General Business Law § 622-a.
Document Preview: Attorney General commenced special proceeding to enjoin health club from operating without bond, and to freeze bank account of alleged health club owners and require them to post $500,000 bond.  The Supreme Court, New York County, Santaella, J., issued injunction, and appeal was taken.  The Appellate Division affirmed, 174 A.D.2d 438, 571 N.Y.S.2d 23, and certified question, and alleged owners appealed.  The Court of Appeals held that: (1) appeal was not rendered moot by Supreme Court's subsequent judgment; (2) alleged owners were not denied due process; and (3) record adequately supported temporary relief awarded by Supreme Court. Affirmed, and certified question answered in affirmative.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: N.L.R.B. v. O'Neill
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: National Labor Relations Board's (NLRB's) finding that corporations which took over operation of meat plant were alter egos of prior employer, so as to warrant treating them as single employer liable for unfair labor practices in connection with closing, reopening and permanent reclosing of plant, was supported by evidence of interrelationship of operations and financial control, unusual circumstances surrounding corporations' formation, evidence that employer's principals knew initial plant closure would be brief, and evidence of hostility toward labor.
Document Preview: National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) petitioned for enforcement of two of its orders entered in connection with meat plant's closing, reopening and subsequent permanent closing. The Court of Appeals, D.W. Nelson, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) fraudulent concealment exception applied to toll running of limitations period applicable to unfair labor practice complaint until date unions received testimony of indicted company official that majority shareholder of original employer was heavily involved in new corporations operating plant and, thus, NLRB properly allowed reinstatement of previously dismissed charge; (2) NLRB's finding that corporations which took over operation of plant were alter egos of prior employer, so as to warrant treating them as single employer liable for unfair labor practices, was supported by evidence; and (3) piercing of corporate veil so as to hold majority shareholder liable for unfair labor practices was justified. Orders enforced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Superior Derrick Services, Inc. v. Anderson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support conclusion that two companies operated as single business enterprise, so as to be held jointly and severally liable for obligations under purchase order, where shareholder of first corporation formed second corporation, first corporation provided office space, business forms, services, and paid all bills, expenses, and employee salaries for second corporation.
Document Preview: Manufacturer brought action against buyers for balance due under purchase order to design and manufacture four masts for use in oil and gas industry.  The 295th District Court, Harris County, Frank O. White, J., entered judgment for manufacturer, and buyers appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Sears, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support trial court's conclusion that masts were conforming goods; (2) evidence was sufficient to support trial court's finding that buyers accepted delivery of first mast at manufacturer's facility; (3) evidence did not support recovery under sworn account for fourth mast; (4) buyers operated as single business enterprise; and (5) trial court properly admitted videotape and photographs of masts during fabrication. Modified in part and affirmed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Sternberg v. Osman
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Fifty percent shareholder in close corporation failed to carry his burden of proving that five satellite corporations and close corporation were single, unified franchise, either for purpose of piercing the corporate veil, or in order to demonstrate that close corporation could not be dissolved without bringing about involuntary dissolution of satellite corporations, or to establish that other shareholder's share in six-store enterprise was less than 50 percent, disqualifying him from petitioning for dissolution under deadlock statute. McKinney's Business Corporation Law § 1104.
Document Preview: Fifty percent shareholder of close corporation petitioned to dissolve corporation on ground of shareholder deadlock.  The Supreme Court, Nassau County, Molloy, J., granted petition and denied other shareholder's cross motion to dismiss petition.  Other shareholder appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) proceeding could not be converted into proceeding for common-law dissolution; (2) statutory buy-out provision was not applicable; and (3) other shareholder failed to prove that five satellite corporations and close corporation were single, unified franchise, either for purpose of piercing the corporate veil, or in order to demonstrate that close corporation could not be dissolved without bringing about involuntary dissolution of satellite corporations or to establish that petitioner's share in six-store enterprise was less than 50 percent, disqualifying him from petitioning for relief under dissolution statute....

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Las Palmas Associates v. Las Palmas Center Associates
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Finding that sister corporations formed single enterprise for purpose of committing continued fraud against real estate purchasers, and thus that imposition of alter ego liability was warranted, was sufficiently supported by evidence; first corporation, which dealt with purchasers, was shell being operated and financed by second corporation.
Document Preview: Shopping center vendors sought declaratory relief concerning their duty to guarantee rents, and purchasers filed cross complaint for fraud and breach of contract.  The Superior Court, Los Angeles County, No. C575906, Arthur Baldonaldo, J., entered judgment on jury verdict for purchasers, and vendors appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Nott, J., held that: (1) evidence supported finding of fraud; (2) compensatory and punitive damage awards were excessive; and (3) purchasers were not entitled to contractual attorney fees on their fraud claim, but were entitled to recover fees incurred in defending vendors' contract action. Affirmed as modified; remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Jacksonville Elec. Authority v. Eppinger and Russell Co.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division. .
Headnote: Current owner of site contaminated by creosote and arsenic failed to show any facts justifying piercing corporate veil of prior owner of site so as to hold its parent corporation liable under CERCLA for response costs; although parent and prior owner had common stock ownership, officers, and directors, corporate formalities were strictly observed, parent and prior owner did not file consolidated financial statements or tax returns, and parent did not finance prior owner. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 107(a)(2), 42 U.S.C.A. § 9607(a)(2).
Document Preview: Current owner of hazardous waste site brought action under CERCLA seeking to recover cleanup costs from parent corporation of prior owner and others.  On parent corporation's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, John H. Moore II, J., held that: (1) current owner of site contaminated by creosote and arsenic failed to show any facts justifying piercing corporate veil of prior owner of site so as to hold its parent corporation liable, and (2) parent was not liable for cleanup of site as operator under CERCLA, even though parent and prior owner did have common officers and directors. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Gall Landau Young Const. Co., Inc. v. Hedreen
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: Evidence did not justify disregard of corporate form to hold one corporation liable for second corporation's obligations, even though both were owned by same person and had same directors; there was no evidence to establish that corporate form had been manipulated to violate or evade duty owed to creditor or that remedy of corporate disregard would prevent unjustified loss to creditor.
Document Preview: Creditor brought action seeking to hold successor to assets of debtor corporation liable for debtor's obligations.  The Superior Court of King County, William L. Downing and Warren Chan, JJ., found that successor, which was owned by same person who owned debtor, was not alter ego of debtor but was mere continuation of debtor and was thus liable for debtor's obligations.  Parties appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Webster, Acting C.J., held that: (1) evidence did not support finding that successor was mere continuation of debtor, and (2) evidence supported finding that successor was not alter ego of debtor. Affirmed in part, reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Minnesota Power v. Armco, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence supported district court's findings that taconite mining company and subsidiary corporation created by mining company's owner to hold its partnership interest therein served as owner's alter ego, and corporate veil could be pierced under Minnesota law and owner held liable to utility for mining company's unpaid electric bills; subsidiary and mining company were both undercapitalized and officers and directors were nonfunctioning with little or no power, owner's silence when asked about security for payment was prejudicial to utility, and utility was not on any notice that any reorganization had occurred, absent changes in mining company's outward appearance.
Document Preview: On appeal from judgment of the United States District Court for the District of Minnesota, Robert G. Renner, J., holding corporation liable to utility for breach of electric service agreements entered into with mining company in which corporation held a partnership interest, the Court of Appeals, Lay, Chief Judge, held that evidence supported findings that mining company and subsidiary created to hold corporation's partnership interest therein were owner's alter egos, and that mining company's corporate veil could be pierced under Minnesota law and owner held liable for unpaid electric bills. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Pederson v. Paragon Pool Enterprises
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Sixth Division.
Headnote: Worker injured while cleaning a pool failed to preserve sufficient evidence to justify piercing the veil of separate corporate identities of corporation which installed pool and filtering system and corporation named as defendant; although corporations had common shareholder, business addresses, officer and director, they existed simultaneously in separate unrelated businesses, neither took over the stock or ownership of the other, and there was no allegation of a scheme by the sole common shareholder to commit fraud on potential creditors of the two companies or evidence that corporate assets were mixed or that one company was underfunded to benefit the other.
Document Preview: Worker injured while cleaning a swimming pool and filter filed a negligence and products liability action against corporation which allegedly manufactured, sold and installed pool and filter system.  The Circuit Court, Cook County, Willard J. Lassers, J., granted summary judgment for corporation, and worker appealed.  The Appellate Court, LaPorta, J., held that: (1) plaintiff failed to preserve sufficient evidence to justify piercing corporate veil or separate corporate entities of named defendant and corporation which installed pool and filtering system, which had common shareholders, business addresses, officers and directors, and (2) defendant corporation's four and one-half-year delay in filing motion for summary judgment did not estop it or waive its right to present defense that the wrong corporation had been sued. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Miller v. Tony and Susan Alamo Foundation
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to establish that two alleged corporate entities were alter egos of defendant; there was no evidence that one corporation was ever incorporated, and defendant moved corporate assets into and out of corporations, and between them, at will, and without regard to any ownership interest by corporate entities; moreover, corporate officers and boards, and corporate form in general, were ignored by defendant.
Document Preview: Plaintiffs brought suit against four individuals and two alleged corporate entities, alleging violations of the Fair Labor Standards Act, the Davis-Bacon Act, and the Arkansas minimum wage law.  Other counts alleged various common-law torts perpetrated against defendants.  The United States District Court for the Western District of Arkansas, Morris Sheppard Arnold, J., ruled that corporate entities were alter egos of individual defendant, and entered personal judgment against individual defendant in the amount of $1,448,549.  Corporate entities appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Henry Woods, District Judge, sitting by designation, held that: (1) district court did not err in disallowing testimony of defense witnesses; (2) court properly denied motion for accusal; (3) court had personal jurisdiction over defendant under the Arkansas Long Arm Act; and (4) evidence supported finding that alleged corporate entities were alter egos...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Jeras v. East Mfg. Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: There was insufficient evidence to hold parent corporation liable upon principle of piercing corporate veil for death of worker; not only did plaintiff fail to prove complete domination and control of subsidiary by parent but plaintiff failed to prove that the control and misuse caused wrong.
Document Preview: Wrongful death action was brought based on worker's death.  The Supreme Court, Niagara County, Koshian, J., entered judgment.  An appeal was taken.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) worker was special employee of defendant company and, accordingly, wrongful death action could not be maintained against that company, and (2) evidence was insufficient to establish that another company was negligent. Reversed and dismissed. Dillon, P.J., and Lawton, J., dissented in part and voted to reverse and grant new trial in memorandum.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: USP Real Estate Inv. Trust v. Discount Auto Parts, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, First District.
Headnote: Evidence established that wholly-owned subsidiary to which retail lease was ostensibly assigned and which was conceded to be mere instrumentality of parent corporation was used by parent to mislead creditors or perpetrate fraud upon them, thus justifying piercing corporate veil to hold parent liable for lessor's judgment against subsidiary, notwithstanding parent's contention that lessor never made any inquiry as to financial condition of either subsidiary or parent and that neither subsidiary nor parent made any misrepresentations of fact material concerning corporate entities or their financial condition; subsidiary was never operated as bona fide corporation, parent was party that used leased premises and that ultimately abandoned those premises, and lease in fact required lessee to actually occupy premises and operate retail business; moreover, lessor was entitled to rely on lease requirement that lessee actually occupy premises.
Document Preview: After obtaining judgment against wholly-owned subsidiary to which retail lease had ostensibly been assigned, lessor obtained court order impleading parent corporation as third-party defendant and sought to have parent held liable for judgment against subsidiary.  The Circuit Court for Clay County, William A. Wilkes, J., refused to pierce corporate veil, and lessor appealed.  The District Court of Appeal, Zehmer, J., held that evidence established that parent used subsidiary to mislead creditors or perpetrate fraud upon them, thus justifying piercing corporate veil. Reversed and remanded. Barfield, J., dissented with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: In re Jarax Intern., Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Evidence established that wholly owned subsidiary of parent bank was "mere instrumentality" of parent and that there was improper conduct, thus permitting piercing of corporate veil on behalf of client of subsidiary, assuming conduct alleged proximately caused injury to client; bank had total control over assets and accounts of subsidiary and at its whim could make determination as to how much its subsidiary would have in assets or accounts on any particular day.
Document Preview: Trustee in Chapter 7 case of debtor client of subsidiary brought action against parent bank and subsidiary, seeking to pierce corporate veil. The Bankruptcy Court, A. Jay Cristol, J., held that evidence established that wholly owned subsidiary of parent bank was mere instrumentality of parent and that there was improper conduct by parent, thus permitting piercing of corporate veil, assuming conduct alleged proximately caused injury to client. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: In re Denton
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Bank, which provided financing for sales of automobiles by corporate dealership of almost $100,000, based on sight drafts signed by acting chief executive officer, for sales that apparently never took place, failed to establish that debtor president of dealership and corporate dealership were alter egos, and thus, acting CEO, as agent of corporation, would not also be considered agent of debtor so as to render resulting debt nondischargeable; debtor was semi-retired, and corporation had operated car dealership for at least ten years preceding event in question. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. § 523(a)(2)(A).
Document Preview: Bank which provided financing for automobile sales by corporate dealership brought suit against Chapter 7 debtor president, seeking determination that debt was nondischargeable. The Bankruptcy Court, Letitia Z. Clark, J., held that: (1) evidence established that fraud committed on bank was perpetrated by acting CEO of dealership, rather than debtor, who was semi-retired, for purposes of determining whether debt owed by debtor was nondischargeable, and (2) bank failed to establish that debtor president of dealership and corporate dealership were alter egos, and thus, acting CEO, as agent of corporation, would not also be considered agent of debtor so as to render resulting debt nondischargeable. Judgment for debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Southern Environmental Group, Inc. v. Rosebud Landscape Gardeners, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Evidence that corporate fiction was maintained when one corporation purchased assets and assumed debts of another corporation, which then ceased doing business, was sufficient to support trial court's finding that the two corporations were not one and same for purposes of garnishment of debt owed by first corporation, even though same individual was majority shareholder of both corporations.
Document Preview: Garnishment action was filed against monies owed by customers for landscaping services to landscaping corporation.  The State Court, Gwinnett County, Hoffman, J., after bench trial, dismissed garnishment on grounds that debtor corporation had ceased doing business after its assets and liabilities were acquired by new corporation.  Garnishor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Beasley, J., held that evidence that corporate fiction was maintained after new corporation was formed and acquired assets and liabilities of old corporation, which thereupon ceased doing business, was sufficient to support trial court's finding that the two corporations were not one and the same for purposes of garnishment of debt owed by first corporation, even though majority stockholder of corporations was same individual. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Trailways, Inc. v. Clark
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Evidence that corporations were wholly-owned subsidiaries and had their principal places of business in the same office building as parent and that majority of directors of corporations were the same was not sufficient to hold parent corporation liable for subsidiaries' actions in connection with bus accident.
Document Preview: In wrongful death action against United States and Mexican bus lines arising out of Mexican bus accident, the 138th District Court, Cameron County, Robert Garza, J., entered judgment for plaintiffs.  On appeal, the Court of Appeals, 756 S.W.2d 786,reversed and remanded, and plaintiffs brought error.  The Supreme Court, 774 S.W.2d 644, reversed and remanded.  On remand, the Court of Appeals, Kennedy, J., held that: (1) supervisor for Mexican federal police was qualified to testify as expert on speed of bus and its contribution to cause of accident; (2) there was some evidence to support finding that bus driver exceeded rate of speed at which person using high degree of care would have driven; (3) Texas had the most significant contacts, for choice of law purposes; and (4) United States bus line was not liable for actions of its subsidiary. Affirmed in part and reversed and rendered in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Key v. Liquid Energy Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Truck drivers who were injured during an explosion that occurred in connection with hauling butane condensate from a subsidiary's facility did not demonstrate any basis under Oklahoma law for disregarding subsidiary's corporate structure and holding parent corporation liable; only evidence presented by drivers was that sign had indicated the subsidiary's status and fact that same mailing address was used for parent and subsidiary, and there was no evidence that the parent subsidiary relationship was detrimental to the public good, justified wrong, or protected fraud.
Document Preview: Truck drivers who were injured during an explosion that occurred in connection with hauling butane condensate brought action against, inter alia, their employer, and employer's parent corporation.  Following a jury trial, the United States District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma, James O. Ellison, J., entered a judgment finding negligence on all parties and awarding damages to the drivers.  Thereafter, court denied defendant's motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict, or in alternative, for a new trial. Defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Conway, District Judge, sitting by designation, held that: (1) plaintiffs failed to offer evidence sufficient to hold parent liable on theory that subsidiary was mere instrumentality or alter ego, and failed to offer sufficient evidence of fraud, illegality or inequity; (2) the peculiar risk doctrine would not be applied to the parent subsidiary relationship;...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Industrial Com'n of North Dakota v. Wilber
Court: Supreme Court of North Dakota.
Headnote: Purchasers failed to establish that vendor was an "alter ego" of its parent corporation, which financed purchase of home, or acted as parent's agent in sale of the property.
Document Preview: In foreclosure suit, the District Court, Grand Forks County, Kirk Smith, J., granted the plaintiff's motion for summary judgment, ordering foreclosure and dismissing the purchaser's counterclaim, and the purchasers appealed.  The Supreme Court, Meschke, J., held that purchasers failed to establish that vendor was an alter ego of its parent corporation, which financed purchase of home, or acted as parent's agent in sale of the property. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Culbreth v. Amosa (Pty) Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Plaintiff alleging injury from asbestos exposure had not established that corporations which owned majority of voting stock of British corporation which owned Illinois subsidiary that marketed asbestos so pervasively dominated the British corporation that the British corporation was the alter ego of the defendant corporations under Pennsylvania law, so as to support piercing of corporate veil and imposition of liability on defendant corporations.
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought action to recover damages for injuries suffered as result of asbestos exposure against, inter alia, corporations which owned majority of voting stock of British corporation whose Illinois subsidiary marketed asbestos.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, Edmund V. Ludwig, J., granted summary judgment for the corporations on all claims, cross claims, and third-party claims, and plaintiff appealed.  The Court of Appeals held that asbestos plaintiff had not established pervasive domination of British parent corporation that would permit finding British corporation to be defendant corporations' alter ego, under Pennsylvania law, so as to support piercing of corporate veil to impose liability. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: LaChalet Intern., Inc. v. Nowik
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Documentary evidence that funds were transferred between corporations is insufficient to pierce corporate veil, where there was no evidence of commingling of corporate accounts or of failure to observe corporate formalities, to hold director or shareholder meetings, or to keep separate records.
Document Preview: Participants in joint venture ski lodge brought action against coventurers seeking rescission of agreement and damages under Deceptive Trade Practices Act.  The 95th District Court, Dallas County, B.F. Coker, Visiting Judge, entered judgment for plaintiffs, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, McClung, J., held that: (1) rescission as well as award of damages was proper; (2) evidence was sufficient to support finding that Deceptive Trade Practices Act violations were committed knowingly; and (3) evidence was sufficient to support award of punitive damages. Affirmed in part, reversed and rendered in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Itel Containers Intern., Corp. v. Atlanttrafik Exp. Service, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: There was no showing that Bermuda limited company fraudulently used related corporate structures to justify disregard of corporate entities so as to hold Bermuda limited company liable to lessors which leased equipment to related corporate structures; Bermuda limited company specifically declined to indicate that it would be held liable on debts of related corporate structures.
Document Preview: Equipment lessors brought action against Bermuda limited company and related corporate structures seeking recovery of money on equipment lease. The District Court, Robert L. Carter, J., held that Bermuda limited company could not be held liable for debt of related corporations. Judgment for defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Mapco, Inc. v. Carter
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Owelty judgment should not have been awarded in personam against parent company of cotenant in mineral estate absent evidence establishing that cotenant was alter ego of parent company or that parent company was equitable owner of cotenant's interest in estate.
Document Preview: In action for partition of mineral estate, the 75th District Court, Liberty County, Clarence D. Cain, J., ordered partition and in personam owelty award against parent company of cotenant of estate.  Cotenant and parent company appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Burgess, J., held that: (1) mineral lessors were not collaterally estopped by prior action brought by mineral lessee against cotenant from denying that cavern in mineral estate belonged to cotenant; (2) findings of fact did not support attributing value of cavern to mineral estate, as was essential to its being considered for owelty purposes; (3) owelty was inappropriate remedy in light of evidence establishing that salt comprising mineral estate was of uniform value throughout; and (4) owelty judgment should not have been awarded in personam against parent company absent evidence establishing that cotenant was alter ego of parent company or that parent company was equitable owner of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Stochastic Decisions, Inc. v. DiDomenico
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: Trial court's piercing the corporate veil to hold closely held corporations jointly and severally liable for the bad checks a closely held corporation had issued to an insurance broker for prepaid premiums due was supported by substantial credible evidence that all the corporations had identical owners, there was a commingling of assets between the corporations including one corporation taking tax depreciations for another corporation's assets, that one of the corporations did not pay rent for the use of another corporation's garage, corporate bills were paid from whichever corporate checking account had the funds at the time, and the corporations operated in each other's names.
Document Preview: Insurance broker brought action against closely held corporations and their owners for the payment of amounts due on bad checks issued to the insurer for prepaid insurance, and for punitive damages against one of the owners.  The Superior Court, Law Division, Middlesex County, Garrenger, J., held all the corporate defendants jointly and severally liable based on commingling of corporate assets and misrepresentations, and held one of the owners personally liable in fraud for the four bad checks and liable for an additional punitive damages award.  Defendants appealed.  The Superior Court, Appellate Division, Dreier, J.A.D., held that: (1) substantial credible evidence of commingling of funds between corporations and misrepresentations regarding ownership supported piercing the corporate veil, and (2) finding that owner committed fraud when he purposely misled plaintiff by signing postdated checks that were given to pay premiums when owner knew that the...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Estes Equipment Co., Inc. v. Corporate Steel, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Evidence supported trial court finding that corporation sued by contractor was actually alter ego of sister corporation with which contractor entered into contract.
Document Preview: Contractor brought suit against corporation for failure to pay for work performed.  The State Court, Cobb County, Adams, J., found for contractor and awarded damages.  Corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Deen, P.J., held that: (1) evidence supported finding that corporation was alter ego of sister corporation with which contractor actually entered into contract, and (2) evidence supported the amount of the judgment. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Eastern States Elec. Contractors, Inc. v. William L. Crow Const. Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Electrical subcontractor could not pursue breach of contract claim against general contractor's parent corporation; subcontractor failed to meet its burden of demonstrating domination and control by parent and abuse of that control sufficient to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Electrical subcontractor brought action against general contractor, its parent corporation, and owner for breach of contract.  General contractor filed counterclaim and sought to join subcontractor's successor.  The Supreme Court, New York County, Leonard Cohen, J., denied motion by owner and contractor for summary judgment and denied motion by contractor to join successor, and appeals were taken.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) subcontractor could not pursue claim against owner in absence of privity; (2) subcontractor failed to meet burden of demonstrating domination and control by parent corporation sufficient to pierce corporate veil; and (3) joinder motion was not required to be served on successor before being considered by the court. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Kelsey Axle & Brake Div., Div. of Kelsey-Hayes Co. v. Presco Plastics, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Sixth Division.
Headnote: Determination not to disregard corporate identity was supported by evidence that corporation was adequately capitalized, that transactions between it and another corporation were arms-length transactions, that all its listings and advertisements indicated that it had a separate entity, and that it was operated as a separate entity, even though no minutes were kept after the initial corporate meeting, loans were made to it which were not repaid to its owner, and it simply went out of business without its assets being sold or debts being paid.
Document Preview: Buyer brought action against manufacturer and others for breach of warranty.  The Circuit Court, Cook County, Howard M. Miller, J., entered judgment in favor of buyer against manufacturer, but in favor of others against buyer, and appeals were taken.  The Appellate Court, Egan, P.J., held that: (1) evidence sustained determination not to disregard corporate entity of the manufacturer; (2) buyer had not given adequate notice of breach of warranty; and (3) buyer did not prove that its damages were the result of breach of warranty. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Bodenhamer Bldg. Corp. v. Architectural Research Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Determination that two wholly owned subsidiaries and their parent corporation had violated Michigan's Uniform Fraudulent Conveyance Act when parent foreclosed on first subsidiary's revolving loan and then set up second subsidiary to carry on first subsidiary's business was supported by sufficient evidence showing that revolving loan and foreclosure were accomplished to defraud first subsidiary's creditors, and that parent did not give fair consideration for assets transferred at foreclosure auction sale. M.C.L.A. §§ 566.11 et seq., 566.13, 566.15, 566.17, 566.19, 566.101 et seq., 566.221, 566.224.
Document Preview: General contractor brought action against subcontractor, subcontractor's successor corporation, and parent corporation of both subcontractor and successor alleging disregard of corporate entity and violation of Michigan Fraudulent Conveyance Act and Michigan Bulk Transfer Act.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan, Lawrence P. Zatkoff, J., rendered judgment for contractor and imposed sanctions against defendants, and defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Engel, Chief Judge, held that: (1) evidence supported determinations that defendants violated Fraudulent Conveyance Act and that piercing corporate veil was proper, and (2) contractor was not entitled to Rule 11 sanctions. Affirmed in part, reversed and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Leo Eisenberg & Co., Inc. v. Payson
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 2, Department A.
Headnote: Real estate agency was not entitled to commission under agreement which required that prospective tenant open for business as condition for payment of commission, where tenant located by agency never opened for business, although tenant located by agency was shareholder in corporation which later signed lease and opened for business; evidence did not show that corporation was alter ego of tenant located by agency, and there was no contention that there was any fraud or subterfuge.
Document Preview: Real estate agency brought action to recover commission from landlord for renting of restaurant property.  The Superior Court, Pima County, Cause No. 207765, Ronald J. Stolkin, J. pro tem, granted summary judgment in favor of agency, and landlord appealed.  The Court of Appeals, 152 Ariz. 390, 732 P.2d 1128, reversed and remanded.  On remand, the Superior Court entered judgment for agency pursuant to jury verdict, and landlord appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Hathaway, J., held that agency was not entitled to commission for renting to corporation, even though original tenant found by agency, which had been unable to open for business, was shareholder in that corporation. Remanded with direction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: In re Carterhouse, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Evidence established that activities of second corporation which related to its representation of competitor of principal were attributable to corporate debtor, which had signed agency agreement with principal containing noncompetition agreement, and thus, conduct of second corporation was attributable to debtor under Connecticut corporate veil analysis and debtor violated noncompetition clause; president and sole shareholder of debtor was also president and sole shareholder of second corporation, corporate formalities were not observed between debtor and second corporation, and no books or records were offered to demonstrate that debtor and second corporation, which shared same office, were treated as separate corporations.
Document Preview: Principal in agency agreement with Chapter 11 debtor objected to confirmation of plan.  The Bankruptcy Court, Alan H.W. Shiff, J., held that: (1) noncompetition clause in agency agreement prohibited Chapter 11 debtor's president, as well as debtor, from competing with principal, and clause was violated under Delaware law by president's formation of second corporation, of which corporation was sole shareholder, to act as agent for principal's competitor, and (2) debtor's plan, which did not provide for cure of debtor's breach of noncompetition in agency agreement, prevented debtor from assuming agency agreement, and thus, plan, which was to be funded primarily by continuance of debtor's contractual relationship under agency agreement, could not be confirmed. Objection sustained.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Gibraltar Sav. v. LDBrinkman Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, corporation's creditor was not entitled to pierce corporate veil, though evidence may have supported its "sham to perpetrate fraud" theory asserted on appeal, where sole ground addressed by parties below was "alter ego," which was distinct theory, and evidence did not support such theory; though there was some laxity of corporate minutes and documentation, and holding company officers provided certain services for subsidiary debtor, entities had separate directors and kept separate books, and made effort to observe corporate distinctions.
Document Preview: Creditor brought action against corporate debtor's holding company and its owner following default on promissory note.  The United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, Lucius Desha Bunton, III, Chief Judge, entered judgment for creditor, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Jerry E. Smith, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) creditor had standing to bring suit, though debtor was in bankruptcy; (2) holding company and its principal shareholder were not alter egos of subsidiaries who obtained loans, and thus were not contractually liable to lender, absent evidence of lack of separateness; and (3) evidence was sufficient to support finding that holding company tortiously interfered with debtor's contractual relations. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Total Care Health Industries, Inc. v. Department of Social Services
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: No evidence demonstrated that corporate official used his corporation to transact personal business or that corporation was alter ego of now defunct corporation and thus precluded piercing corporate veil of defunct corporation in withholding Medicaid reimbursement to current corporation to make up for overpayments to now defunct corporation.
Document Preview: Medical supply corporation brought Article 78 proceeding to review determination of Department of Social Services which withheld Medicaid payments to it to offset overpayments made to another defunct corporation which had been owned and operated by same shareholder operating petitioner.  The Supreme Court, Queens County, Kassoff, J., granted the petition and reversed the determination.  Department appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) there was no evidence to demonstrate that shareholder had used petitioner to transact personal business or as alter ego of now defunct corporation which would warrant piercing corporate veil, and (2) fact that one person was shareholder, officer and director in two corporations does not by itself warrant disregard of separate corporate entities. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Aero Planning Intern., Inc. v. Air Associates, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon.
Headnote: In action to pierce corporate veil and hold individual shareholders of two corporations liable for corporations' debts, evidence that two corporations did not keep separate accounts or records, that shareholders managed corporations jointly, that only one corporation compensated shareholders although they performed services for both corporations, did not show that as between shareholders and corporations, shareholders disregarded corporate entities.
Document Preview: After judgment creditor received judgment against corporations for breach of contract, and was unable to collect upon it, creditor amended its complaint to add corporation's shareholders as parties.  The Circuit Court, Multnomah County, Donald Londer, J., granted shareholders' motion to dismiss and entered judgment in their favor, and creditor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Newman, J., held that creditor failed to make prima facie showing of improper conduct by shareholders in exercise of control over corporations, and thus corporations' corporate veil would not be pierced to hold shareholders liable for judgment against corporations. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: United Steelworkers of America, AFL-CIO-CLC v. Connors Steel Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Determination that parent corporation was alter ego of subsidiary, liable for continued payment of insurance benefits to subsidiary's retirees and their surviving spouses, was sufficiently supported by evidence of common stock ownership, consolidated tax returns, parent's financing of subsidiary, parent's causing of subsidiary to become incorporated, common directors on boards, common business departments, and subsidiary's undercapitalization.
Document Preview: Union sought to enjoin parent corporation of bankrupt subsidiary employer from terminating payment of retirement benefits under expired collective bargaining agreement.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama, No. CV87AR0374S, William M. Acker, Jr., J., held for union, and parent appealed.  On rehearing The Court of Appeals, Tuttle, Senior Circuit Judge, held that: (1) employer was obligated to continue providing benefits even after expiration of agreement, and (2) parent was alter ego of subsidiary. Affirmed. Opinion superseded, 847 F.2d 707.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: U.S. v. Arkwright, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Hampshire.
Headnote: Facts as alleged established prima facie case of personal jurisdiction over nonresident parent, which may not have had requisite minimum contacts with forum state, based on its control over resident subsidiary, in action arising out of subsidiary's failure to comply with air pollution control regulation. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rules 4(e), 12(b), 28 U.S.C.A.; U.S.C.A. Const.Amends. 5, 14.
Document Preview: Environmental Protection Agency brought action against parent and subsidiary, which was plastic film surface coating plant, to obtain injunctive relief and civil penalties under the Clean Air Act.  Parent and subsidiary moved for dismissal and the EPA cross-moved for partial summary judgment.  The District Court, Devine, Chief Judge, held that: (1) facts as alleged established prima facie case of personal jurisdiction over parent; (2) genuine issues of fact, concerning amount of control parent exercised over subsidiary, precluded summary judgment as to parent; (3) consent agreement, which was negotiated between Rhode Island and subsidiary and which incorporated exceptions to Rhode Island's original state implementation plan, had to approved by the EPA as matter of law; and (4) failure of the EPA to approve or disapprove the proposed consent agreement within four months did not bar simultaneous EPA noncompliance enforcement proceedings. So...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: A. Stucki Co. v. Worthington Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence adduced by patentholder which had prevailed on infringement claim did not justify disregard of status of infringer and corporation which had acquired majority of shares of second corporation whose assets included 50 percent of infringer's stock as distinct, separate corporations, such that corporation could be held liable for direct infringement; although patentholder alleged that corporation was liable because it did nothing to stop infringer's actions, there was no evidence that corporation had control over infringer's actions and could have stopped infringement merely because it indirectly acquired stock of other corporation long after infringement had begun. 35 U.S.C.A. § 271(a).
Document Preview: Patentholder which had prevailed on infringement claim brought action against corporation which had acquired majority of shares of second corporation whose assets included 50 percent of infringer's stock, claiming that corporation was liable for direct infringement and inducing infringement, and further asserting claim under RICO.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, Raymond J. Broderick, J., granted directed verdict to corporation, and patentholder appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Markey, Chief Judge, held that: (1) evidence adduced by patentholder did not justify disregard of status of infringer and corporation as distinct, separate corporations; (2) evidence adduced by patentholder did not justify holding corporation liable under corporate/successor theory of liability; (3) evidence was insufficient to establish that corporation induced infringement and (4) evidence was insufficient to...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: MBC, Inc. v. Space Center Minnesota, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: Trial court's decision, not to pierce corporate veil and attach liability for subsidiary's breach of bulk sale and commercial lease contract on parent company, was not against manifest weight of evidence.
Document Preview: Buyer of commercial warehouse business sought rescission of sale and lease contract, and seller/lessor sought damages for breach of contract and lease.  The Circuit Court, Cook County, James C. Murray, J., found for seller/lessor and awarded damages.  On appeal, the Appellate Court, Freeman, J., held that: (1) buyer of warehouse business waived condition precedent that seller's warranties be true, and (2) seller/lessor failed in its duty to mitigate damages under lease. Affirmed in part and reversed in part. McNamara, J., dissented with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: In re Brickell Inv. Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Under Florida law, debtor corporations were not alter egos of former corporations, for purpose of imposing former corporations' tax liabilities upon debtors; evidence did not support allegations of commingling of funds, or that debtor and former corporations were organized and controlled by same individuals.
Document Preview: Chapter 11 debtors objected to IRS claim arising from unpaid employment taxes of nondebtor corporations. The Bankruptcy Court, Sidney M. Weaver, J., held that evidence was insufficient to support government allegation that debtor corporations were alter egos of nondebtor corporations which owed unemployment taxes. Objections sustained.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Scott v. AZL Resources, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of New Mexico.
Headnote: There was insufficient showing of improper purpose to warrant piercing corporate veil so as to render parent corporation and subsidiary corporations jointly and severally liable for another subsidiary corporation's breach of employment agreement; there was no showing that subsidiary corporations were undercapitalized when incorporated, that their financial setup was only sham, or that any injustice resulted from setup.
Document Preview: Former chairman and chief executive officer of subsidiary corporation brought action against subsidiary, its parent corporation, and other subsidiaries of parent corporation for breach of employment contract.  The District Court of Santa Fe County, Bruce E. Kaufman, D.J., found breach of employment agreement and found each corporation jointly and severally liable under theory of piercing corporate veil, and appeals were taken.  The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that there was insufficient showing of improper purpose to warrant piercing corporate veil. Reversed and remanded with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Smith v. Dainichi Kinzoku Kogyo Co., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: American wholly owned subsidiary of Japanese lathe manufacturer was not liable for alleged defect in lathe which it neither manufactured nor sold, absent evidence to controvert American corporation's contention that it was separate and distinct corporate entity from Japanese parent.
Document Preview: Texas resident brought action against Japanese lathe manufacturer, California retailer, and wholly owned domestic subsidiary of Japanese manufacturer to recover damages for injuries sustained as result of alleged defect in lathe.  The District Court, Walter S. Smith, Jr., J., held that: (1) service of process directly upon Japanese corporation by registered mail was sufficient to comport with Hague Convention; (2) Japanese manufacturer which sold lathe to regional retailer which served only states of California, Arizona, and Nevada was not subject to personal jurisdiction in Texas; and (3) plaintiff could not pierce corporate veil to hold wholly owned American subsidiary of Japanese manufacturer liable for alleged defect, absent evidence that corporations were not separate and distinct. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Hansen v. Green River Group
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: Substantial evidence supported trial court's finding that purchaser was not alter ego of subpurchaser, so as to enable original vendors to disregard purchaser's corporate entity and enforce subcontract; use by purchaser and subpurchaser of joint hyphenated name did not constitute legally sufficient proof of "unity of interest."
Document Preview: Original vendors of motel filed action against purchaser, subpurchaser and its individual partners, requesting decree of foreclosure and damages for waste to the premises.  The District Court, Carbon County, Boyd Bunnell, J., entered judgment against purchaser, with order directing foreclosure sale of motel, but dismissing action as to all other defendants.  Vendors appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Jackson, J., held that: (1) language in subcontract was not an assignment to or an assumption by subpurchaser of purchaser's rights and duties under its contract with original vendor; (2) original vendors were not third-party beneficiaries of subcontract between purchaser and subpurchaser; (3) substantial evidence supported trial court's finding that purchaser was not alter ego of subpurchaser; and (4) original vendors failed to establish cause of action for waste against subpurchaser and any of its individual partners. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Dorn v. Stanhope Steel, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support finding that parent corporation was liable for obligations imposed upon its separately-operated subsidiary by agency agreement; the trial court had determined that although parent and subsidiary had observed many of the requirements for maintaining separate corporate identities, they did not do so in their dealings with agent. 15 P.S. §§ 1907, 2111.
Document Preview: Employee brought action against employer and employer's parent corporation for breach of exclusive brokerage agreement.  The Common Pleas Court, Civil Division, Allegheny County, No. GD 849536, Weir, J., directed verdict in favor of employee against employer, and the jury returned verdict in favor of employee against parent corporation.  Employer and parent corporation appealed.  The Superior Court, No. 455 Pittsburgh, 1986, Rowley, J., held that: (1) brokerage agreement established contract of agency, rather than contract of employment; (2) agency agreement was terminated by operation of law when employer voluntarily discontinued operations; (3) employer remained obligated under the agreement to pay agreed upon compensation, notwithstanding termination of the agreement; and (4) implied condition that employer's obligation would remain effective only so long as employer remained in business could not be read into the...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Hideca Petroleum Corp. v. Tampimex Oil Intern., Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence that although domestic oil company claimed it had authority to deal with seller of crude oil for purpose of international oil cargo only at direction of international oil company, and only pursuant to specific instruction, that domestic oil company acted with seller in absence of any direction or instructions from international oil company, that both oil companies used same address, that names of two oil companies were never referred to as two separate entities and that it was customary in petroleum business to use various forms of corporate name to refer to same company, was sufficient to support finding that both oil companies generally disregarded separateness of their corporate entities to detriment of seller of oil, so as to warrant disregarding corporate fiction under alter ego theory to hold both oil companies liable in breach of contract suit arising from aborted international crude oil transaction.
Document Preview: Action was brought for breach of contract arising out of aborted international crude oil transaction.  The 234th District Court, Harris County, Ruby Sondock, J., entered judgment for seller of crude oil and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Levy, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support finding that domestic crude oil company was individually liable on contract because it was acting for undisclosed or partially disclosed principal, and substituted its own responsibility for, or pledged its own responsibility in addition to, that of its principal; (2) evidence was sufficient to support finding that domestic oil company was alter ego of oil company operating in international markets; and (3) evidence was sufficient to support finding that domestic oil company was liable for damages for negligent misrepresentation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Gaskins v. A.B.C. Drug Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Record supported conclusion that two corporations were separate corporate entities, not "the same creature," even though both corporations had same vice-president.
Document Preview: Personal injury action was filed against corporate defendants.  The Superior Court, Lowndes County, Lilly, J., entered an order granting summary judgment and dismissing the complaint with prejudice.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Pope, J., held that: (1) service of process on the originally named corporate defendant was not sufficient to constitute service upon a subsequently named defendant, even though both corporations had the same vice-president; (2) the personal injury action was barred by the two-year statute of limitations; and (3) the husband's loss of consortium claim was not time barred, as it was governed by a four-year statute of limitations. Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Brunswick Mfg. Co., Inc. v. Sizemore
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: In view of possible impeachment of corporate officer and employee and resultant credibility issues, evidence in action brought by former corporate employees for compensation earned but not paid could be viewed as showing depletion of corporate assets, thus authorizing piercing corporate veil of employer so as to hold two other corporations liable for employer's debt to employees.
Document Preview: Former employees of corporation brought action against corporate and individual defendants, seeking judgment for bonus or vacation pay compensation, allegedly earned but not paid.  The Glynn State Court, Adams, J., entered judgment in favor of employees against corporate defendants and awarded actual damages, interest and expenses of litigation.  Corporate defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, McMurray, P.J., held that: (1) employees were entitled to the compensation at issue; (2) evidence of depletion of corporate assets authorized piercing of corporate veil to reach corporate defendants other than the nominal corporate employer; and (3) employees were entitled to award of expenses of litigation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: In re Landbank Equity Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division. .
Headnote: Evidence permitted finding corporation was mere instrumentality of corporate debtor's fraudulent operations, and thus supported piercing of that corporation's veil in bankruptcy trustee's action, although evidence was introduced that the corporation was in loan brokerage business and generated income for debtor in form of loan points; corporation received cash loans from debtor as well as payments described as brokerage fees, no formal brokerage agreement between corporation and debtor was found, and former employee for corporation testified that completed loan packages were sent to debtor, were handled by regional manager who was employee of debtor, and were ultimately funded by debtor.
Document Preview: Trustee brought action seeking to recover from relatives and entities related to debtor funds trustee believed went to them illegally.  The Bankruptcy Court, 66 B.R. 949, Hal J. Bonney, Jr., J., awarded trustee monetary damages against various defendants, and defendants appealed.  The District Court, Clarke, J., held that: (1) evidence supported piercing of veils of various corporations; (2) loans made to officers or employees of corporate debtor and its affiliates with no payment or nominal payment of points violated debtor's policy and deprived debtor and its creditors of assets that would have been available if loans been made to public, and accordingly, points not paid were allowable item of damages; (3) loans received from debtor by individuals who were officers and employees of debtor and its affiliates were recoverable on grounds they were fraudulently obtained; and (4) threefold damages were properly awarded against various...
