Title: In re Landbank Equity Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division. .
Headnote: Evidence permitted piercing veil of corporation affiliated with corporate debtor in bankruptcy trustee's action seeking to recover from relatives and entities related to debtor funds trustee believed went to them illegally; testimony revealed that corporation was indebted to debtor based upon series of transactions by which foreclosed property was transferred from debtor to corporation without consideration, those transfers were not documented, nor were corporate minutes found reflecting authorization for transfers, minutes from debtor's board meeting indicated that corporation was to be used as means of avoiding revelation of foreclosure losses to investors in corporate debtor, and counsel for defendants appeared to concede in final argument before bankruptcy court that evidence was presented at trial from which it could be concluded corporate veil should be pierced.

Title: In re Landbank Equity Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division. .
Headnote: Evidence established corporation was sham used to divert funds from corporate debtor, and thus supported piercing corporation's veil in bankruptcy trustee's action to recover from relatives and entities related to debtor funds trustee believed went to them illegally; corporation received $37,500 in brokerage fees from debtor, but had no independent employees, and according to letter drafted by corporate debtor's accountant, corporation had no assets, liabilities, or net worth, and was merely trade name used by corporate debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Johnson v. Flowers Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Absent showing that parent company, which allegedly replaced employees of one subsidiary with younger employees of second subsidiary, maintained anything other than normal parent-subsidiary relationship with second subsidiary, replaced employees failed to establish prima facie case of age discrimination. Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 621 et seq.
Document Preview: Employees brought suit against their employer, its parent and another subsidiary, alleging that parent replaced them with younger employees of other subsidiary, in violation of Age Discrimination in Employment Act.  The United States District Court for the Western District of Virginia, at Roanoke, James C. Turk, Chief Judge, granted summary judgment for defendants, and employees appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Wilkinson, Circuit Judge, held that absent showing that parent company, which allegedly replaced employees of one subsidiary with younger employees of second subsidiary, maintained anything other than normal parent-subsidiary relationship with second subsidiary, replaced employees failed to establish prima facie case of age discrimination. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Riquelme Valdes v. Leisure Resource Group, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence failed to establish that lender's parent corporation and lender exercised particularly persuasive control over purchaser of Mexican hotel, that interim operating agreement demonstrated control of lender and lender's parent corporation over purchaser, that lender and parent acted as alter ego of purchaser under Texas law, and that lender and parent corporation were liable for purchaser's fraud that induced sale of Mexican hotel for vacation time-share business.
Document Preview: Mexican vendor brought action against purchaser, purchaser's lender, and lender's parent corporation for fraud and civil conspiracy in connection with purchaser's inability to perform contract for sale of hotel.  The United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, Walter S. Smith, Jr., J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of vendor.  Purchaser, lender, and parent corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Edith H. Jones, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) evidence established that purchaser fraudulently misrepresented financial support necessary to perform successfully under purchase contract; (2) evidence failed to establish that lender and parent corporation were in civil conspiracy with purchaser; and (3) evidence failed to establish that lender and parent corporation were alter ego of purchaser. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Resorts Intern., Inc. v. Charter Air Center, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Finding that offshore casino was liable under contract between subsidiary of casino and airline was supported by evidence that airline dealt only with casino and its representatives in negotiating contract for air service to casino, and casino did not inform representative of airline that subsidiary would replace casino as named party in contract until immediately prior to signing of contract.
Document Preview: Airline brought action against offshore casino and its subsidiary for breach of contract to provide air service to casino.  The Circuit Court, Dade County, Richard S. Fuller, J., found in favor of airline, and casino and subsidiary appealed.  The District Court of Appeal, Nesbitt, J., held that: (1) finding that casino was liable under contract between subsidiary and airline was supported by evidence that casino intended to fraudulently avoid liability by having airline contract with subsidiary; (2) admission of evidence establishing oral contract between airline and casino for financial guarantee was not barred by statute of frauds; and (3) award of damages for lost profits and expenditures made in reliance on contract was erroneous. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Miller v. Dixon Industries Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: Parent corporation could not be held liable for its subsidiary's breach of an employment contract where there was nothing suggesting that the parent and subsidiary were anything other than distinct and adequately capitalized incorporated financial units and where record disclosed no evidence that the parent perpetrated fraud or acted inequitably in negotiating the contract pursuant to which the plaintiff was employed by the subsidiary.
Document Preview: Suit was brought against the employer and its parent corporation for breach of an employment contract.  The Superior Court, Providence County, Lagueux, J., entered judgment in favor of the plaintiff, and appeals were taken.  The Supreme Court, Weisberger, J., held that: (1) stock-option benefits that were available to another executive during the term of the plaintiff's employment agreement were additional fringe benefits to which the plaintiff was entitled under his employment contract; (2) for purposes of applying interest-on-judgment statute, plaintiff's claim for breach of employment contract, which was based on the employer's failure to offer him stock-option benefits, accrued on the dates on which he first could have exercised the stock options rather than on the dates the stock options were granted; (3) cash-bonus program offered by the employer to its other executives was an additional fringe benefit as...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Christian Bros., Inc. v. South Windsor Arena, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Findings that seller was owed sum of money for hockey sticks sold to defendant corporation, that second corporation was merely an extension of defendant corporation and that individual defendant had control over the management of both corporations were not clearly erroneous and supported conclusion that second corporation and individual defendant should be held liable for the debts of the defendant corporation under instrumentality rule or identity rule.
Document Preview: Seller brought action against two corporations and individual defendant on debt owed to seller.  The Superior Court, Judicial District of Hartford-New Britain, Stoughton, J., rendered judgment accepting referee's report recommending judgment for seller and corporation and individual defendant appealed.  The Appellate Court held that: (1) finding that defendant corporation owed seller money, that second corporation was merely an extension of defendant corporation and that individual defendant controlled both corporations justified holding second corporation and individual defendant liable for debts of defendant corporation, and (2) award of 18% interest on debt owed by defendants to seller was improper where there was no finding that defendants had agreed to 18% interest. Error in part; judgment directed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Brock v. Executive Towers, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence that first corporation operated bar featuring go-go dancers and nude and seminude entertainment and rented nearby property to second corporation, with same majority shareholder, for operation of adult bookstore, that second corporation previously operated another nearby adult bookstore, and that bookstores and bar used certain employees interchangeably and employed single record keeper demonstrated activities of bookstores and bar involved coordinated retailing with common purpose of providing erotic entertainment and, accordingly, two corporations constituted single enterprise for purposes of determining whether they met Fair Labor Standards Act jurisdictional requirement of $250,000 in gross sales. Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, § 3(r, s), 29 U.S.C.A. § 203(r, s).
Document Preview: Secretary of Labor brought action against corporations with same majority shareholder and majority shareholder under Fair Labor Standards Act. The United States District Court for the Southern District of West Virginia, Dennis R. Knapp, J., awarded Secretary recovery of unpaid minimum wages on behalf of certain employees of corporations and enjoined corporations from violating Act's minimum wage, overtime and record-keeping provisions, and corporations and majority shareholder appealed. The Court of Appeals held that: (1) corporations constituted single enterprise for purpose of determining whether corporation met jurisdictional requirement of $250,000 in gross annual sales under Act, and (2) corporations met jurisdictional requirement of $250,000 in gross annual sales under Act. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: AgriStor Leasing v. Meuli
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, individuals claiming liability of parent corporation for alleged defects in equipment designed and manufactured by subsidiary failed to show evidence to justify piercing the corporate veil so as to render parent liable, although it owned 100% of subsidiary's stock, shared officers, and caused its incorporation, absent showing of parental financing, inadequate capitalization, or facts showing relationship was so intimate that recognizing subsidiary as a separate entity would work injustice.
Document Preview: Lessor of farm storage system brought action against lessees for breach of lease and wrongful detention.  Lessees counterclaimed alleging strict liability, negligence, breach of warranties and claims on other theories and also brought third-party complaint against dealer, manufacturer, and manufacturer's parent corporation.  The District Court, Patrick F. Kelly, J., held that: (1) agreements were true leases rather than sales; (2) claims under Kansas Consumer Protection Act regarding lease of one piece of equipment and seeking civil penalties regarding lease of second piece of equipment were barred by statute of limitations, although other claims regarding second piece of equipment remained; and (3) claims for economic losses could not be recovered under tort theory. Judgment accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Adriatic Ship Supply Co., Inc. v. M/V Shaula
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: "Corporate veil" could not be pierced in order to hold vessels' owners or company which alleged controlled it liable for goods and services furnished to the vessels on the orders of the vessels' charterers where there was no evidence that the owner nor the company which allegedly controlled it had any interrelationship with or control over the charterers.
Document Preview: Suit was brought against two vessels in rem and against their owner and a company which alleged controlled the owner seeking compensation for supplies furnished to the vessels.  The District Court, Luongo, Chief Judge, held that provider of goods and services to two vessels failed to establish that vessels' charterers acted as agents for the vessels' owner and company which allegedly controlled the owner; thus, the owner and the company allegedly controlling it were not personally liable for goods or services furnished to the vessels. Judgment in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: City of New York v. Exxon Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Prior to discovery, city which brought suit against foreign corporation was required only to make prima facie showing that activities of subsidiary should be imputed to foreign corporation in order to establish jurisdiction over foreign corporation.
Document Preview: City brought action under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 against major corporations which generated and transported hazardous wastes dumped at city landfills.  All defendants moved to dismiss for failure to state claim for private cost recovery, one defendant moved to dismiss on grounds that wastes generated by such defendant were not hazardous, and one defendant moved to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction.  The District Court, Edward Weinfeld, J., held that: (1) city, as private party, was not required to secure approval from federal or state authorities as precondition for commencement of action; (2) issue of whether wastes deposited in city's landfills were hazardous was question to be addressed after discovery; and (3) city made prima facie showing of jurisdiction over foreign corporation. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: City of New York v. Exxon Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to establish jurisdiction over foreign corporation after completion of discovery, city which brought suit against foreign corporation would be required to demonstrate by preponderance of evidence upon the trial that activities of subsidiary acting within state should be imputed to foreign corporation.
Document Preview: City brought action under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 against major corporations which generated and transported hazardous wastes dumped at city landfills.  All defendants moved to dismiss for failure to state claim for private cost recovery, one defendant moved to dismiss on grounds that wastes generated by such defendant were not hazardous, and one defendant moved to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction.  The District Court, Edward Weinfeld, J., held that: (1) city, as private party, was not required to secure approval from federal or state authorities as precondition for commencement of action; (2) issue of whether wastes deposited in city's landfills were hazardous was question to be addressed after discovery; and (3) city made prima facie showing of jurisdiction over foreign corporation. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: City of New York v. Exxon Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: City which brought suit against foreign corporation under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act made prima facie showing of jurisdiction over foreign corporation, where uncontroverted affidavit of official of subsidiary, which allegedly generated and transported hazardous waste dumped at city landfill, established that subsidiary was financially dependent on foreign corporation, that there was failure to observe corporate formalities and that foreign corporation exercised degree of control over marketing and operations of subsidiary, regardless of whether foreign corporation had specific knowledge of subsidiary's alleged illegal dumping operations. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, §§ 101-308, 42 U.S.C.A. §§ 9601-9657; Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 12(b)(6), 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: City brought action under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 against major corporations which generated and transported hazardous wastes dumped at city landfills.  All defendants moved to dismiss for failure to state claim for private cost recovery, one defendant moved to dismiss on grounds that wastes generated by such defendant were not hazardous, and one defendant moved to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction.  The District Court, Edward Weinfeld, J., held that: (1) city, as private party, was not required to secure approval from federal or state authorities as precondition for commencement of action; (2) issue of whether wastes deposited in city's landfills were hazardous was question to be addressed after discovery; and (3) city made prima facie showing of jurisdiction over foreign corporation. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Paramount Petroleum Corp. v. Taylor Rental Center
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Finding that corporations were single business enterprise, so that one was liable for equipment rental on invoices to other, was supported by evidence that same shareholder owned all stock in both companies, companies operated from same office and were referred to by same name, both companies paid funds to employee for repair work on ship on which equipment was used, one company transferred funds with no ledger entries to checking account over which employee of other company was signatory, and in response to discovery request no corporate records of either company were produced.
Document Preview: Lessor sought payment of equipment rental charges in 152nd District Court, Harris County, Jack O'Neill, J., from oil company.  Following judgment for lessor, oil company appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Cannon, J., held that: (1) single business enterprise theory was supported by evidence; (2) theory of partnership by estoppel was supported by evidence; and (3) trial court could refuse to allow oil company to enter contract into evidence because of failure to produce at discovery request. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Combs v. Ryan's Coal Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence that individual directed and controlled finances of both companies, as well as numerous others, and ran all of them out of one office, that the decision not to pay an obligation under consent decree was his, and that he authorized over $60,000 in payments to himself and others while he was in default of his obligations under the consent decrees sustained finding that individual was alter ego of one corporation and that second corporation was successor of first, so that all were liable under the consent decree.
Document Preview: Appeals were taken from orders of the United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama, U.W. Clemon, J., which found individual and corporations in contempt.  The Court of Appeals, Johnson, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) initial finding of contempt was not an appealable order; (2) underlying injunction adequately complied with Rule 65; (3) determination that individual was alter ego of corporation and that another corporation was successor to first corporation was proper; (4) contempt could not be used to enforce money judgments; and (5) contemnors did not show inability to pay. Affirmed in part, remanded in part, and dismissed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Teixeira v. Van Camp Seafood Co., Div. of Ralston Purina Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Ship's crew, who alleged that employer and its husbanding agent had no separate corporation existence independent of their common parent corporation, but who offered no evidence of alter ego or that either corporation was not independent business entity, failed to establish lack of separate corporate existence so as to warrant imposition of liability on husbanding agent for unpaid wages and wrongful discharge.
Document Preview: Captain and crew of tuna fishing vessel brought action against employer's husbanding agent and ship in admiralty for unpaid wages and wrongful discharge.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of California, M.D. Crocker, J., found for husbanding agent and ship, and captain and crew appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Pregerson, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) husbanding agent, which provided accounting, administrative services, credit arrangements and assistance in arranging repairs and selecting ship personnel was not the ship's owner pro hac vice so as to be liable as employer to crew for unpaid wages and wrongful discharge, and (2) ship could not be held liable in rem for unpaid wages, where no warrant was ever issued for ship. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Kashfi v. Phibro-Salomon, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Bald allegations that parent corporation exerted control over decisions of its wholly owned subsidiary were not sufficient to sustain claim against parent by piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: Iranian citizen brought action to recover payment for services he claimed to have rendered in Iran for Delaware corporation.  On corporation's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Tenney, J., held that: (1) written personal services contract, under which citizen arranged meetings between corporation and key officials of Iranian Government in connection with oil barter transaction, was between citizen and British subsidiary of corporation; (2) British subsidiary was not subservient to corporation so as to permit piercing of corporate veil between the corporations; (3) citizen's quantum meruit claim for finder's fee for having introduced corporation to Iranian officials was barred by New York six-year limitations period; and (4) contract violated Iranian penal statute and contravened public policy of United States and, thus, was unenforceable. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: In re Bellanca Aircraft Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Record, which indicated that creditor's subsidiary maintained, to some extent, active existence separate from that of creditor, established that creditor was not entitled to pierce its own corporate veil so as to offset new value advanced by subsidiary to debtor against prior preferential transfers by debtor to creditor under § 547(c)(4). Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. § 547(b), (c)(4).
Document Preview: Trustee filed complaint seeking to avoid certain allegedly preferential and postpetition transfers from debtor to creditors, a corporation and its subsidiary, and to equitably subordinate creditors' claims against estate. Creditors sought claim for administrative expenses.  The Bankruptcy Court, Margaret A. Mahoney, J., held that: (1) property debtor preferentially transferred to second creditor was entirely offset by second creditor's subsequent new value advances to debtor, and thus, trustee was not entitled to avoid any transfers to second creditor; (2) first creditor was only entitled to partial offset against preferential transfers for new value subsequently advanced to debtor, and thus, trustee was entitled to avoid preferential transfers in amount of $111,010.38; and (3) trustee failed to establish inequitable conduct on part of creditors warranting equitable subordination of their claims. Order accordingly.

Title: U.S. v. Jon-T Chemicals, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: District court's finding that there was commingling of corporate funds of parent and subsidiary was supported by record, where it was undisputed that parent made ongoing advances to subsidiary, whenever subsidiary could not pay his bills, parent did so by writing check, and intercorporate loans were handled informally, without any corporation resolution authorizing them.
Document Preview: After obtaining criminal conviction against corporation and individuals in connection with fraudulent misrepresentations to obtain agricultural subsidies under upland cotton program, Government brought action to recover erroneously paid subsidies.  When corporation went into bankruptcy, and further proceedings were stayed, Government sought to hold corporation's parent company liable on ground that subsidiary was its alter ego or agent.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas, Halbert O. Woodward, Chief Judge, sitting without jury, found that parent exercised total domination and control over subsidiary and that consequently subsidiary was alter ego of parent, and entered judgment against parent in amount of $4,787,604.20, and parent appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Goldberg, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) District Court's finding that there was commingling of corporate funds was supported by record; (2) subsidiary was...

Title: Wichers v. Solomon Valley Feed Lot, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Kansas.
Headnote: Even if appraisal statute, K.S.A. 17-6712, contained a provision to allow stockholders of absorbed corporation to pierce the corporate veil to reach assets of surviving corporation into which absorbed corporation merged, record did not demonstrate that the two corporations were but one entity so as to entitle shareholders to be paid a proportionate value of assets of surviving corporation, therefore, shareholders were not entitled to an element of value representing what would be their proportionate interest in surviving corporation if they exchanged their shares for that corporation's shares.
Document Preview: Stockholders with shares in corporation which merged into another corporation brought action for declaratory and other relief.  The District Court, Mitchell County, Richard W. Wahl, J., granted summary judgment in favor of surviving corporation, and stockholders appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Rees, J., held that: (1) stockholders were not entitled to a judicial declaration that appraised value of their shares of their corporation included an element of value attributable to combined worth of the two corporations; (2) even if appraisal statute contained provision to allow stockholders to pierce corporate veil to reach surviving corporation's assets, record did not bear out assertion that corporations were but one entity, and therefore stockholders were not entitled to an element of value representing what would have been their proportionate interest in surviving corporation had they exchanged their shares; and (3) merger did not violate any...

Title: Donovan v. Burgett Greenhouses, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence supported district court's piercing of corporate veil and holding corporations with assets to be employer's alter ego for purposes of determining his ability to comply with injunction restraining him from continuing to withhold payment of unpaid wages due to certain employees. Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, § 1 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 201 et seq.
Document Preview: Secretary of Labor filed petition for adjudication in civil contempt alleging that employer had failed to comply with retroactive mandatory injunction restraining him from continuing to withhold payment of unpaid wages due to certain employees. The United States District Court for the District of New Mexico, Howard C. Bratton, Chief Judge, found employer in contempt, and appeal was taken by employer. The Court of Appeals, McKay, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) statute of limitations found in section of the Portal-to-Portal Act did not bar Secretary's petition seeking enforcement of judgment entered in 1977; (2) Secretary's petition was not time barred under applicable state statute; and (3) employer failed to meet his burden showing that he was unable to comply with injunction. Affirmed.

Title: American Pioneer Life Ins. Co. v. Sandlin
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: In insurance fraud case arising from sale of annuity, finding that corporation owning stock of insurer which issued annuity was alter ego of insurer was supported by at least a scintilla of evidence, including testimony of president of insurer, who had also been vice-president of corporation, that he ran day-to-day operations of insurer and corporation, that regular transfers of funds were made between corporation and insurer, and that executive committees of corporation and insurer completely overlapped.
Document Preview: Executor of insured's estate brought insurance fraud action against insurer which issued annuity to insured and corporation owning stock of insurer.  The Circuit Court, Marion County, Bobby Aderholt, J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of executor, and insurer and corporation appealed.  The Supreme Court, Almon, J., held that: (1) settlement agreement between estate and insurance company whose registered agent persuaded insurer to purchase annuity released insurer only to extent of settlement, and did not operate as full satisfaction of judgment; (2) whether letter sent to insured by vice-president and underwriter of insurer was sufficient to raise his suspicion to extent that statute of limitations should begin to run was question for jury; (3) whether registered agent of insurance company who persuaded insured to purchase annuity was agent of insurer was question for jury; (4) evidence would support finding of conspiracy among...

Title: In re Baker Fence, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Union benefit fund failed to adduce sufficient proof for ignoring traditional corporate fiction so as to impose liability upon debtor for sister corporation's agreement to settle fund's claim for accumulated defaults.
Document Preview: Union benefit fund filed a claim pursuant to agreement with the debtor's sister corporation for accumulated defaults.  The Bankruptcy Court, Harold Lavien, J., held that the union benefit fund failed to establish any basis upon which the debtor could be held liable for its sister corporation's settlement. Ordered accordingly.

Title: Maurice Pierce & Associates, Inc. v. Computerage, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under "agency" theory, employed in determining whether business activities of one corporate entity may be imputed to related corporate entity for purposes of personal jurisdiction, plaintiff must make prima facie showing that agency relationship exists.
Document Preview: In action for unpaid portion of design service contract, corporate defendant moved to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction or, in the alternative, to transfer for improper venue.  The District Court, Fish, J., held that neither agency theory nor control theory supported assertion of personal jurisdiction. Motion granted.

Title: Maurice Pierce & Associates, Inc. v. Computerage, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: In order to assert personal jurisdiction over "related" corporation on theory that it was under control of another corporation or individual, plaintiff must make prima facie showing that "related" corporation was so extensively controlled by first corporation or individual that it was mere instrumentality of the other.
Document Preview: In action for unpaid portion of design service contract, corporate defendant moved to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction or, in the alternative, to transfer for improper venue.  The District Court, Fish, J., held that neither agency theory nor control theory supported assertion of personal jurisdiction. Motion granted.

Title: Board of Trustees, Container Mechanics Welfare/Pension Fund v. Universal Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Substantial evidence supported conclusion of district court that employer's wholly owned subsidiary, which took over employer's on-pier operations and all of employer's employees who belonged to union, was the alter ego of employer and therefore employer effectively voluntarily signed the multiemployer collective bargaining agreement through its alter ego and was bound by the retroactive fringe benefit provisions therein.
Document Preview: Board of trustees of union welfare and pension fund brought suit under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act against employer for pension and welfare contributions alleged to be owing under an industrywide collective bargaining agreement.  Employer asserted a counterclaim against individual trustees alleging breach of fiduciary duty as to merger of the fund with another fund.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of Georgia, B. Avant Edenfield, J., entered judgment in favor of the board on its complaint and in favor of the trustees on the counterclaim, and employer appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Tuttle, Senior Circuit Judge, held that: (1) board of trustees of welfare and pension fund did not have such an identity of interest with union as to be deemed in privity with union for purposes of res judicata (2) substantial evidence supported conclusion of District Court that employer's wholly owned subsidiary, which took over...

Title: Van Dorn Co. v. Future Chemical and Oil Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, evidence, including facts that, of two corporations dominated by same individual, corporation which ordered cans and labels from vendor had no assets, while corporation which actually used cans and labels had substantial assets, that individual operated both corporations very loosely as suited his convenience, and that corporations were completely intermingled, warranted piercing corporate veil to extent of disregarding separate corporate identities of the two corporations and treating them as a single corporate entity responsible for obligations to vendor.
Document Preview: Vendor brought action for breach of contract against two corporations dominated by same individual and against individual to recover for various labels and cans ordered by one of the two corporations.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, Hubert L. Will, J., entered judgment against both corporations jointly and severally in amount of $57,498.62.  An appeal and cross appeal were taken.  The Court of Appeals, Fairchild, Senior Circuit Judge, held that: (1) under Illinois law, evidence, including facts that, of two corporations dominated by same individual, corporation which ordered cans and labels from vendor had no assets, while corporation which actually used cans and labels had substantial assets, that individual operated both corporations very loosely as suited his convenience, and that corporations were completely intermingled, warranted piercing corporate veil to extent of disregarding separate corporate identities...

Title: United Nat. Records, Inc. v. MCA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Facts that two officers of subsidiary served as officers of parent corporation, that parent guaranteed several million dollars in loans made to subsidiary and that at one time parent owned all outstanding stock of subsidiary were insufficient to create triable issue on whether subsidiary was a mere instrumentality of parent such that parent could be held liable for subsidiary's claimed antitrust conduct in nature of price fixing.
Document Preview: In an antitrust action based on alleged price fixing in the record industry the defendants moved for partial summary judgment on limitations grounds and one defendant moved for summary judgment on ground that it was not liable for acts of its subsidiary.  The District Court, Bua, J., held that: (1) plaintiffs raised triable issues of fact under either the equitable tolling doctrine or the fraudulent concealment doctrine, and (2) motion by parent corporation for summary judgment was to be continued pending discovery. Motions denied in part and continued in part. See also, 101 F.R.D. 323.

Title: Grywczynski v. Shasta Beverages, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Where affidavit of senior vice-president of subsidiary who was responsible for personnel matters stating that all matters affecting employees of subsidiary were made by subsidiary's officials, not by parent corporation, was uncontradicted, there was no reason to depart from usual presumption that subsidiary corporation was legally separate from its parent and, therefore, former employees could not maintain action against parent corporation arising out of their termination.
Document Preview: Former employees filed suit against employer, its parent corporation and pension plan alleging wrongful discharge in violation of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act and the California Fair Employment and Housing Act.  The employer and its parent corporation moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Weigel, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) the ERISA claim was not barred by the employees' failure to exhaust their intraplan remedies; (2) the age discrimination claim under California law was time-barred; (3) claims for intentional and negligent infliction of emotional distress were barred by California's one-year statute of limitations for personal injury torts; (4) consequential damages could be awarded for emotional distress resulting from the alleged breach of an implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, but punitive damages could not be recovered; and (5) the parent corporation was entitled to dismissal of...

Title: Rhode Island Hosp. Trust Nat. Bank v. Almonte
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: Defendant's admission that a check was drawn on corporation which he owned to the order of another corporation which he owned, that the latter then drew a check payable to a particular person, defendant's admission that he signed that check with the endorsement of that person, and testimony of that person that the endorsement was made without his knowledge was virtually sufficient to support judgment against defendant in favor of bank upon which the first check was drawn.
Document Preview: Bank brought action to recover from owner of various corporations amount which it had been required to repay to the federal government after bank paid to one of the corporations a federal Treasury check with an improper endorsement. The Superior Court, Providence District, Cochran, J., entered judgment in favor of bank and owner of corporations appealed.  The Supreme Court, Weisberger, J., held that: (1) evidence sustained the judgment; (2) corporate veil was properly pierced; and (3) evidence of demand for payment made by the government to the bank was properly admitted. Appeal denied and dismissed and judgment affirmed.

Title: Lucas v. Texas Industries, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Evidence in personal injury action that parent and subsidiary had some or all of the same directors and officers, that parent and subsidiary filed consolidated income tax returns, that they shared same corporate logo, and that the two companies conducted intercorporate business did not establish basis for finding that subsidiary was alter ego of parent for purposes of liability; moreover, no evidence was introduced by plaintiff that subsidiary was undercapitalized or incapable of paying a judgment if found liable.
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought action to recover damages for personal injuries allegedly sustained on construction site when concrete beam which was being lifted from truck fell on plaintiff's leg.  Defendants included subcontractor and parent of subsidiary who fabricated the beam.  The 190th District Court, Harris County, Wyatt H. Heard, J., rendered judgment against defendants jointly and severally for $2,000,000, and they appealed.  The Court of Appeals, 634 S.W.2d 748 reversed the judgment against subcontractor and affirmed the judgment as modified.  Plaintiff appealed.  The Supreme Court, Campbell, J., held that: (1) evidence introduced by plaintiff was insufficient to pierce corporate veil to hold parent liable for alleged negligence of subsidiary in construction of concrete beam, and (2) from testimony of president of subcontractor, jury was entitled to conclude that advising that only one and a quarter-inch lifting equipment was necessary at job...

Title: Herman v. Siegmund
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: In judgment creditor's attempt to levy on property owned by corporations which were owned by owner of dissolved judgment debtor, evidence was insufficient to establish that owner failed to respect separate identities of corporations or used corporations to pursue his personal business, as distinct from corporate business, and, in addition, established that property of dissolved corporation was sold prior to accrual of creditor's claim, and thus, corporate veils of other corporations should not have been pierced to satisfy creditor's claim.
Document Preview: After remand, 69 A.D.2d 871, 415 N.Y.S.2d 681, in proceeding, inter alia, to determine adverse claims, the Supreme Court at Special Term, Suffolk County, McInerney, J., denied owners' application to set aside sheriff's sale, and owners appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) evidence was insufficient to establish that corporate veils of two other corporations owned principally by owner of dissolved corporate judgment debtor should have been pierced; (2) proceeding to set aside sale was not barred by laches; and (3) owners were entitled to vacation of sale. Reversed; petition reinstated and application to set aside sale granted.

Title: Ponderosa Development Corp. v. Bjordahl
Court: United States District Court, D. Wyoming.
Headnote: Evidence failed to establish that savings and loan associations, as shareholders of corporation, were the alter ego of the corporation and, therefore, they could not be held personally liable for judgment against the corporation.
Document Preview: In fraud action by development corporation against another corporation, its shareholders, and numerous others, defendants moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Brimmer, Chief Judge, held that: (1) claims presented by plaintiffs herein, who were previously defendants in separate foreclosure action filed by defendant corporation herein, were precluded by doctrines of res judicata, collateral estoppel, judicial estoppel, and compulsory counterclaim rule, and (2) corporate officers' and directors' duty to supervise corporate employees did not permit present or potential judgment creditors of corporation to sue the directors and officers for any alleged negligent supervision. Motion granted and complaint dismissed.

Title: People v. Parsons Co.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: Evidence that subsidiary maintained its own books, kept its own accounts, prepared its own payroll, did not hold joint directors' meeting with foreign corporation, purchased component parts from foreign corporation in same manner that it bought them from other sellers, and determined its own daily internal affairs, established that subsidiary and nonresident parent were separate legal entities, and thus, was insufficient to establish parent's "transaction of business" in state on basis of alleged control over subsidiary within meaning of long-arm statute, and parent could not be required to answer for all acts and omissions of subsidiary. S.H.A. ch. 110, ¶ 2-209(a)(1).
Document Preview: State brought action against nonresident parent corporation alleging violation of Environmental Protection Act.  The 17th Circuit Court, Boone County, Paul A. Logli, J., granted parent's motion to quash service of summons and to dismiss complaint against it for want of in personam jurisdiction, and the State appealed.  The Appellate Court, Hopf, J., held that: (1) evidence established that parent and subsidiary were separate legal entities, and thus, that parent could not be required to answer for all acts and omissions of subsidiary; (2) evidence that parent shipped waste into state was sufficient to establish prima facie case of jurisdiction under long-arm statute; (3) evidence was sufficient to establish prima facie case of agency which would permit parent to be held responsible for tortious acts and omissions of subsidiary relating to waste; (4) question of fact existed as to whether particular barrels of waste complained of had been...

Title: Rose Hall, Ltd. v. Chase Manhattan Overseas Banking Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Although there might be sufficient basis for concluding that sister corporation of parent of Jamaican banking subsidiary defrauded Jamaican court by misinforming subsidiary's director, who, contrary to parent's apparent intention, informed Jamaican court that subsidiary would not be closing, the parent could not be held liable in damages for the alleged fraud absent any evidence of parent's direct control of subsidiary as regards the representation or of indirect control through the sister corporation.
Document Preview: Mortgagor sued lessee of hotel, which was located on mortgaged property, charging that it conspired with mortgagee to sell collateral at unreasonably low price and to prevent mortgagor from suing lessee for alleged interference with more lucrative sale and also sought to hold mortgagee's parent corporation, a federally chartered Edge Act corporation, liable on a control theory.  Judgment was entered on jury verdict for mortgagor against the parent.  On motions for judgment n.o.v. and for new trial, the District Court, Murray M. Schwartz, J., held that: (1) fact that before judgment was entered on special verdict the presiding judge became unable to proceed did not mandate new trial; (2) under Jamaican law civil damage action for fraud on the court could not be brought against mortgagee's employee who allegedly made the false statement, the mortgagee or the parent corporation and that American rule on witness immunity also required same result; (3)...

Title: Hargrave v. Fibreboard Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Defendant in asbestos-related litigation failed to establish that English parent corporation was "alter ego" of its former wholly owned Pennsylvania subsidiary under Pennsylvania law.
Document Preview: Cross appeals were taken from orders of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Texas, Robert M. Parker, J., which denied third-party defendant's motion to dismiss third-party complaint against it for lack of in personam jurisdiction in asbestos-related litigation and which granted third-party defendant's motions for summary judgment in two asbestos-related lawsuits.  After consolidation, the Court of Appeals, Goldberg, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) even assuming that English parent corporation's former wholly owned Pennsylvania subsidiary was subject to jurisdiction under Texas long-arm statute, defendant failed to establish that the English parent possessed and exercised the nature and degree of control over the subsidiary necessary to fuse the two corporations for purposes of Texas long-arm statute, and (2) defendant failed to establish that English parent corporation was alter ego of its wholly owned Pennsylvania subsidiary under...

Title: M/V American Queen v. San Diego Marine Const. Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Parent corporation of ship repairer was not liable to shipowner for negligent repairs as there was no evidence indicating that disregard of the ship repairer's corporate form, e.g., commingling of funds or disregard of legal formality, and even if parent corporation was the alter ego of the ship repairer, parent corporation could not be liable since ship repairer was not liable under contract.
Document Preview: Vessel and shipowner brought action against two marine repair and construction companies alleging improper service and repair of ship's rudder.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of California, Gordon Thompson, Jr., J., granted summary judgment in favor of defendant companies, and plaintiffs appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Boochever, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) provision in ship repair contract stating that no claim under contract or for tort shall be valid unless written notice is given repairer within 60 days of redelivery of vessel and suit commenced within six months of redelivery was reasonable; (2) consideration existed for ship repair contract; (3) contract was not one of adhesion; (4) parent corporation of ship repairer could not be held liable; (5) trial court did not abuse its discretion in using two unpublished orders from same judicial district in unrelated actions in which ship repairer's...

Title: Ex parte Baker
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support finding that business affairs of subsidiary corporation were conducted in a manner that was appropriate to its separate purposes and functions, without nomination or any excessive degree of control by parent corporation, and that subsidiary corporation could not properly be regarded as alter ego or mere instrumentality of parent corporation.
Document Preview: Petition for writ of mandamus was brought seeking vacation of judicial order dismissing medical malpractice action against parent corporation of subsidiary hospital corporation and transferring venue as to all other defendants.  The Supreme Court held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support finding that business affairs of subsidiary corporation were conducted in a manner that was appropriate to its separate purposes and functions, without nomination or any excessive degree of control by parent corporation, and that subsidiary corporation could not properly be regarded as alter ego or mere instrumentality of parent corporation, and (2) failure to show awareness of brochure, in which it was alleged that holding out to public fact that corporations were subsidiaries of a parent corporation clothed corporations with apparent authority to act on behalf of parent corporation as agents, belief in what brochure said, or detrimental reliance on brochure precluded finding...

Title: Moffett v. Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Jury finding in products liability action that at time allegedly defective tire was manufactured, tire company whose logo appeared on tire did not dominate and control business of French subsidiary which manufactured tire so that subsidiary was not separate and distinct entity, was not so against great weight and preponderance of evidence as to be manifestly wrong.
Document Preview: Products liability action was brought against tire company for damages sustained when pickup truck overturned, allegedly from failure of right rear tire.  The 261st District Court, Travis County, Pete Lowry, J., entered judgment in favor of defendant company, and plaintiffs appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Brady, J., held that: (1) where plaintiffs' objections to jury charge were based on refusal of trial judge to submit plaintiffs' requested special issues to jury, objections did not preserve error based on such refusal since failure, to submit requests separately from objections to trial court's charge resulted in requests being waived; (2) where there was no endorsement of Refused by the trial court of any of three requested special issues, none were signed officially by trial judge, and there was no formal bill of exceptions in the record, error based on trial court's refusal to submit special issues was not preserved; and (3)...

Title: Translation Systems, Inc. v. Applied Technology Ventures
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Plaintiff failed to meet its burden of proving that significant decisions of defendants' subsidiary that transacted business in Maryland were subject to approval of defendants, as required to "pierce corporate veil" for purposes of jurisdiction under Maryland's long-arm statute. Md.Code, Courts and Judicial Proceedings, § 6-103(b)(1).
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought suit alleging that defendants violated provisions of Maryland Bulk Transfer Act and Maryland Fraudulent Conveyances Act.  On defendants' motion to dismiss for want of personal jurisdiction, the District Court, Joseph H. Young, J., held that it lacked personal jurisdiction over all defendants. Motion granted.

Title: Lindsay Credit Corp. v. Skarperud
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 3, Panel 1.
Headnote: Where mere allegation, which was nebulous at best, was made that connection between corporation providing credit for manufacturing corporation and manufacturing corporation was of such a nature that the two corporations should be considered one entity under doctrine of corporate disregard, but no affidavits or other documents were presented to trial court indicating why doctrine should be applied, doctrine would not be applied.
Document Preview: Purchasers of irrigation equipment appealed from entry of summary judgment and certification of finality of judgment entered by the Superior Court, Franklin County, Fred R. Staples, J., in favor of creditor on its action of default and foreclosure on promissory note.  The Court of Appeals, Munson, Acting C.J., held that: (1) creditor had requisite capacity to bring action; (2) creditor was not so dominated and controlled by manufacturer of irrigation equipment that they should be considered one entity; (3) trial court did not abuse its discretion in entering certification of finality of judgment in view of fact there was no just reason for delay; and (4) where prevailing party in action of default and foreclosure on promissory note, which provided for attorney fees, failed to itemize or include statement of hours when it filed affidavit for attorney fees, and also failed to give detailed list of expenditures in supplemental brief allowed regarding...

Title: Midcontinent Broadcasting Co. v. AVA Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: Mere identification of a subsidiary without more information is insufficient to reach conclusion that the subsidiary is the alter ego of the parent.
Document Preview: The Circuit Court, Second Judicial Circuit, Minnehaha County, William H. Heuermann, J., entered judgment in favor of payee and against guarantors in suit on a promissory note and guarantees, and guarantors appealed.  The Supreme Court, Henderson, J., held that: (1) failure of guarantors' counsel to notify guarantors of trial or to contest the issues at trial did not constitute grounds to vacate the trial court's judgment against guarantors where guarantors, who failed to furnish evidence to establish that they inquired into the status of their affairs with their counsel, fell short of the reasonably prudent person standard, and (2) since principal, which filed a bankruptcy petition and was dismissed from the action, could not be held liable for attorney fees for collection of promissory note, guarantors could not be held liable for attorney fees. Affirmed in part, reversed and remanded in part.

Title: Maki v. Copper Range Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Evidence that subsidiary and its parent corporation shared personnel, officers, and top management employees and that parent used subsidiary's offices and property and monitored performance of its departments was insufficient to allow disregarding subsidiary's corporate entity to permit its employees to bring direct negligence action against parent for failing to insist upon reasonable safety precautions, and, even if sufficient control was in issue, there was insufficient evidence that control was exercised to defraud or wrong employees of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Injured employees of subsidiary brought negligence action against parent corporation.  The Circuit Court, Ontonagon County, Donald L. Munro, J., granted summary judgment to parent corporation, and employees appealed.  The Court of Appeals held that evidence was insufficient to show sufficient control by parent of subsidiary to pierce subsidiary's corporate entity. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Williams Plaza, Inc. v. Sedgefield Sportswear Div. of Blue Bell, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Evidence that corporations had common ownership, that one was a subsidiary of the other, that acquisition of the subsidiary corporation may have been in the interest of the parent corporation, and that the two corporations had a joint obligation on a bank note was insufficient to raise a jury question as to whether the corporate veil should be pierced to hold the parent corporation liable for an unsecured debt of the subsidiary, absent proof that funds of the subsidiary were misappropriated or misused.
Document Preview: Unsecured creditor of subsidiary corporation brought action to reach the assets of the parent corporation to satisfy the subsidiary's debt on its account with the creditor.  The State Court, Houston County, Paul C. Armitage, J., entered judgment in favor of the creditor, and the parent corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Shulman, P.J., held that, evidence that corporations had common ownership, that one was a subsidiary of the other, that acquisition of the subsidiary corporation may have been in the interest of the parent corporation, and that the two corporations had a joint obligation on a bank note was insufficient to raise a jury question as to whether the corporate veil should be pierced to hold the parent corporation liable for the unsecured debt of the subsidiary corporation, absent proof that funds of the subsidiary corporation were misappropriated or misused. Judgment reversed.

Title: Regal Ins. Co. v. Summit Guar. Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Iowa.
Headnote: In action in which corporation's liquidator's challenge to a transfer of 15,000 shares of corporation's preferred stock was sustained, evidence established that a subsidiary corporation was a purchaser of the stock and that it had not been purchased by a person, who was sole owner of parent corporation and who asserted that he was a bona fide purchaser because he had no reason to be on notice of the adverse claim; having adopted the corporate form, he could not disregard it at will to avoid some disadvantage going with it. I.C.A. §§ 554.8302, 554.8315.
Document Preview: In action involving challenge to transaction in which 15,000 shares of preferred stock were transferred from corporation without it receiving any consideration, the Polk District Court, Luther T. Glanton, Jr., J., sustained challenge, entered judgment on promissory note and imposed constructive trust, and appeals were taken.  The Supreme Court, Harris, J., held that: (1) such transfer operated as fraud and deceit on corporation's creditors, and, thus, was wrongful transfer for purposes of statute which would permit corporation to reclaim the stock from anyone but a bona fide purchaser if corporation could show that transfer was wrongful; (2) bank, which, when it took stock as collateral, must have had notice of corporation's adverse claim to stock, was not bona fide purchaser; (3) evidence established that certain person was not a purchaser of the stock; (4) a corporation's officer's notice of the wrongful transfer was...

Title: New York State Teamsters Conference Pension and Retirement Fund v. Hoh
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Bald allegation that a corporation exerts influence and control over the corporate decisions of its wholly-owned subsidiary is not sufficient to sustain a claim against the parent corporation.
Document Preview: Pension fund brought action against employers which allegedly made illegal contributions to pension fund to recover pension benefits and credits allegedly illegally paid to certain persons. The District Court, Miner, J., held that: (1) parent corporation of one employer was not liable for any illegal contributions made by corporations; (2) evidence demonstrated that contributions were made by employers as conduits for unions for which certain persons were working as union officers; and (3) under collective bargaining agreements, union officers on leave from their employers were employees. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Uchitel Co. v. Telephone Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Alaska.
Headnote: Insufficient evidence was presented to warrant piercing corporate veil with regard to contract between telephone company and proposed buyers of phone system, and therefore individual, who was sole owner, and part owner and chief executive, respectively, of the two buyers, was not individually liable on the subject contract.
Document Preview: Proposed buyers of office phone system and their principal operative appealed from a judgment of the Superior Court, Third Judicial District, J. Justin Ripley, J., in favor of telephone company in breach of contract suit. The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, J., held that: (1) evidence supported findings that an oral contract was entered into between the parties, and that proposed buyers failed to establish statute-of-frauds defense; (2) principal operative was not individually liable on subject contract; (3) trial court's findings were specific enough as to the date of breach to resolve issue of mitigation; (4) trial court should have based its calculations of lost profits on the option price, rather than total lease price of the phone equipment; and (5) remand was appropriate with respect to proposed buyers' entitlement to a credit representing an amount telephone company allegedly recovered from resale of some of the equipment. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Title: New Sheridan Hotel & Bar, Ltd. v. Commercial Leasing Corp., Inc.
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. I.
Headnote: In action brought by telephone system lessee against lessor corporation for rescission of leasing agreement, record did not reveal a sufficiently close relationship between lessor and installer corporation to render lessor, which had purchased the system from installer, responsible for any representations or warranties made by installer to lessee.
Document Preview: Lessee of telephone system brought action against lessor to rescind the lease agreement, and lessor counterclaimed to accelerate payments required under the lease and to recover attorney fees. The District Court, San Miguel County, Jerry Lincoln, J., entered judgment for lessor on both the complaint and counterclaim, and lessee appealed. The Court of Appeals, Coyte, J., held that: (1) lessor was not responsible for any representations or warranties made by installer, from whom it had purchased the system, to lessee; (2) trial court did not err in accelerating payments due under terms of lease when lessee failed to make required payments; and (3) since no objection was timely made, lessee had no basis to complain as to amount of attorney fees awarded to lessor. Affirmed.

Title: Texas Industries, Inc. v. Lucas
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: In action to recover damages for personal injuries allegedly sustained on construction site, evidence was sufficient to support jury finding that parent corporation of manufacturer of beams which fell on plaintiff was manufacturer's alter ego for purposes of liability.
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought action to recover damages for personal injuries allegedly sustained on construction site. The 190th District Court, Harris County, Wyatt H. Heard, J., entered judgment. Appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, James, J., held that: (1) evidence did not support finding that advice of fabricator and erector of steel beams which fell on plaintiff constituted negligence; (2) evidence was sufficient to support jury finding that defendant corporation was alter ego of manufacturer of steel beams; (3) under contract, manufacturer had duty to manufacture beams in manner called for by plans and it breached duty it had since beams in question deviated from plan; (4) evidence was sufficient to support finding of proximate cause; (5) action against employer was precluded; (6) trial court abused its discretion in permitting plaintiff's expert witness to testify over objection; and (7) jury award was proper. Ordered accordingly.

Title: Kwick Set Components, Inc. v. Davidson Industries, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: In view of evidence that both allegedly dominant and subservient corporations had same president and board of directors and that dominant corporation purchased goods through name of defunct subservient corporation and used such goods to perform contracts, combined with apparent scheme of dominant corporation to avoid payment of subservient corporation's debts while benefiting from use of goods causing debt, evidence permitted finding that subservient corporation had become mere instrumentality of dominant corporation and that justice required court to look directly at dominant corporation for payment of injuries and damages caused plaintiff by way of failure to pay debt on open account.
Document Preview: Company brought action against allegedly subservient corporation doing business as allegedly dominant corporation and against such corporations' president for failure to pay debt on open account. The Circuit Court, Russell County, Paul Jack Miller, Jr., J., dismissed corporate president as party defendant and entered judgment against corporations, and dominant corporation appealed. The Supreme Court, Beatty, J., held that: (1) in view of evidence that both allegedly dominant and subservient corporations had same president and board of directors and that dominant corporation purchased goods through name of defunct subservient corporation and used such goods to perform contracts, combined with apparent scheme of dominant corporation to avoid payment of subservient corporation's debts while benefiting from use of goods causing debt, evidence permitted finding that subservient corporation had become mere instrumentality of dominant corporation and that justice required court to look...

Title: Main Bank of Chicago v. Baker
Court: Supreme Court of Illinois.
Headnote: In action on lease, evidence sustained trial court's finding that separate status of lessee's parent corporation could not be disregarded so as to render parent liable on lease.
Document Preview: Corporate obligee sued obligors on a note and obligors counterclaimed against a subsidiary of the obligee and against the obligee itself seeking recovery on the lease with the subsidiary. The Circuit Court, Cook County, Walter J. Kowalski, J., rendered judgments on directed verdicts for the obligee and obligors appealed. The Appellate Court, 88 Ill.App.3d 28, 43 Ill.Dec. 681, 410 N.E.2d 681, affirmed in part and reversed in part. Obligors appealed. The Supreme Court, Underwood, J., held that: (1) parol evidence was inadmissible to establish an oral agreement to make payment on the note contingent on the subsidiary's obligations under the lease; (2) the corporate veil could not be pierced so as to hold obligee liable on the lease; (3) a jury question existed as to the amount due under the lease; and (4) the obligee was entitled to recover from obligors the portion of the attorney fees attributable to recovering on the note itself, but not that portion attributable to the balance...

Title: Amfac Foods, Inc. v. International Systems & Controls Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon.
Headnote: In food processing firm's action against parent and subsidiary corporations for damages for alleged breach of subsidiary's contract to supply and install equipment in connection with construction of potato processing plant, evidence warranted a finding that parent corporation could be held liable on the contracts, which had been made by the subsidiary, on theory that parent acted as subsidiary's alter ego or on theory that subsidiary had become agent of the parent.
Document Preview: Food processing firm brought action against parent and subsidiary corporations for damages for alleged breach of subsidiary's contract to supply and install equipment in connection with construction of potato processing plant. The Circuit Court, Multnomah County, Patrick Dooley, J., entered judgment for firm, and corporations appealed. The Court of Appeals, Thornton, J., held that: (1) in such action in which firm contended that it had standing to bring the action because construction contractor acted as firm's agent in making contract with subsidiary, issue whether there had been agency relationship between general contractor and firm was for jury; (2) evidence warranted finding that parent corporation could be held liable under alter ego theory or under theory that subsidiary was parent's agent; (3) certain instruction was not a comment on probative value of evidence, but, rather, was an instruction that an offer could be accepted by performance; (4) mere allegation, by way of...

Title: Institute of Veterinary Pathology, Inc. v. California Health Laboratories, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: In action brought by veterinary pathology corporation against laboratory and laboratory's parent corporation for compensatory and punitive damages for tortious destruction of plaintiff corporation's business, evidence of interlocking directorates of parent corporation and defendant laboratory was insufficient to warrant piercing of corporate veil such as to render parent liable for alleged actions of defendant laboratory.
Document Preview: Veterinary pathology corporation, which entered into contract with laboratory, brought action against the laboratory and laboratory's parent corporation for compensatory and punitive damages for tortious destruction of its business after laboratory terminated the contract and entered the market on its own. The Superior Court, San Diego County, Joseph A. Kilgarif, J., directed verdict in favor of parent corporation on punitive damage issue, granted parent's motion for judgment notwithstanding verdict on compensatory damage issue, and granted motions by laboratory for new trial unless plaintiff accepted a reduced amount in satisfaction of all verdicts, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeal, Wiener, J., held that: (1) parent's relationship with defendant laboratory, based on either alter ego or agency principles, did not warrant issue of its liability for punitive damages to reach jury, nor was there sufficient evidence to support a verdict in plaintiff's favor...

Title: Selman v. Harvard Medical School
Court: United States District Court, S. D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, in absence of any evidence of common ownership or control or of any suggestion of the existence of an agency agreement and where two corporate entities are truly separate, a valid inference that one corporate entity is the agent of the other for jurisdictional purposes cannot be sustained. CPLR N.Y. 301.
Document Preview: Medical student at Mexican university whose transfer applications to United States medical schools had been rejected brought suit against several United States medical schools, individual employees of those schools and an association of medical colleges. Defendants moved to dismiss the complaint on four grounds and plaintiff cross-moved for an order certifying the suit as a class action. The District Court, Kevin Thomas Duffy, J., held that: (1) the district court did not have personal jurisdiction over the association of medical colleges, an Illinois corporation whose offices were located in the District of Columbia; (2) the district court did not have personal jurisdiction over six individual employees of the University of California; (3) the claims against University of California medical schools were barred by the Eleventh Amendment insofar as they sought monetary damages; (4) there was no diversity jurisdiction with respect to plaintiff's claims against several New York...

Title: Jetty, Inc. v. Hall-McGuff Architects
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: In action to recover for architectural services, evidence was sufficient to hold that subsidiary was a mere tool or business conduit of parent corporation, for purposes of rendering judgment against the parent on contract entered into by the subsidiary.
Document Preview: In suit to recover for architectural services, the District Court, Harris County, W. Ervin James, J., entered judgment in favor of plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, J. Curtiss Brown, C. J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support findings that parties had not agreed on fixed limit on construction cost, that building designed was not larger than specified, and, thus, that architects were entitled to recover for architectural services under the express written contract; (2) legal rate, in reference to prejudgment interest, was 6% rather than 9% as awarded by the trial court; and (3) there was sufficient evidence to hold that subsidiary was a mere tool or business conduit of parent corporation, for purposes of rendering judgment against the parent in connection with contract entered into by the subsidiary. Modified and affirmed.
