Title: Commodity Futures Trading Commission v. Comvest Trading Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: In action brought by Commodity Futures Trading Commission against commodity trading corporation, commodity trading advisor and pool operator corporation, and principals in such corporations wherein violations of Commodity Exchange Act were alleged and wherein appointment of receiver was sought, evidence established that the two corporations should be treated as one corporation for purposes of receivership. Commodity Exchange Act, §§ 1 et seq., 4d(2), 4f(2), 7 U.S.C.A. §§ 1 et seq., 6d(2), 6f(2); 28 U.S.C.A. § 959(b).
Document Preview: Commodity Futures Trading Commission brought action against commodities trading corporation, commodities trading advisor and pool operator corporation and two principals in such corporations for alleged violations of Commodity Exchange Act. On motion by the Commission for appointment of receiver, the District Court, Keeton, J., held that the Commission was not entitled to have receiver appointed where receiver was sought to protect less than $11,000 in assets in hope of serving interests of investors and others who had more than $600,000 at stake, receivership was not shown to be essential to protection against inequitable distribution among customers of the assets or the best means of protecting the customers against such risk, and the Commission advanced no plan for paying expenses and made no showing that the costs of receivership would not outweigh its benefits. Motion denied.

Title: Miller v. Premier Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: In suit arising out of unsuccessful tax shelter investment ventures, district court's findings that separate corporate identities of defendant and a subsidiary of defendant that was not a party to the case should not be disregarded and that, therefore, defendant was not liable for usury in connection with certain feedlot agreement notes given to the subsidiary were not clearly erroneous.
Document Preview: Investors brought suit against various corporate managers, financiers and corporate officers, alleging violations of securities and usury laws and seeking damages for common-law fraud. The principal defendant counterclaimed against each of the plaintiff investors for sums allegedly due on promissory notes and management contracts. The United States District Court for the District of South Carolina, Robert W. Hemphill, J., entered judgment on a verdict for plaintiffs on their common-law fraud claims and against the principal defendant on its counterclaims and the court sitting without a jury on the usury claims found for the plaintiffs on one claim and against plaintiffs on the other. Appeal was taken, and the Court of Appeals, James Dickson Phillips, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) there was sufficient evidence to submit the case to the jury on the theory that material misrepresentations induced the investments; (2) there was sufficient evidence for the jury to find the elements...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Fuller v. Horvath
Court: Court of Special Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: In suit for breach of contract and fraud brought against corporation and officers thereof, alleging that two individual defendants, on behalf of the other defendants, promised to forgive a promissory note of plaintiffs in return for their procuring a buyer for the corporate defendant's subsidiary, the facts were such that a strong inference of fraud was available to a fact finder, and it could follow that neither the corporate veil of the corporate defendant nor that of its subsidiary was available as a matter of law to the individuals who served reciprocally between the two corporations and met simultaneously in regard to the subject matter of the suit; accordingly, plaintiffs produced enough evidence to warrant a factual determination.
Document Preview: Suit for breach of contract and fraud was brought against corporation and officers thereof, alleging that two individual defendants, on behalf of the other defendants, promised to forgive a promissory note of plaintiffs in return for their procuring a buyer for the corporate defendant's subsidiary. The Montgomery County Circuit Court, William Cave, J., directed a verdict for defendants, and plaintiffs appealed. The Court of Special Appeals, Lowe, J., held that the facts were such that a strong inference of fraud was available to a fact finder, and it could follow that neither the corporate veil of the corporate defendant nor that of its subsidiary was available as a matter of law to the individuals who served reciprocally between the two corporations and met simultaneously in regard to the subject matter of the suit; accordingly, plaintiffs produced enough evidence to warrant a factual determination. Reversed and remanded.

Title: Eagle Transport Ltd., Inc. v. O'Connor
Court: United States District Court, S. D. New York.
Headnote: Fact that individual, who was shipping corporation's president and sole stockholder, was also president and a 42% stockholder of second corporation, and fact that two corporations had same address and telephone and telex numbers, did not by themselves establish that shipping corporation was so "dominated" by second corporation as to be alter ego; nor did they alone establish that second corporation was shipping corporation's "virtual representative" or possessed such an "identity of interest" with shipping corporation as to render it the latter's privy and thus liable for shipping corporation's breach of charter party agreement.
Document Preview: Action was brought to hold corporate defendant and individual defendant, who was president, sole director and sole shareholder of shipping corporation, and who was also president and a 42% Stockholder of corporate defendant, liable for shipping corporation's breach of charter party agreement. The District Court, Lasker, J., held that: (1) because individual defendant was a privy of shipping corporation, he was estopped from relitigating determinations made against such corporation in earlier proceedings, i. e., that there was a charter party agreement between plaintiff and corporation, that corporation breached it and that, as result, plaintiff suffered damages of $557,925.15, but fact that individual defendant was privy of such corporation did not suffice to establish that he was personally liable for obligations incurred by corporation, and to establish his personal liability, plaintiff had to also show that such corporation was individual defendant's alter ego,...

Title: Team Central, Inc. v. Teamco, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Iowa.
Headnote: In suit in which franchisee counterclaimed against franchisor and its parent corporation for tortious interference with business, breach of contract, wrongful attachment, trespass and conversion, evidence on issue whether franchisor was a mere sham for parent corporation without real independent existence, and with such arrangement used to do severe harm to franchisee through tortious conduct, so as to permit corporate veil of parent corporation to be pierced, was sufficient for jury.
Document Preview: Franchisor brought suit on open account to recover for electronic equipment furnished and services rendered to franchisee. Franchisee counterclaimed against franchisor and its parent corporation for tortious interference with business, breach of contract, wrongful attachment, trespass and conversion. The Polk District Court, Dale S. Missildine and Leo Oxberger, JJ., denied claim on open account and entered judgments in favor of franchisee on counterclaims, and franchisor and parent corporation appealed. The Supreme Court, LeGrand, J., held that: (1) evidence did not, as matter of law, establish the amount due from franchisee, and, thus, issue whether franchisor could recover on open account was for jury; (2) permitting certified public accountant to testify concerning value of franchisee's business was not error; (3) evidence on issue whether franchisor maliciously and deliberately engaged in course of conduct designed to destroy franchisee's business was sufficient for jury; (4)...

Title: Jones v. White Motor Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Erie County.
Headnote: Evidence did not establish that subsidiary corporation which manufactured allegedly defective hauling vehicle had become a mere instrumentality of its parent corporation; thus, parent corporation was properly dismissed as defendant in products liability action.
Document Preview: Wrongful death action was brought against manufacturer of a large hauling vehicle designed for use in quarries, mines and construction sites, its parent corporation and the operator of the vehicle which caused decedent's fatal injuries. The Court of Common Pleas, Erie County, rendered judgment in favor of defendants, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, Erie County, Potter, P. J., held that: (1) new trial was necessitated for reason that certain jury instructions were not tailored to particular case under consideration and were read in a disjointed and confusing manner; (2) trial court's instruction with regard to contributory negligence was not erroneous; however, interrogatory submitted to jury regarding decedent's contributory negligence was erroneous in that it assumed a fact which was for jury; and (3) parent corporation was properly dismissed as a defendant. Affirmed in part; reversed in part. Clifford F. Brown, J., filed concurring opinion in which Connors, J., joined.

Title: Rauch Industries, Inc. v. Poloron Products of Mississippi, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: Evidence in action for breach of contract requiring royalty payments by licensee was not sufficient to prove or intimate that subsidiary of licensee was created for purpose of profiting from license agreement while licensee evaded burden of such agreement.
Document Preview: Licensor filed bill of complaint praying for injunctive relief and for accounting against licensee and subsidiary of licensee. Suit against licensee was dismissed for lack of service of process and the Chancery Court, Panola County, Kermit R. Cofer, Chancellor, found that license agreement was between licensor and licensee alone, that there was no proof that subsidiary of licensee had anything to do with contract or activities and benefits thereunder, and that no reason was shown why relief had not been sought against licensee by proper suit, and licensor appealed. The Supreme Court adopted the opinion of Billy G. Bridges, C., that: (1) contract was exclusive agreement between licensor and licensee, and subsidiary of licensee was not party to such agreement, and (2) there was no proof or intimation that subsidiary of licensee was created for purpose of profiting from contract while licensee evaded burden of contract. Affirmed.

Title: Mortgage and Trust, Inc. v. Bonner & Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi.
Headnote: Evidence that two corporations had overlapping officers and directors and that their offices were in same building did not invoke "alter ego" theory so as to permit disregard of corporate entities and result in priority of mechanic's lien over deed of trust held by corporation, particularly where resulting fraud or injustice was not raised by pleadings, by evidence, or by trial court's findings.
Document Preview: Contractor brought suit against a number of defendants to establish and foreclose a constitutional and a statutory mechanic's and materialman's lien. The 156th District Court, San Patricio County, Rachel Littlejohn, J., entered joint and several judgment against deed of trust lienholder and purchaser of land at foreclosure sale for outstanding amount found to be due plaintiff under its construction contract, and entered judgment foreclosing plaintiff's mechanic's and materialman's lien on a portion of land secured under deed of trust and defendants perfected appeal. The Court of Civil Appeals, Nye, C. J., held that: (1) evidence that two corporations had overlapping officers and directors and that their offices were in same building did not invoke alter ego theory so as to permit disregard of corporate entities and result in priority of mechanic's lien over deed of trust held by defendant corporation; (2) where plaintiff contractor's mechanic's and materialman's...

Title: Dixon v. Process Corp.
Court: Court of Special Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: In action to have court decree that property and assets of subsidiary were those of parent corporation so that judgment lien against parent would be collectible from subsidiary, evidence supported finding that there was no fraud and no paramount equity such as would justify disregard of corporate identities.
Document Preview: Action was brought to obtain decree that properties and assets of subsidiary were those of parent so that judgment lien against parent would be collectible from the subsidiary. The Circuit Court, Prince George's County, William B. Bowie, J., entered judgment adverse to plaintiffs and they appealed. The Court of Special Appeals, Gilbert, C. J., held that: (1) evidence supported finding that there was no fraud and no paramount equity such as would justify disregard of corporate identities, and (2) plaintiffs seeking disregard of corporate identities on basis of fraud was properly required to demonstrate by clear and satisfactory proof that there was fraud, rather than being allowed to show fraud by preponderance of evidence. Affirmed.

Title: Urbanational Developers, Inc. v. Shamrock Engineering, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana, Third District.
Headnote: In action to recover balance due under construction contract, evidence that general contractor was so organized and controlled as to make it a mere instrumentality of its parent corporation supported theory of recovery against such parent corporation, and therefore, successor judge, on motion to correct errors, did not err in implicitly rescinding prior order denying subcontractor's motion to amend complaint to conform to evidence and entering judgment against general contractor's parent corporation.
Document Preview: Subcontractor brought action against general contractor, surety and others to recover balance due under contract and to foreclose its mechanic's lien. The Superior Court, Lake County, David T. Ready, Special Judge, entered judgment for subcontractor, and following appointment of successor judge, parties' motions to correct errors were granted in part, and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Hoffman, J., held that: (1) successor judge abused his discretion in attempting to resolve question as to whether president of general contractor agreed to compensate subcontractor for additional grading, since such question required for its resolution a determination of weight and credibility of evidence; (2) successor judge did not abuse his discretion in awarding subcontractor compensation for extra excavation necessary to reach required compaction of soil, since contract expressly authorized additional compensation under such circumstances; (3) successor judge abused his discretion...

Title: Bendix Home Systems, Inc. v. Hurston Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Although fact that bank which had "floor planned" corporate purchaser's inventory of mobile homes extended credit to purchaser on basis of its parent corporation's president's individual guarantee may have been some indication that line between president as individual and corporate subsidiary purchaser was somewhat fuzzy, it was no indication that lines between corporations were not properly maintained.
Document Preview: Action was brought to recover from a bankrupt corporate buyer money owed from sale by plaintiff of four custom built mobile homes. After refusing plaintiff's request to set aside the separate corporate identities of the defendant, its parent corporation and another subsidiary which had counterclaimed for warranty, service and repair operations on mobile homes, the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida, Charles R. Scott, J., entered judgment for plaintiff on the principal claim and against the plaintiff on the counterclaim, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals held that: (1) under Florida law, the separate identities of two or more corporations will be disregarded only on a showing that one corporation is the mere instrumentality of the other and that the corporation is a device or sham to mislead creditors or exists for fraudulent purposes, and (2) where the plaintiff failed to show that the parent corporation exercised an...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Bendix Home Systems, Inc. v. Hurston Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Where nothing in record showed that seller of custom built mobile homes was misled concerning financing and corporate structure of purchasing corporation and its parent and another subsidiary, and where there was no evidence that parent exercised impermissible degree of control over subsidiaries, trial court, in suit to recover money owed from sale of mobile homes to bankrupt subsidiary, properly refused to disregard separate corporate entities and aggregate assets of three companies.
Document Preview: Action was brought to recover from a bankrupt corporate buyer money owed from sale by plaintiff of four custom built mobile homes. After refusing plaintiff's request to set aside the separate corporate identities of the defendant, its parent corporation and another subsidiary which had counterclaimed for warranty, service and repair operations on mobile homes, the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida, Charles R. Scott, J., entered judgment for plaintiff on the principal claim and against the plaintiff on the counterclaim, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals held that: (1) under Florida law, the separate identities of two or more corporations will be disregarded only on a showing that one corporation is the mere instrumentality of the other and that the corporation is a device or sham to mislead creditors or exists for fraudulent purposes, and (2) where the plaintiff failed to show that the parent corporation exercised an...

Title: Kellyguard Sec. Services, Inc. v. Church
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: Insufficient evidence was presented to pierce corporate veil and group four corporate defendants together as joint defendants.
Document Preview: In an action arising out of a fight in a shopping center poolroom, the Jefferson Circuit Court, Raymond C. Stephenson, J., rendered judgment on verdict apportioning liability between three defendants and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Howard, J., held that: (1) plaintiff was not contributorily negligent; (2) instruction was not improper as requiring apportionment; but (3) instruction on guard company's liability was erroneous as assuming disputed facts, and (4) there was insufficient evidence to pierce corporate veil. Reversed and remanded.

Title: Farkar Co. v. R. A. Hanson DISC., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S. D. New York.
Headnote: Where wholly owned subsidiary which signed agreement to sell excavating equipment was alter ego of parent corporation, subsidiary's officers and directors were identical to those of parent, subsidiary had no employees, parent's personnel performed all of subsidiary's functions, and subsidiary had no inventory, buyer under purchase agreement made prima facie showing that, under Washington law, identities of parent and subsidiary were so confused and intermingled as to result in probable fraud upon third persons, and therefore, parent would be ordered to appear at arbitration proceedings arising out of dispute under purchase agreement, notwithstanding fact that parent had not signed purchase agreement.
Document Preview: Buyer of excavation equipment filed petition to compel arbitration of dispute arising under contract for sale of excavation equipment, and sellers moved to dismiss. The District Court, Lasker, J., held that: (1) provision in purchase agreement to the effect that sellers would in no event be liable for consequential damages did not remove buyer's claim for consequential damages from subject matter jurisdiction of arbitrators; (2) district court would not direct arbitrators to make specific findings concerning clause in purchase agreement to the effect that sellers would in no event be liable for consequential damages, and (3) where wholly owned subsidiary which signed agreement to sell excavating equipment was alter ego of parent corporation, subsidiary's officers and directors were identical to those of parent, subsidiary had no employees, parent's personnel performed all of subsidiary's functions, and subsidiary had no inventory, buyer under purchase...

Title: Coastal States Trading, Inc. v. Zenith Nav. S. A.
Court: United States District Court, S. D. New York.
Headnote: In suit brought by consignee corporation seeking to recover from vessel owner value of cargo of oil lost when vessel vanished, evidence failed to establish that subcharterer corporation, which, together with consignee, was subsidiary of same parent corporation, was so controlled or affected by consignee corporation as to justify application of "instrumentality rule," so as to bind consignee by arbitration clause contained in voyage charter executed between subcharterer and vessel owner.
Document Preview: Delaware consignee brought diversity action against Panamanian vessel owner to recover value of cargo of oil lost when vessel disappeared at sea. The District Court, Motley, J., held that: (1) although the vessel owner was not a signatory to a charter party containing an arbitration clause executed between the subcharterer of the vessel and the consignee, the charter party was incorporated by reference into the bill of lading and the arbitration clause could be enforced against the consignee by the vessel owner, but (2) under the New York attachment statute, the vessel owner was a citizen of the United States, even though it maintained its principal place of business in New York, and its assets in the state could be attached. Action stayed pending completion of arbitration.

Title: Coastal States Trading, Inc. v. Zenith Nav. S. A.
Court: United States District Court, S. D. New York.
Headnote: In subsidiary corporation consignee's suit to recover from vessel owner value of cargo of oil lost when vessel vanished, evidence failed to establish that consignee's parent corporation exercised such pervasive, direct, and complete dominion over consignee as to justify application of "instrumentality rule" so as to bind consignee, which was not signatory, to arbitration clause in time charter agreement entered into by vessel owner and parent corporation.
Document Preview: Delaware consignee brought diversity action against Panamanian vessel owner to recover value of cargo of oil lost when vessel disappeared at sea. The District Court, Motley, J., held that: (1) although the vessel owner was not a signatory to a charter party containing an arbitration clause executed between the subcharterer of the vessel and the consignee, the charter party was incorporated by reference into the bill of lading and the arbitration clause could be enforced against the consignee by the vessel owner, but (2) under the New York attachment statute, the vessel owner was a citizen of the United States, even though it maintained its principal place of business in New York, and its assets in the state could be attached. Action stayed pending completion of arbitration.

Title: In re County Green Ltd. Partnership
Court: United States District Court, W. D. Virginia, Charlottesville Division.
Headnote: Bankruptcy court's findings that development corporation, the general contractor for corporate debtor's apartment construction project, was not the "alter ego" of the debtor and that the claimed mechanic's lienors did not furnish labor and materials to the owner were clearly erroneous, since an examination of the manner in which the affairs of the development corporation were conducted made it apparent that it had no separate existence of its own and was in all respects a mere fiction and the "alter ego" of the debtor; e. g., its policies were not directed to its own interests but to those of the debtor and the debtor's general partners, it was undercapitalized, and it failed to keep reliable records. Code Va.1950, § 43-1.
Document Preview: On appeal of mechanic's lienors from a judgment of the bankruptcy court holding invalid the liens on certain property owned by the bankrupt debtor, the District Court, Turk, Chief Judge, held that the bankruptcy court's findings that development corporation, the general contractor for debtor's apartment construction project, was not the alter ego of the debtor and that the claimed mechanic's lienors did not furnish labor and materials to the owner were clearly erroneous, since an examination of the manner in which the affairs of the development corporation were conducted made it apparent that it had no separate existence of its own and was in all respects a mere fiction and the alter ego of the debtor; e. g., its policies were not directed to its own interests but to those of the debtor and the debtor's general partners, it was undercapitalized, and it failed to keep reliable records. Reversed and remanded.

Title: Duplan Corp. v. Deering Milliken, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Spartanburg Division.
Headnote: Evidence supported contention that corporate subsidy acted as corporate parent's agent or alter ego with reference to settlement of patent litigation which was found to be violative of antitrust laws, and that corporate parent should therefore also be held liable for antitrust violation. Sherman Anti-Trust Act, §§ 1, 2, 15 U.S.C.A. §§ 1, 2.
Document Preview: In consolidated suits for recovery of patent royalties alleged to be due from patent sublicensees on patents involving textile machinery, the District Court, Dupree, J., held inter alia, that the defendants had been guilty of horizontal, but not vertical, antitrust conspiracy. Order accordingly.

Title: Centurian Corp. v. Fiberchem, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Utah.
Headnote: In action by corporation for sums advanced under contract to purchase materials from defendant which applied money to account of corporation of similar name which defendant claimed to be alter ego of plaintiff, since it had same original incorporators and shareholders as plaintiff, evidence supported trial court's rejection of defense of alter ego.
Document Preview: Action was brought against corporate seller for return of sum advanced by corporate buyer under contract to purchase materials to be used in manufacture of boats. The Third District Court, Salt Lake County, Stewart M. Hanson, Sr., J., entered judgment in favor of buyer and seller appealed. The Supreme Court, Crockett, J., held that evidence supported order rejecting defense of alter ego asserted to justify seller's refusal to deliver materials or return buyer's advance payment on theory that the money could properly be applied to debt previously owed to seller by another corporation with similar name and same original incorporators and shareholders as buyer. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Matter of Bowen Transports, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence that Delaware corporation was owned by a parent corporation which was purchasing an Illinois corporation and the officers and directors of all three corporations were identical was insufficient to permit piercing of corporate veil to permit creditor of the Delaware corporation to recover from the Illinois corporation where the corporations acted as separate and independent entities, where separate corporate records were maintained, where financial transactions between the corporations were recorded in the respective corporate ledgers, and where proceeds of loans to Delaware corporation which were an issue were used by the Delaware corporation and not for the benefit of the Illinois corporation.
Document Preview: Creditor appealed from order of the District Court for the Eastern District of Illinois, James L. Foreman, J., which sustained objection of debtor to claim filed by the creditor. The Court of Appeals, Harlington Wood, Jr., Circuit Judge, held that state court proceedings had not resulted in a lien in favor of the creditor on certain amounts being paid to the debtor; that the debtor was not the maker of eight notes which were basis for the judgment against a related corporation; that there was no basis for application of doctrine of piercing the corporate veil so as to permit creditor to recover from debtor amounts which were owed to it from related corporation which had also been involved in bankruptcy proceedings. Affirmed.

Title: DeBoer Const., Inc. v. Reliance Ins. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Where only evidence that general contractor had suffered loss in connection with fraudulently issued construction contract surety bond as result of delay was evidence that its sister corporation had to pay extra $108,000 in interest on interim construction loan, and there was no evidence that general contractor was charged in any way for delay damages, separate identities of wholly owned subsidiary corporations would not be disregarded and thus general contractor could not recover delay damages in its action against independent insurance agency and commercial surety.
Document Preview: Action was brought by general contractor against independent insurance agency and commercial surety after they denied liability on construction contract surety bond fraudulently issued by their agent. The United States District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma, Luther L. Bohanon, J., entered judgment for contractor, awarded contractor one dollar punitive damages against commercial surety, and gave surety judgment for indemnity from insurance agency, and appeals were taken. The Court of Appeals, Hill, Circuit Judge, held that insurance agency and surety were not liable on contract made by agent or for his fraud; that contractor was guilty of contributory negligence in failing to read agent's power of attorney and discover his lack of authority; that surety was not estopped from denying liability; that surety was bound on contract to extent its agent had authority under power of attorney; and that as matter of contract, agent bound only surety and not insurance...

Title: Burger Man, Inc. v. Jordan Paper Products, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana, First District.
Headnote: Evidence showing, inter alia, that parent company and subsidiary shared same officers and directors, that parent company had complete dominion over affairs of subsidiary and that director and president of parent company made assurances that parent company would stand behind subsidiary's obligations under oral sales contract justified the piercing of parent company's corporate veil and the charging of it with debts incurred by subsidiary under oral contract.
Document Preview: Defendants appealed from a judgment of the Circuit Court, Delaware County, Alva Cox, P.J., awarding $22,089.48 plus costs to plaintiff in action to recover under oral contract for purchase of special printed merchandise. The Court of Appeals, Lowdermilk, J., held that trial court did not violate best evidence rule by admitting into evidence carbon copies of unpaid invoices; that evidence supported judgments against subsidiary corporation which accepted and received special printed merchandise and its parent company which assured plaintiff, seller of merchandise, that it would guarantee subsidiary's obligations; that service of process upon corporate officer was proper; that contract fell within exceptions to statute of frauds; and that defendants' failure to utilize proper procedure to correct any error which existed because of court's delay in ruling on motion for more definite statement constituted waiver of any error arising because of delay. Affirmed.

Title: Avco Delta Corp. Canada Ltd. v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence showing, inter alia, that parent company and its two subsidiaries had same officers, shareholders and corporate offices, that paid-in capital of subsidiaries was grossly inadequate, that companies failed to maintain their respective identities when dealing with third parties and to maintain customary formalities when dealing with each other and that companies' only business was with each other established that companies were alter egos so that assets of subsidiary and parent were available to satisfy tax liability of other subsidiary.
Document Preview: Proceeding was brought to determine ownership of funds recovered from sale of mortgaged equipment in excess of amount paid mortgagee. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Illinois, Northern Division, Robert D. Morgan, Chief Judge, entered a judgment, and the Court of Appeals, 484 F.2d 692, reversed and remanded. On remand, the District Court, Robert D. Morgan, J., entered a judgment that such funds belonged to the Government, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, Pell, Circuit Judge, held that evidence showing, inter alia, that parent company and its two subsidiaries had same officers, shareholders and corporate offices, that paid-in capital of subsidiaries was grossly inadequate, that companies failed to maintain customary formalities when dealing with each other and that companies' only business was with each other established that companies were alter egos so that assets of subsidiary and parent were available to satisfy tax liability of other...

Title: Clayton Brokerage Co. of St. Louis, Inc. v. Teleswitcher Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In action under Missouri law by brokerage company against computer company alleging that brokerage company was induced to enter into two contracts and lease regarding communication system for its commodity exchange brokerage house as result of misrepresentations made by computer company and its corporate alter egos, evidence established that defendants were merely conduits for each other's operations and were in fact alter egos of each other and was sufficient to pierce corporate veil and impose liability upon all defendants.
Document Preview: Brokerage company brought action against computer corporation alleging that it was induced to enter into two contracts and a lease regarding a communication system for its commodity brokerage house as a result of misrepresentations made by the computer company. The District Court, Wangelin, J., held that under Missouri law, where the computer company and its corporate alter egos were aware of the impossibility of their performing the various contracted-for services to the brokerage company at the time the promises were made, they were liable for fraud and for breach of contract and the brokerage company was entitled to rescission of leases between the parties and to damages. Judgment for plaintiffs.

Title: Omaha Pollution Control Corp. v. Carver-Greenfield Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Nebraska.
Headnote: Evidence that stock control of one corporation was not in the hands of two persons who had stock control of second corporation, that first corporation dominated its own finances and that personnel of the first corporation, rather than personnel of the second corporation, controlled project involving construction and sale of sewage plant demonstrated that the first corporation was not a mere alter ego of the second corporation so that corporate veil would not be pierced to permit purchasers of sewage treatment plant to hold the second corporation liable for first corporation's breach of warranties with respect to construction and sale of the plant.
Document Preview: City and its pollution control corporation brought action against contractor seller of sewage treatment plant which was designed to remove certain packinghouse waste from the city sewer system so as to permit the sewage to be handled by city's already extant sewage treatment plant and which was also designed to convert the materials removed from the system into marketable products and against a related corporation for breach of warranties with respect to the construction and sale of the treatment plant. The District Court, Van Sickle, J., held that the contractor seller impliedly warranted the merchantability and fitness for particular purpose of the plant; that the warranties were breached; that the city could recover for the breaches as a third-party beneficiary of the implied warranties; that the contractor seller was entitled to recover on its counterclaim for amounts not paid for work pursuant to change orders and was also entitled to recover insurance loss proceeds resulting...

Title: Rymal v. Ulbeco, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District, Second Division.
Headnote: In action against two German corporations wherein service of process was made on United States corporation allegedly acting as agent for German corporations one of which was great-grandparent corporation of United States corporation, evidence did not establish that corporations were in fact inseparable warranting disregard by court of corporate entities and holding service of process on one corporation effective as to others; thus, German corporations' motions to quash service of process on ground that United States corporation was not their agent were properly granted. S.H.A. ch. 110, §§ 13.3, 16(1).
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought action for injuries caused by packeting machine against German corporation which allegedly designed, manufactured and sold machine, and its alleged United States representative, and later named second German corporation as additional defendant. The Circuit Court, DuPage County, Gordon Moffett, J., granted motions of both German corporations to quash service of process on ground they were improperly served since neither corporation did business in United States or had registered agent in United States and granted motion of Illinois corporation for summary judgment. The Appellate Court, Thomas J. Moran, J., held that plaintiff could not recover against Illinois corporation where plaintiff failed to deny allegations in corporation's answer that it had no connection whatsoever with packeting machine, that evidence did not establish that United States corporation and German corporations were in fact inseparable and thus German corporations' motions to quash service...

Title: Schlecht v. Equitable Builders, Inc., A. E. C. G.
Court: Supreme Court of Oregon, En Banc.
Headnote: In absence of any evidence that control exercised by parent corporation over its wholly owned subsidiary was used to perpetrate a fraud on judgment creditors of subsidiary, in view of fact that, though parent might have caused subsidiary to guaranty certain loans, there was no evidence that the rights of creditors were jeopardized thereby, and in light of fact that there was no evidence that parent caused subsidiary to transfer to parent any funds or other assets, subsidiary's corporate veil would not be pierced for purpose of requiring parent to pay judgments against subsidiary.
Document Preview: Judgment creditors of wholly owned subsidiary brought action to require parent corporation to pay those judgments. The Circuit Court, Washington County, Hollie Pihl, J., entered judgment from which plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, McAllister, J., held that in absence of any evidence that control exercised by parent corporation over its wholly owned subsidiary was used to perpetrate a fraud on judgment creditors of subsidiary, in view of fact that, though parent might have caused subsidiary to guaranty certain loans, there was no evidence that the rights of creditors were jeopardized thereby, and in light of fact that there was no evidence that parent caused subsidiary to transfer to parent any funds or other assets, subsidiary's corporate veil would not be pierced for purpose of requiring parent to pay judgments against subsidiary. Affirmed.

Title: Aamco Automatic Transmissions, Inc. v. Tayloe
Court: United States District Court, E. D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Evidence showing, inter alia, that certain initial incorporating and operational expenses of corporation were paid for by another corporation which operated franchised automobile transmission repair shop and which was founded by individual who submitted to personal jurisdiction of court in antitrust action and that corporation subsequently took over operation of transmission repair shop did not prove that corporation was a "sham" corporation existing only as alter ego of individual so that his submission to court's jurisdiction could be imputed to corporation.
Document Preview: Franchisor's action for breach of franchise agreement in which counterclaim was filed alleging violation of antitrust laws was consolidated with antitrust action against franchisor. On motion for determination of a class, the District Court, Van Artsdalen, J., held that former franchisees whose interest conflicted with present franchisees could not adequately represent class consisting of both former and present franchisees but could represent class of former franchisees; and that action, which involved common question of law as to whether franchise agreements requiring franchisees to purchase initial equipment and repair parts from franchisor constituted illegal tying arrangements, should proceed as class action. The court also granted motion to dismiss certain defendants in franchisor's action since it had no jurisdiction over them, denied franchisor's motion to dismiss counterclaim which stated cause of action against franchisor for breach of contract and denied franchisor's...

Title: In re Kirk Kabinets, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M. D. Georgia, Albany Division.
Headnote: Bankruptcy court's amendment to bankrupt's caption to read " * * * Inc. d/b/a * * *, Inc." was of no evidentiary value in determining whether corporations were alter egos for purpose of bankruptcy turnover order.
Document Preview: Sole shareholder and attorney of bankrupt appealed a turnover order of the bankruptcy judge. The District Court, Owens, J., held that where no objection was raised by appellants to the bankruptcy court's exercise of summary jurisdiction, they could not raise the contention on appeal; that the evidence was sufficient to support the bankruptcy court's findings that the attorney was counsel for the bankrupt, that the corporation in whose account the funds were held was merely the alter ego of the bankrupt and that the funds were in appellants' possession. Affirmed.

Title: Chengelis v. Cenco Instruments Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Parent corporation could not be held liable for breach of royalty payment contract entered into by plaintiff with subsidiary corporation where plaintiff entered into the contract which bound only the subsidiary notwithstanding knowledge of interrelation of the two corporations, and where there was no proof that corporate form of subsidiary was used by parent corporation to perpetrate a fraud or promote an injustice akin to fraud.
Document Preview: Action against a parent corporation for breach of a royalty contract entered into by plaintiff with a subsidiary corporation. The United States District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania, Weber, J., held that where parties deal at arm's length, represented by counsel, corporate veil cannot be removed merely to give a litigant an advantage at law; the court also held that parent corporation could not be held liable for breach of royalty payment contract entered into by plaintiff with subsidiary corporation where plaintiff entered into the contract which bound only the subsidiary notwithstanding knowledge of interrelation of the two corporations, and where there was no proof that corporate form of subsidiary was used by parent corporation to perpetrate a fraud or promote an injustice akin to fraud. Judgments for defendant in accordance with opinion.

Title: Ampex Corp. v. Office Electronics, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Evidence, in action on account to recover value of magnetic tapes sold to two corporations, one of which was a new corporation formed by the other as its marketing arm, was sufficient to justify application of doctrine of piercing corporate veil against the parent corporation several of whose officers served as directors and officers of the marketing corporation.
Document Preview: Plaintiff corporation brought suit against electronics corporation and marketing corporation created by the electronics corporation to recover value of magnetic tapes sold by plaintiff to both defendants. The Circuit Court, Cook County, Wilbert F. Crowley, J., entered judgment on the verdict in favor of the plaintiff and against both defendants. The electronics corporation appealed. The Appellate Court, Dieringer, J., held that where two out of three directors of the marketing corporation were officers of the electronics corporation, the electronics corporation owned 51% Of the stock in the marketing corporation, the electronics corporation capitalized the marketing corporation, and received merchandise, along with monthly statements and invoices from the plaintiff, principle of piercing the corporate veil was properly invoked, and that court properly instructed the jury and properly refused to submit special interrogatories which did not relate to an ultimate issue of fact....

Title: Whatley v. Crown Sash & Door, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Eastland.
Headnote: In action on sworn account against two corporations and their officer to recover for materials purchased by corporations, there was no evidence of probative force that the two corporations were the alter egos of officer whom supplier sought to hold personally liable.
Document Preview: A material supplier brought action against corporate purchasers and officer thereof who had guaranteed corporate debts. The District Court, Dallas County, Dee Brown Walker, J., entered a judgment against the corporations and the officer and the officer appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Walter, J., held that there was evidence to support finding that officer's letter to supplier regarding procedure for future purchases did not revoke his guaranty but that since guaranty did not mention attorney's fees it was not proper to award attorney fees against officer. Judgment reformed and, as reformed, affirmed.

Title: Ace Supply, Inc. v. Rocky-Mountain Machinery Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho.
Headnote: In light of evidence which established, inter alia, an almost complete interlocking directorate and ownership of two corporations and dealings by surviving corporation with assets of liquidated corporation as its own, surviving corporation was estopped from establishing itself as an innocent and defrauded creditor of the liquidated corporation by reason of sale of tractor to creditor of liquidated corporation.
Document Preview: Action against equipment dealer for conversion of tractor. The Seventh Judicial District Court, Bingham County, Arnold T. Beebe, J., entered judgment in favor of plaintiff, and dealer appealed. The Supreme Court, Shepard, C. J., held that evidence was sufficient to sustain trial court's finding that general manager of subsequently liquidated corporation had at least apparent authority to sell tractor to plaintiff; that evidence was sufficient to sustain trial court's finding that transaction between general manager and plaintiff constituted a completed and present sale of subject tractor; that where defendant dealer dealt with assets of liquidated corporation as its own, defendant dealer was estopped from establishing itself as a defrauded creditor of liquidated corporation by reason of sale of tractor to plaintiff; and that trial court properly permitted plaintiff to amend its prayer for relief to conform to the proof. Affirmed.

Title: Spinoza, Inc. v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Where Delaware corporation transferred all its outstanding shares to publicly held corporation in exchange for stock of such corporation and then transferred stock in publicly held corporation to shareholders of Texas corporation and merged Texas corporation into Delaware corporation, Texas corporation's closing of fiscal year, adoption of different method of accounting for long-term contracts, and status as subsidiary of publicly traded corporation rather than private corporation sustained conclusion that Delaware corporation was not the alter ego of Texas corporation and was not entitled to offset losses against profits of Texas corporation. 26 U.S.C.A. (I.R.C.1954) § 368(a)(1), (1)(F).
Document Preview: Action seeking refund of income taxes. The District Court, James Lawrence King, J., sitting by designation, held that transaction was a B-A reorganization and taxpayer was not entitled to refund of taxes paid by corporation which was merged into it. Judgment accordingly.

Title: Storm v. Marsischke
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana, Second District.
Headnote: Where the only evidence that lumber company was partner or joint venturer with construction company in the building of two apartment buildings was that the president of the lumber company was a director of the construction company and there was no evidence of an arrangement or history of prior practice which would lead to the conclusion that the lumber company, either itself or through its agent, referred parties to construction company under representation that the two work together, trial court properly refused to disregard the corporate entity and find existence of a joint venture.
Document Preview: Action by landowners against construction company and its owners and against lumber company for breach of construction contract. The Superior Court, Marion County, Room 7, Charles W. Applegate, J., sustained lumber company's motion for dismissal and entered judgment for the lumber company. The plaintiffs appealed. The Court of Appeals held that plaintiffs did not make out prima facie case of apparent authority on part of employee of lumber company to bind the lumber company, that there was no prima facie case of inherent agency power on part of the employee and that neither the statements of employee nor identity of officers of construction company and lumber company were sufficient to find the existence of a joint venture. Affirmed.

Title: U.S. v. Wood
Court: United States Customs Court, Third Division, Appellate Term.
Headnote: Where every aspect of the entire business of Fargo subsidiary of Canadian manufacturer of engine heaters was fully controlled and supervised by manufacturer, factors that subsidiary had its own room in Fargo warehouse, had its own account at Fargo bank, and issued its own profit and loss statements did not warrant conclusion that subsidiary was a "buyer" from rather than an agent or alter ego of manufacturer, and even if subsidiary was a "purchaser," invoice prices did not fairly reflect market value since manufacturer's price for one model to warehouse distributors and jobbers in Canada was more than double its price to the subsidiary. Tariff Act of 1930, § 402(b), (f)(1)(B) as amended 19 U.S.C.A. § 1401a(b), (f)(1)(B).
Document Preview: Appeals were brought to contest appraised value of engine heaters and car warmers manufactured in Canada. The Customs Court, Ford, J., 340 F.Supp. 1398, entered judgment holding that invoice prices of merchandise exported from Canadian manufacturer to its wholly owned American subsidiary fairly reflected market value and Government appealed. The Customs Court, Appellate Division, Maletz, J., held that where every aspect of the entire business of American subsidiary was controlled and supervised by Canadian manufacturer and there was a complete lack of independence on part of subsidiary, factors that subsidiary had its own room in Fargo warehouse, had its own account at Fargo bank, had sales representatives in the United States to whom it was liable for commissions, purchased merchandise from suppliers in the United States and issued its own profit and loss statement did not warrant conclusion that subsidiary was a buyer from rather than an agent or alter ego of manufacturer. The...

Title: Jackson v. General Elec. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Alaska.
Headnote: Evidence sustained trial court's finding that corporate manufacturer of appliance purchased by plaintiff and financed through finance company which was wholly owned subsidiary of manufacturer was not liable for defamatory collection letter sent by finance company and did not establish that the finance company was a mere instrumentality of the corporate manufacturer.
Document Preview: Action against manufacturer of electical appliance by purchaser who claimed he was damaged by defamatory letter sent by finance company which was wholly owned subsidiary of manufacturer and through which purchaser financed purchase. The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Eben H. Lewis, J., found for manufacturer and purchaser appealed. The Supreme Court, Fitzgerald, J., held that evidence sustained trial court's finding that manufacturer was not liable for actions of subsidiary. Affirmed. Erwin, J., did not participate.

Title: Rudy v. Metropolitan Commuters Transp. Authority
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Plaintiffs seeking to recover for injuries from parent corporation for alleged negligence of subsidiary failed to show that relationship between parent and subsidiary was such that separate corporate status of the subsidiary could properly be disregarded.
Document Preview: Action to recover for injuries from parent corporation for alleged negligence of subsidiary. The Supreme Court, Nassau County, granted defendant's motion for summary judgment dismissing complaint and plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that plaintiffs failed to show that relationship of parent and subsidiary was such that separate corporate status of subsidiary could properly be disregarded. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Allright Texas, Inc. v. Simons
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence that bookkeeping for five companies, all of which had similar names and all of which operated parking lots, was handled through one of the companies and that employees of all companies were paid by one of two of the companies supported court's going beyond corporate form and determining as a matter of law that the corporations constituted a single business and entering judgment, for failure to redeliver automobile parked on its lot, against two of the companies.
Document Preview: Automobile owner brought action against owner of parking lot for losses suffered when automobile and its contents were stolen from parking lot. The District Court, Harris County, Edward D. Coulson, J., entered judgment on the verdict in favor of automobile owner and parking lot owner appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Evans, J., held that evidence supported finding that automobile was stolen from lot, that parking lot employees were negligent, that testimony justified court in looking beyond corporate form and determining, as a matter of law, that corporations constituted a single business enterprise, and that automobile owner was entitled to recover for losses suffered by having to return by air to his hometown and having to come back to city where car was stolen to recover car after its was found, but was not entitled to recover for loss of earnings suffered as result of theft of car and its contents. Affirmed as modified upon filing of remittitur.

Title: Frito-Lay, Inc. v. Procter & Gamble Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Fact that four directors of nonresident parent corporation sat on five-man board of directors of wholly owned subsidiary corporation, which conducted business within forum state, and that 15 officers of parent corporation comprised the corporate officers of the subsidiary and statements which appeared in annual report of parent corporation and its subsidiaries and in preliminary prospectus filed with Securities and Exchange Commission failed to establish that subsidiary corporation was the alter ego of parent corporation and that parent corporation could be subjected to personal jurisdiction in the forum state by service of process upon subsidiary. Vernon's Ann.Tex.Civ.St. art. 2031b.
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought action against parent and subsidiary corporations for declaratory judgment of the invalidity and unenforceability of a patent issued to the parent corporation. The defendants moved for dismissal. The District Court, Mahon, J., held that absent showing that nonresident parent corporation, which was not licensed to do business in Texas and which did not maintain either a regular place of business or a registered agent for service of process in Texas, exercised actual control of the internal affairs of subsidiary corporation, which was licensed to do business and was doing business in Texas, subsidiary was not the alter ego of parent and service upon the wholly owned subsidiary was not effective as service upon parent and did not subject parent to in personam jurisdiction. Dismissed.

Title: In re Beck Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Where bankrupt debtor sought to pierce corporate veil on ground that its subsidiary was mere dummy or alter ego, burden of proof was on debtor, and was not sustained in the case, though subsidiary was wholly owned by the debtor. Bankr.Act, §§ 116, 116(4), 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 516, 516(4).
Document Preview: From an order of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, John M. Cannella, J., affirming an order of a bankruptcy referee, Asa S. Herzog, J., restraining state court plaintiffs from continuing their action directed at a wholly owned subsidiary of the debtor in a Chapter X proceeding, the state court plaintiffs appealed. The Court of Appeals, Mansfield, Circuit Judge, held that though the subsidiary corporation was perhaps a mere shell when, immediately prior to merger, it was formed, and the transaction was structured to conform to a hybrid Type A form of corporate reorganization for purposes of Internal Revenue Code, conclusions that the subsidiary, which was a vital and viable independent entity was devious * * * legal rigamarole and independent entity by the sheerest fiction and an adjunct or instrumentality of the parent were, under evidence showing an arm's length transaction, clearly...

Title: In re Beck Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: In reorganization proceeding, equities, as between the debtor and state court plaintiffs seeking to rescind merger transaction shaped to conform to Internal Revenue Code requirements for hybrid "Type A" form of tax-free reorganization, were not shown to be in favor of disregarding separate corporate existence of debtor's wholly owned subsidiary. Bankr.Act, §§ 116, 116(4), 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 516, 516(4); 26 U.S.C.A. (I.R.C.1954) §§ 354(b)(1), 358(a)(1), 368(a)(1)(A), (2)(D).
Document Preview: From an order of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, John M. Cannella, J., affirming an order of a bankruptcy referee, Asa S. Herzog, J., restraining state court plaintiffs from continuing their action directed at a wholly owned subsidiary of the debtor in a Chapter X proceeding, the state court plaintiffs appealed. The Court of Appeals, Mansfield, Circuit Judge, held that though the subsidiary corporation was perhaps a mere shell when, immediately prior to merger, it was formed, and the transaction was structured to conform to a hybrid Type A form of corporate reorganization for purposes of Internal Revenue Code, conclusions that the subsidiary, which was a vital and viable independent entity was devious * * * legal rigamarole and independent entity by the sheerest fiction and an adjunct or instrumentality of the parent were, under evidence showing an arm's length transaction, clearly...

Title: Scott-Douglas Corp. v. Greyhound Corp.
Court: Superior Court of Delaware, New Castle County.
Headnote: Where, in action for breach of franchise contract and fraud in inducement of contract there was no evidence in any way tending to show fraud by parent corporation, except evidence of ownership and common directors and officers, there was failure to make case against parent corporation.
Document Preview: Actioin for breach of franchise contract and for fraud in inducement of contract. On motion by defendants for dismissal of action as to one defendant and on defendants' motion for summary judgment, the Superior Court, Wright, J., held that where there was no evidence in any way tending to show fraud by a parent corporation except evidence of ownership and common directors and officers, there was a failure to make a case against the parent corporation. The Court also held that the question whether franchisees were justified in their reliance upon representations was a question of fact precluding summary judgment. Motion of defendant parent corporation for dismissal granted; motion of remaining defendant for summary judgment denied.

Title: Heitler v. Museum Print Editions, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Mere showing of interlocking directorships and stockholdings did not sufficiently establish domination and control of one corporation by others to justify piercing of corporate veil so as to render latter corporations liable for former corporation's debts.
Document Preview: Action against corporations. The Supreme Court, New York County, Samuel A. Spiegel, J., denied motion by some of corporations to dismiss complaint for failure to state a cause of action, and those corporations appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that mere showing of interlocking directorships and stockholdings did not sufficiently establish domination and control of one corporation by others to justify piercing of corporate veil so as to render latter corporations liable for former corporation's debts. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Chicago Budget Rent-A-Car Corp. v. Maj
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: Evidence on issue whether corporate franchise licensee of parent automobile renting corporation was liable for debts of sublicensee, a separate Illinois corporation, supported finding that corporations were independent identities.
Document Preview: Appeal by corporate automobile renting franchise licensee from judgment of the Circuit Court, Lake County, Ezra L. D'Isa, J., in favor of garage lienor on its counter-claim in action by licensee to replevin automobile which lienor had repaired. The Appellate Court, Seidenfeld, P.J., held that garage lienor who did not show any conduct of corporate licensee calculated to mislead lienor to rely on anyone other than corporate sublicensee for repairs made to vehicles, which were leased by licensee to sublicensee under lease providing that sublicensee was to make all necessary repairs on vehicles at its own expense and four of which were repaired by lienor who admittedly had no knowledge of licensee when it made repairs, failed to establish that licensee was estopped from denying liability because it had placed vehicles in possession of sublicensee and thus clothed it with indicia of ownership. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Title: Service Afloat, Inc. v. U. S.
Court: United States Customs Court.
Headnote: Evidence established that corporation claimed to be selected purchaser of boat from its manufacturer-exporter (so that appraisement should have been made at f. o. b. price) was not independent entity but was under control of manufacturer-exporter.
Document Preview: Appeal for reappraisement. The Customs Court, Maletz, J., held that evidence would not sustain plaintiffs' contention that corporation was selected purchaser of boat from its manufacturer-exporter and established, to contrary, that corporation was sales agent of manufacturer-exporter. Order accordingly.

Title: Hassell v. Harmon Foods, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence in employment discrimination action supported finding that employer corporation, which did not have jurisdictional number of employees, and its parent corporation did not have such substantial identity as to constitute single employer for purpose of action. Civil Rights Act of 1964, § 701(b), 42 U.S.C.A. § 2000e(b).
Document Preview: Civil rights action based on alleged discrimination in employment. The United States District Court for the Western District of Tennessee, Western Division, 336 F.Supp. 432, Bailey Brown, Chief Judge, rendered judgment for defendants and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals held that evidence supported finding that employer corporation, which did not have jurisdictional number of employees, and its parent corporation did not have such substantial identity as to constitute single employer for purpose of action. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Berger v. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Facts that board of directors of wholly owned subsidiary, a film maker, consisted solely of employees of parent corporation, a national broadcaster, that parent's organizational chart included subsidiary, that all lines of employee authority from subsidiary passed through employees of parent and other subsidiaries to chairman of board of parent or that several lay witnesses related that subsidiary was a "division" of parent, standing alone, were insufficient to sustain application, under New York law, of instrumentality rule for purpose of establishing that contract, which involved syndication of fashion spectacular and which there had been entered into in name of subsidiary, was in fact that of parent and had been breached by parent's subsequently entering into similar contract with another.
Document Preview: Diversity action to recover from parent corporation, as alleged alter ego of subsidiary, for breach of contract entered into with subsidiary. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, John V. Singleton, J., awarded damages to plaintiff, and defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Goldberg, Circuit Judge, held that where evidence failed to establish that parent corporation, national broadcaster, completely dominated not only the finances, but policy and business practices of wholly owned subsidiary corporation, a film maker, subsidiary could not, under New York law, be found to have been a mere instrumentality of parent; thus, parent could not be found to have breached contract, which involved syndication of fashion spectacular and which had been entered into by and in name of subsidiary, by entering into a similar contract with another. Reversed.

Title: Del Monte Corp. v. Stark & Son Wholesale, Inc.
Court: Springfield Court of Appeals, Missouri.
Headnote: In seller's action against corporate wholesaler on open account for goods sold to corporate distributor, "piercing of the corporate veil" theory was inapplicable in absence of evidence disclosing number or identity of stockholders, directors or officers of either corporation other than that vice-president and secretary of wholesaler for period had been secretary treasurer of, but not majority stockholder in, distributor.
Document Preview: Seller brought action against corporate wholesaler and corporate distributor on an open account. The Circuit Court, Newton County, Paul E. Carver, J., stayed proceedings against distributor pending disposition of bankruptcy proceedings and rendered judgment in favor of the wholesaler, and the seller appealed. The Court of Appeals, Stone, J., held that in absence of any evidence concerning number or identity of stockholders, directors or officers of either corporate wholesaler or corporate distributor other than that vice-president and secretary of wholesaler was also secretary and treasurer of, but not a majority stockholder in, distributor and in absence of any writing, memorandum or note of alleged contract obligating wholesaler to answer for debt of distributor, seller was not entitled to recover against wholesaler for goods purchased by distributor. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Chatterley v. Omnico, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Utah.
Headnote: In action by former employees of subsidiary against parent corporation for unpaid wages, severance pay and other benefits, evidence supported finding that subsidiary was merely instrumentality of parent, that subsidiary did not have a valid board of directors and officers and that its affairs were actually operated by parent.
Document Preview: Action by former employees of subsidiary against subsidiary and parent corporation for unpaid wages, severance pay and other benefits. The Third District Court, Salt Lake County, Emmett L. Brown, J., entered judgment for plaintiffs and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Crockett, J., held that evidence supported finding that subsidiary was mere instrumentality of parent, that subsidiary did not have valid board of directors and officers and that its affairs were actually operated by parent. Affirmed.

Title: Professional Beauty Products, Inc. v. Jay
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Amarillo.
Headnote: Evidence that corporate supplier and corporate discount supplier had common secretaries and treasurers, that vice president of supplier was president of discount supplier, that there were three common shareholders in the two corporations, that the supplier had complete management and control of the discount supplier and that advertising was mailed by discount supplier to supplier's customers sustained finding that sales of discount supplier were sales by the supplier and that discount supplier was the alter ego of the supplier for purposes of determining whether supplier breached employment contract with former salesman who was to receive commissions from all sales to customers listed in his territory.
Document Preview: Corporate beauty products supplier brought action against former salesman for a permanent injunction to enforce a covenant not to compete contained in employment contract and for liquidated damages and the salesman brought a cross action for breach of the employment contract by the supplier and for wrongful issuance of temporary injunction. The District Court, Potter County, Mary Lou Robinson, J ., denied a permanent injunction and awarded the salesman nominal damages and the supplier appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Denton, C.J., held that supplier's action in establishing a discount supplier as an alter ego of itself resulting in reduction of salesman's sales and commissions constituted wrongful conduct which precluded supplier from obtaining injunctive relief or damages against salesman. Affirmed.

Title: St. Petersburg Sheraton Corp. v. Stuart
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Second District.
Headnote: Husband and wife suing for injuries suffered by wife when flames flashed back from cherries jubilee prepared by headwaiter in restaurant of hotel owned by subsidiary corporation failed to prove that parent corporation was merely the alter ego, adjunct, agency or instrumentality of defendant corporation which acquired all of assets of parent corporation, in exchange for proportionate amount of defendant's stock, a year after the accident.
Document Preview: Action for burns received by guest at restaurant in hotel during preparation of cherries jubilee brought against corporate owner of hotel and corporation allegedly chargeable with its liabilities. The Circuit Court, Pinellas County, Robert E. Beach, J., entered judgment for compensatory and punitive damages and defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Pierce, Acting Chief Judge, held that chef at restaurant in one defendant's hotel was not grossly negligent in preparing cherries jubilee at banquet when he poured flambe on cherries at time he did not see any fire in pan and plaintiff is not entitled to punitive damages for burns received when the flambe was ignited causing flame to shoot out and strike plaintiff. The Court also held that where the other defendant or a subsidiary was to receive all of stock of hotel corporation, the parent of corporate owner of restaurant, in exchange for defendant's stock, a wholly owned subsidiary of defendant was organized and by bill...

Title: Lit v. Storer Broadcasting Co.
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Employee of resident wholly owned subsidiary corporation failed to show subsidiary was "alter ego" of nonresident parent. 15 P.S. § 2011, subd. C.
Document Preview: Employee of resident subsidiary corporation brought action against nonresident parent corporation on trust agreement following the termination of his employment. The Court of Common Pleas, Trial Division-Law, Philadelphia County, No. 1881 October Term, 1969, Joseph Sloane, J., denied preliminary objections and the parent corporation appealed. The Superior Court, No. 462 October Term, 1970, Hoffman, J., held that nonresident parent corporation's making of trust agreement with employee of wholly owned resident subsidiary did not constitute doing business' within state sufficient to subject nonresident parent corporation to jurisdiction of state courts in absence of a showing that parent entered or intended to enter into a series of such trust agreements. Reversed and remanded.

Title: Miller v. Trans World Airlines, Inc.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Kentucky, Covington Division.
Headnote: Where plaintiff in wrongful death action brought in Kentucky failed to establish that corporate separateness between parent and its subsidiary (manufacturer of instruments found in airplane which crashed in Kentucky and killed plaintiff's decedent) was fictitious, that parent had held subsidiary out as its agent, or that parent had exercised an undue degree of control over subsidiary, federal district court in Kentucky did not have jurisdiction over parent corporation under Kentucky long-arm statute. K.R.S. 454.210(2) (a) 4, 5.
Document Preview: Proceedings on motion of certain defendant to dismiss wrongful death action for lack of jurisdiction over the person. The District Court, Mac Swinford, J., held that corporate foreign manufacturer of instruments found in airplane which crashed in Kentucky killing plaintiff's decedent must have known that buyers of its products would sell airplanes to airlines which would fly into Kentucky, so that it must have known that plaintiff's decedent would use, consume or be affected by goods in Kentucky within meaning of Kentucky long-arm statute, and further held that it did not have jurisdiction over manufacturer's parent corporation, in absence of a showing that corporate separateness was fictitious. Motion granted in part.

Title: City Trade and Industries, Limited v. New Central Jute Mills Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: Mere fact that Indian corporation's attorney participated as an advisor to certain foreign banks in attachment proceedings did not establish that the foreign banks were Indian corporation's alter egos acting at its instigation and command, as affecting question whether Indian corporation was precluded from asserting its rights to arbitration under distributorship agreement with American corporation because of its alleged involvement in prior litigation against American corporation in other jurisdictions through various "alter egos".
Document Preview: Action against Indian corporation by American corporation seeking an accounting for duration of a distributorship contract. The Supreme Court, Special Term, New York County, Samuel H. Hofstadter, J., entered order which directed parties to proceed to arbitration and stayed all further proceedings in this action and in action pending in United States District Court for the Southern District of Georgia. On appeal, the Appellate Division, 30 A.D.2d 513, 290 N.Y.S.2d 108, by modification deleted provision staying plaintiff from proceeding in action pending in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Georgia without prejudice, and appeals were taken. The Court of Appeals, Burke, J., held that even if distributorship agreement contained price fixing arrangement, provision in agreement for arbitration was not unenforceable, where parties failed to adhere to such arrangement and by their conduct reduced principal-to-principal relationship described in agreement to a...
