Title: Country Maid, Inc. v. Haseotes
Court: United States District Court E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under evidence that individual defendants through corporate defendants were involved in one large enterprise with officers and stockholders of all corporations being same individuals, individual corporate entity's integrity would not be protected.
Document Preview: Proceedings on motion to dismiss civil antitrust action. The District Court, Body, J., held that where individual defendants were officers and management employees of various corporations that were engaged in one single enterprise, service upon statutory agent for one corporation in Pennsylvania constituted service of antitrust action upon individual defendants even though they did not reside in Pennsylvania, owned no property in Pennsylvania and had residences and places of business outside Pennsylvania, and that corporations which were engaged in one operation were transacting business' in Pennsylvania where one corporation had its principal office. Motion dismissed.

Title: Elliott v. Occidental Life Ins. Co. of Cal.
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: In action by widow against insurer to recover on group policy on ground that policy issued to decedent while employed for one baking company had remained in effect under clerical error provision contained therein when deceased had been transferred to another baking company which failed to make further premium deductions on deceased's behalf, evidence sustained finding that both baking companies were in fact the same firm.
Document Preview: Action by widow against group life insurer to recover on policy on ground that it had remained in effect, under clerical error provision contained therein, when employee had been transferred from one firm to another and the premium deductions had been discontinued. The Superior Court, City and County of San Francisco, Clayton W. Horn, J., entered judgment for plaintiff on jury verdict and then granted defendant's motion for judgment notwithstanding verdict. The Court of Appeal, Shoemaker, P.J., held that evidence sustained jury findings that firm from which insured had been transferred and that to which he had been transferred were in fact the same firm and that the transferor firm had made clerical error consisting of ceasing to make premium deduction on insured's behalf without first having arranged for transferee to assume that responsibility. Judgment for defendant reversed with directions to reinstate judgment for plaintiff.

Title: Bunge Corp. v. St. Louis Terminal Field Warehouse Co.
Court: United States District Court N.D. Mississippi, Greenville Division.
Headnote: Evidence established that plaintiff foreign corporation's subsidiary which operated in Mississippi at time plaintiff's cause of action accrued, had been a corporate entity separate and apart from plaintiff, that its association with plaintiff did not create relationship of principal and agent between them and that plaintiff had not been engaged in doing business in Mississippi through activities of subsidiary, in diversity action wherein defendants asserted that plaintiff was prohibited from bringing action for failure to obtain authority to do business in Mississippi. Code Miss.1942, §§ 5309-221, 5309-239.
Document Preview: Complaint in equity for order subrogating plaintiff to rights of bank in and to warehouse receipts and directing that warehouse receipts be revived, reissued and delivered to it to be redeemed by defendant. The District Court, Orma R. Smith, J., held that where plaintiff exercised reasonable care, before advancing sums to grain dealer, to determine that barge with 35,000 bushels of beans had been delivered to carrier by dealer for shipment to it and defendant warehouseman negligently performed its duties setting stage for dealer's fraud on plaintiff by representing that there were 35,000 bushels when there were only 22,000 bushels and dealer and warehouseman entered into arrangement whereby sums advanced by plaintiff were used to discharge liability of warehouseman to bank on warehouse receipts, equities of plaintiff were superior to those of warehouseman and plaintiff was entitled to be subrogated to rights held by bank in receipts. Judgment for plaintiff.

Title: Phelps v. Missouri-Kansas-Texas R. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Missouri, Division No. 1.
Headnote: In absence of evidence that corporation furnishing substitute rail freight service by highway for railroad was not a going, solvent corporation or that purposes of both corporation and railroad were anything but proper, the corporate entity of corporation could not be disregarded and truck driver was not an "employee" of railroad, which owned all stock of corporation furnishing substitute rail freight service by highway, for purpose of liability under Federal Employers' Liability Act. Federal Employers' Liability Act, §§ 1-10, 45 U.S.C.A. §§ 51-60.
Document Preview: Truck driver brought action under Federal Employers' Liability Act for personal injuries. The Circuit Court of Jackson County, Charles Shangler, J., entered judgment on verdict for driver, and railroad appealed. The Supreme Court, Higgins, C., held that in absence of evidence that corporation furnishing substitute rail freight service by highway for railroad was not a going, solvent corporation or that purposes of both corporation and railroad were anything but proper, the corporate entity of corporation could not be disregarded, and truck driver was not an employee of railroad, which owned all stock of corporation furnishing substitute rail freight service by highway, for purpose of liability under Federal Employer's Liability Act. Judgment reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Rockford Equipment Co. v. J. R. Simplot Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho.
Headnote: Even though two corporations, organized at different times and engaged in potato warehousing business, had same president and interlocking directors and officers, and sign of one corporation was on office building and warehouse used by both, evidence was insufficient to establish that corporations were anything other than separate and distinct legal entities, and one corporation was not liable for alleged conversion by other corporation.
Document Preview: Action for conversion of potato crop brought by assignee of notes secured by chattel mortgage covering potato crop against mortgagors and potato warehousing corporation. The Seventh Judicial District Court, Bingham County, Paul Crane, J., entered default judgment against mortgagors and dismissed action against warehousing corporation and assignee appealed. The Supreme Court, Spear, J., held that even though two corporations, organized at different times and engaged in potato warehousing business, had same president and interlocking directors and officers, and sign of one corporation was on office building and warehouse used by both, evidence was insufficient to establish that corporations were anything other than separate and distinct legal entities, and one corporation was not liable for alleged conversion by other corporation. Affirmed.

Title: Griffin & Co. v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Claims.
Headnote: Evidence in actions, consolidated for trial, by parent corporation and its wholly-owned subsidiary for refund of federal income taxes collected from corporations established that subsidiary was a mere corporate shell during 1960 and 1961, without employees or plant with which to carry on a substantial business as a manufacturer of sheet-metal products.
Document Preview: Actions, consolidated for trial, by parent corporation and its wholly-owned subsidiary against United States for refunds of federal income taxes collected from corporations pursuant to deficiency assessments following disallowances of net operating loss deductions and surtax exemptions. The Court of Claims held that the subsidiary was not conducting business as an entity separate from parent corporation in 1960 and 1961, and, therefore, income reported by subsidiary was taxable to parent corporation, that evidence sustained internal revenue service's determination that only designated parts of compensation paid by parent corporation to two stockholder-officer-directors in years 1960 and 61 were deductible for federal income tax purposes, and that internal revenue service's allocation of parent corporation's automobile expenses between corporation's business expense and its officers' personal expense would be upheld in absence of clear showing of error. Judgment in accordance with...

Title: Griffin & Co. v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Claims.
Headnote: Fact that parent and wholly-owned subsidiary corporations maintained separate bank accounts and books of account and filed separate federal and state income tax returns might, standing alone, support a finding that the two corporations were engaged in conduct of separate businesses for federal income tax purposes, but such facts could not overcome strong evidence that business activities were conducted, and income in question was actually earned, in substance by parent corporation, where only parent corporation was shown to have personnel and assets with which to carry on a substantial business as manufacturer of sheet-metal products.
Document Preview: Actions, consolidated for trial, by parent corporation and its wholly-owned subsidiary against United States for refunds of federal income taxes collected from corporations pursuant to deficiency assessments following disallowances of net operating loss deductions and surtax exemptions. The Court of Claims held that the subsidiary was not conducting business as an entity separate from parent corporation in 1960 and 1961, and, therefore, income reported by subsidiary was taxable to parent corporation, that evidence sustained internal revenue service's determination that only designated parts of compensation paid by parent corporation to two stockholder-officer-directors in years 1960 and 61 were deductible for federal income tax purposes, and that internal revenue service's allocation of parent corporation's automobile expenses between corporation's business expense and its officers' personal expense would be upheld in absence of clear showing of error. Title: Griffin & Co. v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Claims.
Headnote: Evidence in actions, consolidated for trial, by parent corporation and its wholly-owned subsidiary for refunds of federal income taxes collected established that existence of subsidiary, which sold, F.O.B. parent corporation's plant, items manufactured by parent corporation's "production" workers for such sale, and subsidiary's relationship to parent corporation lacked real significance with respect to labor agreement permitting parent corporation to employ less expensive "production" workers in manufacture of items sold F.O.B. plant.

The Court of Claims held that the subsidiary was not conducting business as an entity separate from parent corporation in 1960 and 1961, and, therefore, income reported by subsidiary was taxable to parent corporation, that evidence sustained internal revenue service's determination that only designated parts of compensation paid by parent corporation to two stockholder-officer-directors in years 1960 and 61 were deductible for federal income tax purposes, and that internal revenue service's allocation of parent corporation's automobile expenses between corporation's business expense and its officers' personal expense would be upheld in absence of clear showing of error. Title: Bell Oil & Gas. Co. v. Allied Chemical Corp.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas. Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence sustained finding that two corporations formed to operate retail filling stations were representatives, devices, or dummies through which third corporation engaged in retail distribution of oil and gasoline thereby making such third corporation liable to seller of goods and services to such corporations.
Document Preview: Action against corporation to recover for goods and services sold to affiliated and subsidiary corporations. The District Court, Harris County, George E. Cire, J., found for plaintiff against corporations which received the goods and services as well as against interrelated corporation and such latter corporation appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Coleman, J., held that evidence sustained finding that two corporations formed to operate retail filling stations were representatives, devices, or dummies through which third corporation engaged in retail distribution of oil and gasoline thereby making such third corporation liable to seller of goods and services to such corporations. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Wirtz v. Mercantile Stores Co.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Oklahoma.
Headnote: Plaintiff United States failed to sustain burden of showing that defendant corporation had no autonomous identity because it was merely a branch of second corporation, so as to support government's contention that service of process on agent of second corporation was in effect service on the defendant. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc. rule 4(d) (3), 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: On motion by defendant corporation to quash process and to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction, the District Court, Daugherty, J., held that evidence adduced by plaintiff United States was insufficient to show that party served with process, who was store manager of second corporation, had any legal relationship with defendant corporation other than through parent-subsidiary corporate structure of the stores, so that service of process upon the manager was not effective as to defendant corporation. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Hawaiian Oke & Liquors, Limited v. Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, Inc.
Court: United States District Court D. Hawai‘i.
Headnote: Evidence, in action to recover treble damages for injury allegedly resulting from defendants' violations of the anti-trust laws, established that four unincorporated divisions of defendant distiller were each distinct and separate operating, marketing entities, legally and factually capable of entering into and conspiring with one another in restraint of trade, contrary to the Clayton Act, notwithstanding fact that the divisions might have had certain common functions within the same parent corporation. Clayton Act, § 4, 15 U.S.C.A. § 15; Sherman Anti-Trust Act, § 1, 15 U.S.C.A. § 1.
Document Preview: Action to recover treble damages under the Clayton Act for injuries allegedly resulting from violations of the anti-trust laws. The District Court, Martin Pence, Chief Judge, held that in ruling on plaintiff's requested instruction concerning intracorporate conspiracy, held that evidence established that four unincorporated divisions of defendant distiller were each distinct and separate operating, marketing entities, legally and factually capable of entering into and conspiring with one another in restraint of trade, contrary to the Clayton Act, notwithstanding fact that the divisions might have had certain common functions within the same parent corporation. Order in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: TSS Sportswear, Limited v. Swank Shop (Guam) Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence sustained finding that corporate creditors were mere facades manipulated by seller of corporate debtor's stock.
Document Preview: From a judgment of the United States District Court of Guam, Paul D. Shriver, J., dismissing action, plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Tavares, District Judge, held that even if seller did not have authority to bind corporate creditor when he represented to buyer of corporate debtor's stock that debt would be considered paid, corporate creditor's assignee, which was seller's alter ego, was bound by such representation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Wallach v. Williams
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey Appellate Division.
Headnote: Record would not support inferences the subsidiary corporation which held title to service station which was leased to parent corporation and subleased to operator held title for any illegal or fraudulent purpose as affecting liability of subsidiary for injury sustained by business invitee on service station premises.
Document Preview: Action for injuries sustained by business invitee at service station when he was struck by automobile. The Superior Court, Law Division, entered judgment for lessor, lessee and sublessee of service station and against owner of automobile which struck plaintiff and plaintiff appealed. The Superior Court, Appellate Division, Labrecque, J.A.D., held that where sublease of service station gave sublessee right to exercise control over conduct of business, sublessor had no duty to plaintiff invitee who was struck by automobile which had been left with motor running even though sublessor routinely had sent its agent to inspect premises and even if sublessee habitually failed to require that motors be shut off before customers were served. Affirmed. Affirmed 52 N.J. 503, 246 A.2d 713.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Washington and Old Dominion Users Ass'n v. Washington and Old Dominion R. R.
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of Virginia.
Headnote: Evidence that intrastate freight railroad and large interstate railroad which held all its capital stock had separate books and separate car and accounting records, filed separate reports with the State Corporation Commission and the Interstate Commerce Commission, had different labor agreements, and were not physically connected sustained finding by State Corporation Commission that railroads should be regarded as separate corporate entities.
Document Preview: Appeal from order of State Corporation Commission authorizing railroad to abandon the intrastate operation of its entire line. The Supreme Court of Appeals, Eggleston, Chief Justice, held that evidence that operation of intrastate freight railroad was conducted at a loss, that there was no continued public use for railroad and no reasonable prospect that its operation would become profitable, and that other public facilities were reasonably available to users of railroad sustained order of State Corporation Commission that railroad might abandon its operation. Affirmed.

Title: U. S. for Use of Powers Regulator Co. v. Hartford Acc. & Indem. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals First Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence in action by third level subcontractor against prime contractor's surety on Miller Act bond sustained finding, on issue whether one of intervening subcontractors was merely sham or alter ego of another subcontractor, that subcontractor and sub-subcontractor were bona fide separate corporations.
Document Preview: Action by third level subcontractor against prime contractor's surety on Miller Act bond. The United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts, Andrew A. Caffrey, J., 261 F.Supp. 278, dismissed complaint, and the plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Aldrich, Chief Judge, held that third level subcontractor was too remote to be entitled to recover on Miller Act bond. Affirmed.

Title: U. S. for Use of Powers Regulator Co. v. Hartford Acc. & Indem. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals First Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence in action by third level subcontractor against prime contractor's surety on Miller Act bond failed to establish that plaintiff was misled into believing that subcontractor corporation and sub-subcontractor corporation were one and the same so as to justify ignoring their separate corporate entities in determining whether plaintiff was within scope of bond.
Document Preview: Action by third level subcontractor against prime contractor's surety on Miller Act bond. The United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts, Andrew A. Caffrey, J., 261 F.Supp. 278, dismissed complaint, and the plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Aldrich, Chief Judge, held that third level subcontractor was too remote to be entitled to recover on Miller Act bond. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: U. S. for Use of Powers Regulator Co. v. Farina Const. Corp.
Court: United States District Court D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Evidence, in an action under the Miller Act, by a third level subcontractor, against surety for prime contractor, was insufficient to establish that heating and air-conditioning subcontractor and a sub-subcontractor which subcontracted with plaintiff were alter egos of each other and that case was appropriate for application of doctrine of piercing the corporate veil to reduce plaintiff's remoteness from payment bond. Miller Act, §§ 1-4, 40 U.S.C.A. §§ 270a-270d and § 270e.
Document Preview: Action under the Miller Act by a contractor thrice removed against surety on prime contractor's bond. The District Court, Caffrey, J., held that subcontractor three times removed lacked standing to maintain the action, such party not being a subcontractor within the meaning of the Miller Act. Complaint dismissed.

Title: U.S. v. Ross
Court: United States District Court S.D. New York.
Headnote: Evidence in proceeding to reduce to judgment jeopardy tax assessments on foreign personal holding company income did not establish taxpayer's contention that foreign holding corporation was merely agent of taxpayer's second corporation. 26 U.S.C.A. (I.R.C.1954) § 552 and (a).
Document Preview: Proceeding to reduce to judgment jeopardy assessment on alleged foreign personal holding company income. The District Court, Levet, J., held, inter alia, that evidence did not establish claim that taxpayer's foreign corporation was a dealer, whose income would not be subject to provisions invoked, but established that it was an investor or speculator. Judgment for United States.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Whayne v. Transportation Management Service, Inc.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: For plaintiff injured while employed as cook aboard vessel owned by one corporation to hold another corporation liable, plaintiff must establish that corporate owner of vessel was mere instrumentality of the second corporation. Jones Act, 46 U.S.C.A. § 688.
Document Preview: Action for injuries sustained by cook aboard vessel owned by one corporation trict Court, on defendant's motion to disagainst a second corporation. The Dismiss, Van Dusen, J., held that where defendant corporation owned no stock in corporate owner of vessel, the two corporations had only one common director and officer, corporate vessel owner regularly paid defendant for bookkeeping and other services that defendant performed, directors meetings of corporations were held at different times and in different places, defendant did not direct movement of vessel, purchase any equipment or supplies used on it, finance building of it or hire or fire personnel on board, corporate vessel owner was not mere instrumentality of defendant and defendant was not liable for cook's injuries. Action dismissed with prejudice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Markow v. Alcock
Court: United States Court of Appeals Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence did not establish that corporate mortgagor was a wholly owned subsidiary of bankrupt corporation, nor that such mortgagor was not a legally constituted separate corporate entity from bankrupt, as ground for invalidating mortgage as being in fraud of bankrupt's general creditors. Bankr.Act, § 70, sub. e, 11 U.S.C.A. § 110(e).
Document Preview: Action by corporation's bankruptcy trustee claiming a mortgage to be invalid as in fraud of general creditors. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, Emett C. Choate, J., rendered judgment for defendants, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Benjamin C. Dawkins, Jr., District Judge, held that evidence did not establish that corporate mortgagor was a wholly owned subsidiary of bankrupt corporation, nor that such mortgagor was not a legally constituted separate corporate entity. Affirmed.

Title: Magyar v. American Tel. & Tel. Co.
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey Law Division.
Headnote: Evidence established that parent corporation authorized to do business in New Jersey and Pennsylvania subsidiary which challenged validity of service of process on it by personal service upon registered agent of parent were separate corporate entities.
Document Preview: Action arising out of automobile accident against parent corporation and Pennsylvania subsidiary which by motion challenged validity of service of process upon it. The Superior Court, Law Division, Bennett, J.C.C., temporarily assigned, held that where parent corporation, authorized to do business in New Jersey, did not procure customers or act in New Jersey in any way on behalf of wholly owned Pennsylvania subsidiary, personal service upon registered agent of parent was ineffective to subject subsidiary to jurisdiction of New Jersey court and that service of process on subsidiary by registered mail, return receipt requested, pursuant to rule was also insufficient. Motion to quash service of process granted.

Title: National Bond Finance Co. v. General Motors Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence in action against parent corporation to recover on debt owed by subsidiary corporation supported finding that subsidiary was not instrumentality or alter ego of parent.
Document Preview: Action against parent corporation to recover on debt owed by subsidiary corporation. The United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri, Richard M. Duncan, J., 238 F.Supp. 248, dismissed complaint, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals held that evidence supported finding that subsidiary was not instrumentality or alter ego of parent. Affirmed.

Title: Fire Ass'n of Philadelphia v. Vantine Paint & Glass Co. of Bismarck
Court: Supreme Court of North Dakota.
Headnote: In action by property owners and their fire insurers to recover for fire damage on ground that defendant corporations were in fact one entity, there was no showing that corporations conducted a single business insofar as public was concerned, there was not the slightest intimation that anything was unfair or fraudulent in conduct of defendant corporations, and there was no showing that the plaintiffs relied upon any previous dealings with corporations or individuals that could lead them to believe that they were dealing with one entity. NDCC 9-03-09.
Document Preview: Actions by various property owners and their fire insurers against named individual who allegedly started the fire, a partnership and various corporations to recover for the fire damage on the theory that the separate businesses did not have a separate corporate existence but were used and existed for the sole purpose of permitting the incorporators to transact individual businesses under a multiple corporate guise. The District Court, Morton County, C. F. Kelsch, J., entered summary judgment for defendants except as to named individual who allegedly started the fire and his employer and the plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, Schneller, District Judge, held that there was no showing that the business conduct of the four corporations had been so intermingled and confused that the four corporations conducted a single business insofar as the public was concerned, that there was not the slightest intimation that anything was unfair or fraudulent in the conduct of the defendant...

Title: Consolidated Sun Ray, Inc. v. Oppenstein
Court: United States Court of Appeals Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Finding that corporation which executed lease was alter ego of defendant corporation, which owned all of stock of tenant corporation, was supported by substantial evidence.
Document Preview: Suit by landlord to recover damages for breach of lease against tenant corporation and parent corporation. The United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri, Floyd R. Gibson, Chief Judge, 216 F.Supp. 268, entered judgment adverse to tenant and parent corporation and the parent corporation appealed. The Court of Appeals, Vogel, Circuit Judge, held that the parent corporation's complete and absolute control over subsidiary, making subsidiary a supplemental part of parent corporation's economic unit, and parent corporation's operation of subsidiary without sufficient funds to meet its obligations to creditors was circumstantial evidence from which advisory jury and court, as finders of facts, could reasonably draw inference that parent corporation's purpose was improper and detrimental to landlord who had signed lease with subsidiary, but there was error in refusing to admit certain evidence on issues of mitigation of damages. Court: United States Court of Appeals Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Parent corporation's complete and absolute control over subsidiary, making subsidiary a supplemental part of parent corporation's economic unit and parent corporation's operation of subsidiary without sufficient funds to meet its obligations to creditors was circumstantial evidence from which advisory jury and court, as finders of facts, could reasonably draw inference that parent corporation's purpose was improper and detrimental to landlord who had signed lease with subsidiary.

Title: Neese v. Fireman's Fund Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Eastern Section.
Headnote: Evidence established that relationship between corporations was not merely that of principal and agent and that they were in fact a single entity.
Document Preview: In a case which originated as a general creditor's bill, the Chancery Court, Hamilton County, Ray L. Brock, Jr., Chancellor, allowed all claims against surety on statutory Real Estate Agent's and Salesman's Bond except that of bankruptcy trustee, and the trustee appealed. The Court of Appeals, Cooper, J., held that where domination of both parent and subsidiary corporation by majority stockholder and principal executive officer of both corporations was so complete that neither had any mind, will or existence of its own, relationship was such that they were to be treated as single entity, for purposes of parent's trustee's claim on subsidiary's bond. Affirmed.

Title: Pike Motor Co. v. Adams
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: Under evidence that lessee corporation and a second corporation were distinct corporate entities, and that their only relationship to each other was that of debtor and creditor, the second corporation and its president were not liable for rent owed by lessee corporation. KRS 271.215(2).
Document Preview: Action to recover rent for leased premises. From a judgment of the Circuit Court, Johnson County, W. D. Sparks, J., two of the defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Stewart, J., held that under evidence that lessee corporation and a second corporation were distinct corporate entities, and that their only relationship to each other was that of debtor and creditor, the second corporation and its president were not liable for rent owed by lessee corporation. Reversed and remanded.

Title: National Bond Finance Co. v. General Motors Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Western Division.
Headnote: Evidence regarding relationship between finance company which purchased automobile conditional sales contracts, the automobile manufacturer and automobile dealer did not justify piercing of corporate veil of dealer and holding the manufacturer liable for actions and conduct of dealer's president and of dealer so as to render manufacturer liable to company for losses sustained.
Document Preview: Action for actual and punitive damages growing out of transactions between plaintiff and an automobile dealer doing business in Illinois involving the purchase of conditional sales contracts for sale of motor vehicles. The District Court, Duncan, J., held, inter alia, that evidence regarding relationship between finance company which purchased automobile conditional sales contracts, the automobile manufacturer and automobile dealer did not justify piercing of corporate veil of dealer and holding the manufacturer liable for actions and conduct of dealer's president and of dealer so as to render manufacturer liable to company for losses sustained. Judgment for defendant in accordance with opinion.

Title: Tell v. General Meat Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Defendant was not entitled to set off against its indebtedness to first corporation an indebtedness to it from second corporation guaranteed by an individual who was indirectly a stockholder and beneficially interested therein and was also a stockholder in first corporation, absent showing that the corporations were mere instrumentalities of the individual and his brother or showing that, for other reasons, there should be disregarding of corporate entities.
Document Preview: Suit by assignees of an account for goods sold and delivered. The Supreme Court, Appellate Term, affirmed the judgment of the Municipal Court dismissing the complaint, and the assignees appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that defendant was not entitled to set off against its indebtedness to first corporation an indebtedness to it from second corporation guaranteed by an individual who was indirectly a stockholder and beneficially interested therein and was also a stockholder in first corporation, absent showing that the corporation were mere instrumentalities of the individual and his brother or showing that, for other reasons, there should be disregarding of corporate entities. Determination of Appellate Term reversed and judgment directed for plaintiffs.

Title: Oppenstein v. Consolidated Sun Ray, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Western Division.
Headnote: Evidence established that parent corporation, sued by lessor of premises leased to defendant subsidiary, had complete and absolute control over actions and rights of subsidiary and elected not to respect separateness of corporate entity of subsidiary, causing subsidiary's assets to be intermingled with its own so that subsidiary became alter ego of parent.
Document Preview: Action for declaratory judgment brought by lessor against lessee subsidiary and its parent corporation. The District Court, Gibson, Chief Judge, held that by reason of parent corporation's disregarding separate corporate entity of subsidiary and its appropriation of subsidiary's rights in subsidiary's assets resulting in damage to lessor, parent was liable on obligations of lessee. Judgment accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Oppenstein v. Consolidated Sun Ray, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Western Division.
Headnote: Evidence established that plaintiff lessor was damaged by use of defendant lessee subsidiary as instrumentality of defendant parent, loss of control by subsidiary of its own destiny and imposition of excessive financial burden on subsidiary for benefit of parent.
Document Preview: Action for declaratory judgment brought by lessor against lessee subsidiary and its parent corporation. The District Court, Gibson, Chief Judge, held that by reason of parent corporation's disregarding separate corporate entity of subsidiary and its appropriation of subsidiary's rights in subsidiary's assets resulting in damage to lessor, parent was liable on obligations of lessee. Judgment accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Acton Plumbing & Heating Co. v. Jared Builders, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: In determining whether corporate entity should be disregarded and parent company held liable on contracts of its subsidiary because latter served as a mere instrumentality or adjunct of the former, each case is sui generis and must be decided in accordance with its own underlying facts.
Document Preview: Action by plumbing contractor to recover balance due on work and materials furnished by plaintiff. From a judgment of the Circuit Court, Wayne County, Horace W. Gilmore, J., in favor of the plaintiff, the defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Kavanagh, J., held that where evidence preponderated in favor of findings of trial court sitting without jury that building corporations had been formed for purpose of trying to limit liability and for tax purposes, that they all had common directors, that capital stock was not paid until profits were made, that all corporations were agents of each other and that they were manipulated by individuals for sole purpose of evading their responsibility, trial court correctly held that plumbing contractor was entitled to judgment against all of defendants, jointly and severally. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Associated Vendors, Inc. v. Oakland Meat Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Evidence, in action by landlord to recover rental due from a corporate tenant and another corporation and certain officers and stockholders of the tenant corporation and the other corporation, sustained finding that tenant corporation was not the alter ego of other corporation or officers and stockholders thereof, even though there was a certain mutuality of stock ownership.
Document Preview: Action by a landlord to recover rent. The Superior Court, Alameda County, Monroe Friedman, J., entered judgment adverse to landlord and it appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Molinari, J., held that evidence sustained finding that tenant corporation was not the alter ego of other corporate defendant or officers and stockholders thereof, even though there was a certain mutuality of stock ownership. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Gerhard v. Chemical Bank New York Trust Co.
Court: Civil Court, City of New York, Bronx County, Trial Term, Part VII.
Headnote: Evidence established that restaurant corporation, whose assignee for benefit of creditors had endorsed for deposit in his account a check payable to caterer, and caterer were one and same entity and that restaurant corporation was doing business under trade name of caterer.
Document Preview: Action by maker of check payable to caterer against bank on theory bank had improperly deposited check in account of assignee for creditors of restaurant corporation. The Civil Court of the City of New York, County of Bronx, Trial Term, Arthur Wachtel, J., held that where restaurant corporation and caterer were one and same entity, check was properly deposited by bank in account of assignee for creditors of restaurant corporation. Complaint dismissed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Brown v. Benton Creosoting Co.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence compelled conclusion that sawmill company was mere alter ego of creosoting company after arrangement putting sawmill company in position as owner and operator of business conducted under name of creosoting company, with result that sawmill company had full management and control.
Document Preview: Suit for workmen's compensation for permanent and total disability from burns. The Twenty-Sixth Judicial District Court, Parish of Bossier, O. E. Price, J., rendered judgment for defendants and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeal, Ayres, J., held that trial court erred in denying compensation for total and permanent disability on theory that plaintiff had not sustained demands where plaintiff adduced evidence establishing that, at time of trial, because of burns, he was unable to return to and discharge employment duties, though rpobable duration of disability was not established, but he was to be awarded compensation for permanent total disability, and that sawmilling company which was mere alter ego of creosoting company immediately employing plaintiff could not escape liability for compensation by cloaking itself behind corporate shield of creosoting company and held that under the circumstances penalties and attorney fees were not warranted. Reversed and rendered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: McLaughlin v. L. Bloom Sons Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: There was substantial evidence to sustain finding that new corporation which was operating a fourth shoe store was, for purposes of collective bargaining agreement, merely alter ego of older corporation which operated three shoe stores and which had signed agreement with union.
Document Preview: Union's action for declaratory judgment that the new defendant corporation was the alter ego of the old defendant corporation for the purposes of collective bargaining agreement. The Superior Court, County of Santa Clara Robert F. Peckham, J., entered a judgment for the union and the defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Agee, J., held that it was not an abuse of discretion to apply the alter ego doctrine to the new corporation which was controlled by the same individuals as the old corporation that had signed a collective bargaining agreement. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Fisser v. International Bank
Court: United States Court of Appeals Second Circuit.
Headnote: On petition by German coal importers to enforce against the International Bank under the Federal Arbitration Act the arbitration provisions of contract of affreightment, which was signed solely by importers and a Liberian corporation, on ground that the Liberian corporation was the alter ego of the International Bank, evidence was insufficient to establish that the International Bank was the alter ego of the Liberian corporation. 9 U.S.C.A. §§ 1–14, 2, 4.
Document Preview: German coal importers brought libel against the International Bank charging breach of a maritime contract and filed a petition to enforce arbitration pursuant to the Federal Arbitration Act in accordance with contract of affreightment, which was signed solely by importers and Liberian corporation, on ground that the Liberian corporation was the alter ego of the International Bank. The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, in admiralty, Edmund L. Palmieri, J., rendered a decree dismissing the libel and the petition, and the importers appealed. The Court of Appeals, Hincks, Circuit Judge, held that the District Court erred in ruling that International Bank was not bound by the arbitration provisions merely because the International Bank had not signed the contract, and that amenability of International Bank to arbitration could be solved only by determining whether Liberian corporation entered into the contract as the alter ego of the International...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Temple v. Bodega Bay Fisheries, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: In action by corporation's creditors against the corporation, another corporation, and several individuals, evidence supported finding that the debtor corporation had never been organized and operated as a true corporate enterprise, but was the alter ego of the other defendants.
Document Preview: Action by corporation's creditors against debtor corporation, several individuals, and another corporation. The Superior Court, Sonoma County, Hilliard Comstock, J., rendered judgment against all defendants, and they appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Van Dyke, P. J., held that evidence supported finding that the debtor had never been organized and operated as a true corporate enterprise, but was the alter ego of the other defendants. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Wyoming Const. Co. v. Western Cas. & Sur. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: In action for indemnity, to recover cost in completing construction contract after default by sub-subcontractor, brought by surety on performance bond against sub-subcontractor and corporation which had acquired all of stock in sub-subcontractor under agreement containing repurchase option which was not exercised, evidence warranted jury finding that such corporation had controlled and dominated sub-subcontractor in its own interest with full knowledge of situation, causing sub-subcontractor to default on contract with resulting detriment to surety.
Document Preview: Action by surety on sub-subcontractor's performance bond, for indemnity, to recover its costs in completing contract, against sub-subcontractor and company which had acquired its stock. The United States District Court for the District of Wyoming, rendered judgment for plaintiff and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Breitenstein, Circuit Judge, held, inter alia, that evidence on issue of whether sub-subcontractor had been excused from performance because of alleged breach by subcontractor warranted finding by jury adverse to sub-subcontractor and that evidence warranted jury's finding that defendant which had acquired stock in sub-subcontractor had dominated it, in its own interest, and, with full knowledge of situation, had caused sub-subcontractor to default on contract to detriment of surety. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: American Tobacco Co. v. Goulandris
Court: United States District Court S.D. New York.
Headnote: In libel for loss and damage to goods carried on owners' vessel, evidence failed to establish that a corporation formed to re-establish a steamship passenger service under the Greek flag between North America and Greece was controlled by vessel owners or by a wholly-owned corporate agent of vessel owners, or that Greek flag corporation was organized to defraud creditors or to evade existing obligations, even though vessel owners owned some of the stock of Greek flag corporation.
Document Preview: Suits in admiralty for damage sustained to cargo shipped on defendants' vessel. Vessel owners filed a cross-libel for contribution in general average. The District Court, Ryan, J., held, inter alia, that vessel owners had the right and duty to file cross-libels to enforce collection from cargo interests of their contribution of their indebtedness to the general average fund, and vessel owners had such obligation even though on balance they might be debtors in general average. Decree in accordance with opinion. See also D.C., 134 F.Supp. 475.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Riddle v. Leuschner
Court: Supreme Court of California.
Headnote: In action by creditor of one corporation against that corporation, a second corporation and shareholders, officers and directors of both corporations for amount due, evidence sustained findings that two corporations were controlled, dominated, managed, and operated by two members of family, and that there was no separateness between them and corporations.
Document Preview: Action by creditor of one corporation against that corporation, a second corporation and shareholders, officers and directors of both corporations for amount due. The Superior Court, Stanislaus County, David F. Bush, J., rendered judgment for creditor and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Gibson, C. J., held that where one corporation's assets were intermingled with those of a second to suit convenience of parties who controlled both corporations and to assist them in evading payment of their obligations, and manipulations of affairs of corporations were designed to foster controlling parties' own purposes to disadvantage of first corporation and its creditors, separate entity of first corporation would be disregarded with respect to creditor of first corporation, but that man, who was managing employee of both corporations but who did not hold a single share of stock of either corporation, could not be held liable. Judgment reversed as to managing employee and affirmed as...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Pan Pac. Sash & Door Co. v. Greendale Park, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: In action for goods, wares and merchandise sold and delivered to corporate defendants, one of whom allegedly owned tract of land and the other of whom allegedly constructed houses thereon, evidence was sufficient to support findings that the corporation which constructed houses was the alter ego of the corporation which owned the land and that each corporation was but an instrumentality or conduit of the other in the prosecution of the single venture of construction and sale of houses upon the tract.
Document Preview: Action for goods, wares and merchandise sold and delivered to defendants. The defendants filed counterclaim for defective material furnished by plaintiff. The Court allowed the counterclaim and entered judgment in favor of plaintiff, and the defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Patrosso, J. pro tem., held that plaintiff was entitled to interest only on the amount for which judgment was awarded and was not entitled to interest on a greater amount on any theory that until allowance of the counterclaim the defendants were indebted to plaintiff in amount of counterclaim. Affirmed as modified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Wheeler v. Superior Mortg. Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: In action to recover treble amount paid as interest on an alleged usurious loan, whether corporate defendants were in fact separate entities, or whether there was such a unity of ownership of both corporations that individuality of the corporations did not exist, and there was merely a fiction of separate existence was a question of fact, in determining whether there was a proper basis for a charge of commissions by one of the corporations for its alleged services as a broker in allegedly obtaining a loan for plaintiff from the other corporation.
Document Preview: Action to recover treble the amount paid as interest on an alleged usurious loan and to enjoin foreclosure sale based on another alleged usurious loan. Judgment granting a motion of rnonsuit in the Suerior Court, Los Angeles County, Gerald C. Kepple, J., and the plaintiff appeals. The District Court of Appeal, Parker Wood, J., held that there was a question of fact as to whether the loan transactions were usurious. Judgment reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: State ex rel. Grinnell Co. v. MacPherson
Court: Supreme Court of New Mexico.
Headnote: In prohibition proceeding based on alleged insufficiency of service upon corporation, evidence compelled conclusion that parent manufacturing corporation and two subsidiary selling corporations with same board of directors and secretary and bearing same basic name, with manufacturer designated as "corporation", first seller designated as "company, incorporated", and second seller designated "company", were in fact one giant octopus corporation. 1953 Comp. § 21-3-6(b).
Document Preview: Original prohibition action against D. A. MacPherson, Jr., Judge of Division Four of the District Court of the Second Judicial District, based on alleged improper service of process. The Supreme Court, Sadler, J., held that where three foreign corporations, a parent manufacturing corporation and its two subsidiary selling corporations which had common directors and secretary and bore same basic name were in fact a giant octopus corporation, so that in advertising and sales, there was no distinction between manufacturer corporation and selling corporations, service of process upon the one selling corporation which was qualified to do business in state was sufficient to confer jurisdiction over the other two corporations. Alternative writ discharged.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Hudson v. Wylie
Court: United States Court of Appeals Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: In proceeding brought by bankruptcy trustee to recover profits earned by corporate joint adventurer, evidence sustained finding that corporation in question was the alter ego of the bankrupt.
Document Preview: Proceeding brought by bankruptcy trustee to recover profits earned by bankrupt and a coadventurer under a construction contract. The United States District Court for the Southern District of California, Central Division, William C. Mathes, J., granted the relief sought, and an appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, Ross, District Judge, held that even though divisible joint adventure agreement required bankrupt to procure and perform contracts with Commodity Credit Corporation for construction of grain bins, and recited that the availability of bankrupt for such time as might be necessary to procure and perform such construction contracts was an inducing consideration, requirement therein that other adventurer supply management and all labor and material made it clear that real consideration running from bankrupt was his procurement of construction contracts; and held that since the construction contract in question had been procured prior to adjudication, right to...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: American Anthracite & Bituminous Coal Corp. v. Amerocean S. S. Co.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: On motion to vacate a writ of foreign attachment and to dismiss libel on the grounds that the respondent named as owner of the ship against which the writ issued was not the owner thereof and that the real owner was a Liberian corporation, evidence did not justify disregarding the corporate identity of the Liberian corporation.
Document Preview: Libel in admiralty. On motion to vacate a writ of foreign attachment and to dismiss the libel on the ground that the respondent named as owner of the ship against which the writ issued was not the owner thereof and that the real owner was a Liberian corporation. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, Ganey, J., held that the evidence did not justify disregarding the corporate entity of the Liberian corporation. Writ of foreign attachment dissolved.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Allied Bldg. Credits v. Mathewson
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: In action on note endorsed to plaintiff corporation by payee company without recourse, evidence was insufficient to show that such company was so intertwined with plaintiff as to be a branch thereof.
Document Preview: Action on a note for the purchase price of lumber and building supplies. From a judgment of the Circuit Court for the County of Oakland, George B. Hartrick, J., on a jury's verdict for defendants, plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Butzel, J., held that proof of notice to plaintiff of failure of consideration for the note before completion of negotiation thereof by plaintiff's payment therefor to payee company, which endorsed the note to plaintiff without recourse, was sufficient to take to the jury the question whether plaintiff was a bona fide holder of the note in due course without notice. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Kuttner & Kuttner v. Career Studios
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District Second Division.
Headnote: In action to garnish bank account which allegedly had been transferred by primary debtor corporation to another corporation, evidence sustained finding that the two corporations were one and the same to all intents and purposes, and that the bank account was in reality the credit of primary debtor.
Document Preview: Garnishment proceedings by Kuttner & Kuttner, Inc., against the National Boulevard Bank of Chicago, garnishee, to satisfy the judgment debt of the Career Studios, Inc. The Municipal Court of Chicago, Cook County, Joseph A. Pope, J., entered judgment for plaintiff, and garnishee appealed. The Appellate Court, Tuohy, P. J., held that the evidence sustained the findings that to all intents and purposes the judgment debtor and the corporation to which the judgment debtor had transferred its bank account were one and the same, and that the account was in fact the credit of the judgment debtor. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Henderson v. Rounds & Porter Lumber Co.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Arkansas, El Dorado Division.
Headnote: In action by a trustee in bankruptcy and certain creditors of bankrupt against corporate stockholder, evidence established that defendant controlled and manipulated bankrupt to such an extent that it should be charged with obligations giving rise to claims of creditors of bankrupt. Ark.Stats. § 27-340; Bankr.Act § 70, sub. e(3), 11 U.S.C.A. § 110, sub. e(3).
Document Preview: Action by George H. Henderson, doing business as Angelina Hardwood Sales Company, J. T. Haley, Jr., trustee in bankruptcy, and others, against the Rounds and Porter Lumber Company to place liability on the defendant for the converting of the assets of the bankrupt Taylor Oak Flooring Company. The District Court, Miller, J., held that the evidence established that the defendant controlled and manipulated the affairs of the bankrupt corporation and therefore was responsible for the full amount of the obligations incurred by the bankrupt. Judgment in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Rounds & Porter Lumber Co. v. Burns
Court: Supreme Court of Arkansas.
Headnote: Evidence warranted finding that parent corporation had wrongfully manipulated subsidiary corporation to its own advantage at expense of owner of lumber to be processed and sold by subsidiary corporation and had stripped subsidiary corporation of its liquid assets so as to entitle owner of lumber to a judgment directly against parent corporation for lumber which subsidiary corporation had sold largely to parent corporation at less than prices charged third persons and for which subsidiary corporation had not accounted.
Document Preview: Suit by Homer Burns and wife against Rounds & Porter Lumber Company to hold defendant liable for lumber which defendants' subsidiary corporation was to process and sell as agent for plaintiffs, and for which subsidiary corporation had not accounted. The Chancery Court of Bradley County, D. A. Bradham, Chancellor, entered judgment for plaintiffs, and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, George Rose Smith, J., held that the evidence warranted finding that defendant had wrongfully manipulated subsidiary corporation to its own advantage at expense of plaintiffs so as to entitle plaintiffs to a judgment directly against parent corporation, and affirmed the judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: State v. Casselman
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho.
Headnote: Evidence that telephone company, incorporated in 1911, operated in seven intermountain states, and that electric company, organized in 1881, in addition to manufacturing telephone equipment, also manufactured products for use in other fields of transmission, reproduction and amplification of sound with plants widely dispersed throughout the United States, although both were subsidiaries of same parent company, did not warrant the piercing of corporate veil so that labor dispute with one would authorize picketing of other. Laws 1947, c. 265.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Third Judicial District, Ada County; Charles E. Winstead, Judge. J. S. Casselman, James D. Towne, J. E. Abel and George Hill were separately convicted of violating Laws 1947, c. 265, prohibiting secondary boycotts, and they separately appeal. The appeals were consolidated for hearing. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: U.S. v. Figur
Court: District Court D. Minnesota, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Evidence would not justify finding that paper salvage corporation and partnership dealing in second hand paper containers which owned separate plants, offices, kept separate books, etc., and which did not share profits, benefit nor participate in each other's earnings, dominated each other notwithstanding family relationship existed between officers of both concerns.
Document Preview: Actions by the Price Administrator v. Morris Figur, and others, and against Pioneer Paper Stock Company, Inc., a corporation, to restrain violations of the Emergency Price Control Act of 1942, as amended, and for treble damages wherein the United States was substituted as party plaintiff. The proceedings were consolidated for the purpose of trial and came before the Court without a jury. Decision in accordance with opinion.

Title: Nuttall v. Lankford
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of Virginia
Headnote: Record warranted finding of trial court that evidence was insufficient to sustain complainant's contention that corporate lessee of oyster planting grounds in bed of Rappahannock River was a mere dummy corporation designed and chartered for purpose of enabling a foreign corporation or a nonresident to hold and operate oyster planting grounds contrary to statute. Code 1942, § 3193(2).
Document Preview: Appeal from Circuit Court, Lancaster County; E. Hugh Smith, Judge.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Nuttall v. Lankford
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of Virginia
Headnote: Evidence of the close affiliation of several business entities by reason of the financial interest of one individual and that such concerns contracted with each other was not sufficient to prove that all were in fact the same concern or that their association was a device designed to enable a foreign corporation or a nonresident to engage in planting or raising oysters on land leased from commonwealth. Code 1942, § 3193(1-6, 8, 12-15).
Document Preview: Appeal from Circuit Court, Lancaster County; E. Hugh Smith, Judge.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Herman v. Mobile Homes Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: Evidence showed that both subsidiary corporations were completely controlled and dominated by the parent corporation and had no independent existence separate and apart from parent corporation.
Document Preview: Separate actions by Ralph J. Herman and wife, by Dale Ownby and wife, by Harry C. Bidigare and wife by Francis P. Duncan and wife, and by Carl Hoeberling and wife against the Mobile Homes Corporation, Inter Urban Land Company and Currier Lumber Company for damages resulting from sales to defendants of houses which were defective as result of inferior materials and workmanship, which were consolidated. From judgments for plaintiffs for $635 in each of the first four cases and $795 in the fifth case, the defendants appeal. Judgments affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Relaco Rosin Products v. National Casein Co.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Second Division.
Headnote: Where defendant corporation contracted to purchase from plaintiff all of merchandise for which defendant had a market and another corporation was organized by defendant to handle such merchandise, the defense, in action to recover for merchandise shipped to second corporation on theory that such other corporation was defendant's agent and merely a dummy corporation, that defendant had assigned the contract to such other corporation as authorized by the contract, was not sustained by the evidence.
Document Preview: Appeal from Municipal Court of Chicago; John V. McCormick, Judge. Action by Relaco Rosin Products, Inc., against National Casein Company to recover for merchandise sold and delivered. Verdict and judgment for plaintiff, and defendant appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1079 Actions to Pierce Corporate Veil > 101k1086 Evidence > 101k1086(4) Weight and Sufficiency > 101k1086(14) Separate corporations >
Title: Standard Oil Co. v. U.S.
Court: District Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Evidence in action to recover excise taxes paid established that sales of gasoline and oil products by producer to two of its subsidiaries in a larger than normal amount, together with lease to subsidiaries of storage tanks, immediately prior to effective date of excise tax on sale of gasoline and lubricating oils by a producer, were bona fide, and hence corporate entities could not be disregarded and subsequent sales of the products by subsidiaries be regarded as sales by producer subject to the excise tax, notwithstanding that transaction resulted in avoidance of tax. Revenue Act 1932, §§ 601(c)(1), 617(a), and § 617(a), as amended by National Industrial Recovery Act, § 211(a), 26 U.S.C.A.Int.Rev.Acts pages 604, 616.
Document Preview: Action by the Standard Oil Company, an Ohio corporation, against the United States of America to recover back excise taxes in the sum of $158,120.51, plus interest, on ground that such amount was illegally collected from it in connection with sale of gasoline and lubricating oil. Judgment for plaintiff.

Title: Relaco Rosin Products Co. v. National Casein Co.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Second Division.
Headnote: Where first corporation agreed to purchase from plaintiff all the rosin size for which first corporation had a market and first corporation's president organized second corporation, and plaintiff in name of second corporation was to ship rosin for customers of first corporation, evidence made out a prima facie case against first corporation and its president for price of rosin shipped to second corporation on theory that second corporation was a dummy corporation and it and its president were agents of first corporation and its president.
Document Preview: Appeal from Municipal Court of Chicago, Cook County; George B. Weiss, Judge. Action by Relaco Rosin Products Company, Inc., against National Casein Company and Louis T. Cook in the alternative for sale of merchandise and expenses connected with the shipments. From a judgment upon a directed verdict for defendants, plaintiff appeals and defendants move to transfer the appeal to the Supreme Court and to strike the report of proceedings from the record. Motions denied. Judgment reversed and cause remanded for new trial.

Title: Vavricka v. Mid-Continent Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Evidence that company engaged in purchase of oil royalties for profit and company engaged in selling its stock were organized and dominated by the same person who profited from the purchase of royalties, warranted finding that sales company was the "agent" of the royalties purchasing company in the sale of the latter's stock, so that in action against royalties purchasing company to rescind contract for purchase of its stock, such company should be held answerable for representations made by sales company's stock salesman.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Lancaster County; Shepherd, Judge. Action at law by Joseph J. Vavricka against the MidContinent Company and others to rescind contract for purchase of corporate stock on the ground of fraud and recover the purchase price. Judgment for plaintiff, and the named defendant appeals. Judgment affirmed.

Title: H.A.S. Loan Service v. McColgan
Court: Supreme Court of California.
Headnote: Evidence sustained finding that corporate device was used by loan service corporation and finance company as means of thwarting usury and franchise tax laws, and that the two corporate entities were controlled by same persons, and were engaged in single business, so that corporate entities might be disregarded in determining whether loan service corporation was a "financial corporation" within state franchise tax law. Gen.Laws Act 8488, §§ 1, 2, 4, 4a (repealed. See Revenue and Taxation Code, § 23102 et seq.).
Document Preview: In Bank. Action by H. A. S. Loan Service, Inc., against Charles J. McColgan, as State Franchise Tax Commissioner, to recover amount paid under protest as franchise tax. From an adverse judgment, plaintiff appeals. Affirmed.

Title: Marr v. Postal Union Life Ins. Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: In action against insurance company to recover on a note executed by another company as part payment for realty, on ground that the other company acted as agent or as the alter ego of the insurance company, evidence justified conclusion by jury that the other company was merely the alter ego of the insurance company so as to authorize recovery as against the insurance company.
Document Preview: Appeal from Superior Court, Los Angeles County; Myron Westover, Judge. Action by Minnie M. Marr and others, as trustees, against the Postal Union Life Insurance Company, and the Postal Underwriters, Inc., to recover on a note. From an adverse judgment, the Postal Union Life Insurance Company appeals. Affirmed.

Title: Everts v. Sunset Farms
Court: Supreme Court of California.
Headnote: In creditor's suit to have assets of S. corporation applied to indebtedness of F. corporation and of F., an individual, evidence sustained finding that F. corporation was the alter ego of F., and the S., corporation was the alter ego of F. corporation and of F.
Document Preview: In Bank. Suit by H. W. Everts against Sunset Farms, Inc., and others. From an adverse judgment, defendants appeal. Affirmed.

Title: McCurdy v. Spokane Western Power & Traction Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Washington.
Headnote: Evidence held insufficient to support conclusion that separate corporations should be considered as one so as to entitle one corporation to share in proceeds of property belonging to other.
Document Preview: Department 2. Appeal from Superior Court, Spokane County; Bruce Blake, Judge pro tempore. Action by Sarah M. McCurdy and others against the Spokane Western Power & Traction Company and others. From a judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, the defendants appeal. Reversed, with instructions.

Title: Commonwealth v. Southeastern Iron Corporation
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of Virginia
Headnote: In the instant case, ore and manufactured products therefrom belonging to one corporation was assessed as capital of another corporation. It was contended that the two corporations should be held to be one and the same in the eyes of the law; that there was such a community of interest in the property that an assessment against either or both corporations would be proper. The corporation to whom the property belongs owned sixty per cent of the stock of the corporation to whom the property was assessed, but they had different directors and officers. The contract under which the corporation assessed held the property of the other was a fair business arrangement between the corporations and there was no suggestion of fraud. Held: That while the principle relied upon was sound, the testimony did not bring the instant case within it.
Document Preview: Error to Circuit Court, Rockbridge County. Petition by the Southeastern Iron Corporation, to be relieved from certain assessments for taxation upon its capital, opposed by the Commonwealth of Virginia and the County of Rockbridge. From an order granting relief, opponents bring error. Affirmed.
